DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING FOR ALL NEEDING.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the Darryl Strawberry story, first item in PM-Names (a0444) for Tuesday PMs, subject of a bulletin kill late in the cycle, are asked to also use the following.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Jan. 30 that New York Mets outfielder Darryl Strawberry was charged with assault with a deadly weapon after allegedly threatening his wife with a pistol. Strawberry was arrested Jan. 26 in connection with the alleged incident and spent a short time in jail before he was released on $12,000 bail. Los Angeles police erroneously told the AP that felony charges had already been filed against Strawberry. The district attorney's office, however, did not review the case until Tuesday and decided there was insufficient evidence for felony charges, though lesser charges could still be filed.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Hugo Continuing to Create Legal Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In the days after Hurricane Hugo smashed into South Carolina, people needed ice, food and clothing. Later, they needed carpenters and building supplies. Now, many coastal residents find they need a good lawyer. In the wake of disputes over rental agreements, insurance payments and building repairs, South Carolina's judicial system is bracing for an expected influx of cases stemming from the killer hurricane. And with the courts already overburdened by a backlog of criminal cases, there is concern that Hugo-related cases will further bog down the system. ``Somebody is bound to not be happy out there,'' said Louis Rosen, director of the state Office of Court Administration. ``It's one of those factors that will make a bad situation worse.'' Hugo, which came ashore at Charleston on Sept. 21, caused an estimated $5.9 billion in property damage, making it the most damaging hurricane to hit the U.S. mainland. The storm was blamed for 29 deaths in South Carolina alone. ``We're speculating that a storm with that extent of damage will raise construction disputes and insurance disputes,'' said Rosen, whose office oversees the flow of litigation through the court system. But the Hugo cases will not really have an impact before summer, he said. ``You have to look a year after the fact,'' Rosen explained. ``Even after a person thinks he may be engaged in a legal dispute, it takes some time to consult an attorney and look into it.'' People with small claims will probably end up in magistrate courts, which can handle cases involving amounts of less than $2,500, Rosen said. But bigger cases _ insurance settlements and contracting disputes _ will probably be more complicated and have to be settled in common pleas courts. In the days after the storm, the South Carolina Bar offered free legal advice at the Disaster Assistance Centers established by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Volunteer attorneys fielded thousands of calls and questions, although there is no estimate on how many people received legal advice, said Eve Stacey of the bar staff. But the questions raised may give an indication of the types of lawsuits that may follow. Among the questions were concerns about landlord-tenant relations, damage caused by trees and structures from an adjoining property, houses washed across property and insurance disputes over what was flood damage and what was wind damage. ``I can see a lot of those as potential actions,'' Ms. Stacey said in a recent interview. Many disputes over what a tenant was liable to pay when his or her home was damaged in the storm have already been addressed in magistrate courts, said Donna Taylor, an attorney with Neighborhood Legal Services in Charleston. ``They were handled at the magistrate's level and were handled right then,'' she said. ``It was one of the times when the system operated well. If we had to wait to go to circuit court, people would have been homeless or penniless.'' Down the road, she said, ``The courts are going to be flooded with suits stemming from insurance claims _ the insurers' failure to pay the extent of the policy. ``There will also be a lot of lawsuits against contractors _ these young guys who came in from out of state and said, `I can fix your roof if you give me your two grand.''' Meanwhile, the South Carolina Coastal Council has been named in at least 12 lawsuits stemming from the hurricane. All concern pools and seawalls in beachfront areas where the council has determined that structures may not be rebuilt, council spokeswoman Donna Gress said. A circuit judge ruled last week in eight of those cases that property owners may rebuild seawalls and pools. But he required a $10,000 bond in case his decision is overturned by a higher court and the structures must be removed.

DOC.HEAD: Spy Agency Records Tell of Efforts to Maintain Segregation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Newly disclosed documents offer an unflattering portrait of an official state segregation agency that spied on Jewish children and investigated a black dentist at a white dentist's request. The 17-year evolution of the Mississippi Sovereignty Commission was chronicled Sunday in The Jackson Clarion-Ledger, which obtained more than 700 sealed commission documents. The activities of the spy agency, created in 1956 to preserve Mississippi's segregated society, previously had been part of the state's secret past. The files show that: _ Hundreds of people, including teachers, preachers and students, were investigated for alleged civil rights leanings and ``subversive'' activities. Some lost their jobs. _ Dozens more, including a prominent black Delta educator who later had a school named for him, were spies for the commission. They helped gather incriminating information and infiltrated various organizations and groups. _ U.S. Sen. James O. Eastland turned over to the commission the names of some of his constituents who supported civil rights. He also used his position as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee to help the commission link Tougaloo College President A.D. Beittel and others to communism. _ The Clarion-Ledger and Jackson Daily News regularly killed news stories or ran propaganda at the commission's request. _ A black militant group was suspected of plotting to release a lethal gas in a Jackson building. The commission secretly aided the FBI in the case. _ The commission in 1964 planted a story in Mississippi's largest black newspaper to publicize claims that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was linked to the Communist Party. Holding the line between blacks and whites was the commission's goal when it was created by the 1956 Legislature. The commission's influence withered during the 1960s, and Gov. Bill Waller eliminated its funding in 1973. The 1977 Legislature abolished the commission and ordered its files sealed until 2027 to protect those named in the documents. A U.S. District Court case that would open the files is on appeal to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans. The Clarion-Ledger did not say how it obtained the files. Executive Editor John D. Johnson said Monday that the newspaper would not disclose the source of the documents. Commission files at one time contained the names of 250 organizations and 10,000 people, according to a document in the files. However, not all were considered ``leftist or subversive,'' the documents say. In December 1960, the commission spied on 300 Jewish teen-agers attending a five-state B'nai B'rith youth meeting at a motel in Biloxi. ``These youths sang songs and a general party atmosphere prevailed,'' a commission investigator wrote. ``We observed them and listened to them, but we could observe nothing or hear nothing that indicated that they were advocating subversion, integration or anything of a communistic nature.'' In 1969, the commission investigated Presley Autry, a black Holly Springs dentist who was seeking admission to the Mississippi Dental Association. The investigation was conducted at the request of a white Greenwood dentist, Arthur Richter, according to the files. Richter said he had received unconfirmed reports that Autry participated in civil rights activities, and believed he wasn't ``a desirable candidate'' for the dental association, a commission memo says. The investigation uncovered nothing to support the unconfirmed reports. Richter was given the result and asked to hold it in strict confidence. ``I felt that the interest of a matter of this nature to the public would give us the authority to check it out, although it would not come under the category of a tax-supported matter,'' a commission director wrote. Autry, 61, who retired in 1986 and lives in Houston, said he was admitted to the association without any problem. Richter recently said he didn't remember much about the case. A January 1964 report contains some insight into the commission's philosophy. In it, state Sen. George Yarbrough asked commission investigator Tom Scarbrough about integrating the Holly Springs public library. Both men have since died. Scarbrough wrote: ``I told Sen. Yarbrough at the time that it was my thinking that when the City Board made concessions to a group of Negroes, other demands would follow from the same group and as far as I was personally concerned, I felt that we should hold fast our way of life until forced to retreat.''

DOC.HEAD: Lost Skiers Burned Money to Stay Alive
DOC.TEXT: Two lost skiers decided they had money to burn, and the decision may have saved their lives. Don Wing and Jack Joneson, both 29 and from Calgary, Alberta, strayed out of bounds at The Big Mountain ski resort Saturday afternoon and got lost, Flathead County Sheriff Chuck Rhodes said Monday. More than 30 searchers set out in waist-deep snow shortly after dark to find them. The skiers were found about 11:30 p.m., snug and warm beside the campfire they had started eight hours earlier _ by burning dollar bills, Rhodes said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules `Inside Edition' Can Show Hidden-Camera Tape
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Monday ruled unconstitutional an order barring the television program ``Inside Edition'' from broadcasting scenes filmed with a hidden camera in a doctor's office. Judge Boyce F. Martin Jr. of the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ordered U.S. District Judge Barbara K. Hackett of Detroit to lift her Jan. 18 restraining order, which had prevented the syndicated program from using the film shot in the New York office of Dr. Stuart M. Berger. Martin ruled that Ms. Hackett's order violated the constitutional guarantee of press freedom despite Berger's argument before Hackett that showing the tape would invade his privacy and damage his reputation. ``Berger simply has not shown the type of irreparable harm that can justify a prior restraint,'' Martin's order said. ``Inside Edition'' spokeswoman Marcy Baron said the program plans to include the scenes shot in Berger's office in a segment about him which is to be shown Thursday. Berger's attorney, Russell Ethridge, filed a request that Martin delay his order to give the doctor's attorneys time to appeal the ruling to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``Once that footage is broadcast, the images cannot be recalled, and the damage cannot be undone,'' Ethridge said in his request. ``We're disappointed that the court didn't see the distinction we see between defamation cases ... and invasion of privacy,'' Ethridge said by telephone from Detroit. He said Berger's attorneys plan to press his claim for $10 million in damages from the show. ``Inside Edition'' producer Amy Wasserstrom said in an affidavit that she videotaped two visits she made as a patient to Berger's office while preparing a story on controversy surrounding the doctor's medical conduct. Berger is the author of several widely sold diet books. Ms. Wasserstrom said Berger diagnosed her as suffering from an allergy to yeast and chronic fatigue. However, another doctor said she didn't have such ailments. ``We believe that the reporter did nothing wrong,'' said Russell Smith, an attorney for King World Productions, Inc., which produces ``Inside Edition.'' ``She told him of her condition truthfully, and he misdiagnosed her, ripped her off, and caused her stress,'' Smith said. ``If there was any misconduct here, it was by Dr. Berger.''

DOC.HEAD: Court: Ruth's Heirs Cannot Sue Publisher For Trademark Infringement
DOC.TEXT: Babe Ruth's daughters struck out in federal court when an appeals court ruled that a publisher did not infringe on their trademark by using pictures of the Bambino in a calendar. Three judges of the 2nd U.S. Court of Appeals on Monday upheld a lower court ruling that dismissed a lawsuit by Julia Ruth Stevens and Dorothy Ruth Pirone, who has since died, and against Macmillan Inc. After Ruth's death, the sisters registered the words ``Babe Ruth'' as a trademark for playing cards and other uses. The court said the trademark did not apply to photographs of Ruth. The calendar, ``The 1988 Macmillan Baseball Engagement Calendar,'' contained three references to Ruth. The cover was a photograph of Ruth helping a boy with his batting grip; a week in October was illustrated with a picture of Ruth saluting General John Pershing; and a page in the December section had a photograph of a baseball autographed by Ruth.

DOC.HEAD: Most Works Dali Willed To The State To Remain In His Native Catalonia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 190 paintings willed to the Spanish state by surrealist artist Salvador Dali are to remain in his native Catalonia under a newly signed agreement that ends a year of bickering. Dali's will was made public shortly before his Jan. 23, 1989 death at age 84, but it was not until Monday that agreement was reached on where the works he willed to the state will be put on display. Culture Minister Jorge Semprun and Catalonian Culture Commissioner Joan Guitart signed the pact. Under its terms, the Reina Sofia art center in Madrid is to display ``The Great Masturbator,'' considered one of the flamboyant painter's greatest works and reportedly one of the last sticking points of the talks. Another 55 paintings are also to be on display in the Reina Sofia art center and the remaining 134 are to be kept in the building housing Dali's Theater-Museum in Figueras, where he lived his last years confined to a wheelchair. In addition to the 190 paintings, the moustachioed artist's estate includes two castles, 500 sculptures and other Dali-designed objects, and hundreds of signed prints. Government officials in Catalonia and Figueras had complained publicly after Dali's death when they found they were not specifically named as beneficiaries in the will. Press reports at the time of Dali's death said his estate was worth up to $90.1 million. But its real value is difficult to determine because of the erratic prices of 20th century art and the existence of numerous forgeries.

DOC.HEAD: Change In South Africa Unlikely To Be Rapid Despite Rising Hopes
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk has ignited hope that the white government is finally ready to dismantle apartheid and sit down with black leaders to find a solution to South Africa's problems. But there is little sign that de Klerk is about to surrender power or that white rule is in any danger of collapsing even though the president's stated aim is to end apartheid. There are still no signs that the government will accept full democracy _ the main demand of all anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk is expected to outline his plans in a speech Friday at the opening of Parliament. Many South Africans are hoping the speech will be the signal for historic reform, despite official warnings not to expect too much. Some political observers say the quest for peace in South Africa is more like the confrontations in Northern Ireland or the Middle East. There is little chance, they say, that white rule will come crashing down overnight like the Berlin Wall and the Communist regimes of Eastern Europe. The government is in full control of the country, unrest is minimal and the African National Congress, the main black opposition group, admits its military campaign against the government poses little threat at this point. De Klerk, who says he wants a ``new dispensation'' that will give South African blacks a role in the country's affairs, still rejects any suggestion of majority rule. There also are few signs that many white South Africans are ready to share their schools, hospitals and other public facilities with non-whites or share power and opportunity on an equal basis with non-whites. Many observers say de Klerk lacks a definite plan and is feeling his way, playing for time with limited reforms in the hope of finding a solution that will avoid major confrontation and still preserve a special role for whites. De Klerk has given no specific signs of what he wants for South Africa's future beyond stressing that whites must have veto power in any future state. Black leaders say de Klerk must meet a number of basic expectations to clear the way for talks with the African National Congress, including lifting the state of emergency; releasing ANC leader Nelson Mandela; removing the ban on the ANC and other outlawed opposition groups, and allowing exiled black leaders to return to South Africa. How far he goes towards meeting these conditions Friday will be a good indication of how much reform the government wants. Even if de Klerk meets all the conditions, it will only be the start of what promises to be a very long and difficult search for peace. Skeptics point out that de Klerk as leader of the National Party is head of South Africa's Afrikaners, whites of Dutch descent who dominate the government and who have been sustained by a belief in their superiority for three centuries. Because of deeply ingrained beliefs of white superiority and rule, neither de Klerk nor his people can give up power and accept equality with the blacks, Asians and others they have dominated for so long, these observers say. That leaves the question of what de Klerk and the government hope to achieve through a more moderate stance and why they have begun to remove parts of the apartheid system. The government has contained, but not removed black opposition by using the security forces and harsh restrictions. De Klerk apparently wants to defuse the racial confrontation with political means rather than face what he warned would be ``80 years'' of war. A more pressing problem is the ailing economy, buffeted by sanctions imposed by Western nations because of apartheid and poor management. Inflation is soaring and many white South Africans find it harder to make ends meet. The government hopes to ease the economic crunch by offering reforms to ease international sanctions and restore confidence in the economy with new foreign investment. There are also signs that the government hopes a more moderate stance and reforms would encourage some opposition groups to take a softer line. This could lead to a compromise with some opposition groups and isolate or weaken hard-line groups. But the first question de Klerk must answer is whether he has the time and the backing of his white supporters to achieve the compromise he says he wants.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Barry Renfrew is chief of the AP bureau in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir: A Tourist Paradise Becomes a War Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report; In 10th graf, ``We are ...'' Jagmohan uses only one name.
DOC.TEXT: Exotic Kashmir, a tourist paradise of houseboat hotels and Mogul gardens from whose name the English made ``cashmere,'' has become a war zone of separatism and religious enmity. Military jeeps carry senior government officials and civil servants around Srinagar in these dangerous days, as soldiers and paramilitary troopers try to stop a campaign of violence by Moslem separatists in the Kashmir Valley. Intelligence officer M.K. Kaul commands one of the jeeps. At the beginning of a trip through the city of 1 million people, he turned to the four soldiers in the jeep's rear seats and ordered: ``Check your weapons. Be ready to fire.'' Kaul settled into the front seat, a 9mm pistol in his right hand. ``These are bad days,'' he murmured. ``These die-hard terrorists can attack from anywhere. To his men, he said: ``Shoot them if you see them.'' On Monday, an around-the-clock curfew was lifted from 5 a.m. until noon and stores opened to crowds of customers. Soldiers in sandbagged bunkers, armed with light machine guns, guarded main intersections. A spokesman for the Jammu-Kashmir state government said the situation was peaceful and ``absolutely normal'' in Srinagar, the state's largest city. At least 72 people have been killed since the crackdown began Jan. 20 in an effort to curb attacks on government officials and buildings. Most of the dead have been Moslem militants shot by Indian troops. ``We are neither fighting a war nor trying to suppress any popular movement,'' said Jagmohan, governor of Jammu-Kashmir, the only state in predominantly Hindu India with a Moslem majority. ``We are fighting a handful of terrorists who are determined to create a law and order problem,'' said Jagmohan, a Hindu with a reputation for toughness. Other officials in Kashmir say privately the situation is critical, perhaps the most serious threat India has faced in 42 years of independence from Britain. ``It looks like everyone here has turned into a fundamentalist with firm belief that the day is not far off when they will become independent,'' a state police officer said. Kashmir was a separate kingdom, ruled by a Hindu maharajah, when Britain relinquished colonial rule on Aug. 15, 1947, and the subcontinent was partitioned on religious lines into India and Pakistan. The Hindu king opted to join India, not Pakistan, and the dispute over Kashmir has exacerbated relations since. Pakistan took the western part of Kashmir and India the eastern. Each accused the other of forcible occupation. They have fought wars over Kashmir and the border question remains unresolved. U.N. observers are stationed on the truce line and the two sides occasionally trade gunfire. Officials will not say how many reinforcements have been sent to the Kashmir Valley since Jan. 20, but reports from various sources indicate 30,000-and 40,000 soldiers and paramilitary troops have been deployed. It is the valley's heavily Moslem population that tilts the sectarian scale in Jammu-Kashmir state. Of the state's nearly 6 million people, 64 percent are Moslems and 32 percent Hindus. Most Hindus live in the southern Jammu area. Srinagar has 150 mosques. ``This is the best breeding ground for Moslem fundamentalism,'' said a federal official who helps coordinate the new security measures. Nearly every mosque has a loudspeaker to summon the faithful to prayer _ and, more recently, to exhort listeners to defend their faith and Kashmir. ``The residents are constantly bombarded with Islamic sermons and are reminded that fighting a `jihad' (Islamic holy war) is the most sacred duty of every Moslem,'' the federal official said, on condition of anonymity. Electricity was cut off in the city Friday, which was both the Moslem sabbath and India's national Republic Day on India's Republic Day, but many mosque loudspeakers continued operating because militants connected them to car batteries. Intelligence reports suggest the government has an advantage because the separatists are not united. The most powerful group is the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, but there are several others, including the Allah Tigers, Hezb-e-Mujahed Hezb-e-Islami. India claims the fundamentalists get money and weapons from Pakistan. The Pakistanis deny it. Jagmohan, the governor, insists the main issue in Kashmir is economic development, not separatism. ``The people do not want violence or the so-called independent Kashmir,'' he said. ``The need of the hour is development. Let more tourists come. Let new schools be built. Let new hospitals come up.'' As he spoke, military officers waited in the next room to discuss a new strategy to crush rebellion in what the tourist brochures call Paradise. Right now, Paradise looks lost, at least temporarily.

DOC.HEAD: Scrounging for Soviet Food, McDonald's Starts at the Farm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's imported seeds, taught Soviet potato farmers how to increase their yields, built its own food factory, spent $50 million and waited 14 years before selling a single burger in Moscow. George Cohon, chairman of McDonald's of Canada, doesn't have any idea if or when he'll recapture his investment after the opening of the first franchise in the Soviet Union on Wednesday. ``I just know I'm going to take those rubles and build another restaurant,'' he said. The restaurant, located near Pushkin Square, is the biggest McDonald's in the world and is designed to serve 1,250 people an hour. Unlike other foreign ventures, the restaurant will sell its food for rubles, so that ordinary Soviets, not just privileged foreigners, can eat there. A second McDonald's, out of a planned 20, will sell for hard currency to foreigners. Anybody who thinks it was easy to get this far need only glance at the abandoned storefront a few miles away, its ``Pizza Hut'' sign mocking Pepsico's proud announcement that it would open a restaurant in Moscow in 1988. The depth of McDonald's investment in the Soviet market can be measured not only in currency but in the lengths it went to ensure a reliable Soviet food supply. Agronomists brought in seeds and taught Soviet collective farmers who've planted potatoes for years that they could improve their yields 20 to 100 percent using modern methods, Cohon said. To avoid losing 25 percent or more of the harvest to spoilage, McDonald's taught farmers how to pick potatoes gently and store them properly. Purchasing manager Vladimir Boras said the company developed its facilities near Moscow because it couldn't build a new transportation network. A few weeks ago, Boras knelt in the black earth of a greenhouse on the outskirts of the capital and examined the green budding heads of iceberg lettuce used in a Big Mac. Above, 400-watt bulbs blazed along the rows, making up for the short days and cloudy skies of midwinter Moscow. The electric bill was $8,300 in December, said Vladimir Goloveshkin of the Dzerzhinsky Farm, but Boras wasn't sure the lettuce would be ready for the grand opening. He'd tried an experimental crop of lettuce months earlier at a different collective farm, he said, but when he arrived to examine it, the farmers had eaten the entire harvest. ``They said it was delicious,'' Boras recalled. Not all supplies are Soviet-made. The warehouse is brimming with imports, including paper cups, napkins, bags, spices and secret ingredients such as ``McDonald's Crust Improver.'' Up to now, Gorbachev's economic reforms have had little effect on Soviet consumers, who complain bitterly of empty store shelves and the ridiculously high prices charged in private markets. But the new climate opened the way for McDonald's to form a partnership with the Moscow City Council and to contract with collective farms now permitted to sell one-third of their fruits and vegetables on the open market rather than to the state. Cohon said meat is still distributed by allocation and it took the intervention of the mayor to obtain beef for the fast-food restaurant. Even so, carcasses must be hand-selected because the local slaughterhouse won't guarantee McDonald's the meat from the animals it taught farmers how to raise, Boras said. McDonald's also benefited from other foreign investors. A Chicago company built a model dairy to promote its milking equipment, and McDonald's buys its milk there to avoid the high bacteria counts common in Soviet milk. But the company built its own water purification system, machine shop and laundry. For all that, some of the ``Soviet-sourced'' items on the firm's list turn out to be apples from Bulgaria. With the help of Moscow officials, McDonald's bought them for rubles after the government imported them. ``It's a big country,'' said Terry Williams, a quality assurance manager who is one of only three non-Soviets among 150 employees at the food plant. ``There's a distinct possibility we'll find a Soviet source next year.''

DOC.HEAD: A Budget That's Bully on Trees and Intrigued by Magnetic Levitation
DOC.TEXT: Ordinary wheel-on-rail railroads get the back of the hand treatment in a budget proposed by President Bush that looks forward instead to trains floating down the track through magnetic levitation. In Bush's budget, trees make out like bandits, too. So do robots. In every presidential budget proposal there are winners and losers, but Congress often reverses their order by the time it has worked its will, usually after August. This year's loser candidates are familiar targets: owners of boats, riders of trains, buses and subways, children from affluent homes eating subsidized school lunches. Those kids would be required, under Bush's budget, to pay the full cost of lunch, adding about 29 cents per meal to their outlay. President Reagan tried to trim their subsidies, too. Congress balked. Now Bush has taken up the call. In an even more pragmatic attack on the deficit, Bush proposes to make it harder to get away with cheating on taxes. He wants to ``close the gap between taxes owed and taxes paid.'' Toward that end, his budget seeks more money for enforcement of the tax laws, specifically for collecting delinquent taxes, checking out fake dependent claims, auditing mortgage interest deductions, and matching what the taxpayer says he received in interest against what interest payers say they paid. In other time-worn economy proposals, Bush asks Congress to make recreational and commercial boat owners pay a $25 fee; to quit subsidizing Amtrak, a step that could jeopardize long-distance rail travel, and to end big city mass transit subsidies that help pay for day-to-day operations. Municipal taxpayers should shoulder that burden, says Bush. ``The federal government's responsibility is not to run the railroads,'' explained Richard Darman, the president's budget director. The president's budget, however, is intrigued with more futuristic transportation, like magnetic levitation, ``a new transportation technology that relies on the use of magnets for propulsion and levitation rather than conventional steel-wheel-on-rail technology.'' Bush proposed spending $9.7 million to check it out. Along the same lines, the president calls for spending $192 million on robots, ``intelligent machine systems that do physical work.'' Most robots today work in structured environments or under close human supervision, the budget notes, so federal research should focus on building ``more autonomous'' robots ``capable of interacting with a changing and uncertain environment.'' Meantime, in a sharp break with predecessor Ronald Reagan, who said in his 1980 campaign for the White House that trees cause pollution, Bush embraced trees. His budget proposed planting a billion of them a year on private land into the indefinite future. He called for initiating a community ``plant a tree'' initiative that would line the streets of America with 30 million more trees. In most cities, he said, only one tree is planted for every four removed. The president said more trees would fight the threat of global warming, combat the pollution of streams, prevent soil erosion and save energy. Dense evergreens closely placed around a house can cut fuel bills by 20 percent, the president said, and an acre of woodland is capable of removing as much as nine tons of carbon dioxide from the air. Even though 3{ million acres of trees a year are planted in the United States, more are lost. Total woodlands decline by 700,000 acres a year, the budget says.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Proposal Walks the Middle Road
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's budget is as cautious as the man. It is a document that offers a little bit here, takes a little bit there, but gives his congressional critics few safe targets for their outrage. Those who demand deeper cuts from the Pentagon may feel uneasy fighting to save the 55 domestic military bases Bush wants to close. It's a budget tailored to the political image the president fosters. Readers of his budget can watch the environmental president plant a billion trees and the education president bolster funds for Head Start. Still determined to cut capital gains taxes, Bush also offers a plan to encourage long-term savings. Ronald Reagan sent Congress red meat budgets. Abolish the Small Business Administration, cut food stamps and sell the profitable chunk of Amtrak, demanded Reagan in no-compromise budgets intended to implement his conservative agenda. Reagan's goals were clear: big increases for the Pentagon, sharp cuts for domestic programs. Not so the Bush budget. It is a product of a different world as well as a different president. A Cold War pronounced dead. A Berlin Wall crumbled. A communist threat? To themselves, maybe. The new budget reflects the Bush who yearns to travel a middle road, rather than the macho president of the Panama invasion. His budget message was barely 10 paragraphs in length, one page of a volume running nearly 1,600, a dry cover letter introducing Budget Director Richard G. Darman's far more quotable essay that talks of ``Green Eyeshades,'' the ``Cookie Monster'' and the ``Hidden Pacmen'' of federal budgets. It's left to Darman to deal with the sticky question of the deficit. ``Unfortunately,'' wrote the budget director, ``a meaningful answer to the question _ How big is the deficit? _ is not quite as simple as the question.'' As for the peace dividend people think might follow the end of the Cold War and the crumbling of the Berlin Wall, Darman warned there ``is a new game premised on the assumption of a substantial near-term peace dividend. It starts by overestimating the dividend. Then each player plans to spend the dividend in his or her preferred way.'' But Bush did not ignore such expectations. His budget offered a 2 percent cut in defense after inflation. The price for holding down the Pentagon budget was closing 55 bases, many of which were in Democratic districts. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney called the proposed closings ``a real test'' for Congress. If nothing else, the defense proposal enabled the administration to get out front in the race to sound willing to cut Pentagon spending. There are bigger targets out there, like the five B-2 stealth bombers at a total cost of $5.5 billion, or the proposal for a $900 million increase in funding for the Strategic Defense Initiative, the space-based missile defense system dubbed Star Wars. Predictably, Democrats grumbled when the budget reached the Capitol. ``It's another fraud,'' cried Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., who has a fondness for strong rhetoric. But no one was shouting ``dead on arrival,'' the congressional rallying cry of the Reagan budget years when many Republicans joined Democrats in rejecting the president's priorities. More characteristic of the criticism of the Bush budget was House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt's complaint. ``I think it's a stand-pat budget,'' said the Missouri Democrat. ``I don't think it's a budget that really meets our needs.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Donald M. Rothberg is the chief political writer of The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dives From Third-Floor Window After Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Vernon McCartney made a dive for freedom after he was convicted of sexually assaulting a 9-year-old girl, but a three-floor drop to the ground kept him from running, authorities said. McCartney, 48, suffered a sore left chest Monday from his leap from an open courtroom window. A jury had just convicted McCartney of first-degree sexual assault, which carries a possible 15- to 25-year prison term. ``I've been going to court there for 40 years and never saw anyone do that before,'' Prosecutor Ernest Morton Jr. said. McCartney was hospitalized in stable condition. Additional charges against him were unlikely, Morton said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Program Would Get Major Boost Under Bush Budget
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants to give the U.S. space program the largest budget increase for any major government agency, saying ``no value can be calculated'' for the benefits of space exploration. In the budget he sent to Capitol Hill on Monday, the president proposed giving the National Aeronautics and Space Administration an authorization of $15.1 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, an increase of $2.8 billion _ nearly 24 percent _ over this year. ``No price can be put on the lifting of the spirit of people everywhere, like that which occurred at the time of the Apollo landings on the moon,'' Bush said. ``No value can be calculated for the wonder engendered by the pictures of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and, in August of 1989, of Neptune sent back over millions of miles by Voyager.'' In actual outlays for the 1991 fiscal year, NASA would receive a 17.5 percent increase to $14.1 billion. The space agency's spending authority differs from the one-year budget because spending authority includes money for projects that wouldn't be completed and paid for until later years. Bush also was generous to non-space fields of scientific research, adding $895 million for basic non-defense research for a total of $10.9 billion, plus a $2.1 billion increase for applied research and development, for a total $14.4 billion. Among the areas proposed for a boost was the National Science Foundation, getting $2.2 billion, a 13 percent increase; AIDS research, increasing by $749 million to $3.2 billion; and the superconducting super collider, receiving $293 million, a 56 percent increase. The president's request to Congress ``demonstrates the administration's continued strong support for NASA and the civil space station,'' NASA administrator Richard H. Truly told a news conference. The manned space station, which the United States hopes to have in orbit late in the decade, would be the major beneficiary of an increase _ from $1.7 billion to $2.4 billion _ as the project moves from design to the fabrication stage. The first construction flight is scheduled for spring 1995. If approved by Congress, the space budget would pay for starting the ``Mission to Planet Earth,'' an ambitious program to study the Earth's environment using satellites and instruments. The budget request includes $661 million in spending authority to study the Earth, including money to start two polar-orbiting platforms, the first of which would be launched in 1998. It also would initiate the development of Earth probes, a series of smaller instruments focused on specific, high-priority data needs, including ozone depletion. The first would be launched in 1994. Last July, on the 20th anniversary of the first moon landing, the president set a goal of having the United States return to the moon and then begin manned exploration of Mars early in the 21st century. The budget request reflects the first steps toward that goal in a $179 million authority item for ``exploration technology,'' which includes $4.5 million for lunar and Mars science and $11 million to study the possibility of using nuclear propulsion for long-distance travel in the solar system. Bush's proposal also envisions development of two new robotic missions, the Lunar Observer and Lifesat. The latter would be a series of reusable satellites designed to carry living specimens into orbit and be returned to Earth for analysis of the effects of long-term exposure. The National Aero-Space Plane, a joint NASA and Air Force project, would receive a total $277 million in spending authority. An additional $129 million in joint funds is proposed for developing a new family of launch vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: FAA's Fuel ``Shortage'' Doesn't Mean Emergency
DOC.TEXT: A fuel shortage like the one Avianca Flight 52 had before it crashed probably would not be taken seriously by air controllers unless the pilot actually declared a ``fuel emergency,'' controllers and aviation experts say. Under rules and standards set by the Federal Aviation Administration, if a pilot tells air traffic controllers he has ``minimum fuel,'' both he and controllers know that no undue delay can be accepted. But the FAA`s air traffic control manual says, ``This is not an emergency situation but merely an advisory that indicates an emergency situation is possible should any undue delay occur.'' A minimum fuel advisory does not call for the aircraft to get a traffic priority under the FAA rules. But if the pilot declares a fuel emergency, the entire controller system is geared to come to his aid. The FAA manual puts it this way: ``Common sense and good judgment will determine the extent of assistance to be given in minimum fuel situations. If at any time, the remaining usable fuel supply suggests the need for traffic priority to ensure a safe landing, the pilot should declare an emergency and report fuel remaining in minutes.'' Investigators probing the crash of the Avianca flight _ which killed 73 people and injured 85 _ said Monday that regional controllers relayed information from the flight to the control center for Kennedy International Airport. The regional controller said Avianca 52 had just come out of the holding area ``and can only do five more minutes of hold. Can you take him now?'' The local control replied, ``Slow him to 180 knots and I will take him.'' Records indicated the Boeing 707 had more than enough fuel to fly from Colombia to New York, but the jet flew in holding patterns for nearly 90 minutes because of weather-related congestion before it crashed. On Sunday, Lee Dickinson of the National Transportation Safety Board told a news conference in Melville, N.Y., there was an apparent communications gap between high-altitude regional controllers and those handling landings. As the plane neared the end of its final, 46-minute holding pattern south of the airport, the crew told controllers in the regional New York Center about the fuel shortage and requested priority clearance to land, Dickinson said. Dickinson said that after interviewing six local controllers who either handled or tracked the flight, investigators at first determined they were unaware of the shortage, Dickinson said. R. Steve Bell, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, AFL-CIO, called the safety board's assertions ``highly misleading and premature.'' The Avianca pilot never declared a fuel emergency, he noted. ``Tragically, the pilot only said that he was low on fuel, which is a very commonplace occurrence in bad weather and holding.'' ``This information would not necessarily have been transmitted when one pilot hands off to another,'' he said. ``No one knew how perilous was his situation until it was far too late,'' Bell said. ``The air traffic controllers would have moved heaven and earth to make for a safe approach for the crippled aircraft but the pilot never sent out the key words that he was in mortal danger.'' Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Agency, said it is not the responsibility of the controllers to relay information other than the flight's route and number unless the pilot specifically calls an emergency. ``Air traffic controllers have one primary job _ to keep aircraft from getting too close,'' Farrar said. ``It's the captain's job to fly the airplane. It's not the controllers' job to make judgments for him.''

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Differs With Defense Chief Over Troops in Azerbaijan
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin says Soviet troops and security units are in Azerbaijan to stop ethnic bloodshed and not to suppress political dissent. Dubinin's statement Monday appeared to put him at odds with Dmitri Yazov, the Soviet defense minister. But the ambassador to the United States insisted all Soviet officials were in agreement on why force was used in the strife-torn republic. ``The situation was characterized by an orgy of killings and pogroms, violations of elementary law and order, and armed ethnic clashes on a large scale,'' Dubinin told reporters at the Soviet Embassy. Referring to the emergency decree signed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev two weeks ago, Dubinin said ``the only objective was to stop the bloodshed and to restore peace.'' His account appeared at odds with that of Yazov, who was quoted last Friday as telling a group of Soviet journalists in Baku, the regional capital, the military intervention was designed to prevent a nationalist mass movement from seizing power from the Communist Party. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Monday that ``certainly we found those comments disturbing, especially if they represent accurately Soviet policy.'' But Dubinin said Yazov had spoken only about measures taken against ``armed activities'' of the Azerbaijan Liberation Front. ``I would like to point out that the political position, the political line, the political approach of all the Soviet leadership, of all government bodies of the Soviet Union, is unified,'' Dubinin said. ``The only political line is that which was done by the decision of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet ... and the line I have just taken,'' the ambassador added. Dubinin said Gorbachev and the Presidium of the Soviet Parliament were compelled to dispatch troops and KGB units to Azerbaijan because ``the situation was becoming really very dramatic'' despite vigorous efforts by the Soviet leadership over two years to arrange a political settlement to the ethnic tensions between Azeris and Armenians. Dubinin said military force was used to protect the constitutions of the Azerbaijan and Armenian republics in the midst of inter-national strife. ``The introduction of troops was necessitated not by some political objectives related to suppressing dissent,'' he said. ``The only objective pursued by these measures was to stop the bloodshed and restore peace and enter a sense of security to people,'' Dubinin said. He said the situation in Azerbaijan remained difficult, with trains that would carry food and fuel to Armenia under an blockade. Schools in Armenia have been forced to shut down, factories are idle and homes are without electricity at night.

DOC.HEAD: American Symphony Orchestra Appoints Woman as Music Director
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Comet is pronounced co-MAY
DOC.TEXT: Catherine Comet, music director of the Grand Rapids Symphony in Michigan, has been named music director of the American Symphony Orchestra. Ms. Comet, who studied with the late Nadia Boulanger and Pierre Boulez, will assume her new job for the fall season. The New York-based orchestra was founded in 1962 by Leopold Stokowski. Its previous music director, John Mauceri, left in 1986. ``We've used the last couple of seasons to try out people,'' said General Manager Raymond T. Grant.
Here are highlights of the $1.23 trillion spending plan proposed to Congress by President Bush, the first drafted from scratch in his administration.
DOC.HEAD: DEFICIT:
DOC.TEXT: Bush projects red ink of $63.1 billion dollars, a decline from almost $124 billion in the current fiscal year, and a surplus of $5.7 billion in the 1993 fiscal year. The Congressional Budget Office said last week it is highly unlikely that these projections will be borne out.
DOC.HEAD: DEFENSE:
DOC.TEXT: For only the second time since the 1970s, an administration is planning for a decline in defense spending after inflation. Bush proposes $303 billion, including $10.4 billion in nuclear weapons spending by the Energy Department, compared with $296 billion and $8.9 billion in the current year. This is about a 2 percent reduction in buying power. The budget calls for mothballing two battleships, reducing military personnel by about 38,000 to 2,039,000, canceling 15 major weapons programs and closing many bases.
DOC.HEAD: CAPITAL GAINS and SAVINGS:
DOC.TEXT: Bush again proposes reduced taxes on capital gains, something Congress declined to approve last year. The maximum rate would fall to 19.6 percent, for taxpayers in the 28 percent bracket, on assets held at least three years. In an attempt to boost savings, the administration would establish ``Family Savings Accounts'' where interest would be tax-free if allowed to accumulate for seven years. Contributions to these accounts could be as large as $5,000 a year for a married couple. Rules would be eased for Individual Retirement Accounts to waive the penalty on early withdrawals, up to $10,000, if the money is used for the first purchase of a home.
DOC.HEAD: DRUGS:
DOC.TEXT: The president calls for a 41 percent increase in spending for the war against drugs, from $6.9 billion to $9.7 billion.
DOC.HEAD: TRANSPORTATION: Spending on airports and other air transportation programs would rise by 12 percent, from $5.74 billion to $6.47 billion. As the Reagan administration proposed before, the budget calls for eliminating the $600 million annual subsidy to Amtrak.
ENVIRONMENT:
DOC.TEXT: As part of an ``America the Beautiful'' initiative, the president proposes to spend $175 million to begin a major reforestation program, with an eventual goal of planting trees on 1.5 million acres annually. Improvements in natural resource protection and increased land acquisition for parks and other purposes would bring spending under this initiative to $630 million compared with $361 million on these items in the current year. The Environmental Protection Agency would get a 12 percent increase in its operating budget, from $1.9 billion to $2.2 billion. Cleanup of nuclear weapons waste would increase from $3.7 billion to $4.5 billion.
DOC.HEAD: SCIENCE:
DOC.TEXT: A $700 million increase in spending for the planned space station, to $2.6 billion; and a $400 million increase in preliminary spending for manned exploration of the moon and Mars, to about $1.3 billion, are among increases proposed for spending on science and space that would see outlays rise from $14.1 billion to $16.6 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Leahy Unhappy About Farm Commodity Cut
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's unwillingness to be more specific about a proposed $1.5 billion cut in farm commodity programs in fiscal 1991 doesn't sit well with Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. In Bush's budget proposals sent to Congress on Monday, farm commodity programs were projected to cost nearly $10.4 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. But White House budget planners said outlays for the Agriculture Department's commodity programs would be even higher if Congress failed to go along with $1.5 billion in farm program cuts to be worked out later with lawmakers. Although no one was specific about how the $1.5 billion might be carved out of the department's Commodity Credit Corp. spending budget for 1991, the options include further reductions in price support and target price benefits, the ingredients to determine how much direct crop subsidies might be due to farmers. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, told a group of bankers that the budget plan ``suggests they will continue to cut target prices and (price support) loan rates until the farm programs are effectively abolished.'' In a statement later, Leahy added that as Congress begins debate on the 1990 farm bill farmers ``deserve straight answers on the administration's farm policy.'' He said the administration ``talks in generalities and refuses to specify where the cuts will come from.'' For its part, the administration said in its budget report that the White House ``is prepared to work closely with the Congress ... to develop market-oriented farm legislation that allows producers to decide what crops to grow, while also achieving the budget savings needed in the commodity programs.'' The document cited a number of options for reducing CCC outlays by the $1.5 billion, including an extension ``or acceleration'' of the downward slide in target prices and loan rates authorized in the 1985 law. ``Savings also could be achieved by reducing the number of acres eligible for payments, or targeting benefits to smaller farmers in greatest need,'' the budget report said. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said in a statement that ``efforts to balance the federal budget cannot be allowed to destroy one of our greatest accomplishments, which is to provide `safety net' levels of support'' for farmers. Bush also pledged Monday that the administration will work with Congress to prevent some individual farm operations to collect excessively large federal subsidies. ``Failure to do so will result in a loss of public confidence and support for the farm program,'' said the budget report. ``The taxpayers rightly expect these abuses to be curbed.'' The 1985 farm law limits the amount of income-support payments under various crop programs to $50,000 per person each year. The limit on total federal subsidies is $250,000 per year for each person. But these ceilings ``have been routinely exceeded'' because a ``person'' is defined as an individual or business entity, such as a corporation or trust, the budget document said. The report included diagrams of how illegal joint ventures using family members and other entities were set up to evade the $50,000 limit in 1988 and collect $912,089 in federal subsidies. Another example showed payments of $801,619. Both examples were included last year in reports by the Agriculture Department's inspector general. The budget document also said that while reducing farm program costs is important, the administration ``also is concerned about the distribution of those subsidy payments.'' ``A significant portion of benefits goes to larger, wealthy farmers,'' it said. ``In an era of limited resources, this is hard to justify.'' In 1987, for example, 30 percent of the $22.4 billion in commodity related subsidies went to 4 percent of the farmers who had average net cash incomes of more than $100,000 per year and net worths of nearly $850,000. ``This should be changed,'' Congress was told. ``One option for achieving savings of approximately one-half billion dollars would be to eliminate direct payments to farm operators with adjusted gross incomes of over $100,000 per year.'' The budget document added: ``This income level, after all, represents three times the average for an American family of four. Up to a billion dollars could be saved by withholding direct payments to farm entities with gross sales of $500,000 per year or more.''

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans' Police Superintendent Among First for Drug Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to fix `check' to `checked'
DOC.TEXT: Police Superintendent Warren Woodfork's number came up when a computer chose the first 20 officers to be tested for drugs. ``He got a good charge out of it,'' said John Bryson, a department spokesman. The computer has been programmed to randomly choose 20 Social Security numbers a day until the entire department has been checked. An officer has one hour from the time he or she is notified to get to a laboratory and provide a urine sample for testing, said Bryson. He said Woodfork left for the lab immediately after being told. Bryson said nobody knew the chief's number had been chosen until the list of numbers was checked against personnel records. Under the program that went into effect Monday, an officer who tests positive for drugs will be suspended while the result is investigated, said Bryson. Officers who appear to be drunk or on drugs can be tested immediately. Did the chief pass? Results are confidential.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Pleased That Bush Emphasizes Federal Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists are applauding President Bush's budget emphasis on repairing damage caused by construction of dams and other federal water projects. ``The president said he wanted to be known as the environmental president,'' David Campbell, an economist with the Wildlife Federation, said Monday. ``This actually is a fairly good start.'' ``We've been arguing for years that both the Corps of Engineers and the Bureau of Reclamation have overdue mitigation,'' he said. ``We should be redirecting these agency budgets from all this harmful construction into something more environmentally beneficial.'' The $3.2 billion for the 1991 fiscal year for the Army Corps of Engineers _ about the same as sought last year _ designates several million dollars for environmental repairs and continues funding for construction projects under way, but offers no money for new projects. ``The civil works program and budget reflect the new emphasis placed by the administration on maintaining and restoring the environment,'' the corps said in its explanation of the budget. Major provisions addressing environmental concerns are: _$16 million for construction of juvenile fish passage facilities on the Columbia and Snake Rivers in Washington, Oregon and Idaho. _$20 million to begin acquisition of 88,000 acres to mitigate environmental losses caused by construction of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway Project in Alabama and Mississippi. _$13 million to plan repairs to the environment damaged by construction of Richard B. Russell Lake in South Carolina and Georgia, and areas of Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri after navigational improvements were made on the Missouri River. Campbell noted Congress gave the administration authority in 1986 to seek federal funds for the next five years to buy private land around the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway for environmental restoration, but the administration didn't act until this year's budget _ the last year of the authorization. Campbell estimated $20 million should be enough to acquire about 47,000 acres this year. The fisheries on the Columbia River also are desperately needed to restore salmon to the waterway which Campbell called ``decimated by the dam-builders,'' who started building on the river in 1935. The president has asked for $1.039 billion, including $616 million in construction outlays, for the Bureau of Reclamation, an agency within the Interior Department that assists in the construction of irrigation reservoirs in the arid West. The proposal calls for a halt to federal spending on the Garrison Diversion Unit in North Dakota, which was authorized by Congress in 1965 to provide water to the eastern section of the state through canals and rivers. The president's budget calls Garrison is ``an uneconomic and environmentally destructive project which would require in excess of $1 billion to complete.'' No major new construction starts are proposed. However, dam safety work and environmental damage mitigation at existing projects, and most water projects already in construction would receive continued funding.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,215.67, up 41.97 points, or 0.11 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: `Robin HUD' Says She's Ready for Jail
LaserPhoto BA1
DOC.TEXT: The real estate agent dubbed ``Robin HUD'' pleaded guilty to stealing at least $4.75 million from the federal housing program and then said she is optimistic, even if her future includes prison. ``I'm prepared to accept what comes my way. I have no fear,'' said Marilyn Louise Harrell, who entered her plea Monday in U.S. District Court. ``A lot of my friends and former employees are ex-offenders, and they're fine people.'' Harrell, 46, of the southern Maryland town of Waldorf, had said she gave much of the money she had stolen from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to charity. ``I really truthfully consider it an honor to give up years of my life to help some of the people I've helped,'' she said. But U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox said that by April 20, when Harrell is set to be sentenced, ``my assertion that she has been her own biggest charity will be fact.'' In addition to stealing government property, Harrell pleaded guilty to lying on her tax returns and to federal officials. Harrell said she pleaded guilty because she did not want to spend taxpayers' money on a trial. Prosecutors dropped two other tax counts, two counts of lying to HUD officials, and one count of lying to a bank on a loan application. ``I'm very pleased,'' Harrell said. ``That was a very gracious move to offer me what they offered.'' She could be sentenced to a maximum 13 years in prison and fined $500,000. Prosecutors recommended a sentence ranging from 37 months to 46 months in prison. They also plan to recommend a fine, but no amount has been set. Harrell confessed to government officials in December 1988, and became a symbol of mismanagement at HUD under the Reagan administration when scandal erupted there last summer. After her indictment in November, U.S. Attorney Dick Thornburgh called it the largest theft of federal funds by an individual. ``I thought I'd get caught a long time ago,'' Harrell said after Monday's U.S. District Court hearing. ``I'm sorry for what I did. I figured I was history and would help as many as I could before I went down.'' Prosecutors say Harrell stole from HUD at least $6.6 million, money generated by sales of HUD properties that Harrell handled as a private escrow agent for the agency. Harrell said she has documents to prove that she took only $4.75 million and that less than 6 percent of the money benefited her family. Prosecutors previously said she had taken at least $5.6 million, but revised the figure after identifying six more properties for which she allegedly did not remit settlement proceeds. Harrell said she has prepared herself for prison since 1985, when she started diverting HUD funds. She told her family she would use the prison time to get a college education. Harrell appeared relaxed at the hearing before U.S. District Judge Herbert F. Murray. When Murray asked how she felt, Harrell replied, ``Terrific, your honor.'' Supporters who said they had benefited from Harrell's largesse attended the hearing. One held up a giant card, decorated with balloons, reading, ``Marilyn, We're Remembering You.'' Charlotte Chepaitis, who said she runs a Baltimore homeless shelter, said Harrell helped the shelter financially, but declined to give details. ``Jesus said to do your alms in secret, and that's just what Sister Marilyn did,'' Chepaitis said. ``And like Jesus said, she cried out today for forgiveness. Now there are millions praying for her.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Scales Back Defense Spending But Offers Little `Peace Dividend'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposed 1991 budget lops a few billion dollars from defense spending in acknowledgement of the Cold War's demise, but a ``peace dividend,'' or windfall for social programs, is practically too small to fight over, officials say. The spending plan sent to Congress on Monday seeks total military spending of $303.3 billion. That's about 2 percent, or $3.1 billion, less than this year's Pentagon budget, after inflation. The administration is shying away from talk of a ``peace dividend'' for fear that congressional budget axes will land too hard on the Pentagon. But the $3.1 billion figure is the likely starting point for debate over defense savings. Some private analysts advocate cutting defense spending in half over the coming decade. Democrats already accuse the administration of protecting the massive Pentagon budget even as political change in the Eastern Bloc makes war increasingly unlikely. ``It is a Rip Van Winkle budget that has not yet awakened to the changes in the world or the major challenges at home,'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., said Monday. In an essay accompanying Bush's spending blueprint for the year starting Oct. 1, Budget Director Richard Darman made it clear the administration sees no sense in clamoring for a sudden shift in spending priorities. ``The issue has been framed as: `How big is the peace dividend?' _ and, in effect, `How can I get mine?''' Darman wrote. His suggested answers are: Not big enough to matter yet, and don't conclude you'll get yours any time soon. Darman argues that in order to ensure that democracy takes hold in the East bloc, the United States should stick to the ``peace through strength'' formula of high defense spending that Bush contends helped defeat the communist regimes. Congressional leaders already have made it clear they will try to take a bigger chunk out of the defense budget, but the debate over how to use any savings is less clear cut. Should it be used to reduce the federal deficit, or can it make room for a tax cut? Should it go to education or housing programs? What about repairing the bridges, tunnels and roadways across the country that are crumbling of old age? Although he does not link any proposed spending increases to a scaling back of the defense budget, Bush's 1991 budget adds $500 million of spending authority to the Head Start pre-school education program, for a total of $1.9 billion. He also seeks more money for urban enterprise zones designed to encourage self-help in the inner cities, and boosts spending to combat drug abuse. Other proposed increases in domestic spending include an extra $642 million for cleaning up hazardous wastes at facilities run by several federal agencies, and $175 million to kick off a reforestation program aimed at planting 1 billion trees. Some argue that far from realizing a peace dividend, the American people are as likely to see more tax money going to pay for the government's mistakes of the past. One example cited by Darman is the cost of cleaning up the millions of gallons of radioactive and toxic wastes that have been building up virtually in secret at Energy Department nuclear weapons plants over the past 40 years. Darman puts that cost at $140 billion to $200 billion over the next 30 years. And even as the Energy Department seeks increased financing for the cleanup work, it remains committed to expensive projects to modernize the nuclear arms factories. Bush's budget calls for about a 6 percent increase, after inflation, in key weapons production activities, plus a 19 percent jump in spending authority for development of a new generation of reactors to make weapons materials. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said that while spending on weapons factories might eventually be reduced, no savings should be expected until more U.S.-Soviet arms control agreements are completed and East-West relations grow friendlier. ``Far better to press on and show the will to do what is now on the table, then back off later,'' he told reporters. ``We recognize that that's more expensive, but let me tell you it's the only way for this to pay off. It's a peace through strength issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks to Boost White House Spending 14 Percent
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who wants to hold the overall federal budget to a 3 percent increase, is seeking a $20 million, 14 percent increase to run his own office. The president, in the budget sent to Congress on Monday, wants to spend $500,000 to renovate the White House kitchens and $4.5 million for a new White House computer system. The overall budget for the Executive Office of the President would surge by 84 percent from $174 million to $319 million in the 1991 fiscal year, but most of that increase is for the expanded war on drugs. Leaving aside the budget for the Office of National Drug Policy, the U.S. Trade Representatives and several others listed under the White House, the executive budget actually would climb to $158 million from $138 million, spokesman Stephen Hart said. Bush's salary stays frozen at $200,000, but the budget includes an 8 percent increase for staff assistance and support (from just less than $30 million to $32.5 million). Bush, who has also said he wants to be known as an environmental president, also wants to nearly double spending on the Council on Environmental Quality: from $1.4 million to $2.7 million, or 87 percent. He also provided a 19 percent increase for the National Security Council, from $4.8 million to $5.8 million, and the National Space Council would get an 82 percent boost to $1.2 million from $688,000. For the care and upkeep of the White House itself, Bush envisions spending $7.9 million next year, an 18.3 percent jump from the current $6.6 million spending level. The figure includes $500,000 ``for the rehabilitation of the White House kitchens.'' Last year's budget had $800,000 to replace exterior windows of the executive mansion. By law, Bush's own salary is fixed at $200,000, plus a $50,000 entertainment budget. Bush also requested $25 million for his new Points of Light Initiative Foundation, a government-backed non-profit group that will seek to spur community service and volunteerism around America. Bush will be honorary chairman. The cost of maintaining the vice president's home, cars, staff and other services would jump from $470,000 to $609,000, a 30 percent increase. That includes a $15,000 raise in his official entertainment budget to $90,000. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, chaired by Michael Boskin, would get a 6.5 percent increase to $3 million.

DOC.HEAD: What's up Doc? Bugs Bunny is in the Operating Room
LaserPhoto MR1
DOC.TEXT: Patients in operating rooms around the world are asking, ``What's up, Doc?'' From Vermont to Australia, doctors and nurses are tossing aside traditionally bland scrub uniforms and donning ones adorned with Bugs Bunny, Tweety and baby dinosaurs. The designer is Dr. J. Christian Abajian, director of pediatric anesthesiology at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont. Abajian and his wife, Margaret, run Huggable Scrubs Inc., which customizes the pajama-like hospital outfits. Abajian, 46, said he developed the idea for patterned scrubs in 1986 as a way to ease the tension felt by hospitalized children, who often will not pay attention to hospital staff because they are scared. ``We did it just to make my job easier ... just to relate to children easier,'' said Abajian, clad in a dinosaur-dotted scrub in one of the hospital's operating rooms. The first pattern, a jungle inhabited by tigers, giraffes and frogs, was sewn by his wife, and was an immediate success, he said. ``There just wasn't any doubt right from day one that it was a hit,'' he said. ``There really never was any doubt in my mind that it would help me with a child. But I never anticipated the response I get from adults.'' Abajian said one time a man waiting in the delivery room told him, ``Before I saw you wearing that shirt I was about to lose it. I saw you and I just felt so much more relaxed.'' Mrs. Abajian began sewing scrubs for her husband's colleagues. Dr. Richard Hubbell _ an ear, nose and throat surgeon clad in scrubs showing Bugs Bunny as a circus ringmaster _ said the clothing helps him relate to his young patients. ``It helps to ease their mind through a very stressful situation,'' Hubbell said. ``The children love them.'' When the demand started increasing as the word spread, Abajian decided to launch Huggable Scrubs Inc. The Abajians then began the direct-mail company from their northern Vermont home in Williston, with Mrs. Abajian doing the sewing. After several unsuccessful ventures with investors and manufacturers, Huggable Scrubs Inc. is finally getting off the ground. The company now has a business manager, and is having its garments produced by the Hedma Corp. in nearby North Troy. In 1988, the company had sales of about $20,000. That figure jumped to about $74,000 in 1989. Huggable Scrubs needs to approach $150,000 in sales this year to stay in business, the Abajians said. The company processes about 35 orders a week. Destinations include Australia, Belize, Canada, Colombia, France, and about 300 hospitals in the United States. Perhaps the biggest break for the company has been their two-year licensing agreement with Warner Bros. for the use of Looney Tunes cartoon characters, including Bugs Bunny. The Abajians hope Bugs, who is celebrating his 50th anniversary this year, will help them make money. Michelle Greenberg, an account executive with LCA Entertainment, a subsidiary of Warner Bros., said the company views this project with more than just an eye on the bottom line. ``It doesn't really matter to us whether we make money on this,'' Greenberg said. ``He's bringing happiness to a lot of people. That's what his license is all about. It's good will.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stocks Inch Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was marginally higher against the Japanese yen Tuesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange inched up. The dollar closed at 143.25 yen, up 0.03 yen from Monday's 143.22-yen close. It started trading lower at 143.10 yen and ranged between 143.05 yen and 143.50 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 41.97 points, or 0.11 percent, ending the day at 37,215.67. The index, a 299.63 point-gainer the previous day, opened higher but gradually lost some of its early gains as Japanese government bond prices and the yen weakened, said Toshiaki Yui, a dealer with Nomura Securities, Co. Sony's announcement that it will issue 400 billion yen ($2.8 billion) worth of stock to raise its capital discouraged market players, who worried the increase in shares might lower prices, he said. In currency dealings, the dollar inched up from its opening level as some market players sold yen to take profits on the Japanese currency's recent gains, traders said. Minori Takeuchi, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said Japanese investors were not active enough to send the dollar lower. ``Investors overseas have been pushing the dollar lower, but market players in Tokyo seldom take initiatives,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: There's something fishy about the full-page ads taken out by a wood products giant to promote a takeover attempt involving 2.1 million acres in northern Maine. The newspaper advertisements show a smiling sportsman with a big fish. There's just one little problem: There's no such fish in northern Maine. Georgia-Pacific Corp. has been running the ad in Maine newspapers for weeks to drum up support in its battle to buy Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. for $3.8 billion. Biologists say the fish in the ad appears to be a striped bass, which lives in coastal waters and not in northern Maine, the location of the land at stake in the takeover. The advertisement is headlined ``The Maine Facts About Georgia-Pacific.'' Gail Smith, a spokeswoman at Georgia-Pacific's Atlanta headquarters, said she had little information about the picture. ``It was taken somewhere in New England,'' Ms. Smith said. ``It's intended to be a representation of sporting activities.'' The striped bass has been introduced in some freshwater bodies, particularly in the South, and the state is trying to develop a population in the Kennebec River. Fisheries biologist Paul Johnson said Monday the fish probably will never swim in the waters of Great Northern's land. ``We're a long way from the coast,'' he said. ``They should just change that ... picture in their advertisement.''

Gordon Emerson didn't go to New Orleans for the Super Bowl, he brought the look of the Superdome to his home. Emerson, 37, took a week's vacation to attach a house-size cardboard facade resembling the Louisiana Superdome to the front of his house here. ``Some people decorate their homes for Christmas,'' he said. ``I decorate mine for the Super Bowl. The cardboard stadium, 43 feet wide and 22 feet high, covered the front of Emerson's house. Tape, strings and nails hold it in place. ``The way I see it, I have a front-row seat, hot food, short lines for the bathrooms, and I won't have a big Visa bill.''

Alaska should be put in its place _ in the upper left-hand corner of the U.S. map, according to legislators. Too often Alaska is shown in a small box off the coast of California, or just left off U.S. maps altogether, said state Rep. Fran Ulmer. Ulmer is the sponsor of a resolution that asks the nation's newspapers, magazines and book publishers to put the state in its rightful geographic position. The Alaska House passed the resolution unanimously Monday and sent it to the Senate. The resolution was expanded at the request of Rep. George Jacko to ask publishers not to cut off the Aleutian Islands. ``It's usually broken off and stuck there on the bottom,'' Jacko said. ``I want them to show how big Alaska really is.''

DOC.HEAD: `Driving Miss Daisy' Unseats `Fourth of July' at Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' drove ``Born on the Fourth of July'' from the top of the list of ticket sales last weekend. ``Driving Miss Daisy'' collected $5.7 million for a strong per-screen average of $6,375, Exhibitor Relations Co. said Monday. The film stars Jessica Tandy as a Southern Jewish widow and Morgan Freeman as her black chauffeur in a story of manners, race relations and friendship. Overall weekend business at U.S. and Canadian movie theaters was slow because of Sunday's Super Bowl, Exhibitor Relations said. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' the account of Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic, fell to second place with ticket sales of $4.6 million. In third place was the police drama ``Tango & Cash'' with $3.6 million. The dark divorce comedy ``The War of the Roses'' placed fourth with $3.23 million. A close fifth was the stylish police thriller ``Internal Affairs'' at $3.18 million. The fright film ``Tremors'' landed in sixth by grossing $3.15 million. ``Always,'' from director Steven Spielberg, was seventh with $2.41 million. In eighth was the ensemble drama ``Steel Magnolias'' at $2.38 million. Rounding out the top ten were ``The Little Mermaid'' with box-office revenues of $2.2 million and ``Back to the Future Part II'' with $1.8 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations. 1. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Tri-Star, $5.7 million (weekend gross), 895 screens, $6,375 per screen, $16 million (total gross), seven weeks in release. 2. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $4.6 million, 1,311 screens, $3,540 per screen, $39.2 million, six weeks. 3. ``Tango & Cash,'' Warner Bros., $3.6 million, 1,575 screens, $2,267 per screen, $49.5 million, six weeks. 4. ``The War of the Roses,'' 20th Century Fox, $3.23 million, 1,523 screens, $2,124 per screen, $71.4 million, eight weeks. 5. ``Internal Affairs,'' Paramount, $3.18 million, 986 screens, $3,220 per screen, $15.7 million, three weeks. 6. ``Tremors,'' Universal, $3.15 million, 1,477 screens, $2,135 per screen, $7.9 million, two weeks. 7. ``Always,'' Universal, $2.41 million, 1,206 screens, $1,995 per screen, $34.1 million, six weeks. 8. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $2.38 million, 1,370 screens, $1,735 per screen, $64.1 million, 11 weeks. 9. ``The Little Mermaid,'' Disney, $2.2 million, 1,530 screens, $1,421 per screen, $68.1 million, 11 weeks. 10. ``Back to the Future Part II,'' Universal, $1.8 million, 1,473 screens, $1,205 per screen, $109.9 million, 10 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Lists Bases for Closure, Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Here are the U.S. domestic and overseas military bases that are candidates for possible closure or reductions as announced by the Defense Department on Monday. The bases are listed by service or defense agency. Domestic Closures: Army: Detroit Army Tank Plant, Mich.; Fort Ord, Calif.; Fort McClellan, Ala.; Lima Army Tank Plant, Ohio; Sacramento Army Depot, Calif.; Troop Support Command, St. Louis; and Army ammunition plants at Charlestown, Ind., Parsons, Kan., Karnack, Texas, Minden, La., Picayune, Miss., Scranton, Pa., and Desoto, Kan.
