Navy: Alameda Naval Aviation Depot and Alameda Naval Air Station, Calif.; Chase Field Naval Air Station, Texas; Detroit Naval Air Facility, Mich.; El Centro Naval Air Station Facility, Calif.; Long Beach Naval Shipyard, Calif.; Louisville Naval Ordnance Station, Ky.; Moffett Field Naval Air Station, Calif.; Oakland Naval Hospital, Calif.; Oakland Naval Supply Center, Calif.; Philadelphia Naval Staion and Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, Pa.,; South Weymouth Naval Air Station, Mass.; and Treasure Island Naval Station, Calif. Air Force: Bergstrom Air Force Base, Texas; Eaker Air Force Base, Ark.; Los Angeles Air Force Base, Calif.; and Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C. Defense Logistics Agency: The four Defense Contract Administration regional offices at Cleveland, Ohio; Dallas, Texas; New York, N.Y.; and St. Louis, Mo. Overseas Closures: Navy: Nea Makri Naval Communications Station, Greece. Air Force: Comiso Air Base, Italy; Erhac Air Base, Turkey; Eskisehir Munitions Storage Site, Turkey; Hellenikon Air Base, Greece; Kwang Ju Air Base, Suwon Air Base, Taegu Air Base, all in South Korea; RAF Fairford, RAF Greenham Common, and RAF Wethersfield, all in the United Kingdom; and Zweibrucken Air Base in West Germany. Domestic Reductions: Army: Fort Knox, Ky.; Fort Gillem, Ga.; Fort Hood, Texas; Fort Lewis, Wash.; Fort Sheridan, Ill.; Fort Meade, Md.; Fort Sam Houston, Texas; Red River Army Depot, Texas; the Army Material Command's headquarters at Alexandria, Va.; its Depot Systems Command at Letterkenney Depot, Pa.; and its 11 management engineering activities; parts of the Information Systems Command and elements of the Reserve component. Air Force: Luke Air Force Base, Ariz.; Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.; McClelland Air Force Base, Calif.; Eglin Air Force Base, Fla.; MacDill Air Force Base, Fla.; Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio; Tinker Air Force Base, Okla.; Kelly Air Force Base, Texas; Hill Air Force Base, Utah; Hanscom Air Force Base, Mass.; Kirtland Air Force Base, N.M.; Tonopah Research Site, Nev.; Nellis Air Force Base, Nev.; Andrews Air Force Base, Md.; Bangor Air Guard Station, Maine; Robins Air Force Base, Ga., and Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Ariz. Overseas reductions: Navy: Partial draw down at Bermuda Naval Air Station and realignment at San Miguel Naval Communications Station in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Plan to Close Military Bases Draws Fire
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's plan to close or scale back 72 U.S. military installations has riled officials in large cities and small towns. Targeted communities nationwide are mobilizing to ``fight like the dickens'' to avoid the cuts. California would be the hardest hit under Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposal, with 10 bases employing more than 35,000 servicemen and 22,000 civilian workers slated for closure or reductions. But the closings also would hit hard in communities such as Charlestown, Ind., a southern Indiana town of 5,700 where the Defense Department plans to mothball a munitions plant and lay off about 900 workers. ``It's the only place a lot of the people have worked,'' said Mayor Bob Braswell, who once worked as a security guard at the Indiana Army Ammunitions Plant. ``They've worked there all their lives.'' In announcing his $292.1 billion fiscal 1991 spending plan Monday, Cheney called for Congress to ``have the guts'' to make tough decisions about closing military bases. The response in affected communities came quickly. Pennsylvania's two Republican U.S. senators, John Heinz and Arlen Specter, showed up outside the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, pledging to fight the recommendation that the yard be closed. ``The Philadelphia Navy yard is a winner,'' said Sen. John Heinz, ``and we are going to keep it a winner. Anybody who is going to try to make it a loser will find out they are wrong.'' Some lawmakers accused the Republican administration of targeting military installations in Democratic districts. Rep. Glen Browder, D-Ala., sounded a battle cry to save Fort McClellan, which officials said if closed would cost the Anniston area in eastern Alabama 2,700 military positions and 1,500 civilian jobs. ``If they are looking for a political fight, they've come to the right place. We're ready,'' said the freshman congressman, who defeated Republican John Rice last year in a special election to replace the late Bill Nichols. California would bear the largest share of the cuts. One of the bases that would be closed is the Alameda Naval Air Station, which has 8,300 servicemen and employs 5,100 civilians for a combined annual payroll of $340 million in the island city of 77,000 in the San Francisco Bay area. ``This is really a terrible thing to hear, and we're not going to lay back and let it happen,'' said Mayor Chuck Corica. ``We're going to fight like the dickens to keep this base open.'' The largest possible closure in California would be Fort Ord near Monterey and the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, Fort Ord is home of the Army's 7th Light Infantry Division, which helped invade Panama last month. The base has 15,000 soldiers and 3,000 civilian employees with a combined payroll of $732 million and an estimated impact on the local economy of more than $885 million a year. The shipyard in Long Beach, one of the port city's largest employers, could take up to $100 million a year out of the local economy, said Long Beach Area Chamber of Commerce President Bob Creighton. ``Naturally, we oppose it. Naturally, we'll do whatever we can to make sure that it doesn't become reality,'' said Assistant City Manager John Shirey. Officials in some states announced plans to try to find non-military uses for bases slated for closure. States that have been moving away from reliance on defense spending said the strategy has enabled them to cope with budget reductions. In Connecticut, officials said the defense industry has dropped from 12 percent of the state's gross product in 1982 to 6 percent in 1988, with United Technologies leading the switch. The Hartford company has trimmed its defense operations from 75 percent 12 years ago to just about 25 percent today. ``That kind of strategy will be more and more important over the next few years,'' said Stephen B. Heintz, Connecticut's economic development commissioner. Some workers took the announced closings in stride. Tom Ferkler, a union steward at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, said employees have heard several proposals during the past decade to close the shipyard. ``It's the hottest topic, and naturally everyone's concerned, but when it gets down to the workingman's level, the decision's not in our hands.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Nervous, Local Britons Worry About U.S. Base Cuts
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. plan to close or move troops from 14 military bases abroad had some South Koreans worried today, and British communities fretted over the prospect of losing millions of dollars in local spending. However, the Soviet Union said the proposed U.S. defense budget, which calls for a 2 percent overall spending cut, is in keeping with American and Soviet commitments that are bringing the Cold War to an end. And despite local concern in communities near bases, British and other European governments generally reacted calmly to the plan on Monday. South Korean newspapers gave banner headlines in today's editions to the U.S. plan to close three Air Force bases in that country, where security is the No. 1 national priority. Reassuring nervous South Koreans, the country's defense ministry said the combined war capability of the U.S. and South Korean forces would be little affected by the plan. Brig Gen. Jimmy L. Cash, vice commander of the 7th U.S. Air Force based in South Korea, said in a statement today: ``These changes ... do not signal a lessening in the United States commitment to the Republic of Korea.'' The 11,500 U.S. Air Force personnel in the country are among 43,000 American troops in South Korea under a mutual defense pact to guard against aggression from the Communist north. The changes at the U.S. bases abroad would be made under a plan proposed in Washington on Monday by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. He also wants to make similar moves at about 55 military bases in the United States. The overseas bases targeted for closing are the Nea Makri Naval Communications Station in Greece and these Air Forces bases: Comiso Air Base, Italy; Erhac Air Base and Eskisehir Munitions Storage Site, both in Turkey; Hellenikon Air Base, Greece; Kwang Ju Air Base, Suwon Air Base, Taegu Air Base, all in South Korea; RAF Fairford, RAF Greenham Common, and RAF Wethersfield, all in Britain; and Zweibrucken Air Base in West Germany. The U.S. Navy would make force reductions at Bermuda Naval Air Station and change the makeup of forces at San Miguel Naval Communications Station in the Philippines. The British Defense Ministry additionally announced Monday that a squadron of U.S. F-16 fighters based at Bentwaters in eastern England is to be disbanded. Ruth Ritter, the mayor of Fairford, said: ``I am very sorry about this decision because it is going to cause a great deal of uncertainty in our community, particularly for the 300 (British) civilian workers'' at the base. The Fairford base has 18 KC-135 air-to-air refueling tankers. Charles Daybell, chief executive of Braintree District Council in eastern England, which includes the Wethersfield base, said: ``We are very sad at the thought of losing so many good friends. The base spends nearly 6 million pounds a year in the area,'' roughly $10 million. The Wethersfield base houses a civil engineering unit with 531 U.S. servicemen. Lt. Col. Sam Giammo, director of public affairs for the 3rd U.S. Air Force, based at Mildenhall in eastern England, said about 3,000 U.S. personnel will be withdrawn from Britain, or about 7.5 percent of the total. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev, commenting on the proposed U.S. defense budget, said: ``Both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. have agreed the Cold War is over. Any vestige of that should be relegated to history.'' In Italy, Pio Mastrobuoni, a spokesman for Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, said: ``The announcement is a sign of the times. The news expresses the new reality of the climate of cooperation between East and West.'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, a firm opponent of any significant disarmament by the West despite crumbling Communist control in the East bloc, had ``no objections,'' said a spokeswoman at her office. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain said during an official visit to Washington that the U.S. plan was ``entirely compatible with the United States commitment to NATO.'' At Greenham Common cruise missile base west of London, where women anti-nuclear protesters have camped outside for nearly a decade, protester Evelyn Parker said: ``It's stunning news. This has been an amazing thing to live through.'' Missiles are being removed from Greenham and other bases under the 1987 agreement between the superpowers to eliminate their medium-range nuclear missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins in Paris Bombings; Chief Suspect Ejected
DOC.TEXT: As he went on trial with 17 other defendants, a Shiite Moslem charged with masterminding a Paris bombing campaign that killed 13 people told a court that his name is ``Death to the West.'' Police sharpshooters manned rooftops near the courthouse Monday as officers in boats patrolled the Seine River. It was part of a security effort under way for weeks as authorities feared the trial might prompt fresh terrorist attacks. As the proceedings began Monday, the defendant said in a calm but loud voice that drowned out the judge: ``I am not Fouad Ali Saleh. My name is Death to the West. You have killed Moslems .... This is war.'' Presiding Judge Henri Malergue ordered police to escort Fouad Ali Saleh to a cell as the reading of the charges began five minutes into the trial. Saleh, a 31-year-old Tunisian, and 17 other defendants face charges of terrorist conspiracy, possession of illegal arms, trafficking in explosives and a variety of drug offenses. Eight are being tried in abstentia. All face 10 to 20 years in prison if convicted, and a trial on murder charges is planned later this year. The defendants in court Monday included Saleh's French wife, Karima, three Tunisians, two Moroccans and three Lebanese. The 18 defendants are charged in a string of explosions that hit Paris from Dec. 7, 1985, to Sept. 8, 1986. Bombers struck train stations, department stores, and shops along the famed Champs Elysees and throughout Paris, killing 13 people and wounding 250. A group calling itself the Committee for Solidarity with Arab and Middle East Political Prisoners claimed responsibility for the attacks and demanded freedom for three prisoners held by France. French officials believe members of the group were recruited and directed by Saleh, who took his orders from Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed group of extremist Shiite Moslems. Police arrested Saleh and broke up the group in March 1987. French media said Saleh spent a year in Libya before taking a course in theology in Iran in 1981, when he converted from the Sunni branch of Islam to the Shiite sect. He moved to Paris in 1983. Saleh set his tone for the trial when he lashed out at prosecutor Jacques Fourvel at a court hearing three weeks ago. ``Shut up, you!'' Saleh shouted. ``Christians and Jews have no right to speak when a Moslem is talking. Islam will be your death, God will crush you. Assassin, son of a pig ... go to the devil! Hezbollah will crush you!'' Malergue ejected Saleh at that time and sentenced him to a year's imprisonment for contempt.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Taking Conservative Approach
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat once known as one of Virginia's most liberal legislators, has been talking and acting like a conservative since he took office Jan. 13. In his first two weeks as governor, Wilder called for spending cuts to create a budget surplus, supported expansion of the death penalty and consulted with Republican legislators before he presented the state budget. The fiscally conservative approach Wilder has taken even has some Republicans saying he is acting more like one of them than a Democrat. Some people have suggested that Wilder, the nation's first elected black governor, is already looking beyond Virginia politics. ``I think he's perhaps using state politics as a vehicle for some future run for national office,'' said Mark Rozell, a political scientist at Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg. ``He is taking a very cautious approach on many issues.'' ``The national Democratic party needs a fiscally conservative southerner who can hold traditional Democratic constituency groups,'' said Larry Sabato, a political analyst at the University of Virginia. ``What Doug Wilder is fundamentally is a politician. He is not a black politician. The creed of every politician is, `There go the people. ... Let me run in front of them,''' he said. But Sabato said Wilder's liberal roots can be seen in some ways, such as in the record number of blacks he has appointed to high state offices. Wilder has remained mum about his ambitions. Asked whether he would pledge to serve out his four-year term, he replied with a smile, ``I can assure you that it is my intention.'' Wilder has questioned past solutions to social problems, which he said stemmed from bad attitudes. He said he would use his example as a leader to fight drugs, illegitimacy and poor school performance among segments of the black populace, instead of ``simply throwing money at them.'' Wilder, a former criminal defense attorney who once opposed the death penalty, said it should be extended to cover those who kill during drug deals. Those slayings account for about a third of the homicides in Richmond alone. ``I do think society has a right to express its outrage at heinous crimes,'' Wilder said. ``I don't know that it would be any deterrent.'' Wilder's major step so far has been his plan to create a $224 million surplus in the 1990-92 state budget, which already has been squeezed by a projected revenue shortfall that could approach $1 billion. The governor also proposed slashing recommended teacher pay increases and raising liquor prices in state-run stores to create the surplus. ``I was shocked by the proposal on the teacher pay raises,'' said Steve Haner, director of the Republican legislative caucus. ``That's a political group he owes his own existence to.'' Haner said Republicans have found little to complain about in Wilder's first weeks. ``Sometimes we wonder whether or not we won the election,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Proposal Would Force FBI to Cut 400 Agents
DOC.TEXT: The FBI would be forced to cut 400 agents from its workforce in its 1991 budget, largely because of a new overtime law that is expected to add $42 million to the bureau payroll. The 400 agents will be eliminated as a result of attrition, said Deputy Director Floyd Clarke, who noted that there are between 450 and 480 retirements or resignations each year. There are more than 10,000 FBI agents. ``Right now, our hiring program will have to be almost stopped in 1991'' if the proposed budget stands, Clarke told reporters Monday at a briefing on the Justice Department's budget. ``We just have to work harder,'' he said. ``We will get the job done.'' The loss of 400 agents from the FBI's payroll contrasts with planned increases in Drug Enforcement Administration agents to fight President Bush's stepped up war on illegal drugs. The proposed budget would increase the number of DEA agents from 3,167 to 3,547 in the next fiscal year, DEA officials said. ``There is no question the drug war is receiving a very high priority,'' said Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer. ``It is the highest priority in the department.'' The cut in the FBI's agent workforce would be only the second in a decade; the 1981 fiscal year budget cut 93 agents. The proposed $1.54 billion FBI budget would increase expenditures by $100 million from the current budget of $1.4 billion. Proposed increases for more agents for such high-priority activities as white-collar and organized-crime investigations partially offset the across-the-board manpower cuts. But even the white-collar crime section will suffer a net loss of 41 agents under the proposed budget. There would also be a net loss of six agents assigned to organized-crime cases. Those decreases would be implemented despite Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's repeated vow to fight ``crime in the suites.'' ``Those priorities remain the attorney general's priorities,'' said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. But the FBI's ``job is to manage the operation within the budget provided them.'' In the coming months, the Justice Department will work with the FBI ``to ensure that in the implementation of a final budget there will be no diminution of effort in the priority areas identified by the president and the attorney general,'' Runkel said. Runkel suggested the bureau could better manage the time of agents to reduce the overtime budget. Virtually every FBI agent earns overtime, officials said. The FBI will eliminate 227 agents at a savings of $25.7 million to meet deficit-reduction targets, officials said. The bureau also plans to cut 559 agents to finance the higher cost of overtime under a new law enacted by Congress. The overtime formula for paying federal law enforcement agents is expected to cost the FBI $41.9 million in the 1991 fiscal year, according to Justice Department budget documents. The increases for high-priority programs will add 388 agents, resulting in a net loss of 400 agents, according to budget documents. The new law pegs overtime pay to an agent's actual pay grade. Previously, all agents over Grade 10 earned overtime calculated to that pay level. Senior agents will earn between $13,000 and $15,000 in overtime each year instead of $6,000 to $7,000, Runkel said. The Justice Department expects to spend $66 million in additional overtime for FBI, Immigration and Naturalization Service and DEA agents in the 1991 fiscal year. The Office of Management and Budget had originally agreed to add that money to the department's budget, said one department source. However, OMB later decided to force the Justice Department to absorb the extra overtime expenses, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Employer Medical Insurance Costs Jump in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Medical insurance costs for employers rose 20.4 percent last year, according to new survey. The survey of 1,943 employers, released Monday, found the average cost of medical plans rose to $2,600 per employee, up from $2,160 in 1988. The average cost for employees enrolled in health maintenance organizations jumped 16.5 percent to $2,319 from $1,991 the previous year. The figures include both employee and employer contributions, but do not include dental plans. The survey, conducted by the consulting firm of A. Foster Higgins & Co. Inc., said employers commonly cited several reasons for the rise: _Increasing use of new and expensive medical technologies and drug therapies. _Larger and more frequent claims for catastrophic illnesses. _Escalating costs for outpatient services, mental health and substance abuse services.
DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian To Put Air And Space Annex In Virginia
DOC.TEXT: The Smithsonian Institution says Dulles International Airport in suburban Virginia will be the site for a $300 million annex to the National Air and Space Museum. The new facility will house exhibits that will including a space shuttle, the Concorde and the airplane that dropped the first atomic bomb. The Smithsonian's 17-member board decided that of the offers received from Virginia, Maryland and a late proposal submitted from the city of Denver, Virginia's plan offered more space, a better layout and was closer to the existing Smithsonian museums, officials said Monday. Phase I of the complex, which would include exhibition space, a restoration hangar and storage, and a theater, is expected to be finished by 1995, with total completion expected between 2005 and 2010.
DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Let Customers Block Caller I.D. Service
DOC.TEXT: Telephone companies would have to give customers the option of blocking Caller I.D., a new service that displays a caller's phone number before the receiver is picked up, under Senate legislation. Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., said he was in favor of the new technology, but that customers also should not have to give out their phone numbers. ``A privacy balance must be struck,'' Kohl said Monday in introducing the Telephone Privacy Act of 1990. ``Who decides whether the caller will reveal his or her number?'' Kohl said. ``I think the decision must rest with the caller.'' Caller I.D., which has been available in New Jersey for more than a year and is just beginning to be offered in Tennessee, West Virginia, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Maryland, uses a small terminal that displays the numbers of incoming calls. The device costs $50 or more to purchase, and the Caller I.D. service costs about $7 a month.
DOC.HEAD: World Earthquakes, Deaths Down in 1989
DOC.TEXT: The number of significant earthquakes was down last year despite the World Series quake in California, and total deaths were well below average, the U.S. Geological Survey reports. Earthquake fatalities worldwide totaled 526 last year, well below the long-term average of 10,000 deaths per year. The Oct. 17 California quake, which has been named the Loma Prieta quake, killed 62 people, injured an estimated 3,500 and caused damage totaling at least $5.6 billion. In 1988, tremors claimed some 28,000 lives, most in the earthquake that struck Soviet Armenia on Dec. 7 of that year. Overall there were 55 significant earthquakes last year, six fewer than in 1988. On average the world had about 60 significant quake a year. A significant quake is defined as one that registers at least 6.5 on the Richter scale, or one that has a lower reading but which causes casualties or significant damage. Last year's deadliest quake occurred Jan. 22, killing 274 people in the Tajik region of the Soviet Union. Ninety died in Iran in a quake that struck on Aug. 1. The strongest tremor of the year occurred May 23 in the South Pacific. It was a so-called Great quake, measuring 8.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Government Rescinds State of Siege; Exiles Call Move An Empty Gesture
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The military government lifted a state of siege and ended press restrictions after a 10-day crackdown on the democratic opposition, but newly exiled activists called the gesture meaningless. State television, announcing the end of the measures on Monday night, said they had ``produced their full effect and permitted the settlement of the crisis which threatened the future of Haitian democracy.'' Three government critics banished during the crackdown said the true threat to establishing democracy on this impoverished Caribbean island is the military leadership. They said the free elections Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril has promised for October remain an impossiblity under the circumstances. The state of siege was declared Jan. 20 to put an end to ``subversive machinations,'' President Avril told the nation on Saturday. The government had also suspended articles of the constitution that prohibited the forced exile of political opponents. On Jan. 22, the government banned television and radio news broadcasting that it had not authorized. Those restrictions were lifted on Monday. Avril said Saturday that the state of siege would be lifted today, ``in view of the positive results already obtained.'' More than 50 opposition politicians and militants were have been arrested in the crackdown. Most said they were beaten before being released. At least four were reported missing or still in custody. Human rights activist Robert Duval and political leaders Sylvio Claude and Gerard Phillipe-Auguste went into hiding. Dr. Louis Roy, called the ``father of the constitution'' in Haiti; conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray; Communist Party second-in-command Max Bourjolly, prominent businessman and civic leader Antoine Izmery, and three other opposition militants were sent into exile. In Miami on Monday night, Robert Leger, a spokesman for Roy, de Ronceray and Izmery, said, ``The suspension of the decree means nothing to us. A free, fair and honest electoral process under Avril is impossible.'' Another emergency measure imposing an entry visa for Haitian citizens was also rescinded Monday. The government declared the state of siege a day after gunmen killed an army colonel, his wife and their maid. Avril said the crackdown was necessary ``to protect democratic accomplishments against terrorism,'' implying that enemies of the government carried out the assassination. Skeptics saw it, however, as a pretext for Avril to consolidate his power and renege on his promise to hold legitimate elections. The emergency measures had provoked world protest. The United States, Canadian, and French governments and the European Community condemned the measures. France suspended foreign aid negotiations and the Bush administration indicated there would be no early resumption of Washington's $60 million annual aid package. In addition, the Association of Haitian Industrialists and the Haitian Chamber of Commerce and Industry had demanded the emergency measures be revoked. On Sunday, the 10 bishops of Haiti's Roman Catholic Episcopal Conference demanded that the government respect the ``letter and the spirit of the entire constitution,'' that it ``abolish torture in all its forms'' and that it create ``a favorable climate for free and honest elections'' this year. In his speech to the nation, Avril reaffirmed his government's commitment to elections, but ``in a more serene climate.'' Avril rose to power in a September 1988 coup led by noncommissioned officers who professed disgust with the state terrorism under the military man they ousted, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy. He had led the military junta that assumed power when President-for-life Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986 during a popular uprising, ending the harsh 27-year Duvalier dynasty. Presidential elections were held on Nov. 29, 1987 but aborted after thugs, protected by soldiers, massacred at least 34 voters at polling stations. Civilian Leslie Manigat won army-run elections in January 1988 and was overthrown by Namphy in June 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Computerized Therapy Helps Depression Patients, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: A computer did as well as a human therapist in treating depression in a new study, and researchers say the machines may someday help psychotherapists treat the common disorder. Computerized treatment might be provided day and night at a cost of perhaps 50 cents an hour, and the machine ``doesn't have any bad days,'' said researcher John Greist. Human therapists now can treat only a fraction of the 10 million Americans who suffer depression within any six-month period, he said. But roughly a third of people with depression may one day be helped by computerized therapy if further research shows it is useful, said Greist, a psychiatry professor at the University of Wisconsin Medical School in Madison. Humans would still be needed to screen patients for the therapy and to step in if the computer fails to treat the patient adequately, he said in a recent interview. And the therapeutic approach used in the study works best for people with only mild to moderate depression, he said. The study is presented in this month's issue of the American Journal of Psychiatry by Greist, Paulette Selmi, and others at the university. T. Byram Karasu, professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, called the study important. But he cautioned that cognitive-behavioral therapy, the approach used by the computer and the human therapist in the study, is generally less effective for depression than other strategies, including medication. He also stressed that while computers might be useful for some aspects of psychotherapy, they cannot totally replace a human therapist. Most depressed patients are ``starving for human contact,'' he said. The study compared the progress of 12 depressed people who received therapy from a computer, 12 who consulted a therapist, and 12 who received no treatment during the experiment. The two treated groups followed a six-week course of weekly cognitive-behavioral therapy. This approach aims to correct harmful patterns in how people interpret their experiences, such as in people who habitually perceive slights and conclude that they must be worthless and not liked. The therapist's job in this approach is fairly routine and can become repetitious, Greist said. That makes the regimen ``a poor use of human beings'' but a good candidate for being done by computer, he said. Using a program Selmi designed, the computer in the study asked such questions as how long a person had felt depressed and which activities in a list made the person feel better. It also asked about particular symptoms and asked the person to rank the severity of his depression on a standard scale. In this way, the computer could get ``a pretty crisp idea of the nature of this person's depression,'' Greist said. The computer used responses to its multiple-choice questions to shape the course of each session and future sessions. The actual therapy included teaching basics of cognitive-behavioral therapy, testing the person's understanding of the lessons, and assigning homework. Depending on the person's problems, the homework could include such tasks as reading particular chapters of books, thinking about less damaging explanations for perceived slights, or introducing oneself to new people daily to discover that one is not always rejected. Analysis showed that as a group, patients who took computerized therapy improved as much as those in the other treated group, both at the conclusion of treatment and two months later. Both groups improved significantly more than the people who had received no therapy.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Come Out to Help Republicans Raise Money
DOC.TEXT: A parade of show business stars serenaded President Bush and 800 of the Republican party's biggest donors at a Kennedy Center gala that also featured the spectacle of GOP Chairman Lee Atwater trading guitar licks with blues legend B.B. King. Bush advised his party chieftain afterwards, ``Lee, I heard your music. Don't give up your daytime work.'' The show, which also drew much of the Cabinet and GOP leaders of Congress, also evoked a stream of ringing endorsements for Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle, who came in mid-concert fresh from his return from a fence-mending mission to Latin America. Chubby Checker, before twisting the night away with 15 teens from the Duke Ellington School for the Performing Arts, praised the president and added of Quayle: ``He's such a good-looking guy. Don't sell this guy short.'' The crowd responded with loud applause. Bush later said approvingly, ``It was from the heart and well-deserved.'' Tony Bennett sang his signature song, ``I Left My Heart in San Francisco'' and then, without benefit of a microphone, ``Fly me to the Moon.'' Roberta Flack dedicated her trademark song, ``The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,'' to the Quayles, and then followed with ``Always'' for the Bushes. Frankie Valli, backed up by the Four Seasons and two more musicians, serenaded the first couple with, ``You're Just Too Good to be True,'' and said in his brief political pitch, ``We believe you're doing an incredible job and we certainly are looking forward to seven more years of the Bush administration.'' Other entertainers included Harry Connick Jr., a young jazz pianist from New Orleans, and country singer Randy Travis. After watching a slide show that noted Bush had met with 120 foreign leaders and logged 130,000 miles on trips in his first year that took him to 33 states and 15 foreign countries, emcee Mary Hart of television's ``Entertainment Tonight'' quipped, ``Seeing what you have done in one year, I'm exhausted.'' Russian-born comedian Yakov Smirnoff said, ``The chairman of the Republican Party playing a guitar. What a country, I'll tell you! Try to picture Gorbachev doing that.'' Smirnoff took questions from the audience and someone asked what he thought of the Soviet leader. ``I think he's doing a good job,'' he said, but he quickly added, ``Let me ask you this: how many people here trust Gorbachev? Applaud if you do.'' There was a ripple of applause through the hall. ``O.K. How many people here don't trust him?'' Most of the crowd began clapping. ``That's what I think,'' said the emigre comedian. Atwater said the evening brought together three of his idols: his wife Sally, pregnant with their third child; his ``political idol,'' Bush, and blues great King. Atwater, clad in tuxedo, gyrated, shimmied, rolled his tongue and puckered his lips up into a fish face as he played in tandem with King and his famous guitar, ``Lucille.'' It was a sedate audience that resisted most of the stars' efforts to instigate rhythmic clapping or singing. The evening was billed as ``the Presidential Inaugural Anniversary Gala'' by its sponsor, the Republican National Committee. The price of a ticket was $1,000 on top of the $10,000-a-year dues that the donors pay for the privilege of being designated a Republican Eagle _ a club created 15 years ago as one of the GOP's most successful fund-raising devices. Bush, speaking from the stage at the end of the concert, saluted the party's benefactors, saying, ``The Eagle is the symbol of America. ... You've always been our strong right arm.'' ``Last year we got started. We got the ball rolling on ways that we can make America cleaner and leaner and more competitive,'' said Bush. ``And now I will again ask the Democrats up on Capitol Hill to work with us in a bipartisan manner to fight the scourge of drugs and crime, to clean our air and to educate yet another generation of American children.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Check Messages From Plane
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials defended regional air traffic controllers who never explicitly told local controllers that Avianca Flight 52 was short on fuel before it crashed, killing 73 of 159 people aboard. The Colombian jetliner's cockpit crew told regional, high-altitude controllers about the fuel shortage 45 minutes before Thursday night's crash, but did not make clear the severity of the situation, Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Fred Farrar said Monday. The pilot requested only ``priority'' clearance to land, and that word ``has no particular meaning in air traffic control,'' Farrar said. ``If there is an emergency, you use the word `emergency.''' The FAA, whose duties include overseeing the nation's air traffic controllers, released a partial transcript of taped conversations among the crew and controllers as the National Transportation Safety Board today neared the end of its on-site investigation. The transcripts showed that in a telephone conversation, the regional controllers told counterparts responsible for landings at Kennedy International Airport that the Colombian jetliner couldn't remain in a holding pattern south of the airport for more than five minutes. But the regional controllers did not explicitly mention the fuel shortage, the transcripts show. The flight was cleared for landing at Kennedy 37 minutes later, but that attempt was aborted, apparently because of bad weather. Less than 10 minutes later, the Boeing 707 fell powerless into a wooded hillshide in the secluded Long Island village of Cove Neck. The cockpit crew were among those killed. More than 20 survivors remained hospitalized in critical condition. FAA rules for flight emergencies spell out instructions for pilots, including those with foreign airlines, landing at U.S. airports. ``If, at any time, the remaining usable fuel supply suggests the need for traffic priority to ensure a safe landing, the pilot should declare an emergency and report fuel remaining in minutes,'' the instructions say. Investigators are considering the possibility that the Colombian pilot interchanged the words ``priority'' and ``emergency'' by mistake. They also planned to talk with Avianca officials about what instructions are given to pilots when they have fuel problems. The FAA and NTSB, as well as the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, stressed Monday that the plane's message was not urgent and did not use the word ``emergency,'' which would have brought the plane to a quick landing at Kennedy. The words ``emergency'' or ``minimum fuel'' ``would have triggered an emergency response by controllers,'' said controllers association president R. Steve Bell. ``Stating that you are low on fuel does not imply an immediate problem.'' Another union official who listened to the tapes said that the pilot never sounded worried. ``He said, `I'm running out of fuel,' just as calm as if he were sitting in his living room,'' said Barry Krasner, eastern regional representative of the controllers association. About 8:45 p.m., as they were circling over New Jersey, the cockpit crew warned the regional control center that they were low on fuel. ``We think we may need priority,'' a crew member told the control centerl A regional controller replied, ``How long can you hold before you have to go to your alternate (landing site)?'' ``Wait a minute,'' the cockpit replied, pausing apparently to check. ``We can hold five minutes.'' Shortly thereafter, the cockpit said the alternate landing site was Boston, and ``I can't make it.'' At that time, the FAA said, the regional controller phoned the local controllers, and said, ``Avianca 52 just came out of Cameron (the name of the holding area) and can only do five more minutes of hold. Can you take him now?'' The local controller replied, ``Slow him to 180 knots and I will take him.'' After the phone call, the plane was released to Kennedy. It made a missed approach 37 minutes later through rain and fog, coming in too steeply, authorities said. Investigators said the crew agreed to a controller's suggestion that the plane loop back over Long Island and come in for a second attempt. It did so, the cockpit saying twice more it was low on fuel, but the engines soon quit and the plane crashed. Fuel gauges _ which some pilots say are unreliable in 707s _ and cockpit documents have been taken to a Washington lab, NTSB member Lee Dickinson said.

DOC.HEAD: Package Containing Gun Delivered to Federal Prosecutor
DOC.TEXT: A briefcase booby-trapped with a sawed-off rifle probably was sent as a warning to a federal prosecutor who has investigated major heroin traffickers, authorities said. ``It could have killed the person opening it,'' U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said Monday. ``I think it's because of the kind of work this assistant may have been working on.'' The briefcase had not been considered suspicious when it was delivered by mail Monday to the office of Assistant U.S. Attorney Catherine Palmer. It was delivered to the federal courthouse in Brooklyn despite increased security in the wake of the package bombs that killed an federal judge and civil rights lawyer in Alabama and Georgia. The device was disarmed by federal agents working with Ms. Palmer on another case. ``They happened to be there and opened the package. ... I think it was more luck than anything that it didn't go off,'' Maloney said. A police spokeswoman, Officer Janice Swinney, described the gun as a .22-caliber rifle ``set to go off,'' but did not elaborate. Maloney said he believed the device, which contained no note or other threat, was related to Ms. Palmer's work as a drug prosecutor, not to civil rights. The veteran prosecutor specializes in large Asian heroin trafficking networks. The investigation was turned over to the FBI, which refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Film Star's Fans Pay Respects to the Former Country Girl
DOC.TEXT: Ava Gardner, whose sensuous beauty took her to Hollywood and stardom, was buried in native soil in a quiet ceremony attended by family and hometown friends. About 500 people stood in drizzling rain Monday at Sunset Memorial Park in this farming community to pay their last respects. Miss Gardner, 67, died of pneumonia Thursday in London, where she had lived the past two decades. Miss Gardner was buried a few miles from Brogden, where she was born on Christmas Eve, 1922, and lived until she was 13. Smithfield was the town ``she knew and loved as home,'' said the Rev. Francis Bradshaw, pastor of Centenary United Methodist Church in Smithfield, at the graveside service. ``We come to celebrate this life who brought so much to so many publicly but who brought so much to so many privately as well,'' Bradshaw said. ``She touched lives the world over.'' Miss Gardner wound up with a screen test and a $50-a-week contract with MGM after photographs taken by her brother-in-law caught the eye of a studio clerk. Between 1942 and 1980, Miss Gardner made more than 60 feature films, including ``Show Boat,'' ``Mogambo,'' ``The Barefoot Contessa,'' and ``On The Beach,'' with such leading men as Clark Gable, Gregory Peck and Humphrey Bogart. In 1985, she appeared in the CBS television series ``Knots Landing.'' Friends and relatives, including Miss Gardner's sister, Myra Pearce, attended the service. Another sister, Beatrice Cole, had recently been hospitalized and was unable to attend, friends said. Miss Gardner, youngest of seven children, was buried next to her brother Jack, a state legislator who died in 1981. Two other sisters, Inez and Elsie, and a brother, Raymond, also are dead. Miss Gardner had been married to Mickey Rooney, jazz bandleader Artie Shaw and to Frank Sinatra. Family and friends said Miss Gardner often visited, although her family moved to Newport News, Va., when she was 13. ``She was a nice lady _ real reserved,'' said Alan Gardner, who last saw his first cousin at a family reunion 12 years ago. ``She dressed in old clothes and wore no makeup when she was here so she looked quite different.'' Most of those on hand were fans or local residents who recalled their connections to Miss Gardner. Janice Massengill said her father worked at The White Swan, a barbecue restaurant where Miss Gardner ate when she returned to the area. ``It makes it a great honor for her to come to your hometown for her resting place. Ever since I was little, I've always heard of Ava Gardner,'' Massengill said.

DOC.HEAD: Congresswoman: America Needs `User-Friendly' Birth Control
DOC.TEXT: The nation needs ``user-friendly'' birth control methods to reduce its 3.4 million unplanned pregnancies each year and end the ``war'' over abortion, says a lawmaker backing more funding for contraceptive research. ``In the '80s, Iran and the United States were the only two countries that really went backward in family planning,'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Col., said Monday at a Planned Parenthood conference. ``We should be discussing where we want to be five years from now _ whether we still want to be at war on these issues, or whether we want to be at peace.'' Schroeder said she and Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, ``decided we wanted to be at peace,'' and co-sponsored a measure last July to make the federal government the leader in finding new methods of birth control and techniques against infertility, which affects an estimated one of six U.S. women. Their proposal calls for spending $77.2 million over five years to establish five new research centers exploring the two issues. ``Any woman who reads women's magazines knows what the damage of the '80s has been,'' Schroeder said. ``You pick up any magazine and many newspapers, and there's constantly some kind of article questioning the safety of current contraceptives. ... ``Now why isn't the federal government answering those questions?'' she asked. Federal funds for such research through the National Institutes of Health and the Agency for International Development totaled $30.8 million in 1988, down from $32.4 million in 1987. ``The amount of dollars spent a year for this research would keep the Defense Department running for 15 minutes,'' said Dr. Louise B. Tyrer, vice president of medical affairs for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America Inc. Schroeder said safety questions over available contraceptive methods have reduced options for U.S. women. ``They've been left to what Cleopatra had _ sponges,'' she said. ``The question is how do we make contraceptives user-friendly to women, and to men ... and that they feel are safe?'' Lawsuits over intrauterine devices, or IUDs, have undermined the ability of most U.S. pharmaceutical companies to market them. And Congress in the 1970s declined to fund federal research into birth control methods that would act after conception, such as RU-486, the so-called ``abortion pill'' developed by the French. Minutes after Schroeder began speaking, Joe Scheidler, director of the Chicago-based Pro-Life Action League, tried to enter the room but was turned back. ``They're trying to get the government to fund research on abortifacients and contraceptives,'' he said. Abortifacients are birth control methods that prevent pregnancy after conception. ``We're very much opposed to the use of government money to destroy our children.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``They want to change anything but their chairs _ the name of the party, even their ideals.'' _ Lyubomir Pavlov, a senior member of Bulgaria's independent trade union Podkrepa, on the eve of a crucial congress of the ruling Communist Party, expressing skepticism that the party is on a truly democratic course.

``I'm going to try to be charmin' Darman again.'' _ Richard Darman, White House budget chief, who antagonized many lawmakers during last year's bitter budget process, as the Bush administration began this year's push to sell its $1.23 trillion 1991 budget to a skeptical Congress.

``I don't think it's created any excess fear. It's just added to the frustration that the average black person feels on a daily basis.'' _ Pearlie Frazier, Savannah, Ga., city water department employee, on the aftermath of December's mail bombings that killed a city councilman and a federal judge in Alabama. Voters cast ballots today to select a replacement for the slain councilman, Robert Robinson.

DOC.HEAD: Sammy Davis Jr. Hospitalized for Gum Infection
DOC.TEXT: Song and dance man Sammy Davis Jr., who recently completed treatment for throat cancer, has been admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center for a gum infection, a spokesman said today. The 64-year-old entertainer contracted the infection after some dental work in which several teeth were removed, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. ``He had dental work about a month ago and got an infection in a couple of his teeth, which were removed,'' Wise said. ``He's being treated for a second small infection but he's doing well.'' Wise, who was contacted at home, could not say when Davis was admitted. ``Sammy's ambulatory. He's walking around,'' Wise said. ``The infection is controlled and he should be out in a few days.'' During an annual medical examination last September, Davis' physician Dr. Gerald Blankfort detected something out of the ordinary, which was diagnosed as a throat carcinoma. Davis, who had been touring with Frank Sinatra and Liza Minnelli, was forced to cancel concerts to undergo radiation treatment. Miss Minnelli and Sinatra continued with the tour. ``With the help of the good Lord,'' Davis said then, ``I'll be back cooking by the end of the year.'' He was honored in November at an all-star salute to his 60 years in show business. The gala, which included such stars as Eddie Murphy, Ella Fitzgerald, Michael Jackson and tap dancer Gregory Hines, recently was broadcast by ABC-TV. Davis has said his cancer treatment was completed with doctors highly optimistic there would be no recurrence.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Surrender Dynamite, Say They've Abducted Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers surrendered 2,200 pounds of dynamite, saying they wanted to show they are sincere in seeking peace with the government, and claimed to be preparing to free a kidnapped Colombian diplomat. The cocaine barons said Roberto Garcia-Pena, the country's former consul in Miami, would be freed with a peace message for President Virgilio Barco, who declared war on the traffickers five months ago. Colombia has since been terrorized by attacks blamed on drug gangs that have claimed at least 209 lives. The dynamite, packed in a bus, was found in Medellin, the northwestern city that is a hub of the drug trade. The traffickers telephoned reporters to offer the reasons they were giving up the explosives. Their statement on the kidnapping, delivered to the RCN radio network, said Garcia-Pena was abducted Friday in Bogota and would be freed today with the message for Barco. The statement was signed by the Extraditables, the name adopted by the cocaine barons, who are trying to force the government to abandon extradition of Colombians wanted on drug trafficking charges in the United States. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said privately that Garcia-Pena, Colombia's consul in Miami for 18 years until 1988, disappeared Friday but the ministry had not heard from kidnappers. Garcia-Pena, 54, is the son of the editor emeritus of Colombia's largest newspaper, El Tiempo of Bogota. Since Barco declared war on the cocaine gangs Aug. 18 after the assassination of a leading presidential candidate, drug bosses have been blamed for 262 bombings and other terrorist attacks. All 107 passengers aboard a Colombian airliner died in a November crash blamed on the traffickers. Medellin police said in a news release the dynamite found in the bus was not connected to detonators. Also in the bus was a statement saying the traffickers would continue giving up explosives. It, too, was signed by the Extraditables. The statement accused the national anti-narcotics police of torture and murder and claimed, without giving details, the police had murdered 10 men arrested on suspicion of being hired killers. A man saying he spoke for the Extraditables called the RCN station in Medellin on Monday and said the traffickers ``do not have any missiles and don't want to attack the United States.'' He appeared to be responding to reports in the United States that the U.S. Secret Service had learned the traffickers had shoulder-fired missiles and might try to attack President Bush when he visits Colombia next month. Bush is to meet with some Latin American presidents Feb. 15 in Cartagena, on Colombia's north coast, for a discussion of what to do about drug trafficking. On Jan. 17, the Extraditables issued a statement saying Barco had won the drug war and offered to abandon the drug trade, give up their weapons and release all hostages if granted amnesty. In return, they said they wanted constitutional guarantees. They did explain but presumably meant assurances they would not be extradited to the United States. Since the drug crackdown began in August, Colombia has extradited 13 suspects for trial. Colombian analysts have said they doubt the traffickers considered themselves beaten and believed the offer to abandon the drug trade was a ploy to get the government to negotiate. However, since their statement of capitulation, the Extraditables have released six of 22 people kidnapped over the last two months. Police said Monday they had found a weapons cache on a ranch owned by Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a leading trafficker killed in a gun battle with officers last month. A news release said they found 170 rifles and 55 pounds of dynamite on the Veracruz ranch 95 miles north of Bogota.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Plans Nine Space Shuttle Launches in 1990
DOC.TEXT: A new NASA schedule reduces from 10 to nine the number of space shuttle launches planned for this year, with the number rising to 12 in 1992 and 13 in 1993. ``It's a good plan and we think we can do it,'' launch director Bob Sieck told reporters after a schedule was released Monday listing 74 shuttle flights between now and the end of 1996. He noted the launch team has dispatched eight shuttles since flights resumed in September 1988, after a 32-month hiatus following the 1986 Challenger explosion. ``We have a well-trained and competent team,'' Sieck said. ``We are seeing more stability in the hardware and the requirements. We're bringing new equipment on line and the performance of the logistics system looks good.'' He said an orbiter being built to replace Challenger will arrive here next year and be ready for its first flight in early 1992, in time to support the accelerated launch schedule. Nine flights this year would match the record set in 1985. The elimination of one flight in 1990 was necessitated by a delay from March 26 to April 18 in the launch of Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope. That postponement was announced earlier this month after engineers detected a problem with one of the shuttle's two solid fuel boost rockets. That also resulted in the delay of another science payload, that of the Gamma Ray Telescope, from June until November and the rearranging of other flights. The dropped 1990 flight, that of a Strategic Defense Initiative payload, was put off nearly 14 months until January 1992. The explanation given was that this caused the least disturbance to the overall schedule. The space agency's new long-range plans call for eight flights in 1991, 12 in 1992, 13 in 1993, 11 in 1994, 11 in 1995 and 10 in 1996. This year's schedule originally listed nine flights, but was increased to 10 when a planned December launch of Columbia was delayed into January. That flight, launched Jan. 9, deployed a communications satellite and retrieved a science laboratory that had orbited for six years. The new manifest for the remainder of 1990: _Feb. 22, Atlantis, with a Defense Department payload that reportedly is an advanced reconnaissance satellite. _April 18, Discovery, with the Hubble Space Telescope. _May 9, Columbia, with an astronomy laboratory. _July 8, Atlantis, with a Defense Department payload. _Aug. 29, Columbia, with a Space Life Sciences Laboratory. _Oct. 5, Discovery, with the Ulysses spacecraft to study the sun. _Nov. 1, Atlantis, with the Gamma Ray Observatory to study deep space. _Dec. 12 Columbia, with the International Microgravity Laboratory.

DOC.HEAD: Informer: Gotti Wanted Someone `Whacked'
DOC.TEXT: A former gang enforcer who turned informer testified that he was introduced to John Gotti as a man who would ``whack'' somebody for the reputed mob boss. James ``Studs'' McElroy testified in Gotti's assault and conspiracy trial Monday that he was told after another reputed mobster's wake that Gotti wanted somebody ``whacked.'' The pair met, McElroy said, in April 1986 at the wake of Frank DeCicco, reputedly Gotti's underboss in the Gambino crime family. In an unusually hostile cross-examination, Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, disputed McElroy's testimony, calling him a liar, a rat, and a ``yellow dog.'' Cutler tried to portray McElroy, 45, as a coward who shot or knifed many people, but only if they couldn't fight back. McElroy said he accompanied James Coonan, leader of the West Side gang known as the Westies, to DeCicco's wake at a Brooklyn funeral parlor. He quoted Gotti as asking Coonan, ``Is this the kid?'' According to McElroy, Gotti then turned to him and said, ``I've heard a lot about you. I'd like to take you to dinner someday.'' At another point, McElroy said Coonan asked him in Gotti's presence, ``Jimmy, can you do it?'' McElroy said he answered that he could, even though he did not know what Coonan was asking about. ``You agreed to do it and you didn't know what it was they wanted done?'' asked Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky. ``Yeah,'' he replied. Later, at a restaurant, Coonan told him that Gotti's crime family ``wanted somebody whacked,'' McElroy testified. The target was John F. O'Connor, vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608, who was shot in the buttocks on May 7, 1986, in the lobby of a midtown office building. The prosecution says Gotti ordered O'Connor shot because he hired goons to wreck a mob-affiliated restaurant that was being built with non-union labor. Cutler disputed that McElroy met Gotti at DeCicco's wake: ``You met Mr. Gotti in your dreams, didn't you, Mr. McElroy?'' Gotti, 49, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are being tried in state court on charges of assault and conspiracy in O'Connor's shooting. O'Connor, who refused to testify at the trial, has been indicted on larceny, perjury and extortion charges, partly in connection with the destruction of the restaurant. McElroy, who is serving 60 years in federal prison, said he is testifying against Gotti in the hope that prosecutors will have mercy on his girlfriend, Francine Mostyn, 43, who was arrested on drug charges along with McElroy. McElroy, an admitted former drug addict and a heavy drinker, said that he was hung over and unable to go with three other Westies members to shoot O'Connor on the scheduled morning. Instead, they shot O'Connor the next day.

DOC.HEAD: Long Arm of the Law Wields Buckets, Mops at Dilapidated Station
DOC.TEXT: Along with crimes and misdemeanors, officers at police headquarters have been fighting a leaky roof, flickering phone system and crumbling walls. And they say they've had enough. ``We've got to get out of here,'' Sgt. Alan Fletcher said Monday. ``It's not a case where we're a bunch of crybabies here, it's a case where our health is at stake, our safety's at stake.'' As the search for new, dry digs continues, a bucket brigade is catching copious leaks throughout the 10-year-old building, Fletcher said. ``The walls are starting to crumble up pretty good,'' he said. ``The water, when it comes in now it comes in such large volumes we have a platoon of people on the water detail trying to get the water off the floor.'' ``The chief does get a direct hit once in a while on his desk and he has a plastic sheet to put over his papers,'' Fletcher said. After taking a tour of the waterlogged one-story station last week, Mayor Martin J. Dunn ordered a move. ``The general condition of the building has deteriorated to such an extent that we have to move out of there. Within weeks we'll be out of there,'' Dunn said. But officials agree that finding a new headquarters won't be easy, particularly as Massachusetts' fiscal woes make scarce state funds for this old mill city. Police Chief Russell J. Paquette, who has emptied a few pails himself, said money will simply have to be found. ``Somewhere along the line they're going to have to do something,'' he said. All told, about 30 plastic buckets, barrels and assorted trash cans are catching drips, along with makeshift plastic cones that direct leaks to containers. ``It leaks down behind my desk and puddles down under my feet and this isn't the worst part of the building,'' Paquette said. The water problems have damaged phone lines and electric equipment, sometimes preventing people from calling in to the dispatcher, Paquette said. One night, Paquette's office suddenly went dark for a few minutes. ``I was scared to touch the switch. I was afraid I might get a little tickle,'' the chief joked. Problems at the concrete building, funded by a federal grant of $2 million, began before it opened in 1980, Paquette said. The roof, which was originally constructed for parking, has been patched several times. An out-of-court settlement was reached with the design firm some years ago, but that wasn't enough to fix the problems, Dunn said. Abandoning the building will mean leaving behind expensive bulletproof glass and electrically-locked doors installed in the holding cell area, the chief said. That area is one of the driest in the building, so prisoners haven't been as affected by the leaks as officers, Fletcher said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Can Play Handball in New Prison
DOC.TEXT: Deposed dictator Manuel Noriega has been confined to a cell with only a bed, wash basin, toilet and writing table, but is being allowed to play handball during his daily hour of exercise in a 15-by-15-foot metal cage. The former Panamanian leader, awaiting trial on 12 drug-trafficking counts, will spend the rest of his day in isolation in the 86-square-foot cell in the medium-security Metropolitan Correctional Center 25 miles south of Miami. He was moved to the federal prison Sunday from the federal courthouse in Miami. He has no television in his cell. In the prison, where there are some maximum-security cells, Noriega is allowed to go into the 15-by-15-foot cage for one hour a day to exercise, prison spokesman Charles Davis said Monday. ``He can play handball against a wall, or walk around or do calisthenics,'' Davis said. ``But he won't be engaged in any team sports. He'll be out there by himself.'' In court Monday, Noriega's attorney, Steven Kollin, reiterated that the prison is not the proper place for his client, who he says is a prisoner of war. U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler set a trial date for March 5, but conceded that date was not realistic. He set a status conference for Thursday. Hoeveler also delayed a decision until Thursday on requests that two of Noriega's co-defendants _ former Panamanian Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, 46, and Daniel Miranda, 36, _ be released on bond.

DOC.HEAD: Three Storms Spread Rain, Snow, Cold
DOC.TEXT: Three storms today brought wind, snow and frigid temperatures to the Great Lakes region, heavy snows and rain to New England and the East Coast and wind and rain to the Pacific Northwest. An Arctic front churned toward the Great Lakes, bringing snow squalls to Michigan, Wisconsin and northern Minnesota. Temperatures dropped as much as 20 degrees as the front spread across the upper Midwest with winds of 20 to 40 mph, spawning wind chills as low as minus 50 from Montana to Minnesota. Heavy snow in New England's mountains was expected to taper off today. Predictions called for a total of 15 to 20 inches of snowfall in northeastern Vermont. Winter road accidents killed at least nine people in Oregon and New York state on Monday. In New York, more than a foot of snow in some areas mixed with rain and sleet to make traveling hazardous, leaving at least six people dead. Mild weather was expected to melt most of the state's new snow, though forecasts called for colder weather to return by the weekend. Snowy road conditions on U.S. Highway 97 in Oregon were blamed for a pair of wrecks Monday that claimed the lives three Californians, state police said. High winds and rain were predicted in western Oregon and California north of San Francisco for today. Rain was expected to change to snow in the Olympic Mountains and elsewhere in northwestern Washington. The Cascades and northern Sierra braced for more heavy snow. The southern Rockies and Southwest states expected dry, mild conditions today with above-normal temperatures and mostly sunny skies. Louisiana and coastal Texas looked for fog today. Florida was due for a few showers. On Monday, winds gusted to 48 mph at Bern, Ind., after a 6-inch snowfall. Roads were blocked by snowdrifts up to 5 feet deep. Monday thunderstorms produced hail the size of golf balls near Martinez, Ga. A tornado touched down northeast of Blythe, Ga., overturning seven trailers and injuring 6 persons. High temperature records for Jan. 29 broken Monday included readings of 35 at International Falls, Minn., and Negaunee, Mich. Miami Beach's 82 degrees also set a record for the date. The coldest reading in the Lower 48 states on Monday was minus 9 at Warroad, Minn. Monday's hot spots were Fort Myers and Vero Beach, Fla., both with 85 degrees. DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS wife's name; FIXES spelling of son's name in last graf of final obit.
DOC.TEXT: Jack Iams, a journalist, novelist and editor whose career spanned more than half a century, died Saturday of a stroke at age 79. Iams, a reporter for the Daily Mail of London, also wrote for Newsweek and the Daily News of New York, was television critic for The New York Herald Tribune, and was an editor of Atlas Magazine, now known as the World Press Review. An author of comic and mystery novels, he wrote 13 books, including the well-received 1939 novel ``Table for Four.'' Iams moved 18 years ago to Opio in southern France, where he continued writing, but he and his wife sold their house and were returning to the United States when he died. He is survived by his wife, Joan Walker Wenning Iams, and three children by his first marriage: John, a Moscow correspondent for The Associated Press; David, a society reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer; and Alice Kittredge of Panama. There are four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Penalty For Refusing Military Service Cut In Half
DOC.TEXT: The government will reduce the mandatory sentences of white men convicted of refusing compulsory military service from six years to as few as three years, officials announced. Military service by blacks is voluntary. Defense Minister Magnus Malan said Monday night that the decision was in keeping with the recent decision to cut compulsory military service for white men from two years to one year. Both moves follow announcements of major spending cuts in the $4 billion military budget. Officials said the cuts can be made because of reduced racial tension. Since taking office on Sept. 20, President F.W. De Klerk has been making conciliatory moves toward the opposition fighting his white-led government's policy of racial separation known as apartheid. Under the new sentencing rules, religious objectors would do three years of community service. Conscientious objectors could have their prison terms reduced to three years based on good behavior and other factors, Malan said. Conscientious objectors convicted of refusing to serve now receive an automatic six-year prison term. Men who decline to serve for religious reasons are required to perform six years of community service. ``It is only fair and right that the alleviation of military service, which has already been announced, be made applicable to religious objectors and those who refuse to render military service,'' Malan said. Three conscientious objectors are now serving six-year prison terms. At least 800 white men have publicly stated their refusal to perform military duty but have not been prosecuted. Many young white men who leave South Africa cite mandatory military service as one of the main reasons. The End Conscription Campaign, a group opposed to mandatory military service, said it welcomed the change. But it said it wants the government also to allow conscientious objectors to do community service.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Budget `No Longer a Sacred Cow,' Members of Congress Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs of new Cheney quotes after 5th graf, `We are'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney must convincingly argue that his $292.1 billion military budget is the proper U.S. response to changes in the Soviet threat, members of Congress say, and even then lawmakers may be unwilling to go along. ``The defense budget is no longer a sacred cow,'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said Monday after Cheney spelled out his military spending plan for fiscal 1991. The defense secretary, citing a diminished conventional threat from the Warsaw Pact nations and budget constraints at home, proposed an increase from this year's $286.8 billion in outlays to $292.1 billion _ a 2 percent reduction after adjusting for anticipated inflation. But at the same time, Cheney emphasized that the Soviet Union continues to modernize its strategic forces and the United States cannot abandon its own high-tech weapons such as the B-2 stealth bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative. ``We are going to retain and require deterrent capability in terms of our strategic forces for the indefinite future. That will not change,'' Cheney told reporters at a Pentagon briefing on the budget. Elaborating on that point on NBC's ``Today'' show this morning, Cheney said most of the changes seen so far in the Soviet military posture involve a winding down of conventional forces rather than reducing strategic weapons. ``I think the test now will be to see whether or not Congress makes the right kinds of difficult decisions, that is to say to cut overhead in some of those things that are important ... political considerations back home while we preserve the essence of our military capability,'' Cheney said of proposed base closings. ``At home, if we are going to reduce force structure ... then it's also important to reduce the base structure that supports those. You simply don't need as many bases if you're going to have a smaller Army,'' he said. The defense secretary testifies on Capitol Hill later this week, and spelling out his strategy will be the key with lawmakers. ``In my view, Congress will be more likely to go along with these tough decisions if Secretary Cheney can give us a clear vision of where defense policies and programs are going over the next five years in light of the changes in the threat and our overall strategy,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Not surprisingly, the defense secretary garnered quick support from several Republican lawmakers. ``We can't let the dramatic changes in Europe completely turn upside down planning for the future,'' said Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services panel. It would be ``highly risky if Congress went in and made unilateral cuts,'' Warner said, considering the instability in the Soviet Union, the constant threat of terrorism and lack of changes in the Third World. The Bush administration's plan calls for five B-2 bombers at a cost of $5.5 billion, numbers certain to draw fire on Capitol Hill where lawmakers have complained loudly about the radar-evading plane considered the most expensive in history at about $530 million a copy. ``The B-2 is the first victim of the Berlin Wall,'' Schroeder said. The budget also includes $4.5 billion for SDI, popularly known as Star Wars. The total represents a $1 billion increase over last year when Congress adopted _ and the administration accepted _ the first reduction in spending for SDI since President Reagan introduced the antimissile shield six years ago. ``I'm absolutely astounded by the amount asked for SDI,'' said Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee. ``Admiral (William J.) Crowe said $3 billion is a generous figure.'' Crowe retired last year as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The defense budget would continue financing of two land-based nuclear missiles, with $2.8 billion to fund rail-basing for the multiple-warhead MX missile and $202 million for the truck-based, single-warhead Midgetman. The budget also calls for $1.2 billion to involve the U.S. military more deeply in Bush's anti-drug war and to give a 3.5 percent military pay raise. The document envisions a smaller U.S. military force, paring 38,000 men and women from the 2 million in uniform, primarily from attrition in the Army and the Air Force. That step would bring the active duty force down to roughly equal its 1980 size. The plan calls for doing away with some 20 small weapons systems, such as the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey and the Army's M-1 tank, in an attempt to save $2.9 billion. Others cuts include the Navy's F-14D jet fighter, the Phoenix and Maverick missiles, the Apache helicopter, the Army Helicopter Improvement Program and the F-15E fighter. The Navy would lose two of its four battleships from the World War II era, the USS Iowa and USS New Jersey, for an estimated savings of $75 million. The most controversial aspect of the budget is the proposal that at this time has no savings attached. It is a plan to close or scale back more than 72 domestic installations and end U.S. operations at 12 facilities overseas. Among the major bases targeted are Fort Ord in California, Fort McClellan in Alabama and the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard. A significant number of facilities are located in California.

DOC.SECOND: Jury Finds Ford Swiped Inventor's Wiper System
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. infringed on a former professor's patent for the intermittent windshield wiper used on its cars, a jury ruled in a potentially far-reaching and lucrative case for the inventor. The verdict Monday could affect similar lawsuits by Robert W. Kearns against General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Daimler-Benz, Honda, Toyota, Nissan and 21 other companies. The Ford case was the first to go to trial. The federal jury will reconvene Feb. 26 to establish how much Ford must pay Kearns. However, U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn ruled earlier that Kearns failed to prove he could have made and marketed the system on his own and thus can claim only a royalty on each wiper, instead of Ford's profit. Ford had contended the patent was invalid because the windshield system contained no new concepts. But Kearns argued a new combination of parts made his invention unique. The invention allow the driver to set the interval at which the wiper sweeps the window. The jury decided that Kearns' patent was valid. Kearns claimed in his lawsuit that he installed a set of his wipers on a 1962 Ford and took it to the automaker. Kearns ``made numerous disclosures of confidential engineering test designs'' to Ford engineers, the lawsuit claimed. Because they repeatedly asked him to discuss designs, the lawsuit said, Kearns was led to believe Ford would buy his system. Kearns, his attorneys and Ford all said they were forbidden by the judge to talk about the 12-year-old case. Kearns, a former professor at Wayne State University in Detroit who now lives in Gaithersburg, Md., obtained the patents between 1967 and 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Second Crash Victim Suspected of Carrying Cocaine
With PM-Jetliner Crash
DOC.TEXT: A man injured in the crash of a Colombian jetliner passed 14 condoms filled with a white powder, becoming at least the second passenger suspected of carrying cocaine in his intestines, police said. A nurse at the Nassau County Medical Center told police Monday that a 46-year-old Colombian had passed four of the packages, said Nassau County Detective Brian McCormack. Early today, Antonio Zuluaga passed 10 more, McCormack said. Authorities said they will test the powder to see whether it is cocaine. On Friday, surgeons trying to stop internal bleeding in another crash victim discovered four condoms containing white powder in the man's intestines, the Drug Enforcement Administration said. The unidentified patient at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset is suspected of being a ``mule,'' or courier, for drug traffickers, said DEA spokeswoman Mary Cooper. The Avianca jet crashed in the woods in Long Island's Cove Neck on Thursday night, killing 73 people. Investigators suspect it had run out of fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Clerk Foils Robber By Purchasing Holdup Guns
DOC.TEXT: When a convenience store clerk found himself looking at the business end of two pistols, he did the sensible thing _ he bought them. A gunman came into the store Friday night, plunked down a can of beer, pulled out the guns and demanded cash. That's when Wazir Jiwi decided to bargain. ``I said, `You don't need two. Why don't you sell me one of them?''' Jiwi said. The robber thought about it for a moment and named his price _ $100. As Jiwi placed the pistol under the counter, he pushed a button automatically locking the door of the store. Then, he bartered for the other gun. ``He didn't want to give it to me. But I figured he needed the money, and I told him I would pay him for it,'' Jiwi said. The robber grabbed the cash, put the other pistol on the counter and headed for the door but couldn't open it. ``He turned to me and asked what was going on. I told him to bring the money back and I would let him go,'' Jiwi said. ``He brought the money back, and I opened the door.'' The robber was still at large this morning, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Feuding Communists Open Key Congress in Bulgaria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with rejection of delay in elections, offer of national unity government; picks up 12th pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist chief Petar Mladenov today said Bulgaria's economy was falling apart and that ousted hard-line ruler Todor Zhivkov was brutal, selfish and stupid. Mladenov told Communist Party congress that their party faced extinction unless it agreed to reforms to promote democracy or stabilize an economy ``in tatters.'' He also hinted he would step down and reiterated a plan for an interim government that included emerging pro-democracy groups. Mladenov said only such a coalition government is ``capable of leading the country out of the crisis.'' But he gave no specifics on what share of power the Communists would retain in such an administration. Opposition leaders and some reform Communists doubted the leadership, which threw out Zhivkov on Nov. 10 after 35 years of uncontested rule, was sincere about genuine change. ``They want to change anything but their chairs _ the name of the party, even their ideals,'' said Lyubomir Pavlov, a senior member of the independent trade union Podkrepa, before the congress. The leadership has promised multiparty democracy with the first free parliamentary elections in more than 40 years in May, although the opposition has wanted it delayed until November to give it more time to organize.
