Many of the 2,790 delegates cheered when Mladenov rejected the opposition calls, insisting they be held ``not later than May.'' Mladenov appeared to try to exploit divisions within the still weak opposition by reiterating calls for a new ``government of national concord'' before the May elections. Some opposition leaders reject this idea outright, arguing that they do not want to be responsible for the chaos caused by four decades of Communist rule, while others have suggested they might participate in such an interim cabinet. Mladenov was at his most forthright in criticizing the rule of Zhivkov, who has been arrested on charges of misappropriation of state property, inciting ethnic hostility and grave abuse of power. He variously described the former leader, under whom he served as foreign minister for 18 years, as ``a maniac,'' ``egoist,'' a ``bearer of a painful suspiciousness and selfishness'' and a man ``without any intellectual capacities.'' Mladenov hinted he may make way for a new party chief when he suggested the congress vote to split the posts of party chief and president, which he assumed when Zhivkov was ousted. ``It's my suggestion that the comrades adopt a decision that the same person should not be leading the party and the state at the same time,'' he said. There had been unconfirmed speculation that Mladenov might stay on as president but give up the party job. In Poland, which blazed the trail of democratic reform in the East bloc, Wojciech Jaruzelski resigned as Communist Party chief before Solidarity took control of the government and now holds the post of president. In the speech, Mladenov made no mention of ongoing talks with the opposition Union of Democratic Forces to put Bulgaria on the road toward democracy. His lack of new proposals confirmed opposition fears that the party leadership, while ready for moderate reforms, must take into account the conservative mainstream of the party in order to maintain power. Despite his remarks on democracy, Mladenov asserted that Bulgaria's Communists, whose power has remained more intact than that of their comrades elsewhere in Eastern Europe, were the only party capable of changing society. With East Germany's Erich Honecker, Zhivkov is one of two deposed East bloc leaders charged with crimes. Ousted Politburo member Milko Balev, a Zhivkov loyalist, and Ivan Slavkov, Zhivkov's son-in-law, were reportedly under investigation for possession of funds they could not explain. Slavkov was also charged with illegal possession of weapons. It was unclear if Slavkov, long the head of the Bulgarian Olympic Committee, and Balev were in custody. This extraordinary party congress was moved up from 1991 to cope with growing threats to Communist power in Bulgaria. Two weeks ago, the Communist-controlled legislature followed Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Czechoslovakia in amending the constitution to strip the Communist Party of its guaranteed leading role in society. In Poland and Hungary, Communist parties that ruled for four decades have dissolved and formed new groupings to distance themselves from their repressive pasts. The Communist parties in East Germany and Czechoslovakia are still intact, though their power is eroding.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Labs Announces Development of Light-Based Computer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT estimate of speed to 1,000 or 10,000, sted 100, and to change name of spokesman. PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `The prototype ...'; Marj in 10th graf cq; version moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Researchers unveiled a prototype computer that uses light instead of electrical impulses to process data and said it could be as revolutionary as the transistor, which ushered in the computer age. The computer that Bell Laboratories displayed Monday is crude, with enough power only to operate something like a dishwasher. Within a decade, however, it could lead to development of light-based supercomputers operating at least 1,000 times faster than current machines, perhaps even 10,000 times, said Brian Monahan, a spokesman for Bell Labs. ``This stage says it can be done,'' said Bob Trier, technical program director for Research Consortium Inc. of Minneapolis, which studies high-performance computing. ``The next stage is to find out what can be done with this technology.'' For years, researchers have been looking at photons, the fundamental particles of light, as replacements for electrons in electronic equipment. Such a shift promises computers vastly more agile and powerful than today's machines. The prototype data processor is the first to transmit information with light rather than electricity, the movement of electrons. The technique could allow a much greater flow of data. ``Your only limit when it comes to those things is the speed of light,'' said Jim Hammons, an analyst at The Sierra Group computer consulting firm in Tempe, Ariz. Unlike current computer chips, information would pass not just from a chip's edges but also from its surface. Bell Labs physicist David Miller likened the development to a Manhattan island in New York City where cars suddenly weren't limited to bridges and tunnels at rush hour, but could leave through the air. By the end of the decade, supercomputers could be using more light, or ``photonic,'' components rather than electronic, and may run at least 1,000 times faster than today's generation, Monahan said. The prototype _ a variety of lasers, lenses and prisms in a 2-foot-square box _ differs from a true computer in that the program that runs the optical processor is built into its hardware rather than being contained in software, said Bell Labs spokeswoman Marj McKean. It also has limited memory, she said. She said the processor originally took up three large lab benches. Eventually, scientists believe it can be reduced to the size of today's microchips, no larger than a fingernail. Transmitting light impulses, as fiber optics do, is nothing new, but controlling them is another thing. ``They have found a way to hold a piece of light,'' said Trier. The photonic computer depends on new chips that pass light impulses between each other through lenses that perform the function of wires, Bell Labs officials said. Officials at American Telephone & Telegraph Co., which owns Bell Labs, likened the development to that of the transistor, which made it possible to make electronic devices smaller, sturdier and more reliable. The transistor was developed at Bell Labs in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Aide: Israel Isn't Urging Soviet Jews to Settle in Occupied Lands
DOC.TEXT: A senior aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir denied today that Israel urged Soviet Jews to settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have been fighting for independence. ``It has not been our policy and will not be in the future. Anyone who comes to Israel can go wherever he chooses,'' said Yossi Ben-Aharon, the head of Shamir's office. Ben-Aharon said better employment opportunities are attracting Soviet immigrants to the center of the country, and that only a few hundred immigrants out of a total of 12,000 last year chose to live on the land captured from Jordan and Egypt in 1967. Ben-Aharon responded to Soviet and U.S. criticism of Shamir's statement earlier this month suggesting Israel has to retain the occupied territoriesto settle the expected wave of Soviet immigrants. In Moscow, a top Soviet Foreign Ministry official summoned Israel's top diplomat, Arye Levin, to ``strongly condemn endangering Soviet emigres by using them to crowd Palestinians out of their own land,'' the Soviet news agency Tass said Monday. The official, First Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Vorontsov, suggested that settling Soviet immigrants in the disputed areas could forestall Moscow's plans to further liberalize emigration laws and allow more Jews to come to Israel. Levin, who flew to Israel today for what he described as a ``family visit,'' told reporters he was not under the impression that the Soviets were threatening to curtail immigration. Another Shamir aide, Avi Pazner, suggested that the Soviets were trying to allay fears by Palestinians and Arab leaders. ``The Arabs are exerting heavy pressure on the Russians concerning the immigration and Mr. Shamir expressed his hope that the artificial storm would pass,'' Pazner said. U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher was quoted by the Jerusalem Post as telling reporters in Washington Monday that ``putting even more settlers into the territories is an obstacle to the cause of peace.'' Israeli legislators and Soviet Jewish activists in Israel have accused Shamir of endangering Jewish immigration at a time of growing concern about anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Yitzhak Abrahmson, head of a Soviet immigrants group, said on Israel Radio he was worried that Shamir's statement about using occupied land for new arrivals would lead to a Soviet clampdown on issuing exit visas. Three left-wing parties have filed no-confidence motions in the Knesset, or Parliament, to protest Shamir's remark. In a related development, the head of a Soviet diplomatic delegation in Israel, Georgi Martirosov, blamed Shamir for the delay in resuming direct flights between the Soviet Union and Israel. Such flights could be a boost to Soviet immigration to Israel because it would channel all Jews leaving Moscow directly to Tel Aviv. In the past, many have stayed in Europe and sought refuge in Western countries. Chances of implementing such an agreement are ``zero'' and Shamir's statements ``hindered any possibility of moving this process forward,'' Martirosov was quoted as saying by the Jerusalem Post. Moscow broke diplomatic ties with Israel over its occupation of Arab territory in the 1967 Middle East war. It supports Palestinian demands for an independent state in the occupied lands and says the restoration of full ties with Israel is conditional on progress in Middle East peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: White House Pushes ``Managed Care'' to Lower Health Costs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, We are, to CORRECT Moley's title
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a soaring federal health care bill, the Bush administration is proposing incentives in its new budget to encourage lower-cost and preventive care. The incentives would be built into the Medicare and Medicaid health insurance programs to help stem spiraling cost increases that have driven combined spending in the two programs to $148 billion this year. The budget would encourage ``managed care'' _ that is, health maintenance organizations and physicians' networks that treat patients under a single, comprehensive organization designed to save costs. ``We are bullish on managed care,'' Kevin Moley, assistant secretary for management and budget at the Department of Health and Human Services, said Monday. Under President Bush's proposed fiscal 1991 budget, spending for Medicare and Medicaid would increase to $110.5 billion for Medicare and $45 billion for Medicaid. But spending growth in the programs would be trimmed by about $5.5 billion from what they would otherwise spend without changes in the programs. Growth would be stemmed by paring payments to hospitals and physicians. For both the Medicare and Medicaid programs, the administration wants to encourage managed care plans as alternatives to the traditional fee-for-service health care delivery systems. Government health economists say HMOs and preferred provider organizations, called PPOs, put more emphasis on preventive care and are more efficient than traditional systems. The administration is proposing financial incentives for states to enroll Medicaid recipients in HMOs. In the Medicare program, the administration wants to encourage managed care by increasing the payment threshold for certain approved HMOs from 95 percent of the cost of care to 100 percent. That would add about $180 million to the Medicare budget next year, but would eventually reap benefits if more Medicare recipients chose HMOs, which also protect against the financial devastation of catastrophic illnesses. This proposal would reduce premiums for enrollees, but HHS officials said they did not know by how much. Another proposal, called Medicare Plus, is being worked out to help develop a market for PPOs by coordinating Medigap insurance policies with these provider networks. As envisioned, the government would put its seal of approval on PPOs that meet specified standards for comprehensiveness and quality of care. Medicare will serve 31.4 million elderly and 3.3 million disabled Americans in the 1991 fiscal year, according to HHS figures. The Medicaid program, a federal and state effort, covers about 26 million of the nation's poor. The Bush administration also proposed increasing AIDS spending for research, prevention and education by about 7 percent to $1.7 billion. Total AIDS spending by HHS and other federal agencies _ including Medicare and Medicaid payments to AIDS patients _ would rise 18 percent to nearly $3.5 billion. The National Organizations Responding to AIDS denounced the increase in research and prevention efforts as ``woefully insufficient, particularly in the face of the doubling caseload this nation will be experiencing during the next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Stabs Fiance in Super Bowl TV Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A woman was sentenced to 10 months in jail for stabbing her fiance in the neck with a barbecue fork after he switched channels on her to watch the Super Bowl. ``You were almost a football widow,'' Judge Ted Poe told Viola Delores Douglas, 37, after she pleaded guilty Monday to misdemeanor assault. As Ms. Douglas explained it, she was watching a Disney movie Sunday when Eddie Harris, an asphalt firm worker, returned to the apartment they share and switched to the Super Bowl. Ms. Douglas attacked Harris with a knife, but he disarmed her and escaped injury, prosecutor Don Rizzo said. Not long after, she told police, she returned to the room and discovered that Harris was ignoring the game. An infuriated Ms. Douglas stabbed him, prosecutors said. Harris required a few stitches to close the wound. The unemployed nurse could be eligible for release after about five months.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Deposted 40 Tons of Gold in Swiss Account, Ex-Policeman Says
DOC.TEXT: A former policeman said he helped escort 40 tons of gold to Switzerland so it could be deposited in Nicolae Ceausescu's bank account, the state news agency said today. The official Rompress news agency quoted an unidentified former police official who said he was on a September 1980 flight that carried 25 tons of gold ingots and an October 1980 flight that carried 15 tons. The gold, escorted by security officers and finance ministry officials, was loaded in trucks in Zurich in the presence of Romanian diplomats, the police official reportedly said. He estimated that Ceausescu had deposited about $400 million in gold in Swiss banks, but other sources put the figure at $1 billion dollars, Rompress said. Ceausescu was toppled by a violent uprising in December and executed on Dec. 25 after 24 years in power. There have been numerous reports that he and his family lived in excessive luxury while Romanians endured poverty and oppression. The daily Romania Libera called on former Ceausescu aides who took part in alleged smuggling of gold or Western cash to help the new authorities recover ``the tremendous values transferred abroad'' by the former dictator. Swiss lawmakers have pledged to help in tracing hundreds of millions of dollars that Ceausescu reportedly hid in Swiss or other foeign banks, but said there was not yet proof of any momey had been transferred to Switzerland. Henrich Rittmeyer, a Swiss lawmaker who visited Bucharest in mid-January, said the process of finding Ceausescu's missing millions could be difficult. ``It's extremely difficult,'' he told a news conference Jan. 14. ``The Romanian government and Romanian bank representatives don't know yet how much money is missing.'' He added that if Ceausescu had smuggled a fortune out of Romania, it was ``probable'' some of it could be found in Swiss accounts, but said the process could take years.

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Tear Gas, Rubber Bullets To Break Up Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with 45 arrested, marchers later allowed to demonstrate; picks up 8th pvs, `Activists have...'
DOC.HEAD: By JOHN PARKIN
DOC.TEXT: Police fired rubber bullets and tear gas today to prevent more than 1,000 blacks from protesting an English cricket team that broke an international boycott, witnesses said. Obed Nkosi, an organizer for the anti-apartheid National Sports Council, claimed 30 people were hurt in the black township of Mangaung outside the central city of Bloemfontein. Police said 45 people were arrested and one white businessman was slightly injured when his vehicle was stoned by protesters. The demonstrators sought to march from Mangaung to the sports stadium in Bloemfontein, where the British squad was facing South African university players. But police roadblocks prevented the activists from leaving the township, and some of the youths began throwing stones at authorities and setting up barricades of burning tires, witnesses said. Police responded with tear gas, rubber bullets and baton charges, the witnesses added. ``The situation is very tense,'' Nkosi said. The managing director of the South African Cricket Union, Ali Bacher, later obtained permission from a magistrate so demonstrators could march outside the stadium. About 200 did so without incident. Bacher, who arranged the English tour, has said that demonstrators should be allowed to protest peacefully outside the stadiums while the matches are in progress. Activists have been staging protests since the Jan. 19 arrival of the English squad, which is on a six-week tour of South Africa. The team is defying a ban on sporting links with South Africa, imposed to protest the country's apartheid policies of racial segregation. The English team, led by Mike Gatting, began its second three-day match Tuesday. The hundreds of police at the stadium outnumbered spectators when the match began. The English players face expulsion from international cricket for five years for taking part in the tour. According to news reports, they are receiving $160,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: Report: De Klerk To Ease Emergency, Lift Media Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-9, `In the...' with four grafs to UPDATE with arrests, second demonstration; picks up 10th pvs, `Police Gen....'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa-Change, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A pro-government newspaper today said President F.W. de Klerk plans to ease the 43-month-old state of emergency and lift restrictions on the media. The Citizen newspaper said de Klerk will announce the changes Friday at an address before Parliament but he is not expected to release jailed black leader Nelson Mandela until mid-February at the earliest. There has been an surge in political unrest recently, and the government is concerned that freeing Mandela could set off violence among the disenfranchised black majority. The Citizen, which has good contacts within the government, said the immediate release of Mandela also would distract attention from de Klerk's speech to Parliament, when he is expected to outline his plans for reform. The newspaper said the president is likely to remove press restrictions that are part of the wide-ranging emergency measures in effect since June 1986. The media curbs, which have not been widely enforced, prohibit reporting on unrest and some forms of protest. However, de Klerk will maintain some of the emergency security measures to quell unrest, the newspaper said. In the latest incident, police today fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse about 1,000 black demonstrators, some of whom threw stones and erected barricades of burning tires in the Mangaung township near the central city of Bloemfontein. Police reported 45 arrests. The blacks were seeking to leave the township and march on a sports stadium where an English cricket team was playing in defiance of a ban on sports contacts with South Africa. An activist said 30 of the demonstrators were hurt, but witnesses said they saw no serious injuries or mass arrests. Police also used tear gas Tuesday to disperse 150 black squatters protesting their eviction from the ''whites-only'' neighborhood of Kraaifontein outside Cape Town. No arrests or injuries were reported. Police Gen. Herman Stadler said the recent increase in unrest was a result of the government's more relaxed attitude toward political dissent. ``There is a wave of unrest at the moment,'' Stadler said. ``Expectations are created, and people are inclined to come to the fore and apply pressure.'' Anti-apartheid activists have planned demonstrations in Cape Town to coincide with the opening of Parliament and de Klerk's speech. Police have advised citizens to stay away from downtown Cape Town, saying they may have to take action against the demonstrators. The government has allowed peaceful protest since September by marchers who have acquired permission in advance from a magistrate. However, the activists in Cape Town have refused to apply. Organizers say they will demand the immediate release of Mandela, the country's best known black leader. He has been imprisoned since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. South African media have been awash in speculation on when Mandela might be released and the issue is dominating political life. Mandela is a leader of the African National Congress guerrilla movement, the largest black group fighting the white-led government. On Monday night, Defense Minister Magnus Malan said he government will reduce the mandatory sentences of white men convicted of refusing compulsory military service from six years to as few as three years. Malan said the decision was in keeping with the recent decision to cut compulsory military service for white men from two years to one year. Military service by blacks is voluntary.

DOC.HEAD: Maker of `Roger and Me' Gets Cheers, Jeers in Hometown
DOC.TEXT: Phil Donahue came to town to tape a segment about the movie ``Roger & Me'' and came away with enough praise and criticism to fill two shows. The satirical movie by Michael Moore depicts Flint's decline after General Motors Corp. laid off 30,000 workers. An overwhelmingly pro-Moore crowd of about 2,000 showed up at the ``Donahue'' taping Monday at a city auditorium, and so many people wanted to speak that the talk show host decided to spread the tape over two shows. Some cities got the first show live Monday. The second segment was made available in some cities today. ``There's a minority of people in this town that's very upset the film was made. And they're not the people standing in the cheese line,'' said Moore, a Flint native. A few in the audience said Moore's movie made Flint look worse than it is. ``You showed the slummiest areas,'' one woman said. GM, still Flint's biggest employer, was not represented at the taping. The automaker sent Donahue a statement saying the movie was unfair and inaccurate.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Leaves Open Question of Unification, But Urges Caution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with quotes from Modrow, background on Soviet position on reunification, details; no pickup. ^By MARK J. PORUBCANSKY
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany today and appeared less resistant to eventual Germany reunification, saying the matter remains open to debate. Speaking to reporters at a news conference after their meeting, Modrow said Gorbachev ``did not rule out such a prospect in the future, and at the same time did not venture to set some time limits for that.'' Earlier, Gorbachev told reporters that any decisions must include the four Allied powers and take into account European opinions. ``The development of events in the world, in East Germany, in the Soviet Union demand deep consideration and an analytical approach to deciding this problem,'' he said. ``Time itself is acting on this process, giving it dynamism,'' the Soviet leader said. ``We have to act responsibly, and not decide this important question on the streets.'' His remarks were reported by the Tass news agency. Asked by an East German TV correspondent about his attitude toward reunification, Gorbachev said the question was not unexpected and that ``no one can cast doubt'' on the reasonableness of asking it, Tass reported. However, the English-language Tass translation raised questions whether Gorbachev meant that there could be no doubts about reunification. The Soviet Union in past years has strongly opposed any talk of German reunification, but has mellowed somewhat as Gorbachev remolds foreign policy and democratic change sweeps Eastern Europe. Soviets now say that the question of German reunification is one to be decided in the future. Gorbachev, in comments to reporters after meeting French President Francois Mitterrand in Kiev in December, reiterated his view that the existence of two German states is a fact based on the outcome of World War II. But he added, ``The present situation is the result of specific historical events, a specific historical process on this continent. So, history should should decide the future of this continent.'' He urged against rushing with a decision on reunification. ``I don't think it is a topical question today. A different approach may create a situation that would complicate the entire European process, including the relations between the two German states,'' Gorbachev said at the time. Modrow said the two German states could work in a series of stages toward a form of confederation, with no time limit set on it. He said he agreed with Gorbachev that the question of reunification is not only one that must be decided by East and West Germany, but by all of Europe. ``It's difficult to set some time limit, because it must be supported by the European people, and that must be in line with the treaty on the development of the confederation with all its substance and implications,'' Modrow said. ``In light of that concept, the European nations will probably understand it in the following way ... we must be very cautious about the process,'' he added. According to the Tass report, the Soviet leader added that any action taken on Germany reunification must not infringe on the interests of either East or West Germany, the four Allied powers: France, Britain, the United States or the Soviet Union, or anyone else in Europe. Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze joined Gorbachev for the meeting with Modrow, who arrived in Moscow on a one-day visit late Monday. Modrow arrived after a stormy session of parliament in which the East Germany prosecutor announced that former hard-line leader Erich Honnecker will go on trial in March for treason. Modrow, a Communist, also has moved forward the country's first free elections from May to March 18 and brought the opposition into a coalition that will govern until then.

DOC.HEAD: Cripple Creek Votes for Legalized Gambling
DOC.TEXT: Cripple Creek has become the third historic Colorado mining town to back gambling to encourage year-round tourism. Legalized gambling still would require an amendment to the state constitution. Cripple Creek residents voted 152-38 over the weekend in favor of gambling to support historic preservation and make other improvements. The twin mountain towns of Black Hawk and Central City, 40 miles west of Denver, also want gambling. All three towns would limit gambling licenses to their historic districts, limit dollar amounts and restrict gambling to slot machines, poker and blackjack. Two state legislators have said they will introduce a resolution to put the proposed constitutional amendment on the November ballot. But as now written, the resolution would allow gambling only in Central City and Black Hawk. By 1904, some 14 years after gold was first found in the area, the 24-square-mile Cripple Creek-Victor Mining District had 100,000 people and 200 bars, saloons and gambling parlors. Today there are about 15 bars, and the winter population is less than 1 percent of the boom days total. Most businesses close in the winter after a summer rush of about 200,000 people. ``We are dying on the grapevine. It gets dark every night and we twiddle out thumbs'' while people take their money to Deadwood, S.D., which began legalized gambling last year, said Black Hawk Mayor Wilhelm Lorenz.

DOC.HEAD: Man Said to Witness Barry Cocaine Use Pleads Guilty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs new to shorten lead and include when alleged incident occurred; picks up at pvs 3rd graf, McWilliams and
DOC.TEXT: A man who law enforcement sources said could corroborate testimony that Mayor Marion Barry bought and smoked crack cocaine pleaded guilty today to a drug-related charge. James McWilliams pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of aiding and abetting drug possession before U.S. Magistrate Deborah A. Robinson. The crime carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $100,000 fine. McWilliams has been described as a longtime friend of Charles Lewis, a convicted drug dealer who has testified that he sold crack to Barry and smoked it with him in December 1988. McWilliams and his attorney, Daniel Masur, declined to comment on the plea. They were immediately taken by deputy U.S. marshals to a grand jury meeting room. Barry, who has denied using drugs, was arrested in an FBI sting operation on Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge for allegedly smoking crack in a Washington hotel room. He is in a private facility in Florida for what an aide says is primarily treatment of alcoholism. McWilliams, a motor vehicles department employee, is expected to appear before a grand jury investigating Barry's ties to Lewis, according to a law enforcement source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. McWilliams has told prosecutors he saw Barry and Lewis enter the bathroom of Lewis' hotel room, where they allegedly smoked crack cocaine before emerging a short time later, said a law enforcement source. Allegations that Barry used cocaine in the past were also supported by Carol Bland Jackson, a former business partner of the woman who lured Barry into the FBI sting. She said in interviews Monday that she and others used cocaine with Barry at a party in 1986. Lewis pleaded guilty in the nation's capital to cocaine conspiracy charges last November and was convicted on cocaine distribution charges in the Virgin Islands last spring. In meetings with prosecutors in the past week, McWilliams also said the mayor called him after Barry's ties to Lewis became public and told him he trusted him to keep quiet about what he had seen in the hotel room, two law enforcement sources said. Barry has said he only called McWilliams to urge him to cooperate with authorities investigating the case. Sources have said that in addition to McWilliams, members of Barry's police security detail are expected to appear before the grand jury investigating the mayor. The police officers _ who are assigned to the mayor on a round-the-clock basis _ are expected to be asked whether they saw Barry use drugs during his visits to Lewis' hotel room or on other occasions, according to a law enforcement source familiar with the case. R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's attorney, said he was unaware of any deal McWilliams may have struck with prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Kidnapping Victim Found Slain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with cause of death; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Police said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A boy whose kidnappers cut off his finger to persuade his drug-dealing older brother to pay up to $500,000 ransom was found dead wrapped in trash bags, two weeks after the brother was discovered slain, police said. The body of 12-year-old William Porter was found in 14 layers of black plastic bags Sunday by a man collecting cans on a bike path in the Bronx. The boy was killed by a blow to the head, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. The death was classified a homicide, she said. Police said Monday they believe the boy was kidnapped Dec. 5 in an attempt to extort money from his older brother, reputed drug dealer Richard Thomas Porter, who was found shot to death Jan. 4 in the same area. Detectives speculated at the time that the elder Porter, who had refused to cooperate with the police investigation, may have been trying to obtain the boy's release on his own. William's 25-year-old brother was reputed to control several street dealers in Harlem. He was found shot in the head and chest. His wallet, with more than $2,000 in it, was found on his body. The kidnappers demanded up to $500,000 for the youngster's return in a series of telephone calls, notes and a taped message from the boy on Dec. 5 and 6. A police source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said one of the ransom demands included William's severed right index finger and a short taped message, which were left in a coffee cup in a restaurant bathroom. ``They cutted my finger off,'' the sixth-grader cried on the tape, according to police. ``Please help. ... I love you, mommy.'' The last contact with the kidnappers occurred Dec. 10, when a woman handed a note to a child to deliver it to William's aunt, who lived in the area. The note said the boy was in pain and needed medical attention, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Says Ship Carrying 19 Sunk in Storm
DOC.TEXT: A Greek-registered ship carrying 19 crew members and a load of cement apparently sank in a storm in the English Channel, the coast guard said today. The coast guard said two lifeboats and a life raft from the ship Flag Theofano and two bodies washed ashore on England's south coast. One body was identified as a Greek crew member. The coast guard said the vessel left Le Havre, France, on Monday afternoon for Southampton with its crew of 11 Greeks, seven Maldivians and one Egyptian. The last contact with the ship was at 7:35 p.m. Monday, the coast guard said, and no mayday call was received. A Royal Navy diver searched the water five miles south of Portsmouth where the coast guard said an oil slick, air bubbles and a rope attached to something below the water's surface were found. ``We put a diver down, but from 6 meters (19 feet) he couldn't see his hand in front of his face,'' said a coast guard spokesman, who was not further identified in keeping with British custom. Divers were waiting for the weather to improve to begin their search for the 324-foot-long, 1,184-ton ship. Nick Palmer, a spokesman for the ship's agents, Wainwright and Brothers, said the ship sailed despite poor forecasts. ``The cargo was urgently needed and for that reason the captain decided to sail for Southampton,'' Palmer said. ``If a full-scale search cannot find a ship that big, there is not much hope.'' A spokesman for Lloyd's of London insurance market said the ship was built in 1970 and is owned by Seawave Compania Nanera, a Greek company.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Rates Highest Since October
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level since October. The Treasury Department sold $7.7 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.77 percent, up from 7.66 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.73 percent, up from 7.58 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.78 percent on Oct. 30, 1989, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent on Oct. 2, 1989. Three-month bills also sold for 7.77 percent on Dec. 26, 1989. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.04 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,803.60 and 8.16 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,609.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.01 percent last week from 7.97 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Who Ya Gonna Call? City Puts Up No-Weddings Sign
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: New Yorkers are used to being told what they can't do in public spaces: No parking. No dogs. No smoking. No spitting. No left turn. But no weddings? That's what a sign on an East River pier seems to indicate, but a spokesman for the Department of Ports and Trades wants lovers to know the city is not getting into the wedding-busting business. The sign, using the international symbol for prohibition, has a bride and groom inside a circle with a slash through it. ``It's a funky sign and we made it in a fun way,'' department spokesman Frances Resheske said today. ``We didn't mean to imply that weddings are prohibited, just that people are not allowed to close off the pier to the public.'' Resheske said many couples holding receptions at an adjacent restaurant in the borough of Queens were led to believe they could hold private ceremonies on the pier. The pier has an unobstructed view of the Manhattan skyline and has become a popular pedestrian walkway for local residents _ and a wedding hot spot. ``We were getting complaints that it was being closed many Saturdays and Sundays in the summer,'' said Resheske. ``We're not anti-weddings. If someone wanted to go out tomorrow with a judge and get married on the pier, fine. ... You just can't close it off.'' Violators can be fined up to $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Berry Named to Head Administration on Aging
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he will nominate Joyce T. Berry, the acting commissioner on aging, to permanent appointment to the post. Dr. Berry is a career federal worker who has been a top official of the Administration on Aging since 1980 and acting commissioner since last year following the departure of Carol Fraser Fisk. Berry, 42, is a graduate of Howard University with a Ph.D. from Fordham University and a law degree from Georgetown. The Administration on Aging is a branch of the Department of Health and Human Services. It administers social service programs for the elderly.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Bomb Link Brings Heavy Security as Murder Trial Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with jury selection delayed; PICKS UP 5th graf, `A letter ...'
DOC.HEAD: With Bombs-Two Cities, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Security was tight today at the opening of the trial of a black man accused of murdering a white teacher _ a case linked to the mail-bomb slayings of a judge and a lawyer. Extra guards were called in and spectators arriving for the trial of Emmanuel Fitzgerald Hammond had to pass through metal detectors in the lobby and at the courtroom entrance. Guards also searched purses and brief cases. Hammond is charged with murder, kidnapping and armed robbery in the shotgun slaying of preschool teacher Julie Love. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. Security was heavy because of the attention given to the year-long search for the victim, whose body was found last summer, and because of a letter claiming a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer were ``assassinated'' in retaliation for Love's death. ``I don't think we've had any threats,'' said sheriff's Capt. J.C. Booker. ``This is just a precaution.'' Superior Court Judge Ralph Hicks this morning delayed the start of jury selection at the request of prosecutors, who asked defense attorney William A. Wehunt to reveal whether he plans an insanity defense. Wehunt said he had not been able to talk to psychologists who examined Hammond to determine ``how extensive the use of drugs has affected this man's mental powers.'' Hicks granted a recess so that Wehunt could contact the doctors. A letter signed by ``Americans For a Competent Federal Judicial System'' last month claimed responsibility for bombs that killed U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala., and attorney Robert Robinson in Savannah, Ga. The letter, which became the focus of the FBI's investigation into the December mail bombings, expressed rage over Ms. Love's slaying, saying it demonstrated the writer's contention that the judicial system lets black men get away with crimes against white women. Even before the mail bomb case became linked with Ms. Love's slaying, the Atlanta woman's death had been one of the area's highest-profile crimes. Police said Ms. Love, 27, was abducted by two men on an Atlanta road the night of July 11, 1988. Her abandoned car was found three days later in the city's fashionable Buckhead neighborhood. More than a year later, after a nationally publicized search in which ``Have You Seen Julie Love?'' posters and billboards were plastered across the city, her remains were found last August in a trash-strewn, wooded area in Atlanta. Hours before Ms. Love's remains were found, police charged Hammond and his 20-year-old cousin, William Porter, with her slaying. In November, Porter pleaded guilty to felony murder, rape, kidnapping and armed robbery. He has not been sentenced and is expected to testify against Hammond. Police said Hammond shot Ms. Love in the head with a shotgun.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Democracy Will Prevail in Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 3rd graf, Quayle later, with 2 grafs to update with briefing to Bush
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, home from a three-nation trip, is proclaiming a bright future for Panama even as some nations in the region refuse to recognize its U.S.-installed government. Jamaica underscored its refusal Monday on the last stop of Quayle's three-day trip. Quayle today briefed President Bush on his visits to Honduras, Panama and Jamaica, and gave him ``a number of ideas on pushing U.S. policy forward'' in the region, said the vice president's press secretary, David Beckwith. Quayle said earlier he also gave Bush a ``very upbeat'' verbal report on his trip during a telephone call en route home from Jamaica Monday night. However, the vice president acknowledged that while the United States is pressing for other Central American countries to recognize the government of President Guillermo Endara, Jamaica and Venezuela are insisting that elections be held there to legitimize Endara first. ``As far as we're concerned he's legitimized now,'' Quayle told reporters flying home with him from Kingston. The election last May 7, which observers said Endara won but which was invalidated by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, ``was a free and fair election,'' he added. However, Quayle today raised the possibility that balloting on other offices and issues before Endara's term expires in 1994 could satisfy the demands of Latin American leaders for an election. ``There are approximately six to nine seats in the National Assembly that will not have a member because they couldn't certify who won, so they have to have have elections there,'' he said on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America.'' ``Two, the constitution will have to be amended. ... primarily because of the changes President Endara wants to do in the PDF (Panamanian Defense Force), and therefore there is a possibility that perhaps the amendments to the constitution could be offered as a plebiscite. That would constitute an election,'' Quayle added. As he left Panama, Quayle praised Endara's plans to build a national police force in place of an army, to develop a free-market economy and to help crack down on laundering of drug money. Quayle predicted other countries in the region would recognize Endara's government. ``I come away ... with a deep feeling of optimism about the future of Panama. I'm optimistic that democracy will be developed and will prevail,'' he said. ``I'm optimistic that other Latin American countries will join in helping the Endara government.'' Later Monday, Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley said Jamaica is not ready to recognize Endara's government. ``What we do about the Endara government will largely be determined by the speed with which normality is restored, and whether we feel some process is embarked upon that would ... demonstrate legitimacy by some sort of expression of the people's will in a vote,'' Manley said during a press conference with Quayle. Manley also said he still objects to the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama, although he understood why Bush undertook it. Quayle ran into similar sentiments in his talks with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, whom he saw at the presidential inauguration Saturday in Honduras, and spoke with again by telephone from Air Force Two on Monday. Quayle was tasked by Bush with smoothing over the negative feelings aroused throughout the region when Bush sent invasion troops to Panama. Like Jamaica, most of the Latin nations felt the invasion was a violation of Panama's sovereignty. Quayle acknowledged his visit had not reversed those sentiments. But he stressed the significance of his talks was that the other countries would look ahead, not backward. ``Yes, friends have a disagreement on the decision itself,'' he said. ``But as friends we are committed to moving forward, and we're going to move the process forward. That's the most important thing.'' Besides holding talks with Endara and Manley, Quayle met with the presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador, Belize, Costa Rica, Honduras and Venezuela when all attended the Honduran inauguration. Concerns about potential cuts in U.S. economic assistance were a common theme. Manley said his government believed it stood to lose $25 million in economic support funds, but that Quayle indicated he was ``certainly sympathetic toward the problem.'' Quayle promised the $25 million _ part of $124 million overall in U.S. aid to Jamaica last year _ would not be completely slashed. But he refused to say how much Jamaica might lose. He said the administration wants Congress to give Bush more flexibility to free up the foreign aid money, which is now mostly earmarked for a handful of countries with a comparatively small sum left over to be divided among the remaining beneficiaries in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Embrace Reunification; Honecker May go Free
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with prosecution losing appeal to keep Honecker in jail; picks up 6th pvs: The Communists . ..
DOC.TEXT: The embattled Communist leadership made a desperate pitch to win voter support today by endorsing for the first time the idea of eventual reunification with West Germany. Meanwhile, an East Berlin court rejected the Communist-dominated government's request to keep its ousted leader, Erich Honecker, behind bars until his treason trial in March. The chief prosecutor's office appealed Monday's decision by an East Berlin court to the East German magistrate's office, but the appeal was denied, said prosecutor's office spokesman Dieter Plath. Honecker, who was arrested and jailed earlier Monday, was expected to be freed later today. The reasons for the East Berlin court's refusal to issue the necessary warrants to keep Honecker in jail were unclear. The Communists' fervor in prosecuting past leaders and embracing popular causes comes amid a worsening economy, a continued flood of emigration to the West and a surge in protests. The government has moved up elections from May to March 18 to placate the nine opposition groups, whose frequently conflicting demands and views encompass a broad political spectrum. It also will overhaul the current interim Cabinet to include opposition members. The party, trying to win some support so it can gain a foothold in a new elected government, for the first time today acknowledged German unity as a long-term goal, but said it must be part of the process of overcoming Europe's overall divisions. Andre Brie, a leading ideologist for the reformed party, said German unity ``must not occur as fast as possible, but as slowly as is required.'' He said there must remain two German states for some time to ensure European stability. Brie and Jochen Willerding, another leading party official, unveiled a document in which the party, as part of its campaign for elections, calls for a united, free and demilitarized Europe. Willerding also announced the party leadership would meet on Sunday and likely change the party's name. Willerding said his party would rename itself simply Party of Democratic Socialism, following the lead of the Polish and Hungarian parties that are trying to remodel themselves into social democratic organizations. Honecker, who ruled East Germany for 18 years before his ouster after the pro-democracy revolt in October, is one of a dozen former Communist Party Politburo members facing charges of corruption and abuse of office. Honecker was arrested on Monday as he left an East Berlin hospital where he had undergone surgery to remove a malignant kidney tumor. He was taken to the capital's Rummelsburg prison. The disgraced former leader is to be tried in March on a charge of high treason, prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph announced to Parliament on Monday. Doctors who treated Honecker at Charite hospital contended he was still too ill to be jailed. Honecker, who ruled East Germany for 18 years before his ouster in last fall's peaceful pro-democracy revolt, is one of a dozen former Communist Party Politburo members facing charges of corruption and abuse of office. He is accused of leading the nation to the brink of economic collapse through mismanagement and misuse of office for personal enrichment. If convicted, he could spend the rest of his life in prison. Prosecuting the figures of the past has taken a back seat to dealing with the crises of the present, however. At Monday's a parliamentary session, embattled Communist Premier Hans Modrow offered a grim account of the state of the nation. Economic failures and widespread unrest forced Modrow to move up East Germany's first-ever free elections by two months to March 18 and to draw opposition forces into a coalition to rule in the meantime. More than 100,000 people demonstrated in several East German cities Monday night, many of them calling for defeat of the Communists in the elections. Others renewed demands for German reunification. Today, Modrow was in Moscow for a meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and reporters asked the Soviet leader about his attitude toward reunification. Gorbachev said the subject has a place in discussions of Europe's future, but: ``We have to act responsibly, and not decide this important question on the streets.'' Modrow told Parliament that strikes, protests, and the mass flight of people to the West has endangered the existence of the country. Under a coalition plan agreed to late Sunday, each of the nine opposition groups that have been taking part in the weekly negotiations will name a minister without portfolio to join Modrow's 27-member Cabinet. The premier said the restructuring was needed ``to create a government of national responsibility in this fateful situation.'' A new Cabinet is to be announced Wednesday, and a special session of Parliament will be called to approve the changes.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Africans Not to be Discouraged by Poverty
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II capped his visit to this West African nation today by telling 20,000 people at an open-air Mass not to despair in their poverty. His face reddened from the sun and heat during six days of touring sub-Saharan Africa, the Roman Catholic leader smiled as dancers swayed on the altar. A female chorus sang hymns in the Djula language to the beat of drums wrapped in animal skins. ``You are working for the development of your country,'' the pope said from the altar set up in front of the town's train station. ``I appeal with passion to the world to be in solidarity with you who suffer the weight of poverty. I also urge you not to get discouraged .... You are often poor in material goods but rich in generosity,'' Pope John Paul also urged the nation's Roman Catholics, who comprise about 10 percent of the 8.5 million people, to collaborate with Moslems, Protestants and animists in building up their country. ``I encourage you to pursue interreligious dialogue with clarity and friendship,'' he said in a homily delivered in French, an official language of the former French colony. He spoke held the Mass in Bobo Dioulasso, Burkina Faso's second-largest town, in the southwest of the country near the Ivorian border. The Mass was the pope's last activity before departing for Chad, the last leg of his eight-day tour of five sub-Saharan Sahel nations.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Blame New Gov't For Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafst to UPDATE with new law guaranteeing access to media; picks up 4th pvs, `The bill...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the two largest opposition parties today accused Romania's new government of engineering attacks by thousands of people on their headquarters. The broadcasting chief today resigned as chief spokesman of the governing National Salvation Front following charges that it was using the media to control the opposition. Also today, the front published the draft of a proposed law guaranteeing free direct elections for Parliament and president, as well as access to the media, an apparent concession to the burgeoning opposition. Under the proposed election law, the two houses of Parliament would have both elected members and appointed members, including representatives of the military. The bill was debated in a weekend meeting of leaders from Romania's more than 20 political parties, some new and some revamped since the December revolution toppled the 24-year dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. Radio Bucharest said that similar consultations will take place weekly. A series of demonstrations has taken place since the front, which took over as an interim government following the popular revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December, announced it would take part in elections in May. On Monday, about 15,000 supporters of the revolutionary government rallied in the capital, breaking into the headquarters of the Liberal Party and forcing the leader of the National Peasants' Party to flee his party's offices in an armored personnel carrier. Constantin Teodorescu, a Liberal leader, accused the front of trying to destroy the opposition parties and planning to install a new Communist dictatorship if it wins power in the elections. ``We already have a dictatorship of the Communist Party'' under the front government, he said. In the aftermath of the attack on his own headquarters, Peasant Party Vice President Virgil Lambru refused to blame the front. ``We can't say that because that would mean a war'' with the front, he said. However, Peasant Party official Ion Ratiu laid the blame on the government. Monday's well-organized demonstrations _ many participants were workers who arrived in the city center in government-owned trucks and buses _ showed that the people who took charge when Ceausescu was overthrown last month are capable of mobilizing considerable support. But government critics said the way workers turned out to back the government smacked of the time-worn tactics of the East bloc's deposed Communist regimes. One month after Romanians toppled Eastern Europe's most hard-line Communist regime in a bloody revolution, political stability seems far off. The resignation of Aurel Dragos Munteanu from the front came four days after interim Vice President Dumitru Mazilu stepped down and accused the front of using ``Stalinist methods.'' Munteanu, head of the broadcast media that played a major role in fueling the revolution, was one of the most visible figures of the front, acting as spokesman at news conferences, although he was not on the front's unelected 11-man governing council. Munteanu's resignation was announced late Monday night on state TV. The only reason given was the need for objectivity in broadcast reporting. There was no indication whether Munteanu's move was a face-saving tactical maneuver by the front, or whether it would lead to a more equitable distribution of broadcasting time among political parties. The front has so far refused to relinquish its monopoly over broadcasting, despite protests from opposition parties that they have no way of getting their political message across to the electorate. Testimony today continued against four of Ceausescu's top associates during the third day of their trial before a military tribunal on charges of complicity to commit genocide. The four _ former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, former Central Committee Secretary Emil Bobu and former Politburo members Manea Manescu and Ion Dinca _ have pleaded guilty to the charge, which stems from the shooting of demonstrators in December that sparked the uprising. The state Rompres news agency reported that after the military prosecutor and the defense counsel requested new evidence, the trial was adjourned until Thursday. The defendants face a maximum penalty of life in prison. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were convicted of the charge and executed Dec. 25. The new government later abolished capital punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Stride Rite Turns Down Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: Stride Rite Corp., the nation's No. 1 children's shoe company with such brands as Keds and Sperry Top-Sider, said today it has rejected a $900 million takeover bid from a group of investors. Chairman Arnold Hiatt said in a statement that the board determined ``a successful, independent Stride Rite is in the best long-term interests of Stride Rite's shareholders, employees, customers and the communities we serve.'' Stride Rite, which makes and sells shoes and has more than 180 stores and over 60 sections in department stores, received the $32-per-share offer in December from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Co. of Greenwich, Conn. Stephen Walsh, managing general partner of the firm, said his associates would review Stride Rite's response before announcing their next move. Stride Rite announced today it had record sales and earnings for the year that ended Dec. 1. Net income was $45.6 million, or $1.69 per share, compared with earnings of $31.7 million, or $1.16 per share, the previous year. Sales increased 20 percent from $378.7 million in 1988 to $454.3 million. Hiatt said Keds were a major factor in the company's results, with sales 43 percent higher than they were in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: New Jet is a Little Too Jumbo
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s new jumbo jet may need to diet. The MD-11 passenger jet began flight tests this month, six months behind schedule. It is at least 4,000 pounds over its target weight of 290,000 pounds, McDonnell Douglas Vice President Louis Harrington said. The extra tonnage could cut the weight the $90 million plane is capable of carrying or the distance it can fly without refueling. Harrington said the company is not in violation of any contract specifications with customers for the MD-11's range or payload. But the company will still try to drop some weight from the stretched and updated version of its DC-10. ``Many aircraft have failed in history because they were overweight,'' said Richard Kaplan, an aeronautics expert and professor at the University of Southern California. ``Profit margins for airlines are rather slim.''

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Pitches Payroll Tax Cut to Senior Citizens Group
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan told the nation's largest senior citizens group today his plan to cut Social Security taxes poses no risk of benefit cuts and would help keep the system financially sound. Reducing the payroll tax to stop the government from using surplus Social Security revenues for other purposes would help ensure public confidence in the system, Moynihan told the American Association of Retired Persons. ``There would be no risk to benefits at any time,'' the New York Democrat said. ``We are having the system perform just as it was originally intended to do.'' The Bush administration has said Moynihan's plan eventually would lead to benefit cuts. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady today called the proposal ``goofy'' and ``the height of folly.'' Brady said Americans have faith in the Social Security system as it currently works. ``People don't talk about it. They think the money is there'' in the Social Security trust funds. ``He says because of the surplus, you can reduce the taxes. I say that's goofy,'' Brady told a White House briefing. Moynihan has voiced concern that Social Security's growing trust fund reserves are being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit and to pay for other government programs. His solution is to halt the buildup of the reserves and return Social Security to a pay-as-you-go system in which taxes would be raised in the next century to finance retirement benefits then. Moynihan said that if the government continues to use the trust funds for other purposes, it could cause a loss of trust that could be a ``seismic event.'' ``This has the makings of a massive loss of trust,'' he said. The Bush administration, in its proposed fiscal 1991 budget, unveiled a rival plan that would use Social Security's surpluses to retire government debt once the federal budget is balanced. Moynihan said that plan was unacceptable because it postpones dealing with the problem. The New York Democrat addressed the AARP's national legislative council, which has not yet taken a position on the Moynihan plan.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Ivory Cache Unearthed
DOC.TEXT: Police unearthed 1,909 elephant tusks in a coastal town after being tipped off by someone who reported people ``burying things in gunny bags,'' a newspaper said Tuesday. Elephant tusks are valued for their ivory, but in an effort to preserve the dwindling elephant population, ivory trading has been banned worldwide by the International Convention on Trade in Endangered Species. Tanzania and other African countries have cracked down hard on poaching. The Daily News said the tusks weighed a total of eight tons and were found buried on a small island off the Indian Ocean port of Tanga sometime between Jan. 22 and Jan. 26. Elias Lundamila, the Tanga regional police commander, was quoted as saying the ivory was valued at $822,785. He said no arrests had been made.

DOC.HEAD: Wild Elephants Cause $111 Million in Crop Damage
DOC.TEXT: The government has built more than 600 miles of electrically charged fences to keep wild elephants from destroying crops, a newspaper said Tuesday. The fences are not designed to killed the animals but only to scare them away from the plantations, said Mohamed Khan Momin Khan, director-general of the National Parks Department. The problem is a result of Malaysia's expanding crops, which have forced the country's 1,000 or so wild elephants off the jungle lands they once roamed. As the land is cleared for oil palm, rubber and other crops, the elephants return in search of food and eat the crops, Mohamed told the New Straits Times. Since 1969, elephants have caused more than $111 million damage to crops, he said. Mohamed said his department has begun rounding up the elephants and trucking them to areas far from the plantations, but up to 500 of the animals have yet to be caught. Authorities built more than 600 miles of fences that carry enough of an electrical shock to drive the animals away but not kill them, he added. Still, when they can find no other food, the elephants sometimes crash through the fences to get at crops, he said. Department rangers then rush to areas where crops are being attacked, track down the elephants, shoot them with tranquilizer guns and chain them to trees. Flanked by two tame elephants, the wild elephants then are coaxed onto trucks and moved to new locations.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Plunges Into River Killing Five Passengers
DOC.TEXT: A bus skidded off an icy highway Tuesday and fell into a river outside Seoul, and five passengers were killed, police said. The police said the 30 other people on the bus managed to swim to safety. The bus plunged into the North Han River near Paldang, about 15 miles outside Seoul. The bodies of the five killed were found when the bus was pulled from the water, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Police Officer in Basque Region
DOC.TEXT: A bomb believed set by Basque terrorists killed a police officer Tuesday near this northern provincial capital, authorities said. The afternoon explosion instantly killed the officer, Ignacio Perez Alvarez, and damaged cars and shattered windows near his home in the town of Galdacano, six miles east of Bilbao, a municipal police officer said. Investigators were unsure whether the bomb was planted in his car or on a bicycle parked nearby, said the officer, who was not identified in keeping with custom. It blew up as the victim got into his car. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attack, but it bore the hallmarks of the separatist group ETA, which claimed responsibility last year for attacks that killed 17 people. ETA, which stands for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language, has killed more than 600 people in its 21-year armed campaign to secure independence for the northern, three-province Basque region. Most of the victims have been civil guards, police and military officers.

DOC.HEAD: Ireland Asked to Return Aborigine Relic
DOC.TEXT: An aborigine on Tuesday asked Ireland to return the 128-year-old preserved head of an aborigine warrior to Australia for burial. Aborigine Rikki Shields said he has written to Ireland's President Patrick Hillery to help in the campaign to move the head from the Dublin headquarters of the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland to Australia. The head is said to be that of Pemulwoy, who once led an aborigine guerrilla campaign against the British in Australia. He was captured and killed in 1862. ``His head was sent to London, but his memory lives in the minds of the aboriginal people,'' said Shields, who is visiting Ireland. A spokesman for the Royal College of Surgeons said the head, which is not on public display because of the controversy, was left to them in a bequest a century ago and they had to honor it. ``I challenge the college's right to the head,'' Shields said. ``I also want the return of other aboriginal objects which might be in Ireland. ``The British stole them, but the Irish are perpetuating the crime,'' Shields said.

DOC.HEAD: Message in a Bottle Arrives 34 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: A woman said Tuesday that while walking along a beach in southwestern England, she found a barnacle-covered bottle with a message inside that apparently was tossed into the sea 34 years ago in South Africa. ``I could hardly believe my eyes, and I still can't, that this fragile bottle had been in the water all that time,'' Anna Alexander of the Cornish town of New Polzeath said. Ms. Alexander claims to have picked up the bottle Sunday while beachcombing. She said she broke the bottle to get to the contents: a 1956 South African shilling and a piece of paper with the name Ryan Smith and an address near Durban, South Africa, written on it. ``This bottle in all probability has been on the most incredible journey,'' Ms. Alexander said. ``It couldn't have come direct. We think really that this bottle has traveled hundreds of thousands of miles.'' Ms. Alexander said she has begun looking for Ryan Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew Lifted for 8 Hours; One Violent Incident Reported
DOC.TEXT: The government lifted curfew in this violence-torn Kashmir city for eight hours Tuesday, giving residents their longest taste of freedom in 10 days. At least one incident of violence was reported. Witnesses said Moslem militants agitating for independence shot another Moslem, claiming he was helping the Indian government in its crackdown on the secessionist movement. The 23-year-old man, identified only as Kauser, was taken to a hospital, said the witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. His condition was not known. Other witnesses said about 5,000 people demonstrated during the curfew relaxation to protest the alleged entry by paramilitary policemen into a mosque. There was no violence, said the witnesses who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, municipal workers removed hundreds of garbage cans piled on streets and grocers sold fresh fruit for the first time since the curfew was imposed in Srinagar on Jan. 20 after clashes between security forces and Moslem separatists. The Moslem militants demand either independence for Kashmir or unity with Moslem Pakistan. Kashmir is a part of the state of Jammu-Kashmir, the only Indian state with a majority Moslem population. Most Indians are Hindus. Srinagar, the state's summer capital and once a popular holiday retreat, is the flashpoint of the Kashmiri movement. At least 72 people, mostly Moslem males, have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20. The state government said Monday there had been no violence for the previous four days. The curfew was lifted for seven hours Monday, and that was extended to eight hours Tuesday. Pakistan and India have fought two wars over Kashmir since they were partitioned in 1947 upon gaining independence from Britain. The state is divided into Pakistani and Indian sectors by a U.N.-monitored line of control. India accuses neighboring Pakistan of aiding the Kashmiri militants, a charge that has been routinely denied. But Paskistan says it supports the separatism, describing it as a movement for self-determination. Pakistani Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan called Tuesday for India to allow the Kashmir dispute to be decided in a popular vote. ``It is an outstanding issue which is to be resolved through a plebiscite under the United Nations supervision,'' he said in a nationally televised speech. ``The Indian government is trying to suppress the freedom movement in Kashmir through atrocities, resulting in deaths of hundreds of Kashmiris and injuries to many more,'' Yaqub Khan said. The Indian crackdown began after Moslem militants stepped up attacks on the government, burning state-owned buildings, assassinating at least three intelligence agents and kidnapping the daughter of a Cabinet minister in Srinagar in December. She was released after the government freed five jailed members of the pro-independence Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: Man Disputes Gov't Claim He's Dead
DOC.TEXT: Al Denoncour survived three wars, but the federal bureaucracy has killed him off with paperwork. Mary Denoncour got the notice in the mail Saturday. ``My wife opened the letter and said `What is this? What is this?' I said, `What is it?' She said, `Read it. They've got you dead.''' The letter, from the Treasury Department, said Mrs. Denoncour owed the government $508, the amount of her husband's January Social Security check. It said the check was mailed before Denoncour died on Dec. 31. ``I survived World War II, Korea and two tours in Vietnam,'' Denoncour said. ``Then I come out here and this happens.'' Denoncour, 69, retired from the Army in 1969 and has taught energy conservation at Fayetteville Technical Community College for about 15 years. ``I called my supervisor and told him I couldn't teach a class Monday. He asked why. I said, `Well, I'm deceased.' He just laughed,'' he said. He made sure his military retirement benefits weren't affected, then traced the mistake to the Social Security Administration. ``They're the ones that pulled the boo-boo,'' he said. The mistake is unusual, an official said. ``It happens rarely. We pay 38 million people every month and about 99 percent are paid correctly and on time,'' said Darryl Mull, public affairs officer for the Social Security Administration's office in Atlanta. ``He'll get paid next month,'' Mull said. ``It might not be right on time, but he'll be paid sometime shortly after that.'' ``We'll take every action needed to get him paid timely and get him back in current benefit status,'' he added. Denoncour is not so confident. ``It's going to be one heck of a mess,'' he said. ``They're already giving my wife her (widow's) benefits.'' ``By the time they get through messing with it, it will take years and years,'' he said. ``They'll bug me about it. Social Security is like that.'' ``They want me to prove I'm alive,'' he said. He's already gotten the school to prepare a notarized letter attesting to that fact. ``When this is all over, I'll probably have one celebration. Get my friends together and just say, `Look here, I'm still kicking,' '' he said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Report Warns of `Information Gap' as Communications Industry Advances
DOC.TEXT: A report to Congress says poor, uneducated and isolated citizens are likely to suffer from an ``information gap'' in the next century unless the government sets policies to deal with advances in communications. The Office of Technology Assessment said that, given the direction of technological change and current policy uncertainties, the gap is likely to increase between those who can afford and make effective use of communications services and those who cannot. ``Government indecision'' in dealing with the rapidly developing technologies in computers, telephones and video will affect not only the realm of communication, but other key areas such as business as well, OTA said in a report, ``Critical Connections: Communications for the Future.'' The study, released Tuesday, was requested by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Congress is considering bills that would boost U.S. competitiveness in advanced technologies, including communications, by encouraging manufacturing partnerships. It also is expected to consider, later this year, whether to allow the regional Bell telephone companies into the information services businesses from which they were barred following the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. The Bush administration favors easing antitrust laws to pave the way for joint production arrangements, but it has been criticized for foot-dragging in detailing an overall technology policy and for apparently considering cuts in federal support for some high-technology research projects. OTA, a non-partisan, analytical arm of Congress, identified a number of factors that may deprive the poor, the undereducated and the geographically and technologically isolated portions of the public and small and medium-sized businesses. They included: _Shifting government subsidies. _Increased costs for the use of technology. _Growth in the economic power and concentration of many media. _Disagreement among policy-makers about what should constitute universal service. OTA said the concept of providing universal telephone service on a common, shared network is breaking down. It raised the possibility that a two-tiered telecommunications system _ one public, the other private _ may develop. ``If businesses view their needs as unique and decide to develop their own private networks, as some are doing now, there may be insufficient revenues available to support an advanced public network to serve all individuals,'' OTA said. OTA listed different strategies Congress could adopt to improve access to communications services: _Influence the means by which communication services are financed. _Structure the prices at which communication services are offered. _Regulate or redefine the rights of media owners.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Arrested in Hot Pants Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Eight men have been arrested in an undercover sting operation and charged with dealing in stolen jeans, which agents said were destined for European markets at inflated prices. The buyers expected to receive 200,000 pairs of stolen Levi 501 jeans initially, with an additional 200,000 pairs monthly, said agents of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. ``Levi 501 jeans are a hot item in the United States and worth even more in Europe,'' said agent Mike Brick. Investigators said the pants that sell here for $30-$35 bring $55 or more in Italy. Brick said Monday that the agents conducted a sting operation after a Kissimmee clothing broker asked an undercover agent where he could get large quantities of the jeans for resale overseas. Agents made it clear to the buyers that the jeans were stolen from a Levi company distribution center, but the buyers were only concerned that they not get counterfeits, he said. The defendants could face 5- to 30-year prison terms, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Parrot Costume Stolen From Car
DOC.TEXT: A new costume for the Pittsburgh Pirates' parrot mascot, worth about $8,200, has been stolen from a car parked downtown, police said. Mike Recktenwald, 26, of Brentwood, one of two men who play the role of the baseball team's 7-foot-tall mascot, had parked the car near Robert Morris College while he attended classes Monday. Police said a rear window was pried open. A large gym bag containing the parrot's body was taken along with a bag containing the mascot's trademark head with its huge beak and buccaneer hat. Some of Recktenwald's clothing and accessories also were taken. ``I couldn't believe it,'' he said. ``The costume was brand new. I only had it a week.'' Pirates spokesman Rick Cerrone said the 30-pound costume was one of two bought for the upcoming baseball season. ``It's not like you could put it on and just go strolling around somewhere,'' Cerrone said. ``I don't know what anybody would do with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Studying Possible Demise of Florida's Only Endangered Fish
DOC.TEXT: Biologists believe Florida's only endangered fish species is being squeezed out of its habitat by another species descended from discarded bait fish. Brown darters apparently were introduced into Florida Panhandle streams years ago when fishermen cleaned out their bait buckets. The newcomers are now out-competing native Okaloosa darters for food and habitat, and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is conducting a study to find out why. Only 1,500 to 10,000 of the two-inch long Okaloosa darters are believed to be left in streams leading into Rocky and Boggy bayous, the only places in the world where they are found. Both fish eat worms and insects. The Okaloosa darter is related to the Tennesse snail darter, another endangered species that was the center of a controversy in 1978, delaying completion of a huge dam because of fears it would wipe out the last of the tiny fish. The Okaloosa darter doesn't face such a threat. Most of its habitat is on Eglin Air Force Base's military reservation. Weapons testing on the reservation has not harmed the darter, said biologist Noel Burkhead and Jim Williams, who is heading the study. Both work out of the National Fisheries Research Center in Gainesville.

DOC.HEAD: White House Begins Selling Budget to Leery Democrats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7, House Speaker, and 22, Foley said.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: White House budget director Richard G. Darman clashed with congressional Democrats today over whether President Bush's $1.23 trillion 1991 budget is based on realistic economic forecasts. Darman responded to criticism from Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, who noted that Office of Management and Budget projections on economic growth, inflation and unemployment are considerably more optimistic than those of private forecasters. ``You are not dealing with people who are totally out of bounds'' in trying to project what direction the economy will take over the next several months, Darman told the House Budget Committee. He said OMB, which he heads, has been remarkably close to accurate in forecasts made last July.
