Panetta said the administration's economic assumptions and use of such tactics as shifting payments from one year to another to make the deficit look smaller call into question whether the deficit is being taken seriously. ``Of course the president is serious. I am serious,'' Darman shot back. ``I wish you had taken that on some faith.'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, senior Republican on the committee, defended Bush's budget, which was made public Monday, as ``a pretty good beginning.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley Jr. told reporters the administration budget plan ``does not take major directions'' but added, ``I believe we can and should reach a budget compromise.'' Bush said his fiscal blueprint keeps ``an eye toward future growth,'' halving the federal deficit to $63.1 billion while building up government science, space, anti-drug and environment efforts. But majority Democrats on Capitol Hill accused the president of being too kind to the Pentagon despite diminishing tensions with the Soviet Union, too stingy with domestic spending and overly dependent on phantom savings and unrealistic economic projections. ``At a time when we need bold leadership, what we have is another slide-by budget,'' Panetta said. While praising the president's plan, many Republicans conceded fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ poses so many difficult problems that budget work is likely to be time-consuming and thorny. ``I believe there is a real chance here of stalemate,'' lamented Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the Senate budget panel's ranking Republican. Bush proposed paring $36.5 billion from next year's projected budget gap, finding nearly half the savings by collecting $15.7 billion in additional tax revenues. Bush revived his push to cut the capital gains tax rate _ which the Senate denied him last year _ arguing it would raise $4.9 billion next year by encouraging property sales. The new levies are partially offset by $1.8 billion in specific tax breaks, including a $1,000 credit to poor families for each child under 4 years old. Other savings would come from slashing domestic programs by more than $14 billion below the rate they would otherwise grow _ including $5.5 billion from Medicare _ restraining growth in the military budget, collecting new and higher user fees and leasing federal property. ``We have taken pain to exclude gimmicks,'' Darman told reporters. But Democrats pointed to unspecified ``management'' savings of $5 billion in the Pentagon and $2.5 billion at the Internal Revenue Service, among other items. They also grumbled that it assumed a brighter economy this year than many congressional and private analysts expect, a factor that lets the government project higher revenue collections. Using the economic forecasts Democrats consider accurate, Bush's budget would produce a $100 billion shortfall, they said. ``In other words, there's no change in fiscal direction in this budget,'' griped Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. Bush presented his spending plan as one responsive to ``the dramatic changes in the world political situation.'' He limited Pentagon spending to $292.1 billion _ higher than this year's $286.8 billion, but 2 percent less than the total needed to stay even with inflation. Bush sought increases for expensive weapons systems such as $900 million more for the Strategic Defense Initiative, but a cutback of 38,000 troops and the shutdown of dozens of military bases. Foley said the president's defense budget would be reduced, but would not specify an amount. But he also predicted Congress ``will not accept'' the administration's proposed freeze on cost-of-living increases for military and civilian retirees. Bush also hiked spending for foreign aid and other international expenditures to $18.2 billion, a 12 percent boost that included $300 million for Eastern Europe. But Democrats complained Bush should have carved more out of the military. ``You'd think Joe Stalin had come back and entrenched himself in the Kremlin,'' Sasser said. Bush's proposals to raise domestic spending read like a menu of his past campaign promises. He sought a $1.2 billion hike _ to $7.6 billion _ in environmental programs, including an effort to plant 1 billion trees annually. Federal anti-drug efforts would increase from $6.9 billion to $9.7 billion, the Head Start pre-school program for poor children would get a $500 million infusion to $1.9 billion, and NASA's budget would soar from $12 billion to $14.1 billion. Democratic staffers on the Senate Budget Committee said they found 24 programs Bush was proposing to eliminate, including the Economic Development Administration, federal subsidies for the Amtrak passenger railroad, and energy conservation grants to state and local governments. Bush also proposed reducing spending for mass transit aid to communities, several student loan programs and heating bill assistance for the poor. The president also proposed a plan to gradually shift the massive Social Security surpluses out of the deficit calculations. Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., has gained center stage by proposing to cut the retirement system's payroll tax.

DOC.HEAD: Bingaman Wants to Assess Student Progress, Longer School Days
DOC.TEXT: Longer school days and thorough assessment of students at each grade level could improve education in the United States, a New Mexico senator said Tuesday. Democrat Jeff Bingaman introduced bills to authorize a study on the feasibility of lengthening the school day and academic year and to create a council to keep tabs on the academic achievements of students and school quality. ``It is time Congress seriously considers how as a nation we will be prepared to face and succeed in the next century,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said at a news conference with Bingaman. ``We have begun an era of technological sophistication that will require a well-educated workforce.'' Mitchell is co-sponsoring the two bills with Bingaman and Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and Tom Harkin, R-Iowa. Bingaman, chairman of the Governmental Affairs subcommittee on government information and regulation, said there was a good chance the bills would get to the Senate floor this session. However, he was uncertain they would reach the House. The 200-day School Year Study Act would create a commission to review school-day policies among states, as well as the effect a longer school year would have on teacher salaries and on the communities paying those salaries. ``I have long believed that the school year should be extended,'' Mitchell said. American students, he said, attend school about 180 days per year, while Europeans typically attend 220 days, the Japanese 240 days and South Koreans 250 days per year. The school-year commission also would design a plan to assist states and local school districts in meeting the additional costs associated with a longer school year. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos does not support longer school days, Bingaman said. Polls also indicate that the general public and students oppose longer school days, he said. ``That may not determine whether we ought to do it or not,'' Bingaman said, adding that the studies may provide ``persuasive evidence.'' The National Report Card Act of 1990 would establish a council of experts to study, make recommendations and periodically report on the status of the nation's educational achievement from preschool through higher education. ``A realistic assessment of educational quality and the establishment of national education goals is heavily dependent on the quality and availability of U.S. educational statistics and information,'' Bingaman said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Envoy Urges U.S. Pressure On Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League's representative on Tuesday urged the Bush administration to reassess and toughen its policy against settlement of Soviet Jews in Israeli-occupied territories. ``The Soviet Jewish immigration issue, in bolstering Israel's intransigence and whetting its appetite for expansion, must lead to a genuine reassessment of U.S. policy...,'' Clovis Maksoud told a news conference. Israeli expectations of thousands of Soviet immigrants a month represent ``an explosive situation'' and a new threat to Middle East peace prospects, he said. ``The Palestinian people ... cannot sit idly by and watch Soviet Jewish immigrants settling in Israel as full-fledged citizens when Palestinian refugees are systematically denied their inalienable right of return or their right to be compensated,'' Maksoud said. The United States and the Soviet Union should ``realize the potential of this demographic explosion'' and convene a long-discussed international conference on the Middle East, he said. The United States has traditionally opposed the Soviet-backed proposal for an international conference, focusing its efforts on arranging direct Israeli-Arab talks. Maksoud said State Department statements about the settlement issue do not go far enough and the United States should return to its policy during the Carter administration of considering settlements in the occupied territories illegal. The Reagan administration changed this to declaring settlement in the occupied territories as an ``obstacle to peace.'' The State Department said Monday that U.S. aid is limited to use inside Israel and is forbidden for use in settling immigrants in the occupied territories. Maksoud said the Arab countries question whether the aid is adequately monitored to prevent its use in the territories, and said stronger verification is needed to keep Israel from ``cheating on utilization of aid.''

DOC.HEAD: Former President Ordered to Give Diary Excerpts to Poindexter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS North's first name in 13th graf, Poindexter is charged
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today ordered former President Reagan to turn over excerpts of his diaries to former national security adviser John M. Poindexter for use in his Iran-Contra case. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene directed Reagan to produce entries from the ex-president's diaries for 29 different dates in 1985 and 1986. In addition, Poindexter is entitled to receive other diary excerpts, said the judge. He did not detail how many or what dates. Reagan was ordered to produce a diary entry relating to a ``successful'' trip Poindexter took in December 1985 to Central America. ``The entry includes a somewhat ambiguous comment arguably indicating that the former president knew'' of Poindexter's ``activities on behalf of the Contras,'' Greene said. Reagan was ordered to give Poindexter the diary entries by next Monday. Theodore Olson, one of Reagan's lawyers, wasn't immediately available for comment, his office said. Greene gave the former president nearly a week to produce the material in case he decides to assert the doctrine of executive privilege in an attempt to avoid surrendering the diaries. The judge said Poindexter is entitled to diary entries in which Reagan describes an effort to persuade the government of Honduras to release a seized arms shipment that had been destined for the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Greene also said Poindexter must receive diary entries focusing on U.S. military-type assistance to an unidentified Central American country in support of the Contras. This occurred during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid for the rebels fighting the leftist government of Nicaragua. Poindexter is entitled to the entries because ``they may show what types of aid President Reagan thought could legally be provided for the military or paramilitary operations of the Contras,'' Greene said. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of counts of making false statements in connection with Oliver North's assistance to the Contras and the 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. He is scheduled to go on trial Feb. 20. Poindexter also is entitled to Reagan's diary entries concerning meetings with Poindexter and others in December 1985 ``to discuss the sales of arms to Iran,'' said the court ruling. One diary entry ``addresses briefly the issue of the proceeds from these sales'' of arms to Iran, it said. None of the diary entries ``sheds any light on the question of what President Reagan may have know about the diversion'' of proceeds to the Contra rebels from the administration's secret sale of arms to Iran. Reagan has denied knowing about the diversion and Poindexter testified to Congress that he didn't tell the president. Greene said Poindexter isn't entitled to a large number of diary entries that deal with the Iran-Contra affair but aren't relevant to the criminal case against the former national security adviser. Poindexter maintains that Reagan knew of and approved activities undertaken in the Iran and Contra initiatives and that therefore he had no reason to conceal these activities from Congress, as charged in the indictment against him. Poindexter has said that Reagan took notes at meetings focusing on congressional inquiries into whether North, then a National Security Council aide, was raising money and providing military advice to the Contras. The responses sent by Poindexter embraced false denials about North's involvement that had been sent to Congress in 1985 by Robert McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor as national security adviser. ``We believe the president's notes will show his discussions with Admiral Poindexter, first about the letters that were sent by Congress and the appropriateness of any response,'' one of Poindexter's lawyers said in court last Sept. 6. In addition, Poindexter has told the judge that his meetings with Reagan also dealt with the accuracy of a chronology prepared by North on a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Four of the criminal charges against Poindexter deal with this false chronology and Poindexter's alleged statements to Congress that he didn't know until 1986 that the November 1985 shipment contained Hawk missiles.

DOC.HEAD: 90 Prospective Jurors Summoned in Exxon Spill Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with beginning of jury selection; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `Hazelwood faces ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: About 90 prospective jurors were summoned today for the trial of the fired Exxon skipper charged in the nation's worst oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone read the poetential jurors the charges, then divided them into groups of 30, each to be questioned over three days. Former captain Joseph Hazelwood watched quietly in the courtroom where reporters outnumbered spectators until the jury pool filed in. The potential jurors had filled out questionnaires in advance for the lawyers to study. Hazelwood's trial got under way Monday with Johnstone rejecting yet another effort to have charges against the veteran mariner dismissed. But the judge did not rule on whether to bar key evidence _ results of a sobriety test that Hazelwood had failed after the Exxon Valdez spilled more than 10 million gallons of crude oil. In addition to the 12 jurors, Johnstone said three or four alternates probably will be selected. Hazelwood faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Defense lawyer Dick Madson had told Johnstone the charges should be dismissed because federal law pre-empts state law in the case. ``I feel that this show should not go on, at least not here.'' Madson said. ``Federal laws and regulations have covered this (commercial shipping) field for 200 years, and there's a good reason for it,'' Madson said. He said federal law prevails to guarantee consistent rules from port to port, regardless of the state involved. But Johnstone denied Madson's motion, saying it lacked substance. Earlier defense efforts to get the indictment dismissed failed in various courts. Still pending is a defense motion to prohibit as evidence the results of a blood-alcohol test that Hazelwood failed about 10 hours after his ship struck a reef in Prince William Sound on March 24. The spill, which blackened shores and killed wildlife, triggered what Exxon calculated was a $2 billion cleanup. Some state officials and others say the work is not over and should continue this spring and summer. Hazelwood is expected to be present throughout the trial, which is to last six weeks or more. Johnstone told lawyers on both sides he expects jury selection to take less than the two weeks that lawyers predicted. The judge warned he does not want the process to be drawn out with extensive questions about the candidates' backgrounds. The three-page questionnaire filled out by prospective jurors includes questions about experience with vessels, work in the oil and fishing industries, familiarity with the oil spill and personal economic loss or gain tied to the spill. Hazelwood originally was scheduled for an October trial in Valdez, the port from which the tanker set out a few hours before the crash. The trial for the Huntington, N.Y., seaman was moved to Anchorage to increase the chance of a fair proceeding and to take advantage of a larger jury pool and court room.

DOC.HEAD: Army Short of Decorations for Panama Veterans
DOC.TEXT: The Army has a new Panama emergency: a shortage of decorations for infantrymen who saw combat in the Dec. 20 invasion. The deficit of the Combat Infantryman's Badges came as five Democratic senators Tuesday urged the Army to give the awards to women who were in combat in Panama. ``We understand the Army is firm in its objection to women in combat,'' said a letter initiated by Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. ``But, women were in combat in Panama, and deserve full recognition of their accomplishments and courage in behalf of American people. They should be given the Combat Infantryman's Badge,'' the senators said in a letter to Army Secretary Michael T.W. Stone Others senators signing the letter were Democrats Kent Conrad and Quentin Burdick of North Dakota; Thomas Daschle of South Dakota; and Paul Simon of Illinois. The Army says the women who went to Panama did not serve in infantry units, but were assigned to non-combatant support units. Only infantry officers and enlisted soldiers who ``satisfactorily perform the infantry operations in active ground combat'' are eligible for the badges, Army regulations say. Meanwhile, the Army had made an ``expedited buy'' of 10,000 decorations from Lordship Industries in Hauppauge, N.Y., said Frank Johnson, a spokesman of the Defense Personnel Support System in Philadelphia. The 3-inch badges cost 90 cents each and are emblazoned with a wreath and a rifle. Some 2,500 badges will be shipped to Ford Ord, Calif., by March 3 to meet a shortage there. The shortage cropped up because the Army didn't anticipate the Panama invasion in which 9,000 of the roughly 26,000 troops involved in the operation were infantrymen. ``When we looked ahead, we didn't anticipate needing the ones for Panama,'' said Shari Lawrence, a spokeswoman for the Army Personnel Command. ``It's a fairly routine thing,'' Lawrence said of the badge. ``You don't have to have any valorous situation.'' Maj. L.D. Walker at Fort Ord said the badges were highly sought after by infantrymen, who haven't had many combat situations in recent years to qualify. ``They don't have very much opportunity _ opportunity is maybe the wrong word _ to get those,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: When Dorothy Ostwald says she knows how to change a diaper, believe her. The owners of 100 little bottoms could testify to it. Ostwald, 82, last week celebrated the birth of her 100th descendant, great-grandson Jeremy Rice. She raised 10 children. They had 54 children. Now the grandchildren are having babies _ Jeremy, son of Janet and Bob Rice of Cheboygan, is the 36th great-grandchild. Ostwald never has had a driver's license, so when she and her kids went somewhere, they set out on foot. ``I'd take them to Sunday school and I'd go up the steps and people would ask, `Is that your Sunday school class?''' she said. ``People would drive by our house and ask if we were having a party.''

Two hundred fifty dollars buys a lot of bacon, but a group of youngsters got more than 200 pounds of pork for their money. The Junior Humane Society at Brownsville Middle School submitted the winning bid at a sheriff's auction Monday, saving a pregnant sow from the butcher's knife. ``She's going to have babies and we didn't want her or her babies to get slaughtered,'' said Frankie Van Horn, a teacher and the Junior Humane Society sponsor. Sidney Gottlieb, a circulation worker for the Pensacola News Journal, donated $200 to help meet the auction price. The students plan to keep the pig as a pet and are looking for homes for her piglets. The animal, found wandering on Christmas Eve, was auctioned after no one came forward to pay a $115 impoundment bill and other costs of caring for it. The students plan to call the pig Fern, for the little girl who saved Wilbur the pig in ``Charlotte's Web.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY68
DOC.TEXT: Cupid need not point his love-drenched quills in this city. At least that's what a new sign implies. The sign, a take-off on the international symbol prohibiting something, shows a bride and groom inside a circle with a slash through it. But an official insisted Tuesday the city is not anti-love. ``It's a funky sign and we made it in a fun way,'' said Department of Ports and Trades spokesman Frances Resheske. The sign recently went up on a public pier in the borough of Queens after residents complained to their community board that the pier was frequently being closed for private weddings. ``We didn't mean to imply that weddings are prohibited,'' Resheske said, ``just that people are not allowed to close off the pier to the public.'' She said many couples holding receptions at an adjacent restaurant were led to believe they could hold private ceremonies on the pier, with a view of the Manhattan skyline. The restaurant has a lease allowing it to operate on city property but the rights do not extend to the pier, Resheske said. The sign may be fun, but the city isn't joking, Resheske said. Lovebirds who violate it could be fined up to $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Disagree on Adjusting the Census Count
DOC.TEXT: Politicians and statisticians disagreed Tuesday on whether this year's census can be made more accurate by adjusting the final numbers. ``The census is a political act and there are winners and losers. The losers say `count differently,' and the winners say `leave it alone,''' observed Rep. William M. Thomas, R-Calif. ``We count with about 98 percent accuracy, but not perfection,'' added Thomas at a House census and population subcommittee hearing on proposed guidelines for deciding whether to adjust the count following the census this March and April. The 1980 national head count missed about 3.2 million people, often poor and minorities, the Census Bureau has calculated. Efforts to reduce that undercount are underway, but many people are still expected to be missed this year. Because census figures are used to apportion seats in Congress and state legislatures, the anticipated undercount led to a lawsuit filed by New York and other cities fearing loss of representation. The lawsuit was settled by an agreement that the Census Bureau would develop guidelines for deciding if the final counts could be improved by some form of statistical adjustment. A set of proposed guidelines was published in December and promptly drew fire from backers of making the adjustment, who say the guidelines are too stringent. In general the guidelines cite the basic census as a standard of accuracy and suggest changing the count only if it can be shown that the modifications would be even more accurate, not just nationally but on local levels also. In addition the guidelines would discourage adjustment if the process would result in confusion or disruption of the political process of undermine public confidence in the census numbers. Rep. Thomas C. Sawyer, D-Ohio, was concerned that the guidelines ``appear to create a strong presumption against adjustment. ...'' ``These guidelines ... cast grave doubts on the sincerity of the Department of Commerce,'' Barbara A. Bailer, executive director of the American Statistical Association and a former Census Bureau official, said in her prepared testimony. And Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, said that in his opinion the guidelines ``almost insure no adjustment.'' The proposed guidelines ``so stack the deck against the possibility of correction that their adoption will be tantamount to a decision not to correct the differential undercount,'' concluded New York Attorney General Robert Abrams in his prepared testimony. Michael R. Darby, Commerce under secretary for economic affairs, responded that the department hopes to take such an accurate census that adjustment won't be needed; but if it is, the guidelines are still under development and can be modified. ``If the Census Bureau is going to part from its tradition of publishing figures based only on people actually counted, it must have firm and noncontroversial ground to stand on,'' V. Lance Tarrance, co-chairman of the Census advisory panel on adjustment, said in his testomony. ``Arguments against adjustment ... seem to me stronger than the arguments for,'' added William Kruskal, professor emeritus of statistics at the University of Chicago. ``Proponents of adjustment believe that the data, when available, will show overwhelmingly that the counts can be improved by statistical adjustment. Skeptics like myself suspect that they will not,'' concluded Kenneth Wachter of the University of California at Berkeley.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Communists Clash at Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party chief Petar Mladenov fiercely attacked the ousted leadership Tuesday but offered few ideas for change as he tried to please reformers and conservatives and avoid a party split. As the party began a three-day congress, Mladenov proposed splitting the post of party chief and state president, which he assumed when Todor Zhivkov was removed from 35 years in power Nov. 10. ``It's my suggestion that the comrades adopt a decision that the same person should not be leading the party and the state at the same time,'' Mladenov told the 2,752 delegates. In his two-hour opening speech, Mladenov tried to please reformers by talking in general terms of change, while pandering to conservatives by giving little ground to the opposition. But he had few fresh ideas on how to keep the party together and gave only half-hearted support to creation of a market economy. He focused mainly on criticism of Zhivkov. Debate during the afternoon showed divisions emerging between the conservative majority and the various reform factions who favor quicker moves toward democracy. When one hard-line delegate insisted, ``I am against private ownership ... and do not accept the exploitation of man by man,'' another called for removing party structures that ``generate totalitarian ways and rule'' and suggested changing the party's name. The congress was originally not scheduled until 1991, but it was rescheduled after Bulgaria was caught up in the pro-democracy movement sweeping Eastern Europe. Mladenov was at his most forthright in criticizing the 35-year-rule of Zhivkov, who on Monday was said to have been moved from house arrest in a villa to prison pending trial on charges of misappropriation of state property, inciting ethnic hostility and grave abuse of power. ``Bearer of a painful suspiciousness and selfishness, of a manic ambition to be a theoretician in the complete absence of any kind of intellectual abilities, he was unscrupulous and insidious,'' Mladenov said of Zhivkov. He accused the ousted leader of staging fake trials in attempts to fight his opponents with ``the most brutal terrorist means,'' but he added, ``Those designs ultimately failed.'' There has been speculation that Mladenov, who served as Zhivkov's foreign minister for 17 years and is rumored to suffer from a heart condition, might retain the presidency and allow someone else to take over the party. But it was unclear Tuesday whether another holdover from the Zhivkov era, reformer Andrei Lukanov, could win the post, or whether Bulgaria's Communists will follow other East European parties and bring new blood into the leadership in an attempt to boost the party's standing. Opposition leaders and some reform Communists doubt the current ruling group _ Mladenov, Lukanov and Politburo member Alexander Lilov _ are sincere about genuine change. One of the few rounds of applause for Mladenov came when he rejected opposition calls to postpone the nation's first free parliamentary elections in more than 40 years. Mladenov insisted they be held ``not later than May.'' The opposition had sought a postponement until November to give it time to organize against the still powerful Communists. Mladenov appeared to try to exploit divisions within the still weak opposition by reiterating calls for a new ``government of national concord'' before the elections. Some opposition leaders have rejected this idea outright, saying they do not want to be responsible for the chaos caused by four decades of Communist rule. Others have suggested they might participate in such an interim Cabinet. Both East Germany and Czechoslovakia, whose Communist parties have collapsed far faster than Bulgaria's, are now governed by such coalition Cabinets pending free elections. Bulgaria's Communists, drawing on a century of tradition and facing a relatively weak opposition, have relinquished far less power than their comrades in other states. Mladenov warned the delegates they could lose more power if the party does not reform. But he said little to indicate he has concrete plans for change. Mladenov admitted the economy is ``in tatters,'' but he was vague on how to improve it. While saying the economy should be market-oriented and allow for mixed forms of ownership, he said this ``does not mean and cannot mean capitalist orientation.'' All the country's mines were on strike last week, an unprecedented wave of labor stoppages in postwar Bulgaria. Mladenov also gave no specifics on what share of power the Communists would retain in a government of national accord. To date, the Communists have balked at such relatively simple opposition demands as a share in radio and television broadcasts.

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Band to Play in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Waltham's American Legion band will march in Moscow during the Soviet Union's annual May Day celebrations, and the band leader knows the perfect tune for the occasion: ``God Bless America.'' Dorothy Hill said her three years of work had paid off, with the band receiving permission to become the first to participate in the Red Square festivities. Some 150 people, including Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn and more than 70 band members, will make the trip April 28 to May 6, she said Monday. ``I'm a veteran of World War II. I've seen three wars. I don't want to see any more,'' Hill, band leader for more than 40 years, said. ``I know I'm going to be playing `God Bless America' going through Red Square.'' Hill said she and former Mayor Arthur Clark had tried to enlist Thomas P. ``Tip'' O'Neill, then speaker of the U.S. House, to help set up the trip. O'Neill told Hill to wait for the political climate to improve. She took his advice for a while, but later decided relations between Moscow and Washington were warming too slowly. Four months ago she met Rudolph Peselman, a Soviet immigrant living in another Boston suburb, Brookline, and working as an international trader, acting as a middleman on U.S. and Soviet business deals. The week before Peselman met Hill, the director of the Soviet Peace Commission had expressed to him an interest in finding an American band to play in Red Square. The commission later agreed to make the group's hotel and travel arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle in Panama: In Charge at the Locks
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle got a chance to work the Panama Canal locks during his day in this isthmus nation, and seemed to relish the experience. ``I felt like I was in charge,'' he said. Quayle threw the levers during a visit to the Miraflores locks just outside Panama City that opened the gates so a Liberian-registered freighter, Alpheos, could make its way through the canal. As the ship laboriously inched through the narrow channel, the beaming vice president asked reporters, ``How'd I do? Did you see that ship coming through?'' ``I opened the locks,'' he boasted. ``I felt like I was in charge.''

On the other hand, Quayle will never make it as a bargain hunter. He proved that when he stopped at a T-shirt stand on his way out to the Miraflores locks. He picked out three for his children, bearing the slogan ``Operation Just Cause,'' the name for the U.S. military invasion of Panama. The seller tried to give him the shirts, but Quayle said, ``Oh, no, I have to pay. I insist.'' She offered him the three for $10. But Quayle rejoined, ``I'll tell you what, I'll give you $5 each.'' She finally accepted the money. But then she had a request for the vice president. ``Don't leave us unprotected,'' she said referring to the U.S. invasion troops that remain in Panama. ``We will stay with Panama to see the democracy restored here,'' Quayle assured her. ``We want to make sure you have a good future here.''

There were plenty of people who live in the affluent hilltop neighborhood near the U.S. ambassador who also want the U.S. troops to stick around. ``Right now we don't feel safe. We don't go to the movies. We don't go out,'' said Linda Lalo, owner of a sporting goods store that was looted during the invasion. ``I'm afraid to open again because they steal everything,'' she said. ``While we have faith in the new government, we haven't had enough time to organize to protect ourselves. It's too early to leave,'' said her friend, Yvonne Attie, whose husband is an owner of a wholesale factory and shop. They said that the neighbors armed themselves and kept up 24-hour patrols during the invasion aftermath. Even now they are careful about moving about. ``I just went to the drug store. There was a bomb scare,'' said Mrs. Lalo on the day Quayle was visiting. She said a man had been taken hostage by robbers in one store, and she cautioned foreigners not to go jogging after dark. Two teen-age girls curious for a glimpse of the vice president wanted to know if it was true the invasion troops could be gone in just two weeks. ``Don't they know there's a lot of insecurity here?'' the girls asked?

There weren't many people out and about when Quayle went to have lunch at an oceanfront restaurant. But that was mostly because soldiers blocked off the road around the place. Still, the vice president managed to find himself a vivacious lunch partner. Among the few people in the restaurant was a young, attractive woman with two small boys. Quayle went over and introduced himself and asked them to join his table. The woman told her boys to stay put and sat with Quayle's party, chatting animatedly throughout. Quayle's aides later disclosed why the woman probably had so much to say _ she was the popular hostess of a local TV talk show, Rosanna Uribe-Fernandez de Cordoba.

Even in Panama, Super Bowl Sunday was a big event, and at the Fort Clayton Army base, Quayle was part of the pre-game entertainment. He stopped there to join a roomful of soldiers watching the game on a big screen. While waiting for the kickoff, Quayle grabbed a football and tossed it briefly with two women soldiers, who like the others were dressed in battle fatigues and boots. The other soldiers appeared as delighted to watch as the women were to play catch with Quayle. As they all settled in to watch the 49ers clobber the Broncos, a reporter asked Quayle which team he was supporting. ``That's classified,'' the vice president replied diplomatically.

In boning up for his trip, Quayle sought advice from former President Carter, but was unable to reach him because Carter was traveling in Nicaragua. Although the former Democratic president might seem an unlikely adviser to Quayle, one of the administration's most conservative members, the vice president said he wanted to contact him because of Carter's experience in the region. ``I wanted to talk to him about Latin American politics. He spent a great deal of time traveling around, and also converse with him a little bit about the situation in Nicaragua. I was interested in his view of my trip and what I might expect and his assessment,'' Quayle said. Carter has been welcomed by the Nicaraguan government as an independent observer of the Feb. 25 elections. Managua has refused to allow a congressional delegation that President Bush wants to send. While the Bush administration has repeatedly criticized the ruling Sandinistas for trying to choke the opposition's chances in the election, Carter said Monday he believes the voting will be fair and honest. He predicted ``a superb election.''

DOC.HEAD: Pipe Bomb Explodes at Church, Woman Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `There was ...' to RESTORE dropped `not' to show there was no confirmation from police.
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb mailed to a church exploded this morning, injuring the pastor's daughter, the church said. People near the Lakewood Church told police they heard a loud pop and then a person screaming. Lisa Osteen, the 30-year-old daughter of the Rev. John Osteen, pastor of the 10,000-member Baptist church, was taken to Ben Taub Hospital, where she was in stable condition suffering from burns, authorities said. KHOU-TV reported that the bomb contained six- to eight-inch nails and that it blew up in Ms. Osteen's lap. There was no immediate confirmation from police. In December, nail-studded mail bombs killed a white judge near Birmingham, Ala., and a black civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga., in related attacks investigators believe were motivated by race. The Houston church is mostly white. Ms. Osteen was in an office in an auxiliary building across the street from the main church when the bomb went off, the church said. ``We did have apparently a pipe bomb that came in a small package just in our regular mail that was picked up at the local post office today,'' an unidentified church spokeswoman told reporter this morning. ``As normal procedure, Lisa Osteen opened the package, there was an explosion and she did seem to have some injuries, but not anything critical.'' Calls to the church were answered by a recording saying, ``Hello, this is Lakewood Church. We have had a minor explosion here in the church office. Everything is fine, we just want to reassure you that everything is fine here at the church. We will be off the phone for a short period of time. Thank you. God bless you.'' Investigators with the FBI and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were en route to the church, the TV station said. Authorities were trying to find the postmark on the package, the station said. The pastor was not at the church this morning. His daughter is director of ministries there.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Group Blasts Bush Budget's Cuts in Urban Funds
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Conference of Mayors decried on Tuesday proposed cuts in urban funds in the Bush budget, particularly what its executive director called a ``turkey list'' of reductions in some of the cities' major programs. ``We don't know who wrote it (the list), but mayors are concerned they have been singled out,'' Thomas Cochran, the organization's executive director, told a news conference. Cochran referred to a chapter in the Bush budget delivered to Congress on Monday. The chapter, titled, ``Reducing Investment in Low-Return Programs,'' calls for spending cuts in mass transit, sewage plants, housing subsidies, student aid, low-income energy assistance and other urban programs. Cochran said the message in the new budget is that urban programs, which have been reduced 62 percent in the last 10 years, will be cut again if Bush prevails in Congress. A proposed $163 million cut from the $2.9 billion authorized in fiscal 1990 for the Community Development Grant program particularly was a ``serious slap in the face,'' he said, because it is the only major federal urban program remaining. Cochran said the conference ``would get our forces together'' to persuade Cognress not to go along with the idea. At the same time, the conference official saT-R-E-S.'' ``Good luck, and keep puzzling,'' the voice says before signing off. The calls cost 75 cents for the first minute, 50 cents for every additional minute. Nancy Nielson, a spokeswoman for the Times, said the experimental service has been offered since Jan. 21 and may lead to other interactive services sponsored by the newspaper. She said there had not yet been any accounting of how many calls the service had received. There is one small quirk in the system. Puzzlers who called Tuesday were able to get answers to Wednesday's as-yet-unseen puzzle by punching in the date 1-31. If you get stuck, 1 down is WISH.

DOC.HEAD: 500 Participate in Vigil for Missing 14-Year-Old Girl
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 people took part in a candlelight vigil and walk to mark the one-year anniversary of the disappearance of a 14-year-old girl. The walk began Monday at Wells Middle School and ended at St. Raymond's Catholic Church, the route believed to be the one Ilene Misheloff took when she disappeared one year ago Tuesday. Mike and Maddie Misheloff, Ilene's parents, walked arm-in-arm at the head of the procession. ``I am overwhelmed by the turnout,'' said Misheloff. ``We are very pleased that all these people have come together, but we would be even more pleased if the publicity leads to her release.'' Ilene's brother, Robert, said he hoped the vigil sends a message to his sister. ``She needs to know we love her. She needs to know we care.'' Police and the FBI continue to search for the missing teen-ager, but no substantial leads have been developed.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Orders New Weather Radars
DOC.TEXT: Full production of 165 new Doppler weather radars was ordered Tuesday by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher. The $359 million project will cover the next six years, with the first of the new units scheduled for installation in the fall near Oklahoma City, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. Known as NEXRAD, for Next Generation Weather Radar, the new system is expected to improve weather forecasts and provide earlier warnings of severe storms, including tornados. Pre-production versions of the radar have been under test for several months. Doppler radar assists meteorologists by showing the direction of wind and rain movement on radar screens. Traditional radars can detect the presence of storms, but cannot determine wind movements.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Super Bowl Ratings, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0577,0405
DOC.HEAD: Super Bowl Was Lowest-Rated in 21 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th graf pvs, `Only the ...' with highest-rated Super Bowl.
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco 49ers' 55-10 rout of the Denver Broncos was the lowest-rated Super Bowl in 21 years and the third-lowest ever. The game on CBS averaged a 39.0 rating and a 63 share, the lowest Super Bowl rating since 1969, when the New York Jets' 16-7 victory over Baltimore got a 36.0 on NBC for the worst rating ever, A.C. Nielsen Co. said today. The rating is a percentage of the nation's televisions; each point represents 921,000 homes. The share is the percentage of the televisions on at the time. Despite the low rating, Sunday's game was seen by about 108.5 million people, making it the ninth most-watched TV show ever in the United States behind eight Super Bowls and the final episode of ``MASH.'' The higher viewership was made possible by the annual increase in the number of homes with television. ``Given the expected blowout, the numbers are completely understandable and we're happy to have a 39,'' said Susan Kerr, director of programming for CBS Sports. ``It's still a remarkable rating for prime time.'' The 49ers won by the biggest margin in Super Bowl history. Only the 1969 and 1968 Super Bowls had lower ratings; Green Bay's 33-14 victory over Oakland in 1968 got a 36.8. The first Super Bowl was in 1967. The highest-rated Super Bowl was in 1982, when the 49ers' 26-21 victory over Cincinnati got a 49.1 on CBS. Last year's San Francisco-Cincinnati Super Bowl, won by the 49ers 20-16, got a 43.5 rating and was seen in 39.3 million homes, according to Nielsen estimates. This year's game was seen in about 35.9 million homes. Viewership of the 5 p.m. game this year peaked at a 41.6 rating and a 69 share from 6 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., dropping off as it became clear that Denver would not rally. The pregame show got a 39.0 rating and a 63 share and the postgame show got a 22.5 rating and a 35 share. The musical ``Annie,'' which was on ABC opposite the game, got a 9.4 rating. ``Life Goes On'' on NBC got a 6.0 rating and ``Love With a Twist'' on NBC a 7.6.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Reject Appeal for Money for Nicaraguan Election
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Democratic Party has rejected President Bush's appeal for contributions to the campaign of Violeta Chamorro to be president of Nicaragua. ``We are not about to become a political action committee for non-American candidates,'' party chairman Ronald H. Brown wrote to Bush in a letter made public Tuesday. Brown said the Democrats supported Bush's request for a $9 million congressional appropriation to help Chamorro's campaign against Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega. ``The Democratic Party and its leaders in Congress share your hope that a free and fair electoral process in Nicaragua will help that war-torn nation reconcile its differences and achieve peace,'' Brown wrote Bush. But, said Brown, ``I fear that your Jan. 24 appeal could be interpreted as an attempt to politicize this issue in a harmful way. Democrats do not believe that it is appropriate, proper, or wise for our political parties to attempt to influence the outcome of elections in a foreign country. Recalling that Bush once served as Republican Party chairman, Brown said, ``You will well understand my own determination to use the resources of my party to elect Democrats here at home.'' In letters to the Republican and Democratic National committees, Bush said that Mrs. Chamorro and her party, the National Opposition Union, or UNO, were ``desparately short of funds needed for campaign rallies, distributing campaign literature and media time.'' The Nicaraguan election is scheduled for Feb. 25. Bush said the Sandinista government had ``imposed serious obstacles'' to the delivery of funds appropriated by Congress and ``to date UNO has been permitted to make use of only a tiny fraction of them. For these reasons, Mrs. Chamorro's campaign runs the real risk of being crippled for lack of money.'' The president urged the two U.S. parties to make an unspecified joint contribution and urge their individual contributors to do the same.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Delayed on Noriega POW Issue
DOC.TEXT: A ruling on deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega's claim that he can't be tried on drug charges because he is a prisoner of war has been delayed a week, court officials said Tuesday. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler had planned a status conference Thursday on that issue and bond questions for two Noriega co-defendants, but on Tuesday reset the hearing for Feb. 8. The Department of Justice is preparing a response to the POW claim, said David Runkel, chief spokesman for the attorney general in Washington. Noriega's trial on 1988 drug-trafficking charges is scheduled for March 5, but Noriega's attorneys have repeatedly said it will be postponed. The defense claims a federal judge has no jurisdiction in the case because, under the Geneva Convention, Noriega was captured during armed hostilities and is therefore a POW. Hoeveler has expressed skepticism. ``Just because he is found to be a prisoner of war would not rule out the government's ability to bring him to trial,'' Hoeveler said during a bond hearing Monday for co-defendants Luis del Cid and Daniel Miranda. Noriega lawyers Frank Rubino and Steven Kollin have said they are seeking to take the POW issue before an international forum, possibly the World Court at The Hague, Netherlands. Since Sunday, Noriega has been held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center in southwest Dade County. Noriega is under 24-hour guard and kept separate from all other prisoners. He spends 23 hours a day in an 86-square-foot cell equipped with a bed, wash basin, toilet and a table. He is allowed into a 15-by-15-foot metal cage for one hour a day to exercise, prison spokesman Charles Davis said. ``He can play handball against a wall, or walk around or do calisthenics,'' Davis said. ``But he won't be engaged in any team sports. He'll be out there by himself.''

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Say Standards on Violence May Infringe Free Speech
DOC.TEXT: Proposed legislation that would clear the way for industrywide standards on television sex and violence might violate constitutional guarantees of free speech, a broadcaster said Tuesday. Such standards could lead to areas ``in which the government is more or less directing us as to how we should treat various subjects,'' said Charles E. Sherman, senior vice president of the National Association of Broadcasters. ``What then happens if another cause arises? Why then couldn't another senator indicate that he thinks television should be more positive?'' Sherman asked. Sherman's comments came at a roundtable discussion prompted by the results of a three-year audit of television violence and legislation proposed by Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., to restore some of the industry's ability for self-regulation. ``There are still legal scholars and people who feel that we would be subjected to First Amendment suits because we are indeed following government directions in trying to come up with standards on violence,'' Sherman said. The NAB, he said, had to defend the government-mandated ``family viewing hour'' in lawsuits brought during the 1970s by unions for both writers and directors who felt the restriction violated free speech guarantees. ``Violence in television is changing our society and not for the better,'' said Simon, urging the industry to develop its own standards. He said his bill, the Television Violence and Indecent Material Act, would allow that. The audit released Tuesday, part of a 22-year continuing study, developed a television violence profile of programming on the three major networks from 1986-1989. The study said 70 percent of prime-time programs use violence, with between five and six violent acts per viewing hour. Half of all prime-time dramatic characters are involved in violence, according to the study. The report was most critical of children's weekend daytime programming, saying it ``remains saturated with violence.'' ``In each of the past three seasons, children were entertained with more than 25 acts of (mostly humorous) violence per hour committed by more than seven out of 10 characters in nine out of 10 programs,'' the study said. Simon has proposed granting limited anti-trust immunity for three years to television broadcasters _ networks, cable television, local stations, producers and industry trade groups _ to allow them to develop and apply written guidelines on TV violence in entertainment programs. The bill is stalled in a House-Senate conference committee because of an amendment included by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to broaden its authority to guidelines on depictions of televised sexual activity Beth W. Bressan, who oversees program standards and commercial clearance for CBS, said the legislation wasn't necessary because it is unclear how harmful or undesirable television violence is to viewers. ``Last year, CBS received more than 600,000 pieces of mail,'' Bressnan said. ``Of that we had 92 viewers complaining that there was too much violence.'' Congress might do better ``to deal with the ills of society and the violence of the climate in society rather than trying to clean up the reflection of that society'' said Zev Braun, producer of the top-rated series on the Vietnam War, ``Tour of Duty,'' which includes graphic violence.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Pitches Payroll Tax Cut to AARP
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan on Tuesday pitched his plan to cut Social Security taxes to the nation's largest senior citizen group, disputing President Bush's claims that the plan would lead to benefit cuts. The New York Democrat said the financial soundness of the system would be protected under his proposal to reduce the payroll tax to stop the government from using surplus Social Security revenues to pay for other programs. ``There would be no risk to benefits at any time,'' he told the American Association of Retired Persons. ``We are having the system perform just as it was originally intended to do.'' But at the White House, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady assailed Moynihan's proposal as ``the height of folly.'' Brady said Americans have faith in the Social Security system as it currently works. ``People don't talk about it. They think the money is there'' in the Social Security trust funds. ``He says because of the surplus, you can reduce the taxes. I say that's goofy,'' Brady said at a White House briefing. Moynihan's concern is that Social Security's growing trust fund reserves are being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit and to pay for other government programs. His solution is to halt the buildup of the reserves and return Social Security to a pay-as-you-go system in which taxes would be raised in the next century to finance retirement benefits paid out then. Moynihan said that if the government continues to use the trust funds for other purposes, it could cause a loss of trust that could be a ``seismic event.'' ``This has the makings of a massive loss of trust,'' he said. Moynihan said the government should be forced to stop using Social Security revenues for other purposes before it becomes ``inextricably dependent'' on them. ``Now is the moment to do it,'' Moynihan said. ``You wait five years ... and they will have a $3 billion-a-week habit.'' Moynihan rejected the Bush administration's rival proposal to gradually shift the Social Security surpluses out of the deficit calculations, saying it puts off dealing with the problem. The senator addressed the AARP's national legislative council, which has not yet taken a position on his proposal. Speaking to reporters after his speech, Moynihan indicated that his tax-cut plan may become intertwined in Congress with the president's proposed cut in the capital gains tax. ``If a capital gains tax comes to the floor of the United States Senate, there's going to be an amendment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Runs Off Runway After Engine Fails
LaserPhoto ROC1
DOC.TEXT: An AeroCancun jetliner carrying 166 passengers aborted takeoff after one of its two engines failed and skidded off a runway early Tuesday, officials said. No one was injured in the 12:30 a.m. incident at the Greater Rochester International Airport. ``He didn't go airborne, but was very close to where he would have been committed,'' airport administrator Ronald Durand said. ``I would say it was a matter of seconds before he would have gotten airborne.'' The DC-9, a charter flight headed for Cancun, Mexico, wound up mired in mud and snow at the end of the runway. Federal Aviation Administration manager William Reed said the engine may have failed after ingesting snow or a chunk of ice.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Claims Prosecutor Misconduct in Kidnapping Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with opening arguments; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Floria lawyer accused of conspiracy in the kidnapping of socialite Annie Laurie Hearin had blamed Ms. Hearin's husband for the loss of his property, a prosecutor said in opening statements today. Assistant U.S. Attorney Patricia Bennett also said a man resembling defendant Newton Alfred Winn of St. Petersburg was seen in Ms. Hearin's neighborhood in a white van a week before her kidnapping. She said the evidence will also show he wasn't seen by family and friends in Florida between July 23 and 28, 1988. Winn, 65, says he is innocent and was in St. Petersburg when Mrs. Hearin was abducted from her Jackson home July 26, 1988. Mrs. Hearin, then 72, has not been found. Mrs. Hearin's husband, Robert M. Hearin, is among Mississippi's wealthiest people, with investments in oil, gas and banking. His fortune is estimated at $100 million. A note discovered in the foyer of the Hearin home listed 12 people, including Winn, who had been involved in legal battles with School Pictures, Inc., a business in which Hearin had been a stockholder. Bennett charged that Winn held Hearin responsible for a 1983 lawsuit filed by School Pictures against him. As a result, Winn's property was seized and sold in October 1986. Winn is charged with conspiracy to kidnap, mailing a threatening letter and perjury. If convicted on all charges, he faces up to life in prison. No one has been charged with carrying out the kidnapping itself. ``There's another side to the story,'' defense attorney Ed Marger argued today. ``In this case, the evidence will explicitly show that the government cannot show that my client is guilty.'' Before opening statements, Marger argued for admission of tape recordings that he said contain evidence of misconduct by an FBI agent and Robert Hearin Jr., the missing woman's son. ``They are sensational because they reflect a relationship between the Hearin family and the FBI that is improper,'' Marger said. Assistant U.S. Attorney James Tucker said intercepting and recording conversations is illegal and that the law prohibits the tapes from being used. ``It doesn't matter that it was a cellular phone,'' Tucker said. ``That just makes it a misdemeanor.'' U.S. District Judge Tom Lee said he needed to research the law before ruling on the request but returned the tapes to the defense, saying the wiretap law apparently doesn't apply. Hearin mailed checks totaling nearly $1 million to the 12 people named in the ransom note. Winn returned his $145,000 check. Winn is accused of arranging for a second ransom note to Hearin. The letter, in Mrs. Hearin's handwriting, said her captors would seal her in a cellar if the nearly $1 million was not paid to the 12 former franchise holders of School Pictures of Mississippi. Hearin paid the money after the second letter arrived at his home.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting In Moscow Delayed
DOC.TEXT: Talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze have been postponed a day because of a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, the State Department said today. Baker and Shevardnadze will meet Feb. 8-9 in the Soviet capital at the suggestion of the U.S. government, said State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler. They had planned to hold their talks Feb. 7-8. The one-day delay was announced as Cable News Network reported that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was considering resigning as chief of the Communist Party while retaining his post as Soviet president. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of the CNN report, ``I have no idea. We've never heard of it before. I have no information.'' CNN, in a report from Moscow, quoted a ``well-informed and usually reliable Communist Party source'' as saying Gorbachev ``may try to leave his closest ally, Alexander Yakovlev, in charge of the Communist Party while he follows popular pressure to remove the party from its monopoly control of political power.'' Ms. Tutwiler said of the delay in the Baker-Shevardnadze talks, ``It simply makes more sense to have the Soviets complete their plenum before beginning this important ministerial.'' The issues to be discussed in the talks include arms control and the war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed government and U.S.-armed rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Militias Clash for Control of Christian Heartland
DOC.TEXT: Maverick Christian Gen. Michel Aoun ordered his troops Tuesday to take over all bases of a rival militia as the sides prepared to fight for control of the Christian heartland. Police said five combatants were wounded when Aoun's 8th Brigade stormed a major barracks of the Lebanese Forces, the Christians' main militia, in east Beirut. Crack commandos of the 8th Brigade, trained by U.S. Marines in 1983, seized the militia's Tahwita barracks in the residential district of Furn el-Shubbak after a 90-minute firefight, a police statement said. The army claimed militiamen shot down several posters of Aoun with rocket-propelled grenades in the low-income neighborhood and then took shelter in the base. ``Troops seized the Tahwita barracks and rounded up the outlaws,'' said a police statement issued in east Beirut. It did not give the number of arrests. It said four of the injured were Lebanese Forces militiamen and one an Aoun soldier. All were hospitalized. Aoun, in a statement issued on his Radio Lebanon station, said he had ordered his 20,000 troops to take over all other barracks of the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia throughout the Christian enclave. ``No militia barracks are allowed henceforth to remain in the eastern area,'' Aoun's statement said. ``Anyone who wants to carry arms should join the army. The country cannot be rebuilt if it still has militias.'' The declaration suggested a long-expected showdown was imminent between Aoun and the Lebanese Forces commander, Samir Geagea, the only Christian warlord with the potential to challenge Aoun's authority in the enclave. The Lebanese Forces have four major bases controlling the enclave's 30-mile Mediterranean coast. Voice of Free Lebanon radio said Geagea was holding crisis talks with senior aides ``in an effort to defuse the confrontation.'' Aoun's troops control the mountaintops of the 310-square-mile enclave in the Metn and upper regions as well as all inlets from west Beirut, the northern district of Batroun and the central mountains. Aoun moved against the Lebanese Forces in February last year, when his troops flushed out the militia from Metn in a four-day crackdown that left 82 people killed and 200 wounded. The new inter-Christian shootout came as Aoun's troops and Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen skirmished intermittently with automatic fire across Beirut's dividing Green Line. Police said four people were wounded. Police said Aoun's troops established complete control over Furn el-Shubbak and the adjacent residential districts of Ein el-Rummaneh and Sinn el-Fil in east Beirut by nightfall. There was no word whether the troops would push against the Lebanese Forces' main strongholds in and around Jounieh. Rumors have been sweeping east Beirut recently about mounting differences between Aoun and the Lebanese Forces. Both Geagea and Aoun have repeatedly denied such reports, despite their open disagreement over recognizing President Elias Hrawi as head of state. Geagea recognizes Hrawi, elected president Nov. 24 under an Arab League-brokered plan to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war. Aoun, however, has rejected the peace accord because it does not include a deadline for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. He also refused to recognize Hrawi's election.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Chad to Put Turbulent Past Behind
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Tuesday pleaded for reconciliation and unity in this African country still recovering from civil war and hostilities with Libya. ``After the ordeals, the country is now on the road to renewal,'' the pontiff said. ``Chadians have chosen the path of unity and peace. I hope this peace consolidates itself ... in a constant search for forgiveness and reconciliation.'' The pope traveled to Chad from Burkina Faso on the final leg of an eight-day, five-nation tour of the impoverished Sahel region. Repression by the then-Christian government in 1965 against Moslem populations in the center and north of Chad led to fighting throughout the country which ceased only two years ago. In August, Chad and Libya agreed to put an end to 16 years of hostility and agreed to reach a political settlement over the 45,000-square-mile Aouzou Strip that separates them. Chad, however, says Libya continues to support rebel incursions into its territory from neighboring Sudan. The pope did not mention the Libyan dispute in his speeches. ``Your country has known much suffering, suffering due to drought and famine, suffering due to painful years of war,'' the pope said during a service at N'Djamena's Cathedral of Our Lady of Victories. ``Have confidence in life, have confidence in others, in order to rebuild ... a better Chad, a reconciled Chad,'' he said. The cathedral was gutted by mortar fire in 1980 during fighting between forces led by the current president, Hissene Habre, and his Libyan-backed archrival Goukouni Oueddei, president from 1980 to June 1982. The arched-roof yellow cathedral was restored in 1986 and sits on an open field in the center of town, in front of a military camp. ``I see this city reborn from ruins and discover tonight that your cathedral is bathed in youth and light,'' the pope said. The pope was greeted at the airport by Habre, a 47-year-old Moslem French-trained administrator and one-time guerrilla leader. A drum-and-bugle corps played the national anthem and ``Marching Through Georgia'' as a 21-gun salute was fired by French armored vehicles. In his airport speech, the pope offered his greetings to the country's Moslems. ``I salute them and assure them that I come as a man of dialogue and messenger of peace,'' he said in French. Chad has an estimated 5.5 million people, fewer than 400,000 of whom are Roman Catholics. Moslems account for about half of the population. The pope spends Wednesday in Chad before returning to Rome on Thursday. He also has visited Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau and Mali.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Urges Senate Ratification of Ban on Torture
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration joined human rights activists Tuesday in pushing for Senate ratification of a U.N. convention banning torture, but the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee expressed reservations about the measure. Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser, told the Foreign Relations Committee the administration ``places a high priority on early ratification of this important human rights treaty for substantive as well as symbolic reasons.'' While the convention ``breaks little new ground'' and would be unnecessary in the United States, Sofaer said it would put the United States in the forefront of the issue. Nevertheless, Sofaer said the United States would insist on some ``protective measures'' in the convention, which makes all acts of torture criminal offenses and requires parties to extradite those accused of torture. A two-thirds vote of the Senate is required for ratification, but the Foreign Relations Committee must first vote on the issue. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., said he wanted to hold more discussions with the administration before a vote is scheduled. ``Nobody favors torture,'' Helms said, while at the same time raising questions about the convention. He said he was disturbed that countries such as Afghanistan, Bulgaria, China and the Soviet Union have ratified the convention, countries Helms said have promoted serious human rights abuses. Rhetorically, he wondered if parties to the convention had condemned China for the massacre of students last summer in Beijing. ``I guess running over people with tanks is not torture,'' he said. The convention has been ratified by 55 nations, including Libya, a nation the United States has accused of promoting terrorism. Quizzed about Libya's membership, Sofaer said the United States would use the convention as a forum to promote change in places such as Libya. Twenty-two nations have signed the treaty, indicating they intend to ratify it. The torture convention came into force on June 26, 1987. Under the convention, a committee of 10 experts was established with power to investigate allegations of torture and receive reports. A number of human rights and other groups have supported the convention, among them Amnesty International, the U.S. Catholic Conference, B'nai B'rith International, and the American Bar Association. ``U.S. adherence to the convention against torture is of unquestioned importance,'' said Winston P. Nagan, the chairman of Amnesty International.

DOC.HEAD: Middle-Aged Bandits Suspected in Dozens of Robberies
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: An unusually elusive pair of bandits dubbed ``Bonnie and Clyde'' have led police on a frustrating chase around New England, allegedly robbing 27 stores and tying up clerks at knifepoint in the past five weeks. But the duo's age makes them more like Bonnie and Clyde's parents. Police are seeking Edward M. Aranjo, 46, and Ellen M. Marks, 50, in the spree, which grew to 27 with two robberies Monday. No one has been injured. In the mode of operation typical of all the crimes, a middle-aged couple threatened a 68-year-old woman with a knife and tied her to a pipe Monday before robbing her Franklin bookstore cash register of $130. That night, a Burlington video store was robbed and Bonnie and Clyde were the prime suspects again. Phone lines were cut, and a male clerk was held at knifepoint and tied up. The pair reportedly escaped with $160 in cash and $1,500 worth of instant lottery tickets. ``Their pictures are out there on TV so maybe they just want to go for it before they throw in the towel,'' said police Capt. Alan Leach of Coventry, R.I., one of dozens of police detectives tracking the case. ``All we know is, they're moving awfully fast.'' Police believe they're moving in a stolen car with Massachusetts plates. Leach said he saw the pair referred to as Bonnie and Clyde in a police Teletype message. Since Dec. 26, when a West Warwick, R.I., store was robbed of $65, Aranjo and Marks are alleged to have robbed small shops in Connecticut, New York, Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Massachusetts. The pair believed responsible for all of the crimes have rarely taken off more than two days between heists, police said. They are believed to sometimes dye their hair and wear hats and sunglasses, but otherwise they are not heavily disguised, police said. Their biggest take so far has been $400, in the town of Attleboro. ``They're sure not going for a million dollars at one fell swoop,' said Leach. He believes they have holed up in a series of motel rooms and rooming houses in eastern Massachusetts, moving at least 15 times in the last two months. Typically, the robberies have occurred at small stores with just a single clerk, said police Detective Kevin Slattery of Framingham, where a store was hit Jan. 8. He said the male member of the team has brandished a large hunting knife. Leach said Aranjo has a lengthy criminal record including convictions on larceny charges and assault with a deadly weapon. Coventry police said Aranjo and Marks were arrested by Framingham police in July but Leach said he did not know on what charges. Coventry police would not comment. Both Aranjo and Marks are originally from Framingham, a community about 20 miles west of Boston. Marks' husband, who is being treated in an alcoholic rehabilitation clinic, has said he is dumbfounded by any possible role his wife might have in the spree and speculated she may have been coerced. George Marks told The Boston Herald that his wife met Aranjo when he drove her to the clinic for visits. Leach said that while no one has been injured, ``everyone reports being threatened and scared.'' The daughter of the woman held up at Annie's Book Stop in Franklin _ police would not release her name _ said she was shaken but otherwise unharmed. ``I was afraid she would go into shock,'' the daughter said while waiting for her mother at the police station. ``She couldn't stop crying. ``Her pocketbook was scattered all over, like they were looking for the keys to something. They didn't take her credit cards or anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenham Common Closure: The Women Will Stay To The End
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Pam Jones huddled under a tattered umbrella on a muddy patch outside this U.S. air base, where women have kept up an anti-nuclear vigil for nearly nine years. The base is to be closed in 1991, a symbol of the changing face of Europe, but Ms. Jones isn't leaving yet. ``We'll see it through to the end. No one will ever forget Greenham Common,'' she said Tuesday. Surrounded by a dismal clutter of broken chairs, plastic sheeting and the dying embers of a fire, she said, ``It's a time of celebration.'' Greenham Common has been a U.S. base for nearly 50 years. It's where Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower saw off his D-Day invasion troops, and it has been a rallying point for the anti-nuclear movement since it became a base for cruise missiles. It is one of 14 foreign military installations that U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is proposing to close in a cost-cutting measure. Cheney's announcement Monday was a blow to many of the local people in the wealthy, conservative Berkshire countryside around Greenham Common, 50 miles west of London. The base employs nearly 200 Britons and spends $40 million a year locally. ``We'll miss the Americans economically and we'll miss them as people,'' said Ted Ashton, chatting in the Ploughman, a local pub. ``When you play poker you deal from strength _ and that's what the Americans did here and it worked,'' said Ashton, 68. ``It's all been worthwhile.'' Mostly, the locals disdain the dozens of women who since 1981 have protested outside the base, but they more or less learned to put up with them. They also became used to the cruise missiles trundling on cumbersome launchers through the country lanes on exercises that became known as ``walkies.'' The big peace demonstrations of the 1980s, when Greenham Common was the focus of anti-nuclear protest in Western Europe, are just a memory. The protesters? ``They're an absolute nuisance and they've achieved nothing,'' said Ashton. But Ms. Jones, 35, a former secretary with a punk haircut who first camped at Greenham Common three years ago, thinks the protests and her vigil have been worthwhile. ``Women have gained enormous strength here, and it will always be a symbol of the peace movement,'' she said. Half the 110 cruise missiles deployed at Greenham Common have gone since the signing of the 1987 U.S.-Soviet agreement to eliminate medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe. The rest will be out by mid-1991. After that, under the new Pentagon proposals, Greenham Common will become a standby base, non-operational, with about 400 American personnel, compared with 1,645 now. A local movement is campaigning to transform the 1,046-acre base into a park. Left behind will be the concrete bunkers, part of the missiles' $105 million home; the VIP lounges spruced up for the Soviet inspectors who drop by under the 1987 treaty; and a long history. The United States took over the airfield during World War II, and from here Eisenhower, the Supreme Allied Commander, broadcast to forces braced for the invasion of Nazi-occupied Europe on June 5, 1944. ``The eyes of the world are upon you tonight,'' he told them. The women first pitched camp here in 1981, and 200 were living at the base's eight gates when the first cruise missiles to be deployed in Western Europe arrived at Greenham Common in November 1983. They became not just a peace movement, but a focal point of militant feminism, from which men are excluded. A half-dozen remain. As some move on, others come, staying for a few days or a few years. Thousands of women have lived at Greenham _ through rain, sleet and sunshine. They still break into the base, climb aboard the missile launchers or lie down in front of them. Hundreds have gone to prison for refusing to pay fines for damage or obstruction. It has been a long standoff between the U.S. troops and the women. ``I wouldn't say either side has won,'' said Lt. Mike Rein, the Air Force spokesman at Greenham Common. ``They have the issues they stand for and we have ours.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigator: Pilot Had Discretion on Fuel Emergency
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of the Avianca flight that crashed and killed 73 people had complete discretion in determining whether his Boeing 707 was in a fuel emergency and needed to land immediately, an investigator said Tuesday. Barry Trotter of the National Transportation Safety Board, the investigator in charge of the crash probe, said Avianca does not require pilots to declare a fuel emergency when levels drop below a certain point, he said. Officials at American Airlines and Pan American World Airways, which both had flights diverted from Kennedy International Airport the night of the crash, said the final decision on fuel emergencies on their flights rested with the pilot. A possible miscommunication between controllers has been raised in the crash, although federal officials defended the controllers on Monday. A final report on the cause of the crash is not expected for nine to 12 months. Investigators said Monday that tapes show the crew warned regional air traffic controllers that their fuel was low as they circled over New Jersey, about 45 minutes before the crash. That information was not explicitly relayed to the local controllers who were to guide the plane to Kennedy. The plane apparently ran out of gas and slammed into a hillside Thursday on New York's Long Island. The captain, Laureano Caviedes Hoyes, was one of the 73 people killed. Eighty-six people survived. The captain also asked for ``priority'' to land rather than declaring an ``emergency'' in telling the controller he could only stay in hold for another five minutes. Trotter said the controllers responded to the priority request by moving the flight from a holding pattern to an approach pattern, although the plane was not moved to the first slot among approaching planes. The plane's 37-minute wait during approach was not unusual due to the heavy traffic and bad weather, he said. ``Ultimately, it's the captain, although it's the function of interaction between the crew,'' said Pan Am spokesman Jeff Kriendler. An American Airlines jet was brought in shortly before the crash when its pilot told controllers it had just 14 minutes of fuel remaining. American spokeswoman Mary O'Neill said, ``It's the pilot's final say.'' Pilots who land without adequate reserve fuel are liable to be called on the carpet by the airlines or by federal authorities, Trotter said. The Federal Aviation Administration reported that in the two hours before the crash, 13 arriving planes experienced delays averaging 89 minutes at JFK and 33 planes were diverted to other airports. Winds reached 70 mph and wind-shear warnings were up. The pilot had 17 years experience flying into Kennedy, including three trips the month before the tragedy, Trotter said. But the air traffic controller he spoke with at the regional control center had just over six months full-level experience, he said. The other controllers involved at Kennedy and two other sites had an average of eight years experience, Trotter said. The NTSB planned to send investigators to Colombia this week to review maintenance records and gather other information about the plane, Trotter said.
