Trotter said foreign Avianca pilots must meet certain requirements in speaking and understanding English before they can fly in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Spoleto Festival USA Budget Increased by Almost $250,000
DOC.TEXT: Spoleto Festival USA has gotten a $246,000 hike in its budget for this year's annual art fair in Charleston, S.C., because of damage caused by Hurricane Hugo. The board of directors met in New York on Monday and approved the revised budget for the festival, which will be held May 25 through June 10. A preliminary budget of $3.9 million was approved by the board in October. The increase is necessary because of storm damage to some of the buildings used by the festival and other financial conditions, said board treasurer Melvin Solomon. Hurricane Hugo crashed ashore in Charleston on Sept. 21, killing 29 and causing $5.9 billion in damage in South Carolina. The board usually meets this time of year in Charleston, but it met in New York because of a gala benefit held Monday at Lincoln Center. The benefit was expected toraise at least $200,000 for the festival, the Gibbes Museum of Art, the Charleston Symphony Orchestra and the Trident Community Foundation. Much of the festival's programming already has been announced, including a repeat of last year's production of ``The Marriage of Figaro,'' a presentation of the medieval version of ``Tristan and Isolde,'' the theatrical version of ``Salome'' and a opening night gala with Leonard Bernstein on the podium.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Defends Bush Budget
DOC.TEXT: White House Budget Director Richard G. Darman on Tuesday defended President Bush's $1.23 trillion budget against Democratic criticism of gimmickry and rosy predictions and tried to snuff out a movement to cut Social Security taxes. There are far fewer ``gimmicks,'' such as shifting payments from one year to another to make the deficit look smaller, than in past budgets, Darman told the House Budget Committee. ``I think everyone of them (in the new budget) is defensible,'' he said. As for projections of greater economic growth and less inflation than private economists are forecasting, Darman pointed to the administration's figures from July as ``amazingly accurate.'' ``You are not dealing with people who are totally out of bounds,'' he said. Darman spent most of the day before the committee listening to Democratic members complain that the budget, which Bush sent to Congress on Monday, does not reflect a changing world because it proposes $292.1 billion for the military in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. ``You've blown the opportunity for economic growth by spending more on military,'' said Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif. She said the administration proposal to save money starting in 1994 by eliminating several military bases was an effort to intimidate lawmakers who might prefer less spending for defense. ``Why are some kinds of cuts good but other kinds are not?'' Darman asked. Darman was peppered with questions about Social Security, specifically a bill by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. That bill, which has drawn the interest of several lawmakers but opposition from the administration, would cut payroll taxes as a way to keep the government from using surplus Social Security taxes to finance other federal programs. ``It is my personal opinion that he (Moynihan) never intended the plan to be taken as seriously as the press has taken it,'' Darman said, implying that Moynihan was simply trying to draw attention to the practice of using Social Security taxes for purposes other than providing benefits to retirees. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the committee, interjected: ``I get the impression that he is quite serious about the proposal.'' At the White House, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told reporters Moynihan's proposal ``is the height of folly'' and ``goofy.'' Bush's budget proposes that once the federal deficit is eliminated _ and predicts that will be in 1993 _ Social Security taxes that are not needed to pay benefits immediately be used only to retire government debt. Darman bristled when Rep. James Slattery, D-Kan., said ``Social Security is the biggest lie we have told the American people in maybe this generation,'' calling Bush's proposed remedy ``another scam, another scam.'' ``You're saying ... that (federal) debt is no good, that we are bankrupt,'' Darman said. ``The day that ... U.S. treasuries (securities) are no good is a day I think none of us will ever see. ``Our proposal is not smoke and mirrors. It will really get the debt down. ... There isn't a trace of dishonesty in this presentation.'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, senior Republican on the Budget Committee, threw Darman one of the few bouquets during the hearing. ``I happen to think it (the budget) is a pretty good beginning,'' he said. Panetta said he found more gimmicks in the budget than Darman acknowledged. ``If the president is not serious about confronting the deficit issue, why should Congress be serious?'' Panetta asked. ``Of course the president is serious,'' Darman retorted. ``I am serious. ... I wish you had taken that on faith.'' As for gimmicks, he said he has a list of more than 100 that Congress has used to reduce the deficit. The new budget anticipates a $63.1 billion deficit in fiscal 1991, although congressional economists say the figure is likely to approach $100 billion. The budget would rely on spending reductions, user fees and selected tax increases _ but no general boost in income taxes _ to cut the deficit from the 1990 level of about $124 billion. ``I don't see a single tough choice in your budget,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. ``At a time when this president has the political support ... (to push through a radically changed budget) he just sort of walks away from it.'' Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., said the budget reflects ``a view of America that is not shared by a lot of people in my district.'' ``There's more to what we are doing than perhaps your constituents know,'' Darman replied.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's New Budget: Will It Set the Stage for New Taxes?
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON AP) _ To hear some members of Congress tell it, President Bush's ``no new taxes'' budget may have just set the stage for a $20 billion tax increase this year. As the administration launched a defense of its tax and spending blueprint Tuesday, various influential Democrats said they viewed the Bush budget as an open invitation to raise taxes given the fact that Bush included a number of ``revenue raisers'' in his own budget. Both House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said they were willing to accept Bush's proposal to raise revenues by $21.7 billion but they said that Congress was likely to radically alter the mix on how that money was obtained. ``That revenue figure in total is something that we an accept,'' Sasser said. ``Unfortunately, in Bush's budget, it is not legitimately achieved.'' While the president proclaimed that his 1991 spending plan would slash the deficit in half ``without raising taxes,'' the budget actually included a hodge-podge of increases in taxes and user fees that would bring in an additional $21.7 billion in the 1991 fiscal year, which starts next October. The Bush budget proposes $15.7 billion in new tax revenue, which is offset by $1.8 billion in tax cuts. In addition, the president proposes raising $5.6 billion in new user fees charged for providing government services, $1.6 billion in the sale of government assets and $600 million in other new receipts, bringing the total to $21.7 billion. Critics of the Bush budget charge that the administration has recycled a variety of proposals, many dating back to the Reagan administration, that Congress has rejected in the past. One retread is a proposal to assess federal Social Security taxes on state and local government employees in the handful of states who are not now covered by the levy, a $3.8 billion revenue raiser that Bush unsuccessfully sought last year. Other proposed revenue increases would extend the soon-to-expire 3 percent tax on long distance telephone calls, increase the tax on airline tickets from 8 percent to 10 percent and pick up $2.5 billion by beefed up enforcement at the Internal Revenue Service. Bush's biggest revenue raiser for next year is actually a tax cut, the proposed reduction in the capital gains tax, the levy on profits made from the sale of assets such as stocks or real estate. Bush estimates that would bring in $4.9 billion in additional money in 1991 as people rushed to sell assets to take advantage of the lower tax, but critics charge that the proposal would lose money in later years because of the lower tax bite. Panetta suggested that Congress might consider compromising on the capital gains cut sought by Bush if the president was willing to consider tax increases in other areas, possibly a higher top tax rate for individuals or a boost in energy taxes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady told reporters Tuesday that the administration was optimistic about the chances for getting a reduction in capital gains passed this year after failing to do so in 1988. ``All of the comments I have heard by returning congressmen and senators indicate to me that they think it has even a better chance'' this year, Brady said. But complicating the tax debate this year is a rival plan by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to slash Social Security taxes by $62 billion in 1990 and 1991 by rolling back two scheduled rate increases. Brady, speaking to reporters at the White House, said the administration would not support Moynihan's proposal as part of a bargain to get the capital gains tax cut approved and he assailed Moynihan's proposal as ``goofy.'' Brady said that Americans have faith in the Social Security system as it currently works. ``People don't talk about it. They think the money is there'' in the Social Security trust funds, Brady said, terming Moynihan's proposal to return the surplus to taxpayers as ``the height of folly.'' ``He says because of the surplus, you can reduce the taxes. I say that's goofy,'' Brady said. If Bush does accept revenue increases as part of the negotiations over his new budget, it would not be the first time. Last November, as part of a deal to reach an agreement on a budget for the current fiscal year, Bush accepted almost $8 billion in tax increases and nearly $2 billion in tax cuts, for a net tax increase of $6 billion. The agreement was part of a $14.7 billion package of measures, including spending cuts, to reduce the size of the 1990 deficit, currently estimated at $123.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Second Crash Victim Was Carrying Cocaine in His Body
With AM-Jetliner Crash
DOC.TEXT: A man who was badly injured in the crash of a Colombian jet has passed 18 condoms containing cocaine, police said Tuesday. The man, Antonio Zuluaga, is the second passenger from the airline who allegedly had swallowed packages of cocaine. Another man, Jose Figeroa, was found to have packets of cocaine in his intestines when doctors operated on him the day after the crash to stop internal bleeding, authorities said. Nassau County Detective Brian McCormack said a nurse at the County Medical Center called police Monday night to report that Zuluaga, 46, had passed four condoms containing cocaine. Sgt. Richard Snizek said the man has since passed 14 more packages. Each measures about three-fourths of an inch by 1{ inches and has about 8 grams of the drug. Zuluaga has been charged with possession of cocaine. He is in critical condition with a fractured spine, broken ribs, a dislocated hip and possibly a broken knee. Avianca's Flight 52 from Bogota and the Colombian drug capital of Medellin crashed in Cove Neck late Thursday, killing 73 people.

DOC.HEAD: Party Official Blasts Azerbaijani Leaders For Unrest
With AM-Baltic Mediators, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior Communist Party official on Tuesday accused Azerbaijani leaders of not taking strong enough action to prevent ethnic violence in the southern republic. Vyacheslav A. Mikhailov, the No. 2 official at the party Central Committee's Ethnic Relations Department, said Azerbaijani officials used ``slack tactics'' in dealing with extremists in the Azerbaijani People's Front, the grass-roots political group that has organized anti-Armenian protests. Azerbaijan's party chief, Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, lost his job and was expelled from the party Jan. 24 after being accused of serious mistakes that led to the bloodshed. Anti-Armenian riots broke out in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku on Jan. 13, and Soviet troops stormed into the city a week later. At least 197 people have been killed in the strife, by official count, with 125 of them dying after the arrival of Soviet troops. Mikhailov told reporters the Azerbaijani authorities did not act to prevent the rampages. He said they could have ``isolated extremists'' and denounced them but instead granted them ``concession after concession.'' The Moscow official also said some members of Azerbaijan's law enforcement agencies ``did not adopt the best form of behavior.'' He did not elaborate. Some Armenian refugees from Baku have claimed police did nothing to stop terrorists from attacking them. Extremists took advantage of authorities' inactivity to incite nationalist hysteria, Mikhailov told a news conference. It should have been clear to Azerbaijani officials, he said, that attacks on Armenians were ``deeply thought out.'' He said Moscow officials will be following closely how the newly installed Azerbaijani leadership copes with the unrest and works to restore people's faith. Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow, reported that extremists blocked buses and trams in Baku on Tuesday and forced passengers off of them. The official news agency Tass reported that no shots were fired in Baku Tuesday morning. It quoted the city's military commandant as saying the city was gradually returning to normal, with mass transit, stores and other businesses open. A total of 36 people were detained in the previous 24 hours in Baku for violating emergency regulations, the dispatch said. Tass said extremists seized a mosque and disrupted businesses in the Hachmassk region of Azerbaijan. It said six ``terrorists'' were detained. In Nagorno-Karabakh, the disputed region of Azerbaijan that is populated mainly by Armenians, the regional governing body condemned the ``anti-Armenian policy of the Azerbaijani leadership.'' In an appeal to the national legislature in Moscow, Nagorno-Karabakh's legislature also rejected Azerbaijan's right to govern the district because ``Armenians in Azerbaijan are facing genocide.'' The appeal was reported by Interfax.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Protests Romania's Treatment Of Opposition
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Tuesday accused the ruling National Salvation Front in Romania of intimidating the political opposition and said the department's human rights director, Richard Schifter, was in Bucharest ``forcefully stating our concerns.'' Alan Green Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Romania, lodged a protest ``and asked that the right of all political groups to peaceful protests be fully protected,'' Margaret D. Tutwiler, a department spokeswoman, said. ``We will be greatly saddened if the hope for democracy and human rights, won at such great human cost in Romania, were to be lost by a retreat to the habits and practices of an old totalitarian era that should be completely discarded,'' she said. The front, in power since the ouster Dec. 22 of Nicolae Ceausescu, has organized massive demonstrations in Bucharest in response to a protest Sunday by three opposition parties. The pro-government demonstrators have demanded the dissolution of the opposition Peasants' Party and Liberal Party. ``We are deeply troubled by what appears to be active intimidation of legitimate organizations which are seeking a legitimate, independent role in Romania's new political order,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. The stern statement was the latest in a series criticizing actions by the front. So far, the State Department has not directly challenged either its authority or the justice system in Romania, which led to the summary execution of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, and the trial, now underway, of ousted hard-liners. On Monday, Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said anti-front demonstrators were protesting the predominance of Communists in the provisional government and the front's recent decision to run candidates in elections scheduled for May 20. ``There should be no backsliding on the part of transitional officials as Romania moves from revolution to democracy,'' Boucher said. In Tuesday's statement Ms. Tutwiler credited the government with taking ``significant strides'' toward democracy and respect for human rights. She said, however, that many of the groups opposed to the government apparently fear it ``is intent on stealing the revolution from the democratic forces which ousted Ceausescu in order to perpetuate communism in Romania.'' While the Bucharest government has postponed the elections from April to May in deference to these concerns, ``opposition parties continue to argue that they do not have enough time to organize, recruit candidates and publicize their programs and that they are not being given sufficient air time on the government-controlled media,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Group Announces Study of U.S. Penal System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to clarify that the American Friends Service Committee is a Quaker organization.
DOC.TEXT: A Quaker organization said Tuesday that the American penal system Quakers helped create 200 years ago is a failure and announced that they have formed a commission to reexamine the nation's criminal justice system. ``The compelling need in the United States is for transformation of our priorities,'' said Stephen G. Cary, chairman of the board of the American Friends Service Committee. Cary called for ``a new awareness that the strength of a nation does not lie in might but in education and jobs and homes and medical care for all its people.'' Cary said that when Quakers helped create the first penitentiary system, they had hoped for ``a rehabilitative, rather than a punitive, focus.'' The new National Commission on Crime and Justice is composed of black, Hispanic, American Indian and Asian-American experts and community activists from around the country. Throughout the year, the commission will organize a series of hearings and public education tours of prison facilities across the nation under a program called ``200 Years Of The Penitentiary Project.'' By 1990, one million men and women will be held in U.S. prisons and jails, according to the committee, which released statistics saying 46 percent of state prisoners in 1984 were black and 10 percent were Hispanic.

DOC.HEAD: Swarm of Small Quakes Hit Desert Area
DOC.TEXT: Five small earthquakes struck the desert in Southern California within two hours Tuesday morning, seismologists reported. None of the quakes registered higher than 2.9 on the Richter scale of ground motion, said Hall Daily of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The epicenter was 25 miles north of El Centro, near the Salton Sea, Daily said. El Centro is about 175 miles southeast of Los Angeles. The quake times and Richter readings were as follows: 6:01 a.m., 2.8; 6:02 a.m., 2.8; 6:04 a.m., 2.9; 6:16 a.m., 2.7; 7:54 a.m., 2.5. Daily said lab seismologists reported similar waves of small quakes have struck the region before. He said the temblors occurred in the Brawley seismic zone, a complex web of faults. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude, or the height of quake-generated shock waves recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS New York-datelined item in AM-People, a0622, to CORRECT city to Palm Springs sted Palms Springs
DOC.TEXT: Kathleen Sullivan, the soon-to-be-divorced CBS anchorwoman, says she's looking for a date, preferably a ``rugged outdoorsman.'' ``I need a date for next Monday night,'' she told Joan Rivers during a taping of ``The Joan Rivers Show'' to be aired Feb. 1. ``Do you know anyone?'' Her ideal man is ``6 feet 2, 185 pounds about, sandy hair, rugged outdoorsman _ someone who likes to ride, fish, hunt ... with a certain amount of pride and stability,'' Sullivan said. The anchorwoman of ``CBS This Morning'' said of her current marital status, ``I'm a divorced woman, or soon-to-be-divorced, what time is it?'' and described as ``hard'' the breakup of her marriage. Her husband, she said, ``is a very good friend. The saddest thing was that he couldn't move to New York or wouldn't move to New York. And he wouldn't share my life and it was very hard for me to share his. So it became a fait accompli.'' Her husband, real estate developer Michael Kiner, lives in Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: US Angry with UN Chief over Rights Situation in Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials expressed anger Tuesday with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar for what they said was his reneging on a promise to issue a report on human rights in Cuba. But Perez de Cuellar's spokesman said that he had made no such commitment and that the U.S. officials with whom he spoke had misunderstood him. The State Department said U.S. officials had asked Perez de Cuellar to make a report on his assessment of the rights situation in Cuba after he had indicated he would prepare such a report if asked to do so by one or more U.N. members. Other U.S. officials, asking not to be identified, said that Perez de Cuellar had made the commitment to Vice President Dan Quayle, among others. They said Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected to send a letter to Perez de Cuellar setting forth the U.S. position. The Bush administration has been eager to highlight what it regards as the abuse by Cuban authorities of Cubans who testified before a six-member U.N. rights group that visited the country on a fact-finding mission in 1988. The State Department maintained than Cuban persecution of these and other human rights activists ``warrants urgent action by the commission.'' Asked about the Bush administration's irritation over the issue, U.N. spokesman Francois Guiliani said Perez de Cuellar had told Quayle in December that any member of the commission could bring the topic up for discussion. Perez de Cuellar would issue a report if asked to do so by the commission but had not promised Quayle he would take such a step at the request of a single member, Guiliani said. He also said Perez de Cuellar's position was based on the commission's rejection of an amendment at the 1989 session asking him to issue a report on the rights situation in Cuba. An official at the Cuban diplomatic mission here, insisting on anonymity, said it was possible that some Cubans who testified before the commission are now being detained. But he said the detentions were for violations of Cuban law and were not connected to their testimony to the commission.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Housing Chief Sees Critical Need for Low-Income Housing
DOC.TEXT: A former federal housing administrator told a Senate panel Tuesday that there is a critical need for a new goverment program providing more housing for low-income people. Philip N. Brownstein, a Washington lawyer and former Federal Housing Administration commissioner, testified before a Senate Banking Committee subcommittee investigating the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Brownstein, on a panel of former federal housing officials who testified, served under presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. Brownstein said that while housing programs may vary in the ways they fund or encourage development of housing for low-income people, any program will be costly. ``For all intents and purposes, all housing programs responding to lower income needs have been terminated,'' he said. Without more construction, he said, the homeless will grow and ``its human and economic cost will dwarf any price tag attached to federal housing efforts.'' ``It is critical today that some program be instituted and funded which will result in new units being put in place by means of new construction or substantial rehabilitation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 1985 Farm Law Will Help Eliminate Soil Erosion: Conservation Group
DOC.TEXT: Historic provisions in 1985 farm law will help farmers move rapidly toward the elimination of severe soil erosion on much of the nation's cropland by the mid-1990s, a private conservation group said Tuesday. A study of more than 1,000 farms in selected areas across the nation showed that the conservation provisions of the 1985 Food Security Act have been a main force in prodding and luring farmers into protecting soil and water resources. The report, released here by the Soil and Water Conservation Society of Ankeny, Iowa, focused on the 1985 law's provisions governing the use of fragile, highly erodible land, and wetland areas. Specific deadlines were set for farmers to comply with Agriculture Department regulations for conservation planning and project completion. The law also established a 10-year Conservation Reserve Program with a goal of removing 40 million to 45 million acres of highly erodible cropland from production by the end of this year. About 34 million acres have been signed. Under the program, farmers must plant the idled land in protective grass or trees. In return, they get federal cost-sharing payments to establish the soil cover, plus annual rental payments for 10 years. Those average about $50 per acre annually. ``For the first time in history, receipt of most federal farm program benefits _ commodity price supports, agricultural credit and crop insurance _ became legally contingent on the application of appropriate land stewardship practices by agricultural producers,'' the report said. The law's four conservation parts outlined the Conservation Reserve Program, or CRP, and so-called sodbuster, swampbuster and compliance provisions that the report said have been generally well accepted by farmers. ``We may well accomplish a greater measure of erosion control on the nation's cropland in the next five years than we have accomplished in the preceding 50,'' said project director Max Schnepf. ``But this report makes it clear that a great deal remains to be done by farmers and by the federal government if we are to realize the full potential of the 1985 farm bill's conservation provisions,'' he said. Schnepf said the project began in mid-1988 and that the report is the first of several planned for a three-year evaluation. Norman A. Berg, a member of the society's steering committee and former head of the Soil Conservation Service in USDA, said the 1985 farm law for the first time linked farm policies and program benefits to sound conservation practices. ``The law provided leverage we did not have before to curb erosion and protect wetlands,'' Berg said. Society officials said the study, which had financial support from the Joyce Foundation of Chicago, was ``by no means a statistically valid survey'' of all U.S. land. However, the project did entail a close look at conservation work in 22 representative counties. The report said: _Conservation Reserve Program field checks show that soil erosion will be reduced 91 percent on land enrolled in the program, although the total tonnage of soil saved may be lower than USDA has reported. _Sodbuster and swampbuster provisions, with the potential loss of federal benefits, appear ``to be discouraging farmers from improperly cultivating fragile land and converting wetlands to crop production.'' However, there have been violations, and ``USDA officials are not adequately monitoring or enforcing the policies in some areas.'' _Conservation compliance, which requires farmers to adopt and carry out conservation plans will result in significant reductions in erosion if the plans are implemented. But final implementation ``will be difficult for a significant number'' of farmers unless they adopt adopt additional, low-cost erosion-control practices.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe At A Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the major developments Tuesday in Eastern Europe.

EAST GERMANY _ East Germany's Communist Party endorsed for the first time eventual reunification with West Germany as it sought to improve its standing before elections in March. Ousted leader Erich Honecker was freed from prison and put in a nursing home after a court, rejecting government demands he be jailed, declared he was too ill to remain behind bars pending his treason trial.

BULGARIA _ The Communist Party opened a crucial congress expected to result in a showdown between reformers and hard-liners. Party chief Petar Mladenov fiercely attacked the ousted leadership in the opening speech, but he offered few ideas for change. Mladenov refused opposition demands to delay elections that are scheduled in May. He proposed splitting the post of party chief and state president.

ROMANIA _ The trial of four leaders in the ousted regime resumed, with one witness contradicting testimony that Nicolae Ceausescu's defense chief was killed because he refused orders to shoot at pro-democracy demonstrators. Col. Corneliu Pircalabescu testified that the defense chief, Vasie Milea, shot himself in the heart because he could not bring himself to order unarmed protesters to be killed. The provisional government issued a draft of its proposed voting law for May elections, guaranteeing free direct elections for Parliament and president as well as access to the media, a key opposition demand. U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Schifter and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Paula Dobriansky arrived to assess the political situation.

PRISTINA, Yugoslavia _ More than 6,000 ethnic Albanians chanting ``Democracy!'' clashed with riot police Tuesday in the city of Podujevo, and two people were reported killed in another town as protests spread across Kosovo province.

SOVIET UNION _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with East German Premier Hans Modrow, who said the president appeared to soften his anti-reunification stance. Gorbachev ``did not rule out such a prospect in the future,'' Modrow told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Who Illegally Released Alleged Trafficker Gets Jail Term
DOC.TEXT: A judge who illegally released a reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel has been sentenced to six years in prison for obstruction of justice, a federal court said Tuesday. Fabio Pastrana Hoyos was fired from his post as a customs judge in the Caribbean coastal city of Cartagena after his 1986 order freeing Jorge Luis Ochoa Vasquez, considered the second in command of the drug trafficking cartel. Pastrana was found guilty Monday of obstruction of justice and sentenced by the federal court in Cartagena, the court's clerk said in a news release. In 1986, Ochoa was arrested in Spain on charges of shipping 127 fighting bulls to Colombia. The United States asked for his extradition on drug trafficking charges, and Colombia asked for his extradition on the contraband charge. Spain opted to send Ochoa to Colombia, where authorities also had a U.S. request for his extradition. On Aug. 17, 1986, without ever having Ochoa brought before him, the customs judge sentenced Ochoa to 28 months in prison for illegally bringing the bulls into Colombia. He then suspended the sentence, released Ochoa immediately and put him on probation. Pastrana claimed that he released Ochoa because the Justice Ministry had not told him Ochoa was wanted for extradition. But an investigation showed the judge had been notified to keep Ochoa in custody for the extradition request. Ochoa was arrested again Nov. 20, 1987, but again a judge set him free. That judge, Andres Enrique Montanez, of a federal court in Bogota, also was fired. Montanez was never charged with a crime in releasing Ochoa. No major trafficking suspect has ever been convicted and served a prison sentence in Colombia, presumably because drug traffickers either bribe or threaten judges to release them. Five judges have been killed by traffickers since the government started cracking down on the traffickers Aug. 18. In the last five months, 13 middle-level trafficking suspects have been extradited to the United States. One Medellin cartel leader, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was killed in a shootout with authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Leaders Say Emigres Not Urged to Settle in Occupied Lands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with comment from Jordan's prime minister about preparations for Arab delegation to travel to the Soviet Union, INSERT 3 grafs after 13th pvs; pickup 14th pvs, `Six left-wing...' ^By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders on Tuesday denied the government has urged Soviet Jews to settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians are fighting for their own state. The comments followed protests from the United States, the Soviet Union and Arab leaders, who said establishing settlements in the territories could hurt chances for peace. Yossi Ben-Aharon, head of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office, said, ``Anyone who comes to Israel can go wherever he chooses.'' He said only a few hundred immigrants out of a total of 12,000 last year chose to live in the territories, which Israel captured from Jordan and Egypt in 1967. The Soviet Union and United States criticized Shamir's statement earlier this month suggesting Israel has to retain the occupied territories to settle Soviet immigrants. In Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Ministry on Monday condemned any plan to endanger ``Soviet emigres by using them to crowd Palestinians out of their own land'' and suggested such settlements could undercut Moscow's plans to further liberalize emigration laws. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said that ``the Soviet message was not expressed very politely, and we are sorry about it, especially because it is based on misunderstanding over the positions of the Israeli government.'' He added: ``Nobody is sending people to this or the other place.'' Israel's top diplomat in Moscow, Arye Levin, told reporters he did not believe the Soviets were threatening to curtail immigration. He flew to Israel on Tuesday for what he described as a ``family visit.'' Another Shamir aide, Avi Pazner, suggested that the Soviets were trying to allay fears of Palestinians and Arab leaders. ``The Arabs are exerting heavy pressure on the Russians concerning immigration, and Mr. Shamir expressed his hope that the artificial storm would pass,'' Pazner said. U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher was quoted by the Jerusalem Post as telling reporters in Washington on Monday that ``putting even more settlers into the territories is an obstacle to the cause of peace.'' The Arab League's representative in Washington on Tuesday said U.S. comments on the issue have not gone far enough. Ambassador Clovis Maksoud told a news conference that Washington should reassess its policy against settlement of Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Jordan's prime minister, Mudar Badran, said Arab countries were discussing sending a delegation to the Soviet Union and other East bloc countries to discuss the situation. He said continued immigration ``will create instability and tension in the region.'' ``We have good contacts and friendly relations with many Eastern bloc countries and soon an Arab delegation will move to brief those countries on the dangers of this issue,'' Badran said. He spoke to reporters at the end of a two-day visit by Syrian Premier Mahmmoud Al-Zouebi. Both men said they would welcome an emergency Arab summit to discuss the issue. Six left-wing parties have filed no-confidence motions in the Knesset, or Parliament, over Shamir's remarks this month. Israeli legislators and Soviet Jewish activists in Israel have accused Shamir of endangering Jewish immigration at a time of growing concern about anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Yitzhak Abrahmson, head of a Soviet immigrants' group, said on Israel radio he was worried that Shamir's statement could lead to a Soviet clampdown on exit visas. The Jerusalem Post daily reported Tuesday that Georgi Martirosov, head of the Soviet diplomatic mission in Israel, met with Foreign Ministry officials over the issue and blamed Shamir for the delay in ratifying an agreement to resume direct flights between the two nations. Martirosov said Shamir's statements ``hindered any possibility of moving this process forward,'' the Post said. Deputy Finance Minister Yossi Beilin told army radio that officials from a six-member Soviet commercial delegation visiting Israel also expressed ``uneasiness'' over Shamir's remarks and ``linked these things with the development of our ties with them.'' Moscow broke diplomatic ties with Israel over the occupation of the territories. It supports Palestinian demands for an independent state in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and says restored ties with Israel are conditional on progress in Middle East peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Won't Bar Broadcast of Secretly-Taped TV Program
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice Tuesday refused to bar the television program ``Inside Edition'' from broadcasting scenes filmed with a hidden camera inside a New York City doctor's office. Justice Antonin Scalia, without comment, rejected an emergency request in which Dr. Stuart M. Berger's lawyers sought to block the broadcast. An ``Inside Edition'' spokeswoman said the program plans to include the scenes in a segment about Berger. A federal judge in Detroit ordered the program to keep the secretly recorded scenes off the air, but a federal appeals court panel overturned the judge's order as an unconstitutional ``prior restraint'' of free speech. Berger, author of several widely sold diet books, is under investigation by the New York State Department of Health's Office of Professional Medical Conduct for alleged unethical and fraudulent conduct. In its own investigation of Berger, the television program sent one of its producers to the doctor's office as a patient. Producer Amy Wasserstrom said in an affidavit she surreptitiously videotaped two visits she made to the office. Ms. Wasserstrom said Berger diagnosed her as suffering from an allergy to yeast and from chronic fatigue but another doctor told her she had no such ailments. Berger's lawyers said airing the office scenes will do irreparable harm to his reputation ``and the sanctity of his office.'' ``This case raises an important substantive issue dealing with the right of an individual to be free from the publication of information, and more specifically a videotape, illegally obtained by the very same organization which now desires to broadcast it to the 100 largest television audiences in the United States,'' Berger's lawyers said. U.S. District Judge Barbara K. Hackett in Detroit issued a temporary restraining order Jan. 18, blocking broadcast of the office scenes after finding they were filmed in violation of federal anti-wiretape law and New York law. A three-judge panel of the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati, however, unanimously ruled Monday that the restraining order was unconstitutional. ``We are satisfied that the district court clearly erred in its interpretation of First Amendment law,'' the appeals court panel said. ``Any prior restraint bears a heavy presumption against its constitutional validity,'' it said. ``Berger simply has not shown the type of irreparable harm that can justify a prior restraint.'' The syndicated television program is owned by King World Productions Inc. The case is Berger vs. King World Productions, A-516.

DOC.HEAD: Menem Accepts Resignation of Intelligence Agency Chief
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem has accepted the resignation of the State Intelligence Agency (SIDE) chief Juan Bautista Yofre, government officials said Tuesday. Yofre, who announced his plans to resign last week, was expected to be named to the Argentine delegation at InterAmerican Development Bank headquarters in Washington. A journalist and former member of the Radical Civic Union opposition party, Yofre joined Menem's election campaign in 1988 and served as the Peronist party candidate's press spokesman. The government announced this month the intelligence agency would be restructured and sharply reduced in size as part of an overall plan to cut public spending. Economy Minister Antonio Erman Gonzalez said 2,000 employees, about 30 percent of the SIDE staff, would be dismissed. Government officials denied Yofre's resignation was related to the weekend discovery of phone taps in Government House offices used by Menem and in the official presidential residence. Security officials declined to say who was believed responsible for the eavesdropping devices.

DOC.HEAD: African Country Removed From Marxist-Leninist List
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has removed Mozambique from a list of nations barred from receiving certain U.S. economic benefits because of their adherence to Marxist-Leninist principles, the State Department said Tuesday. ``The president made this decision based on Mozambique's move away from the Soviet Bloc in socialism and towards the West,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Among other actions, she said, Mozambique has: _Embarked on economic and political reforms that have included establishment of a mixed economy no longer controlled by central planning. _Joined the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and is adhering to an IMF program that has abolished many state enterprises and turned most land over to private farmers. _Officially abandoned Marxism at a 1988 party congress. Earlier this month, President Joaquim Chissano unveiled a new constitution that calls for direct election of the president and parliament and stresses protection of individual rights. With its removal from the list of Marxist-Leninist states, Mozambique is eligible to take part in a U.S. program under which the government helps finance exports to foreign countries. Mozambique has expressed interest in the purchase of U.S.-made airliners under this program.

DOC.HEAD: Editors:
DOC.TEXT: The LOS ANGELES story in PM-Names, a0444, about Darryl Strawberry's arrest has been killed. Strawberry was arrested, but NOT charged. A kill is mandatory. Make certain the story is not published. A substitute story will be filed shortly.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 1st and 5th grafs to CORRECT by deleting references to charges filed. A longer version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: New York Mets star Darryl Strawberry was arrested after allegedly threatening his wife with a pistol, police said. Strawberry was arrested at his Encino home early Friday and spent a short time in jail, Sgt. Woody Baca said Monday. Los Angeles Police Cmdr. William Booth said Strawberry posted $12,000 bail and is back with his wife, Lisa. ``It was very basic type stuff, a family dispute,'' Booth said. David Disco, a Los Angeles deputy district attorney, was to meet with police to discuss the case for a decision on whether charges will be filed. Two days before his arrest, Strawberry was involved in a paternity case in Missouri, where blood tests established he was the father of a child born in 1988 to a woman in St. Louis. Strawberry did not contest the finding and a judge took under study the amount of child support the All-Star outfielder must pay. Baca said police were called to the home after a report of domestic violence. Mrs. Strawberry, 25, said she and her husband had argued and that her 27-year-old husband slapped her in the face. Mrs. Strawberry then grabbed a metal rod and hit her husband in the ribs and wrist, police said. Mrs. Strawberry told police Strawberry got a handgun and threatened her. Police said Mrs. Strawberry showed no signs of injury but Strawberry had bruises on the rib cage and wrist.

DOC.HEAD: Space Partners Accuse U.S. of Acting in Bad Faith
DOC.TEXT: The United States' international partners in the space station program Tuesday bitterly accused NASA of acting in bad faith by excluding them last year when the station's construction schedule was extended. ``Partners do not operate at arm's length, nor do they make decisions unilaterally that will damage the interest of the other partners,'' Reinhard Loosch of West Germany told a congressional hearing. Loosch said he hoped the schism that developed was merely ``one of the teething troubles'' of the partnership, called the most advanced and costly international technological project ever undertaken. ``The government of the Federal Republic of Germany cannot hide its disappointment,'' said Loosch, West Germany's deputy assistant director for international cooperation. In July, when it appeared Congress might cut $400 million from the space station program, NASA planners secluded themselves at the Langley Research Center in Virginia and worked out plans to cope with the shortfall. The international partners were told in August of the changes, mainly a one-year delay in completing construction. Congress, too, was kept in the dark. Rep. Robert Roe, D-N.J., who chaired Tuesday's hearing of his House Committee on Science and Technology, said ``regrettably, this committee learned of this exercise from media reports and was not directly consulted.'' The committee expressed its anger last year at a hearing to which it summoned top NASA management. It turned out that NASA was denied only $200 million and some design changes were restored. But Reimar Luest, director general of the European Space Agency, said that in the revised plan ``only U.S. payloads were adequately provided for. ... Anything related to ESA was left in the mists of a new, second part of the program ... for which a detailed schedule was not available.'' He said the action violated international agreements ``and offered no protections for ESA's major investment.'' ESA, which represents 10 nations, is obligated to provide the Columbus laboratory module, an unmanned free-flying polar platform and another free flyer _ at an investment of about $3 billion. Japan signed on to provide an experiment module, also to be permanently attached to the space station base, at a similar cost. ``If NASA's space station budget were cut, then the burden of the cuts must be equitably shared among the partners, it should not be shifted by NASA onto the other partners,'' Luest said. Learco Saporito, a senator in Italy's parliament, said that not only the space station but also the credibility of the United States as a partner was at stake. ``It concerns the very substance and basic foundation of the international cooperation and of the entire project of the space station,'' Saporito said. ``Such doubts may have negative consequences in those countries, like Italy, which are your closest allies.'' Any major change in fundamental elements would present Japan with ``great difficulties'' in continuing with the cooperative program, said Akira Kubozono, executive director of Japan's national space development agency. ``Suspicion of the Japanese public on the stability of the international space station program could raise great difficulties in continuing to secure political and financial support to this program,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pell Proposes $511 Million for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats on Tuesday proposed a half-billion dollar aid package, $200 million more than President Bush wants, to foster emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. The bill, introduced by Sen. Claiborne Pell, R-R.I. and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman, would augment $738 million in aid already approved for Poland and Hungary with $511 million targeted at Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. Pell said he would not be surprised if his proposal is increased during the legislative process ``in view of the profound interest of the United States in supporting positive developments in Eastern Europe.'' Bush, as part of the fiscal 1991 budget he proposed Monday, asked for $300 million as a ``special assistance initiative'' for countries behind the crumbling Iron Curtain, including Poland and Hungary. White House Budget Director Richard Darman told the House Budget Committee Tuesday that the distribution of the $300 million, which would need congressional approval, had not yet been determined. Pell's proposal includes liberalizing trade relations and providing non-economic assistance, such as management training, to the Soviet Union. It also would tell the administration to confer most-favored-nation trade status on all of the Eastern European countries at the earliest possible date, support their admission to the International Monetary Fund and make them eligible for Export-Import Bank loans and loan guarantees. In addition, the bill would provide $43 million to foster the development of non-communist parties and free elections in the Soviet bloc counties plus an immediate $80 million in food aid for Romania. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. and a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said he applauded ``the idealism'' of Pell's proposal but noted that the countries to which the aid was to be expanded still are under heavy communist influence. Soviet troops remain; elections have not yet occurred, and multiple layers of old communist bureaucracy remain, he noted. ``We have to be cautious,'' Lugar told reporters. ``Thus far we are not in a position to send a lot of money into areas where the people we are trying to assist may not be in a position to have a whole lot of control over it.'' Pell's bill devotes the bulk of the proposed aid, $250 million, to capitalizing a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development with the intent of facilitating billions of dollars in private investment across the East Bloc. Businessmen told the House Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday they are not willing to make those investments unless Congress goes beyond waiving and actually repeals the 1974 Jackson-Vanik and other restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern bloc countries.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Advisers Try to Stop Reported Abuses by Liberians
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials stepped in to stop abuses of civilians by government troops tracking rebels, but no U.S. officers have engaged in combat, a U.S. official said Tuesday. Rebels of the National Patriotic Front invaded the Nimba County region, which borders Ivory Coast, on Dec. 24 in a bid to oust President Samuel Doe. Liberian authorities say the rebels killed about 200 people, including 16 government officials, before government troops quelled the attempt. Since then, the troops have been trying to chase down the insurgents and Africa Watch, a U.S.-based human rights' group, has accused the Liberian military of killing at least 200 civilians during the search. Amnesty International has quoted refugees and other sources as saying hundreds of civilians were killed by soldiers or rebels, and the U.S. Embassy had expressed concern. In Washington Tuesday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said American military advisers have been working with the Liberian military for a number of years. She said that following reports civilians were being harassed in Nimba County, Doe sent a U.S. officer she identified only as Gen. Craig to take charge of the forces there and instructed him to end these abuses. Two American officers from the U.S. military mission in Liberia accompanied Craig and other senior Defense Ministry officials to assist them in ending abuses, she said. Mrs. Tutwiler said the U.S. officers were acting only as advisers and not engaged in combat operations. The chief of staff of Liberia's armed forces, Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar, said the U.S. officials went to Nimba County to ``assess the situation.'' Some of the more than 60,000 refugees who fled to the Ivory Coast and Guinea to escape the fighting have accused the soldiers of atrocities. The rebels also have been accused of killing civilians. Doe warned soldiers last week that they could face firing squads if they harm civilians. He said the rebel force came from Ivory Coast and was led by former civil servant Charles Taylor. He accused Ivory Coast of aiding the insurgents, a charge denied by that nation. Taylor, a Liberian government official from 1980 to 1983, was accused of embezzling nearly $1 million and fled to the United States, where he was imprisoned pending extradition. He escaped in 1984. Doe came to power in a coup in April 1980 in which President William Tolbert, a descendant of freed American slaves, and most of Tolbert's political allies were killed. Doe has withstood several coup attempts. Liberia was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves. It is the biggest recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa and is the only West African nation that routinely allows U.S. military planes to refuel on its territory.

DOC.HEAD: Canceling V-22 Leaves Special Operations in Quandry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs `Lindsay refused ...' to UPDATE with Cheney quotes. Picks up 8th graf pvs `But Lindsay ...'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision to cancel the tilt-rotor V-22 Osprey aircraft in the new military budget leaves the nation's elite fighting forces ``struggling'' to find an aircraft for high-risk, high-speed missions, their commander said Tuesday. ``If the V-22 is finally canceled, I've got to have something else,'' said Army Gen. James Lindsay, the four-star general in charge of the Special Operations Command. ``I had my day in court more than once. ... I lost,'' said Lindsay, whose specialized forces include the Green Berets and such super-secret fighters as the Navy SEALS. Several thousand of his forces were involved in the Panama invasion. For the second consecutive year, Cheney has proposed shutting down the $27 billion program to produce the helicopter that can also fly like a plane, arguing it is too expensive. Last year, Congress did not provide any money for procurement but did approve some funds to continue research and development. The debate is only one of many that will erupt on Capitol Hill over Cheney's fiscal 1991 spending plan, which has been criticized by opponents as favoring big-ticket nuclear programs over other weaponry. Lindsay refused to directly criticize Cheney's decision, saying he was ``not an expert'' in budget matters and that Cheney ``is in a very different position than I'm in. He has to make pretty tough decisions.'' ``That's right. When you lose, you lose,'' Cheney said in an interview with wire service reporters when told of Lindsay's remarks. ``The V-22 struck me as a lower priority item than other of the things we need to fund. ... We can't afford everything we'd like to have. But Lindsay argued that even if the V-22 is canceled, he will still need a high-speed craft that can drop men into position and return to pick them up, many times when no airfield is available. Lindsay cited the failed operation to rescue U.S. hostages in Iran as a case where a fast-moving, refuelable transport plane could be used on a long-range mission. The United States launched an airborne attempt in April 1980 to free hostages being held in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, but the mission was called off after one of the helicopters developed engine trouble in a staging area in the Iranian desert. Eight Americans were reported killed and several injured in the collision of two planes in the subsequent withdrawal of the U.S. force. Lindsay said he'd lost to those who say his men can get by with helicopters and the Fulton system that allows a flying C-130 transport plane to pluck men from the ground. ``I need something better than that, and I need something reasonably fast,'' he said. ``And it can't be a helicopter. I need more agility.'' Lindsay said he did not have another vehicle to do the job, and did not know where he was going to get one if the V-22 is canceled. ``At this point in time, we are struggling with it,'' he said, adding that even the V-22 did not meet the speed or range requirements he would like. Asked if he could name missions where the V-22 was absolutely necessary, Lindsay said he couldn't cite a specific case. ``But I can tell you, I just know we're going to be faced with situations, where if we can go deep and go fast and not be tied to airfield, that is a distinct advantage,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Proposes Student Police Corps
DOC.TEXT: The mayor proposed a student police corps to augment the police presence downtown and provide young people with part-time jobs. The goals are to ``create more connections'' between police and youths and to set up a new recruiting device for the police department, Mayor Don Fraser said Monday. Under the plan, to be made public in the mayor's State of the City address late Tuesday, trained high school and college students equipped with uniforms and radios, would be supervised by beat officers. The students would not carry weapons. Fraser said they would call for assistance if they witnessed crimes. He discounted any threat to their safety. ``The likelihood is that they would always be in pairs, by themselves or with officers,'' he said. ``The risks would be pretty low.'' Deputy Mayor Rip Rapson said many details have yet to be worked out. ``It is a request from the mayor to the chief to develop the idea and to assess whether it will work,'' he said. Such things as pay, insurance, ways to protect the young people's safety and training still must be worked out, he said. Fraser said he wants the plan to take effect in 1991. It would include active minority recruiting and be open to all students ages 17 to 22. ``We're always looking for opportunities to make the police department a more attractive place of employment for minority candidates and this is one way of doing that,'' Rapson said. Downtown business leaders have been pushing for more police protection in response to a growing perception that the central business district is becoming increasingly unsafe. ``There have been a number of incidents involving groups of kids downtown, such as anti-social behavior, fights among kids,'' Rapson said. ``We have had reported incidents of kids hassling shoppers and there's even been one incident of a potential fight among gang members that was broken up by police.'' Police Chief John Laux's reaction, Rapson said, was ``positive, but guarded.'' Laux was out of the office Tuesday and not available for comment, his secretary said. Fraser said he expects the police officers' union, the Minneapolis Police Federation, to endorse the plan. Lance Zentis, head of the Police Federation, did not immediately return a call Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Accuser Pleads to Misdemeanor, Testifies to Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A District of Columbia employee, who law enforcement sources say has accused Mayor Marion Barry of cocaine involvement, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor drug charge Tuesday then immediately began testifying before a grand jury investigating Barry. James McWilliams testified for two hours after his plea, which U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens called ``another significant step'' in the investigation. Barry, who was arrested Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, has denied under oath using drugs with convicted cocaine dealer Charles Lewis at a downtown Washington hotel more than a year earlier, in December 1988. The charge against McWilliams stemmed from allegations of visits to Lewis' hotel room, some of which prosecutors say coincided with Barry's visits. Meanwhile, Washington's WRC-TV, quoting unnamed sources, said Barry could be indicted within two weeks by the grand jury, which has been looking into allegations of perjury and cocaine possession. McWilliams, a city motor vehicles department employee and a longtime Lewis associate, declined to comment either before or after his grand jury testimony. He pleaded guilty to a charge of aiding and abetting drug possession, which carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. According to a source familiar with the case, McWilliams has told authorities he was present once when the mayor and Lewis disappeared into the bathroom of the hotel room for a short time. McWilliams told prosecutors he smelled crack cocaine and then saw the mayor emerge from the bathroom under the influence of the drug, the source said. McWilliams, 57, was called before the grand jury investigating the case last January but refused to testify at that time. Carole Bland Jackson, a former business partner of the woman who was in a hotel room when Barry was arrested this month in an FBI sting, also said in weekend interviews that she was present when Barry used cocaine at a 1986 party. The mayor is in Florida at a private facility being treated for what aides say is primarily an alcohol abuse problem. Lewis pleaded guilty to cocaine conspiracy charges last November in Washington and was convicted on cocaine distribution charges in the Virgin Islands last spring. Lewis, who is cooperating with prosecutors, testified under oath during his plea bargaining session in November that he had supplied Barry with crack cocaine. In meetings with prosecutors in the past week, McWilliams also said the mayor called him after Barry's ties to Lewis became public and told him he trusted him to keep quiet about what he had seen in the hotel room, two law enforcement sources said. Barry has said he only called McWilliams to urge him to cooperate with authorities investigating the case. At a news conference, Stephens refused to say whether he intends to question bodyguards assigned to the mayor on a round-the-clock basis, but said prosecutors ``will want to cover any witness that might be able to provide information regarding this case.'' The prosecutor also said he would be comfortable showing jurors a videotape of Barry and Rasheeda Moore in the hotel room before and during Barry's arrest on Jan. 18. Stephens also denied the investigation of the mayor was racially motivated, as NAACP President Benjamin Hooks and others have suggested. ``Our job is to follow allegations ... diligently and aggressively,'' Stephens said. ``We have done so without favor to position, to race, politics or any other consideration.'' He said Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, will be given both original and enhanced copies of the tape next week.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Says Drug Warriors Have Already Won `A Victory Over Confusion'
DOC.TEXT: National drug policy coordinator William Bennett said Tuesday that while the nation is a long way from winning its war against drugs, it already has achieved ``a victory over confusion'' about how to fight the battle. And that includes, he said, enough federal, state and local financing for treatment programs to get ``very close'' to meeting the medical and rehabilitation needs of drug abusers. Although some urban and community leaders have charged that the Bush administration has seriously underfunded the treatment and education components of its new, $10.2 billion anti-drug budget, Bennett made clear his rejection of that notion. In fiscal 1991, he said, ``We will bring the treatment budget up to $1.3 billion or $1.4 billion, which, when you combine the treatment availability from all sources _ federal, state and local _ will provide access for something like 1.7 million people to receive treatment. ``We're getting very close to capacity _ to responding to the full dimension of the treatment need,'' he said. In an address to the National Press Club, Bennett repeated his declaration of last week that the nation is ``beginning to end'' the war on drugs. The best news for now, he said, is a political consensus on strategy and the public's ``hardening attitude about drug abuse. ... We now have almmost the entire country becoming more intolerant and more conservative on the issue.'' Bennett noted that he will testify next week before the Senate Judiciary Committee on drug strategy, and ``my guess is that some members of that committee will try to argue fundamental differences. In fact, fundamental differences among Democrats and Republicans on major issues of drug strategy exist no more, though there will always be small differences in emphasis.'' ``And that's the thing. There's been a victory over confusion. That much we surely have won. There's now a great consensus on the various steps we can take.'' He said that overall drug use in America ``went down from 1985 to 1988 by some 37 percent. So says the National Institute on Drug Abuse. ``It's down in urban America, as well as rural America. It's down in white America, as well as black America. It's down in rich America, as well as poor America.'' Still, he acknowledged, ``even as we've seen a decrease in overall drug use, we've seen an increase in addictions. This will be the case for a few more years. We will see the number of people who are addicted keep rising.'' ``There are great casualties,'' he said. ``Some large percentage of a million drug addicts will be dead, or walking dead among use for years to come.''

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Quality Down Slightly Last Year
DOC.TEXT: The quality of last year's wheat crop was down slightly from the 1988 harvest, an Agriculture Department report said Tuesday. Of the 13,363 samples checked by the department's Federal Grain Inspection Service, 56 percent were graded No. 1, compared with 64 percent in 1988. Ratings by grade are based on a number of factors, including test weight per bushel, damaged kernels, foreign material, and shrunken and broken kernels.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Predicts de Klerk Will Lift Some Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf to ADD Pretoria City Council voting to lift apartheid restrictions after 20th pvs, `Also Tuesday'; pickup 21st, `Johannesburg, the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BLM4
DOC.TEXT: Police used batons, rubber bullets and tear gas Tuesday to prevent 1,000 blacks from marching on a stadium to protest a boycott-busting English cricket team's match against a South African university team. The cricket team's tour has caused confrontations every place the visiting cricketers have appeared, including their hotels, where black employees refuse to serve them. The team is defying an international ban on sports contact with South Africa. There also were demonstrations by black squatters in rising political unrest only three days before President F.W. de Klerk is to open Parliament. He is expected to discuss reforms in South Africa and ease the emergency regulations in force since 1986 to quell anti-apartheid activity. A pro-government newspaper, The Citizen, predicted that de Klerk would end news media restrictions but probably not ease other regulations. It also said the release from prison of black nationalist Nelson Mandela could be delayed because of the unrest. The stadium clash between police and blacks was at Bloemfontein, in the Orange Free State. One policeman punched a black teen-ager in the chest with a baton, another pressed his truncheon around a black youth's neck to bring him down, as some demonstrators threw stones at police vehicles and erected burning tire barricades in the streets of Mangaung township. Obed Nkosi, an organizer for the anti-apartheid National Sports Council, said 30 people were hurt. Police said 45 people were arrested and one white businessman was slightly injured when his vehicle was stoned by protesters. An approved protest by about 500 people outside the stadium was allowed to take place. Police also fired tear gas at 150 black squatters protesting their eviction from Kraaifontein, a neighborhood designated for whites outside Cape Town. The Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent anti-apartheid activist, was among those affected by the tear gas. Police in Cape Town urged the public to stay out of the city center Wednesday and Friday ``because people are bound to get hurt'' when action is taken to stop planned protest marches to police headquarters and Parliament. The march organizers refuse to seek official permission, and police Capt. Gys Boonzaaier said, ``The police are obliged to act if the gathering is illegal. We are going to take action and disperse them. ... We would like to urge the public to stay away ... as people are bound to get hurt.'' Since de Klerk became president, the government has allowed several massive marches to take place without the organizers seeking permission. De Klerk was quoted as telling police commanders two weeks ago that they are no longer ``required to prevent people from gathering to gain support for their views.'' But police officials say as long as there are regulations against ``illegal gatherings'' _ those without magisterial permission _ police must act to stop them. The stage is set for a major confrontation Friday, when black activists hope to have 10,000 people marching toward Parliament as de Klerk makes his speech outlining his plans for reforms leading to negotiations with the black majority on a new constitution. ``There are firm indications that ... de Klerk will announce some easing of the state of emergency in his opening address to Parliament on Friday,'' said The Citizen, which has good government sources. ``The first of the emergency regulations expected to be lifted are those which were imposed on the media.'' The paper said Mandela's release is not expected until mid-February at the earliest. Reporters earlier in the week said Mandela might not be freed until March. The emergency restrictions prohibit journalists from being at the scene of political unrest, and from reporting anything about it, or describing any police activity without permission. Journalists are also banned from reporting a wide range of statements that the government considers subversive, including calls for boycotts, economic sanctions, and criticisms of the military. The restrictions have not been uniformly enforced, but photographers and television crews have been most affected. They are often arrested and have their film confiscated. Also Tuesday, the Johannesburg city council declared the city's business districts open to tradesmen of all races but expressed regret it could not do the same for residential areas. The City Council of Pretoria also voted to open most municipal facilities and the business districts, but pro-apartheid Conservative Party members said they will try all legal means to reverse the decision, government radio reported. The new policy applies to buses, libraries, city hall and other buildings. Johannesburg, the nation's largest city, has already opened municipal facilities such as toilets, libraries, public halls and swimming pools to all races. Buses remain segregated in many areas of the city. ``We are moving toward a discrimination-free city,'' said Marietta Marx, a Johannesburg council member from the National Party, which controls the national government and established the policy of apartheid. ``But we still have the contorted logic, which is a black can work anywhere but not live there,'' said Ian Davidson, a council member of the anti-apartheid Democratic Party. City councils have no power to desegregate residential areas, schools or hospitals, which are controlled by the national government.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Large Numbers Killed by Army in North and South Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD Iraq denying Amnesty report; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Tuesday that the Iraqi army attacked dozens of villages in southern Iraq this month and killed many civilians in an apparent attempt to capture army deserters. Also Tuesday, an Iraqi Kurdish group claimed the Iraqi military killed more than 60 fishermen this month. Iraq denied both reports. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights monitoring group, said in a statement it received reports that ``large numbers of people including unarmed civilians and army deserters were killed or wounded'' in southern Iraq. The statement said the attacks targeted more than 30 towns and villages in the predominantly Shiite Moslem region from Jan. 10 to Jan. 23. Amnesty said it was not clear what prompted the military attacks. But reports received by it ``suggest the attacks were related to government attempts to capture hundreds of army deserters.'' An Iraqi rights group, the London-based Organization of Human Rights in Iraq, said Friday that 10,000 people were killed or wounded in an army crackdown in southern Iraq. It said tens of thousands were left homeless after the raids. The group is recognized by the United Nations and coordinates its work with Amnesty. A spokesman for the Iraqi ministry of information invited journalists to visit the areas to investigate the reports. ``We invite any foreign reporter to come to Iraq and see for himself the false and fabricated story of Amnesty International,'' the spokesman, who asked not to be identified, told The Associated Press office in Baghdad. The marshes of southern Iraq were hiding places for army deserters during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, but hundreds surrendered to the army after the August 1988 cease-fire. Requests to visit the marshes in the past usually were rejected by the ministry of information, which supervises the visits of foreign correspondents throughout Iraq. Also Tuesday, a report by the London-based Kurdish Patriotic Union said more than 60 Kurdish fishermen were killed this month when Iraqi helicopter gunships attacked fishing boats on Lake Dukan in northwestern Iraq. The victims were civilians who had no connection to the Kurdish guerrillas fighting the government for autonomy, said the Kurdish group's spokesman, who spoke to The AP in Nicosia, Cyprus, by telephone. He refused to give his name. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unidentified Information Ministry spokesman as saying that the Kurdish report ``is slander and lies aimed at harming stability and security in the Kurdistan area.''

DOC.HEAD: Murder Trial Linked to Mail Bombs Delayed for Psychiatric Tests
With AM-Bombs-Two Cities
DOC.TEXT: A murder trial linked to the mail-bomb slayings of a federal judge and a lawyer was postponed Tuesday so doctors can complete psychiatric tests on the defendant. Jury selection in the Superior Court trial of Emmanuel Fitzgerald Hammond, 24, of Marietta was rescheduled for Feb. 19. Hammond, who is black, is charged with murdering Julie Love, 27, a white Atlanta preschool fitness teacher who was abducted more than a year before her body was found last summer. The prosecution has said it will seek the death penalty upon conviction. A letter claiming responsibility for the December mail bomb slayings cited Ms. Love's death and decried crimes by blacks against whites. Bomb-sniffing dogs were taken through the Fulton County Courthouse on Tuesday but found nothing, authorities said. Spectators were screened with metal detectors, and extra deputies searched purses and briefcases. The postponement came after Assistant District Attorney Richard Hicks told Judge Ralph Hicks he could not properly impanel a jury until defense attorney William A. Wehunt revealed whether he plans an insanity defense. Wehunt said psychiatric tests on Hammond had not been completed and that without results he could not determine Hammond's defense. The letter claiming responsibility for the bombs that killed federal appeals Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala., and attorney Robert Robinson in Savannah was signed by ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System.'' The letter expressed rage over Ms. Love's slaying, saying it demonstrated the writer's contention that the judicial system lets black men get away with crimes against white women. Hammond and his 20-year-old cousin, William Porter of Union City, were charged with the slaying. Porter pleaded guilty in November to felony murder, rape, kidnapping and armed robbery. He has not been sentenced, and is expected to testify against Hammond. Hammond, who police say was the triggerman, is charged with murder, felony murder, kidnapping and armed robbery.

DOC.HEAD: `Coupon' Connie Found Guilty in Conspiracy, Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: ``Coupon Connie'' claimed she clipped and traded like any housewife, but a jury convicted her Tuesday on charges she took part in a $2 million scheme to swap and redeem hundreds of thousands of bogus coupons. Connie Arvidson, 34, of Boca Raton, Fla., was convicted on two counts of mail fraud and one of conspiracy. ``She was the person knowingly buying and selling large numbers of coupons,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Steve Sucsy said Tuesday. ``Her statement to the effect she was only doing what any number of innocent housewives were doing was not so.'' The jury also convicted David Rees of Center Point of the only charge against him _ a conspiracy count, said Maureen Ruprecht, court coordinator for U.S. District Judge Sidney Fitzwater. A third defendant, printer James Floyd Richards of San Antonio, was cleared of all three counts against him. Mrs. Arvidson, also known as the ``Dumpster Lady'' because she would root through garbage bins looking for coupons, faces up to 15 years in prison and $750,000 in fines. Sentencing is scheduled March 23. ``I've always felt that I was being made an example of, so the prosecution ought to be happy,'' Mrs. Arvidson, 34, said after the verdict, adding she will not continue with her coupon business. The defendants were accused of counterfeiting more than 600,000 copies of coupons issued by 47 companies, including Procter & Gamble, Nabisco Brands Inc. and Campbell Soup Co. Prosecutors said Mrs. Arvidson bought the bogus coupons from San Antonio counterfeiter David Rackmill. Rackmill, who faces five years in prison for his role in the scam, pleaded guilty to mail fraud and conspiracy and then acted as an informant. An indictment last June said that beginning in June 1988, Rackmill obtained legitimate coupons and provided them to Rees along with a payment. Rees in turn would give the coupons to Richards for counterfeiting. Sucsy said Mrs. Arvidson used the coupons to buy the products, then sold them at flea markets. But her main income came through selling the coupons for more than she paid for them, he said. In opening arguments, Sucsy said Mrs. Arvidson also initially placed orders for the counterfeit coupons directly with Rackmill, but later became nervous and arranged for Rees to be middleman. Mrs. Arvidson's income from her coupon hobby was once estimated at $40,000 a year. But her attorney said the coupon swapping business only netted about $200 a week and she did not knowingly sell counterfeit coupons. The counterfeit ring was uncovered after a four-month investigation by the U.S. Postal Service. The defendants were arraigned last August and the trial began on Jan. 8. The jury deliberated for five days. Fitzwater ordered Mrs. Arvidson to post a $10,000 bond, while Rees was freed on personal recognizance. Seven other people were indicted, all of whom agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in exchange for leniency.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner to Allow Foreign Airline Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Foreign airlines will be allowed to expand service to more American cities in exchange for open markets for U.S. carriers, Transportation Secretary Samuel K.
