Skinner said Tuesday. ``Deregulation of the U.S. airline industry is working well,'' Skinner said. ``Now it's time that we work to deregulate international aviation markets. ``Let's push the dofree and unfettered competition for air transportation around the world.'' The Department of Transportation invited foreign airlines to apply for the one-year, renewable authority to provide air service between their home countries or wide open to and U.S. cities that don't have such service. Skinner said the decision would improve international service and provide evidence of U.S. commitment to competitive international aviation and ``willingness to try innovative ways to encourage other countries to adopt our approach.'' The new program is limited to cities where no U.S. or foreign airline provides non-stop or one-stop single-plane service from the foreign line's home country. To be eligible, an airline must come from a country that offers U.S. airlines an open market to operate air service.

DOC.HEAD: New City Council Wrings Out the Old, Brings in the New
DOC.TEXT: New city councilors with an anti-tax, anti-spending agenda shot into office, surprising even New Hampshire residents used to independent rule with an attempt to immediately overhaul the government. In a post-inauguration meeting Monday night, the council ordered no increases in the 1990-91 budget, no new services and a city-wide hiring freeze. It also canceled a grant application for money to build a homeless shelter. Councilors proposed a charter change to take away the city manager's sole authority to hire and fire department heads. Another proposal would enable voters, not the council, to decide the city tax rate. ``I did some housekeeping,'' said Thomas Tardif, the new mayor. ``Made some improvements, as I see it.'' The so-called ``Straight Arrow'' slate of candidates caused a stir in November by promising to oppose any budget proposals calling for a tax increase in the town of 16,000, 20 miles north of Concord. Voters elected a two-thirds majority to the council. New Hampshire is proud of independent local government. So why the fuss? It appears the Arrows have gone too far too fast. ``It's a matter of `You didn't use my ball to play, now I`m going to get even.' It's not a constructive council,'' said Armand Bolduc, a former councilor. ``I hate to think the city will have to put up with these clowns for two years.'' He said he has never seen a council do away with everything another council had done. Councilor Wesley Colby, not a Straight Arrow, was upset after the meeting. Six of the seven Straight Arrows elected to the nine-person council said they had met to discuss the plans before Monday night. ``They ran on an open-government platform _ I don't care if they say they had no formal meeting or not, that thing was orchestrated,'' said Colby. ``The arrogance of it all annoyed me.'' But James Burke, city attorney, said the process of changing a city charter is outlined in state statute, and is not a matter of local law. There will be a public hearing Feb. 8 on the proposed amendments. If there is an election scheduled after that, voters will decide any changes, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pipe Bomb Explodes at Church, Wois trying to piece it all together, but we
DOC.TEXT: haven't yet put all the pieces together.'' Police and federal agents were checking the mail and private deliveries to the church Tuesday morning. People near the independent charismatic church founded by Osteen told police they heard a loud pop followed by screams. Ms. Osteen, director of ministries at the 10,000-member church, was taken to Ben Taub Hospital, where she was listed in good condition with burns and bruises to her mid-section and upper legs. Welch said he was not sure of the kind of bomb, but police spokesman Sgt. J.C. Mosier said ``it was some sort of pipe bomb.'' Officer R.C. Smith said the area of the explosion was very smoky and powdery with an obvious odor of explosives. Smith said he was not certain of how the bomb was triggered. In December, nail-studded mail bombs killed a white federal judge near Birmingham, Ala., and a black civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga., in attacks investigators said were motivated by race. The Houston church is predominantly white. ``We have no idea what the motive is. We can't link this to anything else,'' said Bob Switzer, special agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said in response to questions about a possible link to the bombings in Alabama and Georgia. ``There's no indication. This is nothing more than a single incident.'' Welch said he did not know of any threats against the Osteen family.

DOC.HEAD: Third `Captive' Flight Test for Pegasus Rocket
DOC.TEXT: A NASA jet carried a Pegasus air-launched rocket over the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday during a dress rehearsal for the booster's first real launch in March, officials said. ``I'm very happy. This was a very good day for the Pegasus program,'' said Bob Lovell, vice president of Orbital Sciences Corp., the Virginia company that developed the 49-foot-long rocket in a private joint venture with Delaware-based Hercules Aerospace Corp. The 41,000-pound rocket, designed to put small satellites in orbit cheaply, was carried about 50 miles west of Morro Bay, attached beneath the wings of the B-52 bomber, said Nancy Lovato, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It was the third ``captive carry flight test'' for Pegasus, which remains attached to the jet during such tests. ``This third flight lasted two hours and reached a maximum altitude of 43,000 feet,'' Lt. Col. Ed Nicastri of the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, said in a statement. Two attempts to launch the rocket were simulated during the test flight, but the rocket _ which has a 22-foot-wide, delta-shaped wing _ wasn't released, he added. The B-52 took off from this Mojave Desert military base at 8 a.m. PST and landed at 10:01 a.m. PST, Lovato said. During its first real launch, Pegasus is to place in orbit a small Navy communications satellite, a NASA experiment and perhaps a small satellite that Virginia will use for environmental monitoring of Chesapeake Bay. During Tuesday's test, the rocket carried full-scale models to simulate the Navy and NASA satellites. The Pentagon and NASA want to use the small rocket to launch small military and science satellites, but Pegasus also is expected to attract business from companies, foreign governments and university scientists who need a cheap way to place payloads in orbit. Lovell said the cost will be $6 million to $8 million per launch, depending on how much business Pegasus gets. There were some brief losses of radio communication between the jet's crew and ground controllers during Tuesday's test, but were fixed quickly, Lovato said. ``We also had a launch lock light come on when it wasn't supposed to,'' but the jet's crew knew through backup systems that the rocket was still safely locked in place, Lovell said, adding, ``We need to get a better light bulb in there.'' Skies were clear when the rocket-bearing jet took off from Edwards Air Force Base, but weather was cloudy over the Pacific. So the test ``demonstrates the validity of the (Pegasus) concept, which is to take off over the desert where you almost always have good weather and fly above the storms to carry out a successful launch,'' Lovell said.

DOC.HEAD: A Laboratory for New Musicals Announced
DOC.TEXT: An ambitious, for-profit laboratory for new American musicals was announced Tuesday to produce 16 shows in four years using the talents of Harold Prince, Terrence McNally, Jimmy Webb, Erica Jong, Marsha Norman and Marvin Hamlisch. The organization, New Musicals, will present the shows in a theater complex at the State University of New York in Purchase, 25 miles north of New York City. ``This partnership refuses to accept the current depressed state of the American musical theater,'' said Martin J. Bell, producing director of the group. ``All the problems come from one source _ the cost of production,'' he said. He said New Musicals has agreements with Actors Equity, the Dramatists Guild and the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers which will enable it to lower production costs. The budget will be $10 million for the group's initial season of four shows, added Bell. Among New Musicals' other partners are Capital Cities-ABC Inc., which owns ABC television; Columbia Artists Management Inc., the classical concert management agency, and Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns and operates five Broadway theaters. Its first production will be a musical version of ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' directed by Prince, with a book by McNally and music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb. The show will star John Rubinstein and Kevin Gray and will play at Purchase on May 1 through June 10. Bell said ``Spider Woman'' will be followed by ``The Secret Garden,'' based on the classic children's novel by Frances Hodgson Burnett. The book and lyrics are by Norman, author of ``'night, Mother,'' and the music by Lucy Simon. It runs Oct. 23 through Dec. 23. The third offering is ``My Favorite Year,'' based on the movie which starred Peter O'Toole. The music and lyrics are by Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens. The run will be Jan. 8 through Feb. 16, 1991. The first season ends with ``Fanny Hackabout Jones,'' based on Ms. Jong's novel ``Fanny.'' Ms. Jong will adapt her own book. Music will be by Simon and lyrics by Susan Birkenhead. Its engagement will be March 19-May 19, 1991. Eventual Broadway productions of these shows are possible, but New York is not the only option, said Bell. ``We have an agreement with the National Alliance of Musical Theaters, which is a group of 70 theaters all over the nation, to present some shows.'' And there could be international agreements for productions of the musicals or the possibility of shared productions in non-profit theaters, he added. Among projects under consideration for future seasons, according to Bell, are a contemporary musical version of ``Pinocchio'' by Jimmy Webb; a musical about Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt by Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford and an unspecified work from Hamlisch.

DOC.HEAD: Resistance Says Iran Tries to Whitewash Human Rights Record
DOC.TEXT: Iranian resistance officials accused the Iranian government Tuesday of trying to conceal human rights abuses and impeding U.N. officials who conducted an investigation last week. ``What they saw was only the tip of the iceberg, but it was enough to show them what was really going on,'' said Aladdin Touran, spokesman for the People's Mujahedeen of Iran. It was the first outside rights investigation in Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution, and it came amid efforts by Iran's so-called moderate leaders to liberalize society and renew ties with the West. The investigators now are in Geneva, where they will present a report to a meeting being held by the U.N. Human Rights Commission. Touran told a news conference at the United Nations that the investigators visited only one of Iran's 653 prisons _ Evin Prison in Tehran _ and only were allowed to see a workshop. Touran said his group had presented the investigators with voluminous documentation of widespread rights abuses, including 2,000 written statements by alleged torture victims, and a list of 4,725 political prisoners, 1,786 torturers, 653 prisons and 30 mass grave sites. The Tehran government denies all allegations of rights abuse. Touran said the U.N. officials met in Tehran with some families of abuse victims. He said authorities beat and harassed the families of victims who held a demonstration and would let investigators talk with the protesters. ``There was a whitewash,'' Touran said, ``but the very fact that the visit took place represents a victory for the Iranian people, for the mujahedeen and for the international pressure that was brought to bear on the Iranian regime.''

DOC.HEAD: Schlesinger Proposes 200,000-Troop Cut in European Forces
DOC.TEXT: Former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger called on the Bush administration Tuesday to respond to dramatic changes in the East Bloc and plan a drastic cut of nearly 200,000 in U.S. forces in Europe. Schlesinger, who ran the Pentagon under President Carter from 1973 to 1975, acknowledged in testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee that for years he had opposed reductions in U.S. forces attached to NATO. ``Given this background,'' he said, ``I believe a certain weight can be attached to the following recommendation: ``We should plan now radically to scale back our forces in Europe. The time for that planning is now.'' Under questioning, Schlesinger said the U.S. force in Europe should number 75,000 to 100,000, down from the current 305,000 troops. Last May, before the drive for democracy hit high gear in many Warsaw Pact nations, President Bush proposed a ceiling of 275,000 on U.S. and Soviet ground and air force personnel. That would require a reduction of about 30,000 U.S. troops and about 325,000 Soviet troops. But Schlesinger said if the United States sticks to its current position on manpower reductions it may fall into a trap of ``legitimatizing the long-term presence of Soviet forces in Eastern Europe that might otherwise be withdrawn. ...'' The appearance by Schlesinger before the Senate Armed Services panel is part of a series of hearings the committee is holding on how the United States should respond to the lessening Soviet threat and its effects on the military budget.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Calls Base-Closing Plan `Political Gun' for White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to include comment from California congressman asking that a base in his district be closed.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee accused the Bush administration Tuesday of putting ``a political gun to the head'' of lawmakers with a partisan list of military base closings. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's list of more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations that would be closed or scaled back had ``potential.'' But he objected strongly to the way the administration wants Congress to deal with the list. ``This is merely a list of candidates for closure,'' Aspin told reporters at a news conference. ``The upshot is that the list can be changed. Bases can be deleted or perhaps added. That creates hostages for the administration. Vote against a veto override, your base is safe. Vote to override, your base is threatened. ``The process is dead,'' Aspin said of the administration approach, and he introduced legislation that would create a bipartisan commission to make new base-closing recommendations. Cheney, in an interview with news service reporters, disputed Aspin's assertion that his ideas were dead or amounted to political blackmail. ``The idea I'm putting a gun to their head is not a valid one,'' Cheney said. The secretary said that because his list is not final, changes could be made in it. Cheney he said he wouldn't rule out the idea of a blue-ribbon panel and said he had made his suggestions because it takes a long time to study such closures. Aspin's suggested panel _ similar to a commission created by Congress in 1988 _ would produce an all-or-nothing list of closings for approval or rejection by the defense secretary and Congress. The recommendations of the 1988 panel to close 86 bases were adopted by Congress last year. Cheney, in presenting his $292.1 billion military spending plan for fiscal 1991, proposed on Monday a list of bases for closing or realignment that would be considered by lawmakers on an individual basis. ``This puts a political gun to the head of a member with a base in his or her district,'' Aspin said. The lawmaker contended Cheney's process ``opens an enormous bargaining bazaar.'' Aspin cited, as an example, the recent House and Senate votes on President Bush's veto of legislation dealing with extending visas for Chinese stuents in the United States. ``If you've got a list of potential bases to be closed and the vote comes up on say, overriding the veto on the China thing, what you've done is create an awful lot of bargaining chips for the administration when it goes into negotiating with congressmen and senators on how their going to vote on the veto override,'' he said. Questioned whether that was Cheney's intention in proposing the bases for closing, Aspin said: ``You have to ask Mr. Cheney.'' The Wisconsin Democrat also said the defense secretary's list clearly is political with 22 of 32 domestic bases slated for closing in Democratic districts. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said Cheney has ``produced an unbalanced, partisan hit list,'' of base closings. She said, ``Such an unbalanced package is just plain unacceptable.'' However, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., declined to accuse the Bush administration of playing politics in its choice of bases, and said, with a grin, ``I've heard some Republicans are very angry'' with the selections. The speaker did say the decisions must be based on ``strategic needs of the country,'' not ``political considerations.'' Cheney, in the interview, also took issue with the charge that his closure list was partisan. He said a large number of bases were in Democratic districts because there are more Democrats in Congress and because a large number of military installations are in Democratic-controlled states. ``California gets about a third of the defense budget. ... Texas has a large number of bases. It's really not political,'' he said. ``That's a petty kind of game that I don't think serves anybody's interest. I didn't sign on as secretary of defense to get Democrats. If I'd wanted to do that I'd have stayed in the House,'' he said. Meanwhile, Rep. Pete Stark, D-Calif., released a brief telegram he sent to Cheney on Jan. 23, urging him to close Camp Parks, a reserve military base in the congressman's district. Cheney had said Monday that not one member of Congress contacted him about the base closings and suggested that their installation be closed. ``To paraphrase Henny Youngman's famous line: `Take my base, please,''' Stark said. ``Mr. Secretary, I am a member of Congress and I do urge you to close Camp Parks.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Bank Taught Traffickers to Launder Money
DOC.TEXT: Ambitious bankers were so willing to hide illegal drug money that they taught undercover agents how to do it, a prosecutor charged Tuesday as trial opened in a $32 million international money-laundering case. But a defense attorney said the government was trying to smear the bankers by bringing up ties to deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. The bankers, officers with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, were all told up front about the source of the money, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rubenstein. ``The bankers received essentially the same message. ... This money comes from the illegal sale of narcotics in the United States, specifically cocaine,'' he said. The bankers, he said, didn't care. ``It's not any business of mine who the customers are,'' he quoted banker Amjad Awan as saying when told it was drug money. Awan, who once claimed to handle Noriega's secret accounts, is on trial with four other former BCCI officers and a Colombian. They are accused of conspiracy to traffic in drugs, conspiracy to launder drug profits and various other counts of money laundering. If convicted, each faces from 35 years to life sentences and fines of at least $750,000. Defense attorney John P. Hume denied any wrongdoing on the part of Awan and complained that the government was characterizing him as Noriega's onetime personal banker. ``This is guilt by association. By focusing in on Panama and General Noriega, they're causing you not to focus in on the problems of the transactions,'' Hume told jurors. Hume said Awan was never told and had no idea he was dealing with drug profits. The money came through a legitimate Florida bank which the government said was cooperating in the sting investigation. ``There's no evidence Awan knowingly engaged in transactions described in the indictment,'' Hume said. ``Ask yourselves, it is reasonable to do this for a promotion?'' The other defendants are Rudolf Armbrect of Medellin, Colombia; Syed Aftab Hussain, BCCI's operations officer of the bank in Panama; Akbar A. Bilgrami of Miami, a director of the Latin American Division; Sibte Hassan, who was an officer with the Paris branch; and Ian Howard, French country manager based in Paris. Hussain's attorney likewise denied involvement, saying his client was simply a junior officer in training, basically a glorified teller who had no power to act on his own. In opening arguments, Rubenstein described how millions of dollars in cash from drug sales were disguised in a series of international banking transactions involving BCCI. Cash from drug sales was converted into certificates of deposit, which were used first as collateral for loans, then to pay them off as they matured, the government said. Robert Musella, a U.S. Customs agent posing as a high-stakes launderer, met with Awan in Miami and stressed the need for absolute confidentiality for his clients, the prosecutor said. ``My clients are the biggest drug dealers in Colombia,'' Rubenstein quoted Musella as saying. The trial is expected to last four to six months. Before the start of jury selection two weeks ago, guilty pleas were entered by two divisions of BCCI. As part of a plea bargain, BCCI, one of the world's largest private financial institutions, agreed to forfeit a record $14 million in assets frozen earlier by the government and to cooperate against other defendants. The indictment resulted from a two-year sting operation, eventually building a global laundering operation worth an estimated $32 million, investigators said.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow in New England, Cold Wind in Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: A storm dumped as much as 28 inches of snow on New England on Tuesday, and arctic cold dropped the temperature in International Falls, Minn., by 46 degrees in less than 24 hours. By Tuesday afternoon, the day-long snowfall ended in much of Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, leaving snow accumulations of 1 to 2 feet in most of the region. Andover, Vt., got 28 inches, while 15 to 20 inches of snow was reported along the eastern slopes of New Hampshire's White Mountains, according to the National Weather Service. Mount Holly, Vt., got 24 inches; Montpelier, Vt., got 20 inches; Nashua, N.H., 16 inches; and Portland, Maine, 11 inches. Nine inches of snow fell at Houlton and Limestone, Maine. Caribou, Maine, received 6 inches in six hours. Eastern New York state also got heavy snow from the storm, with 17 inches at Utica, Piseco Lake and Bolton Landing, and 11 inches at Albany. Storm and snow advisories were posted across much of the Northwest for Tuesday, and showers and thunderstorms extended from the Gulf of Mexico across the central Gulf Coast region. In Northern California, a strong offshore gale whipped up 20-foot waves, and sunny skies alternated with dark, ``ominous'' skies and hail. ``It's pretty rough offshore north of San Francisco. It's starting to pick up all the way north of there,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Justin Wood. Most of the rest of the nation had dry weather. Strong northwest winds had ushered cold air into the north central states Monday night, and temperatures remained below zero Tuesday afternoon. The temperature at International Falls plunged from a record warm reading of 35 degrees Monday afternoon to 11 degrees below zero Tuesday morning. Strong wind produced a wind-chill reading of 63 degrees below zero at Cutbank, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Police Hold Firebomb Woman Headed for Jewish Holy Site
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday arrested an 18-year-old Palestinian woman carrying a firebomb and heading toward the Western Wall, Judaism's most holy site. ``She was caught during a routine security check,'' Jerusalem Police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. He said the woman lived in Silwan, an Arab village inside Jerusalem, and that the firebomb was ready for use. She was apprehended at a checkpoint in the old, walled city leading to the Western Wall, Sandori said. Israel radio said the woman has refused to tell police her intended target. The Western Wall, also called the Wailing Wall, is the only remnant of the Second Temple built by King Herod and destroyed by the Romans in 70 A.D. Also on Tuesday, Palestinian leader Faisal Husseini spoke in Hebrew to an audience of about 250 Jews in which he appealed for peace talks. In Arabbuna, near Jenin on the West Bank, three Palestinians were stabbed to death and at least 15 other villagers were injured in a fight between rival families, Arab reports and the army said. The fight in the mountain hamlet of 1,000 inhabitants was reportedly over a money loan. In Nablus, the West Bank's largest city with 120,000 people, Israeli troops sealed two homes, the army reported. The homes belonged to Palestinian men suspected of having killed eight Arabs as collaborators with Israel, . About 651 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the 25-month-old uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. An additional 174 Palestinians were killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence. Israel has occupied the lands since the 1967 Middle East war. Husseini, an activist who supports the Palestine Liberation Organization, told his audience it was better Israelis and Palestinians had ``a dialogue rather than a monologue.'' Husseini, a native Arabic speaker, on several occasions turned to the three Israelis on the panel for help with a Hebrew word, and once the audience shouted one for him _ ``matarot,'' meaning targets or goals. ``It has not been easy for us to say we don't want to continue with the same (anti-Israeli) war, with the same targets of our fathers,'' he said. Husseini appealed to Israel ``to talk to the Palestinian people as a people, not as a minority, not as residents of some place, not as refugees.'' Husseini has made a series of appearances before Jewish audiences to try to explain the Palestinian goal for an independent state. As the audience gathered for the speech at Jerusalem's Van Leer Institute, about 40 right-wing Israelis waved banners and shouted slogans against Husseini. They included activists from the Kach Party of American-born Rabbi Meir Kahane, who carried signs reading ``Deport Husseini Now'' and ``Arab Murderer Out.'' Israel radio said a bomb threat was received before the talk but police searched the building and no bomb was found. Army gunfire wounded at least seven Palestinians in clashes in refugee camps in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, hospital officials said. Arab reporters said that in the Shabura camp in Rafah, soldiers tried to arrest students singing nationalist songs on their way home from school, that camp residents tried to stop them and that at least three youths and a 30-year-old woman were shot with plastic bullets.

DOC.HEAD: Another Substance Gives Rats Cancer
DOC.TEXT: A government-sponsored study indicates that high doses of fluoride may cause cancer in male rats, but public health officials cautioned Tuesday that the findings are preliminary. Officials also said the findings do not suggest that tooth-decay-fighting fluoride in drinking water and toothpaste could cause cancer in humans. ``The findings must be evaluated and given final scientific peer review before conclusions can be drawn,'' said Jim Brown, a spokesman for the Public Health Service. Such a meeting is scheduled for April 26. ``It should be noted that all previous studies including those by the National Cancer Institute, the Centers for Disease Control, the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute as well as studies done in Canada, England, Australia, New Zealand and Norway show no linkage between ingested fluoride and mortality from cancer in humans,'' he said. In the study conducted by the National Toxicological Program, 1,360 mice and rats were fed water containing sodium fluoride. Four male rats given high doses got bone cancer. None of the female rats, nor any of the male or female mice in the study, was found to have contracted cancer at any of the four doses given. The high doses contained fluoride in far greater amounts than humans are exposed to in toothpaste and water, Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Group of Businesses Fighting North Dakota's Blue Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CLARIFY that association is state's chamber of commerce. SUBS 9th graf, `West Acres ...,' to CORRECT that Schlossman is company's controller, sted owner.
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen businesses went to state court Tuesday to overturn the nation's toughest Sunday closing laws, saying they are vague, selectively enforced and unconstitutional. ``You cannot discriminate among businesses, giving some special privileges and not affording those to others, and we're saying that this law does this,'' said John Olson, a Bismarck attorney representing the businesses. The lawsuit filed in South Central District Court in Bismarck follows unsuccessful attempts to persuade the state Legislature to overhaul Sunday-closing laws, which have existed in some form since statehood 100 years ago. ``It is evident from what is happening nationally and globally that North Dakota's economy will not grow by restricting business,'' said Dale Anderson, president of the Greater North Dakota Association, the state's chamber of commerce, which is backing the lawsuit. Attorney General Nicholas Spaeth said he personally favors Sunday shopping, but that his own opinion will not prevent him from defending the law. ``It's an important and difficult case, and our office will defend the present law vigorously,'' Spaeth said in a statement. The law lists 44 items that may not legally be sold Sunday except under some limited circumstances like rummage sales. The list includes cameras, shoes, cars and trucks, lawnmowers, and ``clothing other than work gloves and infant supplies.'' The law also lists 37 types of businesses that may open on Sunday, including grocery and convenience stores. But it does not include department stores, forcing North Dakota's shopping malls and other retail outlets to close. West Acres Development, which owns North Dakota's largest shopping mall is one of the 15 plantiffs in the lawsuit. The company's controller, Brad Schlossman, said stores in the Fargo mall are penalized because they must remain closed while other stores selling similar items are open Sundays. ``That isn't fair,'' he said. Schlossman said the state would get an estimated $20 million in tax revenue over a two-year period from Sunday sales. ``So if retailers win, the whole state wins,'' he added. North Dakota is one of eight states with some form of law restricting Sunday sales, according to the National Retail Merchants Association. Most of the other states restrict liquor sales, while Louisiana restricts the sale of cars on Sundays. Olson, who is also a Republican state senator, said the North Dakota law not only is discriminatory, but also is ``very, very confusing.'' For example, he said, it is unclear whether the ban on selling work gloves extends to winter gloves. ``When you have the clerk that's staffing the till at the checkout line in the store, that person has to make those decisions on the spot,'' Olson said. A clerk who illegally sells an item could be convicted of a misdemeanor with a maxium penalty of 30 days in jail and a $500 fine, he said. The lawsuit also contends North Dakota's laws unfairly restrict interstate commerce and inject religion into state lawmaking. No date for a hearing on the lawsuit has been set. The 15 businesses are in Fargo, Grand Forks, Wahpeton, Jamestown, Bismarck and Minot, and include a Bismarck real estate broker, a Jamestown car dealer and a Grand Forks hardware store. Olson unsuccessfully sponsored legislation last year to overhaul North Dakota's blue laws. Sunday-closing laws have been challenged previously in North Dakota courts, but recent decisions in other state courts and the U.S. Supreme Court have added weight to the argument against them, Olson said. ``We have a much better chance of prevailing in 1990 than we would have 10 or 20 years ago,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Demonstrate in Kosovo Province
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with five now reported killed. Picks up 7th, `The report ...; 3 grafs SUB for 21st and final graf, Federal Deputy ... UPDATING with Belgrade demonstration
DOC.TEXT: More than 6,000 ethnic Albanians chanting ``Democracy!'' clashed with riot police Tuesday in Podujevo, and five people were reported killed as protests spread across Kosovo province. Many companies stopped work on the seventh day of unrest in Kosovo. The deaths brought to 13 the number of officially reported deaths since clashes began Jan. 24 in the ethnically troubled region. Radio Pristina reported the deaths of two ethnic Albanians in Malisevo, a town 40 miles outside Pristina, and police sources later reported a policeman was seriously wounded there in an ambush by ethnic Albanians who fired at a passing column of police vehicles. Belgrade televison reported that police shot and killed three other ethnic Albanian demonstrators in two other small towns. The reports could not be independently confirmed. The police sources also said local ethnic Albanian police refused orders to intervene during a small demonstration at Goles, 10 miles northwest of the provincial capital _ the first such instance of disobedience since the unrest began. The report could not be verified independently. The sources spoke on the condition of anonymity. About 30,000 people gathered in the town of Urosevac for the funeral of one of those killed earlier. Demonstrators in several cities and towns defied government demands that they end protest marches. Strikes were reported at several factories in support of the protesters. In Podujevo, a city 20 miles north of Pristina, riot police fired hundreds of tear gas rounds at the mostly young demonstrators who covered their faces with scarves. There was no report on casualties. The ethnic Albanians are demanding free elections, lifting of a year-old state of emergency, release of political prisoners and an end to political trials. Armed riot police, some in helicopters, used clubs and a water cannon to battle stone-throwing demonstrators throughout the province Monday night. Yugoslavia's collective state presidency and the government issued separate statements Monday, both describing the Kosovo situation as ``extremely grave.'' The statements promised ``resolute action'' to stop the demonstrators. Demonstrations also were reported in Orahovac, Kosovska Vitina and several other towns in the province. The ethnic Albanians began rioting last year after the Serbian republic, of which Kosovo is an autonomous province, made constitutional changes to take tighter control of the region. Ethnic Albanians make up about 90 percent of the impoverished southern province's population, and they are predominantly Moslem. The minority Christian Serbs say Moslems in Kosovo want to force them out and then join neighboring Albania. For the first time in Kosovo, Serbs and the ethnic Albanians were reported confronting each other in Kosovska Vitina on Tuesday. Riot police positioned themselves between the two angry groups, which numbred hundreds on each side. Previously, such confrontations were avoided, but last week, an organization of Kosovo Serbs demanded that the authorities distribute weapons so they could protect themselves. A number of Serbian villages have organized vigilante patrols armed with shotguns and pistols in what they say is an effort to defend their homes. ``The situation has never been so bad in history,'' a gun-toting Serb in the village of Donja Gusterica told reporters. In Belgrade, the federal capital and capital of Serbia, thousands of students rallied late Tuesday in an anti-Albanian demonstration. ``We shall give our lives, but not Kosovo!'' they chanted. Federal Deputy Premier Zivko Pregl and Interior Minister Gen. Petar Gacanin met in Pristina on Tuesday to discuss the deteriorating situation in the province with local Communist authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Father Says Washington `Stalled' While Factory Workers Died
DOC.TEXT: Three times as many Americans die yearly from industrial accidents in confined spaces as from commercial air crashes, but the government has stalled on drafting rules to save workers' lives, federal officials were told Tuesday. Relatives of five men who suffocated or were poisoned in three chemical-tank accidents testified before a panel of U.S. Labor Department officials about how the disasters might have been averted if standards proposed years earlier had been in effect. ``Our government has failed us,'' said Phil Claypool, father of one of the victims. His testimony came in the last of three public hearings on rules proposed by the department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Previous hearings were held late last year in Washington and Houston. Stephen R. Jones, one of the four Labor Department officials on the panel, said his agency hopes to finish drafting rules by the end of the year. Three hundred workers die each year from suffocation, poisoning, drowning and injuries in confined industrial spaces such as refinery tanks, tunnels, sewers and grain elevators, according to a 1976 estimate by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. In contrast, from 1980 to 1988, U.S. commercial air crashes claimed an average of 105 people per year, according to figures submitted at the hearing and attributed to the National Transportation Safety Board. Denise Grad, 29, of suburban South Holland told the panel Tuesday how her 32-year-old husband, Tony, was suffocated by nitrogen in a tank car in May 1988 while working for a waste hauler in Matteson, south of Chicago. ``When he looked ... to go in there, he had no idea it had been cleaned out with nitrogen,'' said Mrs. Grad, choked by tears. ``He was always very careful _ it was one thing he was noted for.'' Mrs. Grad, who has a 2-year-old son, called for stricter labeling to protect workers from unknowingly entering confined spaces filled with potentially fatal gases, and for required rescue procedures and equipment. Nitrogen, which comprises four-fifths of the atmosphere, can be fatal if breathed in high concentrations, according to Dr. Stephen Hessl, chairman of occupational medicine at Cook County Hospital. Mark DeMoss, 18, and Dennis Claypool, 21, also were suffocated by nitrogen in December 1988 in a large tanker truck they'd been told to clean in Rockdale, according to testimony. ``There were no markings on the truck to indicate that it had recently contained nitrogen,'' said Joseph Kinney, director of the National Safe Workplace Institute, a Chicago-based advocacy group. Written testimony from Claypool's father noted that a 1979 NIOSH report proposed standards to prevent confined-space accidents. The government never adopted them. Also testifying were the mothers of two men who died in the nation's worst confined-space industrial accident of 1988, in which five men succumbed to hydrogen cyanide fumes in a metal-plating tank in Auburn, Ind. The rules OSHA has proposed would require measurement of chemical levels in confined spaces before workers enter, presence of a standby worker to rescue any stricken employee and special training of workers exposed to hazards in confined spaces. ``We see this as a real litmus test'' for the Bush administration, said Diane Factor, an AFL-CIO industrial hygienist who attended the hearing. ``If they can't do it on this one, it's a pretty bad signal for what the rest of their plans are for the agency.''

DOC.HEAD: World War II Codemaster Dies, Author of `The Ultra Secret'
DOC.TEXT: Group Capt. F.W. Winterbotham, who played a key role in exploiting broken German codes in World War II and wrote the bestselling memoir ``The Ultra Secret,'' has died, British news reports said Tuesday. He was 92. He died peacefully at home on Sunday, the accounts said. Frederick William Winterbotham was a pilot in World War I, and in 1929 was made head of aerial intelligence in MI6, the British intelligence agency. In the 1930s he managed to befriend senior Nazi figures in Germany and glean information about the Luftwaffe. In 1939 he helped devise a vital new method of aerial reconnaissance photography. But his most important work was with ``Enigma,'' the top-secret German code system that the British had managed to penetrate. Winterbotham's job was to get the information from Enigma, or ``Ultra intelligence'' as it was known, to commanders in the field without revealing to the Germans their code had been cracked. He worked out a system that was successful throughout the war, and did not become public knowledge until the 1970s. His work made him a confidant of wartime Prime Minister Winston Churchill. But he remained an unsung war hero, because the cracking of Enigma was considered so secret it was not revealed for 30 years after the war, when Winterbotham published ``The Ultra Secret.'' Winterbotham was married twice and had four children.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Ship Missing, Crew of 19 Presumed Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with coast guard saying crew presumed dead, location of sunken ship found. Picks up 11th, `A spokesman...'
DOC.TEXT: The coast guard said Tuesday it believed it had located the wreckage of a Greek-registered cargo ship that disappeared during a storm and all 19 crew members were presumed dead. Two bodies, one identified as a Greek crew member, washed ashore on the south coast of England with a life boat bearing the ship's name, Flag Theofano. The coast guard said 11 Greeks, seven Maldivians and one Egyptian were on board when the vessel vanished in bad weather Monday night. ``For those seamen left in the water there is no hope whatsoever of them being found alive,'' said senior coast guard officer Bob Woodwark. The coast guard said sonar readings found a sunken vessel five miles south of Portsmouth, but stormy seas prevented divers from positively identifying the wreckage as the 324-foot ship. ``We are quite certain there is definitely a ship down there; what ship it is we don't know,'' said a rescue worker who flew over the sight. The 1,184-ton vessel was last heard from Monday evening as it approached its destination of Southampton carrying cement from Le Havre, France. The coast guard said no emergency call was received. The weather was described as very poor in the channel Monday night with high winds and rough seas. The captain was told to anchor before entering Southampton because of the weather, the coast guard said. Helicopters, life boats and shore search parties have combed the area for survivors, the coast guard said, and a further search will be resumed at dawn Wednesday. A spokesman for Lloyd's of London insurance said the ship was built in 1970 and belongs to Seawave Compania Nanera, a Greek company. The Flag Theofano was on a three-year charter to Blue Circle, a building materials company. Blue Circle spokesman Ian McKenzie said their cement stocks are high and there was no pressure on the ship to sail in the nasty weather. ``The decision about making a voyage always rests with the captain,'' McKenzie said.

DOC.HEAD: Commander Dylan? French Honor Bob Dylan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT day to Tuesday, sted Thursday. Pickup 2nd, `Sporting a...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR7
DOC.TEXT: Rock legend Bob Dylan was named a commander in France's Order of Arts and Letters on Tuesday, in a ceremony in a gilded neoclassical reception room at the Palais Royal. Sporting a black Western outfit and a growth of grey stubble, the 48-year-old signer and composer bowed his head to accept the gold and emerald medal from Culture Minister Jack Lang. ``Thank you very much for presenting me with this honor,'' Dylan said, reading in French from a crumpled envelope. ``It moves me enormously.'' Lang told Dylan that ``for many of us in France and in Europe you bring together an ideal of music, an ideal of poetry.'' The room at the Palais Royal was packed with photographers, journalists and fans, many too young to remember Dylan's earliest tunes in the 1960s when he first performed such classics as ``Blowin' in the Wind'' and ``Like a Rolling Stone.'' Dylan is giving a series of concerts in Paris as part of a European tour.

DOC.HEAD: CBS' Super Bowl Game Tops Television Ratings
With AM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: CBS' Super Bowl game coverage won the weekly Nielsen ratings by a big margin but was one of the lowest-rated games ever and failed to boost CBS out of third place. The 39.0 rating for the telecast of San Francisco 49ers' 55-10 romp over the Denver Broncos was the lowest ever for a Super Bowl in prime time and the lowest overall since 1969. It was the first time since 1981 that the Super Bowl network failed to win the week. The Sunday game was seen by 63 percent of the television audience for the week ended Jan. 28. It was seen in nearly 40 million homes by about 108.5 million people. Its nearest competitor in the ratings was the post-game show, which had a rating of 25.3. The post-game show barely squeaked past NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers,'' which tied for third with a rating of 25.0. The Super Bowl ratings did nothing, however, to lift CBS out of third place. NBC was first and ABC was second. ABC's ``American Music Awards,'' in 10th place, was the only other non-regular show in the Top 10. NBC was first for the week with an average of 15.0. ABC followed with 13.2 and CBS with 12.8. A ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned to a show. For the season to date, NBC is ahead with 14.8, ABC second with 13.0 and CBS third with 12.3. Here are the Top 10: CBS' Super Bowl XXIV Game, CBS' Super Bowl XXIV Post Game Show, NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers'' tied, ABC's ``Roseanne,'' NBC's ``A Different World,'' NBC's ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC's ``Empty Nest,'' ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' and ABC's ``American Music Awards.'' ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was the top evening news show for the week. NBC was second. The ratings: ABC 12.0, NBC 11.1, CBS 10.3. The lowest rated show of the week was CBS' ``Super Bowl Saturday Night.'' Here are the bottom five network shows: the CBS Tuesday Movie ``So Proudly We Hail,'' ABC's ``Mission: Impossible,'' CBS' ``Paradise,'' ABC's ``Life Goes On'' and CBS' ``Super Bowl Saturday Night.''

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Exiles Urge U.S. to Join Effort to Remove Leader
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of banished Haitian leaders Tuesday urged the United States to join an international effort to remove Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril from power through military and economic sanctions. The group, saying it represents all Haitians silenced by Avril's ``regime of terror,'' rejected Avril's announcement Monday that he was restoring civil and press liberties to the impoverished island after a week-long crackdown against opposition activists. ``We believe that there is no possibility, under any circumstances, to resume the democratic process with Prosper Avril. Avril must go,'' the four leaders said in a statement issued after a meeting with the Congressional Task Force on Haiti. Avril rose to power in a 1988 coup led by non-commissioned officers who professed disgust with state terrorism under ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy. Avril promised elections for October, but critics say he has no intention of fulfilling his promise, despite pressure from the United States, France and other governments. The exiles accused the United States of propping up dictatorial regimes in Haiti for more than 30 years under the pretext of fighting communism in the Caribbean. ``We ask the United States now to pay attention to 6 million Haitians,'' said Antoine Izmery, a prominent civic leader exiled last week. Izmery said Avril had worked for the CIA and betrayed the United States as did former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``It's time for the United States to face its true responsibilities,'' Izmery said. Louis Roy, an architect of Haiti's constitution who was arrested, beaten and banished last week, said Haiti would not condone a Panama-like invasion to remove Avril, but that other steps could be effective. ``Pressure by the United States will succeed if it's strong enough and accompanied by threats that they mean business,'' said the 74-year-old leader. U.S. pressure, he said, helped end the harsh 27-year Duvalier dynasty when President-for-life Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986. Asked what kind of threats the United States should make, Roy said military and economic but he did not elaborate. The United States has suspended all aid to the Haitian government, although it provides humanitarian assistance to the Haitian people through private organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Recovered Satellite Removed From Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Scientists got their first look at a rescued science satellite Tuesday, and said they were delighted with its condition despite some wear and tear from six years in space. Wearing contamination-proof clothing and standing on an observation platform several feet away, scientists watched as the shuttle Columbia's 60-foot-long cargo bay doors opened to reveal the Long Duration Exposure Facility. The opening of the doors was the first step toward removing the 11-ton LDEF with a large crane, placing it in an air-tight canister and moving it from the shuttle processing facility to a sterilized building several miles away for close examination. The work was expected to last much of the night. Columbia's astronauts retrieved the laboratory 200 miles out in space Jan. 12, snaring it just weeks before it was to drop into the atmosphere and die a fiery death. LDEF project chief William H. Kinard trained binoculars on the satellite Tuesday, and said it appeared to be a little more weathered than pictures taken in space indicated. ``There are lots of small micrometeoroid craters,'' Kinard said. He said there was some discoloration, and foil covering some experiments had been torn. ``But that's why we sent it up there, to find out what happens to materials after a long time in the space environment,'' Kinard said. ``We're delighted with the condition.'' There are 57 experiments attached to LDEF's exterior, and scientists and engineers want to see how the various materials in them fared during their long exposure to radiation, micrometeoroids and other phenomena in space. The experiments will yield information that will be valuable in designing future long-duration spacecraft, including the Freedom manned space station to be assembled in orbit in the mid-1990s. Four teams will study the recovered laboratory for about three weeks, photographing it and jotting down their observations. The teams are composed of specialists in space debris, materials, spacecraft systems and radiation. Starting in mid-February, the experiments will be covered with protective aluminum and removed one by one from the satellite's racks. They will be delivered to scientists throughout the nation and Western Europe for detailed study. The satellite has 21 materials, coating and thermal systems experiments, five power and propulsion experiments, 17 science experiments and 14 optics and electronic experiments. They involve more than 200 investigators from 33 companies, 21 universities, seven National Aeronautics and Space Administration centers and eight foreign countries. Also aboard are 12.5 million tomato seeds. A few will be planted in research labs. However, most will be sent to schools where students in grades 5 through university level will plant, water and nurture the seeds to research such things as germination rates and genetics.

DOC.HEAD: Baltics See Gains in Arranging Talks on Caucasus Strife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th, `The mediation... UPDATING with speculation on Gorbachev's political plans. Picks up 5th, `The Soviet ...
DOC.TEXT: Baltic separatists say they have arranged an unusual attempt to resolve bloody strife in the Caucasus because that conflict could jeopardize their own peaceful drive for democracy. After a week of intense work, Baltic People's Front leaders said Armenians and Azerbaijanis have agreed to meet in Riga, capital of Latvia. Representatives of the Armenian All-National Movement and the People's Front of Azerbaijan are tentatively scheduled to meet Thursday, but travel problems could delay the discussions. The mediation effort is unusual because it bypasses the Kremlin and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has tried unsuccessfully to end the bitter confrontation between Armenia and Azerbaijan. A Moscow report Tuesday by the Cable News Network meanwhile said Gorbachev ``has spent the last eight days ... considering his resignation as chief of the Communist Party'' and could resign when the policy-setting Central Committee meets next Monday and Tuesday, while still retaining the presidency of the Soviet Union. It said Gorbachev would be following ``popular pressure to remove the party from its monopoly control of political power.'' The official Soviet news agency Tass late Tuesday said nothing of any such plans and later U.S. television newscasts from Moscow, including those by NBC and CBS, expressed skepticism. NBC commented on Gorbachev's problems in Azerbaijan and his struggles with perestroika, or restructuring, in its report on the resignation speculation. The Soviet government sent troops to Azerbaijan, and there have been nearly 200 deaths in the latest round of ethnic violence in the region. ``The situation in the Caucasus threatens the development of democracy in the Soviet Union as a whole, and talks could be a constructive beginning,'' said Ints Upmacis, a lawyer and one of three mediators from the Latvian People's Front. Sending Soviet soldiers to the Azerbaijani capital of Baku on Jan. 20 ``was kind of a half-step forward to introducing the army into all of the Soviet Union,'' said Romas Razukas, a Latvian People's Front member responsible for organizing the talks. ``This precedent seemed very dangerous to us.'' People's Fronts from Latvia's Baltic neighbors, Lithuania to the south and Estonia to the north, also are sending mediators. The negotiations mark the first time that non-official organizations will take such a leading role in trying to settle a national Soviet issue. If successful, the effort could enhance the prestige of the Baltic movements, already in the forefront of the Soviet reform effort. In Moscow, Vyacheslav A. Mikhailov, the No. 2 official of the Communist Party Central Committee's Ethnic Relations Department, told reporters Tuesday he was unaware of the Riga talks but that the Kremlin would support anything that helps resolve the conflict and ends bloodshed. The Latvians also see potential political gain in elections scheduled March 18. ``We obviously have humanitarian intentions, but this initiative could have great profit for us politically as well,'' said Razukas. ``We have elections to the Latvia Supreme Soviet coming up, and this initiative shows that the Lativian People's Front is peaceful.'' The idea for a Baltic initiative was a direct result of the Soviet military intervention in Azerbaijan. According to official sources, 197 people have been killed since the violence began, including 125 since the military moved into Baku. On Monday, the Estonian People's Front issued a declaration protesting the use of military force, said Marju Lauristen, a leader of the Estonian People's Front in an interview from her home in Tartu. ``This move cannot be interpreted as help for the Armenians. It is obviously a military move against the Azerbaijani people's drive for liberation.'' The Baltic states also are concerned about the fate of soldiers from their region who are part of the military force. ``We think there are at least 500 Latvian troops taking part in the occupation, and all the Baltic countries are interested in resolution of the conflict because there are troops from here,'' said Upmacis. The People's Front movements in all three Baltic republics insist that the quest for democracy and independence must be peaceful and rely on parliamentary methods. They hope that in their role as mediators they can pursuade the independence movements in the Caucaus to adopt a similar strategy. ``We will ask them to use diplomacy and follow a parliamentary way. We want them to understand how much we have achieved through those means,'' said Razukas. Serious efforts to organize the Armenian-Azerbaijani talks began Jan. 23, but communication by telephone or telegram with Armenian and Azerbaijani activists thousands of miles away required around-the-clock effort and tremendous patience, Razukas said. The biggest obstacle to arranging talks was the territorial dispute over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian enclave located inside Azerbaijan. The Armenian population and the Armenian republic want Nagorno-Karabakh annexed, but Azerbaijan has resisted the idea. After days of negotiations, the two sides agreed that territorial disputes would not be on the agenda. However, one of the Armenian negotiators, Rafael Popoyan, said that the Armenians wanted to discuss self-determination of ethnic groups, which amounts to much the same thing. The two sides hve agreed to discuss three main issues: the introduction and presence of Soviet troops in Baku and other parts of Azerbaija and Armenia, the problem of refugees, and other humanitarian issues.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Up to 22 in Floods
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains and floods have killed 22 people, left 254 homeless and destroyed farms in the mountain villages of southern Lesotho, officials said Tuesday. Red Cross Society officials said the death toll since the weekend could be higher, but helicopters from the Royal Lesotho Defense Force had not been able to reach remote highlands to check on settlements there. The officials said floodwaters from the Tele River had engulfed 92 homes, and there were not enough tents and food for the refugees in the southern African kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Charges Avianca With Negligence in Crash
With AM-Jetliner Crash
DOC.TEXT: A man and his young son who survived the Avianca jetliner crash filed $202.5 million federal lawsuit Tuesday accusing the Colombian airline of negligence. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court was apparently the first in the Thursday night crash in Cove Neck on Long Island, which killed 73 people and injured 85. The lawsuit alleges Avianca failed to provide a safe and airworthy aircraft and failed to provide a competent crew. Jesus Manuel Pinzon, 31, a Colombian living in Elizabeth, N.J., suffered broken bones, cuts and internal injuries in the crash, and remains hospitalized, said his attorney, Robert A. Solomon. Solomon said Pinzon, who earned about $400 a week at a clothing factory, will be permanently disabled and unable to work. Pinzon's 2-year-old son, Brian, was sitting in the seat next to his father and was thrown out of the aircraft when the Boeing 707 slammed into a wooded hillside, Solomon said. ``The child was not buckled in,'' he said. Brian, who suffered minor head injuries and abrasions on his back, was treated at a hospital and released. The Pinzons were returning from Bogota, Colombia, where they were visiting relatives. The lawsuit seeks $100 million for Pinzon, $1.5 million for his son, $1 million for his 28-year-old wife, Amanda; and $100 million in punitive damages. A telephone call to Avianca's Manhattan offices seeking comment was not answered Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador-turned-Businessman Bows Out in Style
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Mark Palmer hosted a glitzy farewell reception Tuesday to mark the end of his foreign service career and the start of new job as chief executive of an East Europe-based consortium. ``I haven't been a typical diplomat in the past few years and I thought I should not leave in a typical way _ and Washington is cooperating,'' he told those gathered to wish him well in the Hungarian National Gallery, the former royal castle. Guests included members of the diplomatic corps, important Hungarian personalities including Communist Party chairman Gyula Thuermer, government economics advisor Laszlo Antal and expatriate Bela Kiraly, head of the revolutionary army in 1956 that tried to topple Communism. Palmer had been scheduled to leave after the March general elections, until the announcement Jan. 25 that he was joining the newly created Central European Development Corp. as president and chief executive officer. He subsequently resigned as ambassador to avoid possible conflicts of interest. The new company, whose chairman is Estee Lauder cosmetics empire heir Ronald S. Lauder, was created to take advantage of investment opportunities created by the retreat of communism across much of the Soviet bloc. Chilled champagne and a country and western band welcomed guests, who were assured by Palmer that he would see regularly in his new position. ``We'll have a house in Prague and an apartment in Budapest, I'll be here every six weeks,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sims Found Guilty in Death of Child
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to tighten; SUBS 12th graf, `The jury ...,' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that Mrs. Sims was convicted of one count but had been charged with two; picks up 13th graf, `Weber will ...'
DOC.TEXT: A woman suspected of killing two infant daughters she claimed had been abducted was found guilty of first-degree murder Tuesday in the slaying of one of them. Paula Marie Sims, 30, shed no tears as the guilty verdict was read to her, but she later broke down as guards led her back to jail. The jury will begin deliberations Wednesday as to whether or not Mrs. Sims should face the death penalty. Jurors deliberated 10 hours over two days before returning the verdict against the woman in the suffocation of 6-week-old Heather Lee. Heather was one of two infant daughters Mrs. Sims reported abducted by a masked gunman under nearly identical circumstances three years apart. Madison County prosecutor Donald Weber called it the ``hardest case I ever had to try.'' He said he thought the jury was strongly influenced by evidence that Mrs. Sims and her husband, Robert, wanted only male children. ``She didn't like little girls and neither did Robert,'' said Weber. The father has not been charged in either case, but Weber said because of the verdict against Mrs. Sims, the state's attorney's offices in Madison and Jerey counties are considering seeking grand jury indictments against the 37-year-old man. Robert Sims and defense attorney Donald Groshong declined comment. Mrs. Sims looked somber as the jury returned and once appeared to wince as the verdict was read. She sat stoic with her eyes fixed to the table in front of her. She didn't look up as the jurors were polled to confirm their guilty verdicts, nor when they filed passed her and the silver trash barrel and plastic garbage bag where the body of Heather Lee was discovered last May 3. The jury found Mrs. Sims guilty of one count of first-degree murder, two counts of obstructing justice and one count of concealing a homicide. Mrs. Sims had been charged with two counts of murder to allow prosecutors to propose different theories in Heather's death, and jurors consolidated the counts upon conviction, Weber said. Weber will try to show the jury Wednesday that Mrs. Sims' crime qualifies her for capital punishment because the victim was under 12, and the defendants conduct was especially brutal and cruel. If she qualifies for the death penalty, a hearing will be held on the actual penalty, which could vary from death by injection to imprisonment. Mrs. Sims also has been implicated in the 1986 death of her firstborn, 13-day-old Loralei Marie, in Jersey County. No murder charges have been filed in that case. Mrs. Sims faces trial in Jersey County on charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in Loralei's death. She reported that in June 1986, a masked gunman entered her home while she was watching television, made her lie on the floor and fled with Loralei. A body believed to be that of the infant was found a week later near the family home in the rural Jersey County town of Brighton, where they lived at the time. On April 29, 1989, Mrs. Sims reported that a masked gunman approached her as she took out the garbage and ordered her back into the house in the Madison County city of Alton, where the family had moved. She said he knocked her unconscious and that when she awoke, she found Heather gone. Heather's body was found May 3 in a garbage can across the Mississippi River in nearby West Alton, Mo. Mrs. Sims has been jailed since the murder charges were filed in July. Her husband has had custody of the couple's son, Randy, who turns 2 Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: 49 Jail Inmates Escape Santiago Cell after Digging Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: Forty-nine leftist guerrillas including several who tried to kill President Augusto Pinochet in 1986 escaped from a downtown jail Tuesday through a tunnel they spent a year digging, officials said. Authorities said six of the escapees were quickly captured by police, but the others remained at large, prison officials said. One other prisoner proved too big for the tunnel's entrance and was found stuck in it, they said. Horacio Ojeda, director of the national prison system, said the inmates dug a tunnel about 100 yards long and 20 inches wide from a cell block to a nearby lot where a subway station was being constructed. The tunnel passed under a busy road. The escape was discovered at 2:30 a.m., Ojeda said. Several hours later, a man who identified himself as one of the escapees called Radio Cooperativa in Santiago with details of the operation. The man said construction of the tunnel took more than a year and that 24 inmates took part in planning and carrying out the escape. ``The tunnel has a ventilation system operated with blowers,'' the man said. ``It has electric light and a rail system we used to take out the removed material.'' ``After we left, the tunnel remained open, and we think it was used by other prisoners who were not part of our plan,'' the caller added. The details desribed by the caller coincided with what reporters saw at the prison. The entrance to the tunnel was inside a cell. The inmates used a heavy cement block to cover the hole and hide it from the prison guards. Ojeda described all the escapees as leftists, and said several were convicted in a Sept. 7, 1986, ambush of Pinochet's motorcade southeast of Santiago. Pinochet was unhurt but five bodyguards were killed and 11 wounded in the attack, carried out by the pro-Communist Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front. Pinochet took power following a 1973 coup that topped elected President Salvador Allende. He is scheduled to turn over power to a civilian government in February. Other escapees were Front members implicated in the smuggling of more than 30 tons of rifles, rockets, bazookas, grenades and other weapons into the country in August 1986, Ojeda said. A list of the escapees disclosed by prison authorities includes several top commanders of the guerrilla organization. Some belonged to other leftist groups. According to a local organization of prisoners' relatives, four of the escapees had been sentenced to death but were awaiting the outcome of appeals. Three were convicted in the Pinochet assassination attempt and the other for killing a policeman.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Communists End Parliament Majority
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party on Tuesday handed over more than 100 of its parliamentary seats to pro-democracy groups to end its four-decade hold on the nation's legislature. Also Tuesday, the Foreign Ministry announced Czechoslovakia and Israel are expected to restore diplomatic ties on Feb. 8, when Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel visits this capital. Czechoslovakia, one of Israel's strongest supporters after the Jewish state was founded in 1948, broke off ties over objections to the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The realignment of parliament completed an effort to include Czechoslovakia's emerging reform groups in the Federal Assembly before free elections scheduled for June 8. It was the latest abdication of Communist power following a popular revolution in November. Parliament swore in 120 new deputies, only nine of them Communists, under an agreement by various parties and the opposition to replace more than one-third of the 350-member parliament. The action sliced the Communists' representation from 242 to 139, marking the first time since the late 1940s that the Communists have not dominated the legislature. All but nine of the new seats went to the opposition and other, established political parties. More than 40 political parties have emerged in the two months since parliament removed the constitutional provision guaranteeing the Communist Party's leading role. The realignment came following broad talks between the pro-democracy leaders, the Communists and four traditionally allied parties. Earlier, several discredited Communist deputies were asked to resign and were replaced by candidates of the Civic Forum, a loose reform coalition. Deputy Zdenek Jicinsky, one of the new Civic Forum deputies and a constitutional lawyer once forced to work in menial jobs for his human rights activities, on Tuesday presented a draft election law to the legislature. The legislation requires final approval from the country's new non-Communist president, Vaclav Havel. The draft proposes the principle of proportional representation in the elections, with several limitation clauses. Although Jicinsky did not give precise figures in his presentation, Civic Forum sources indicate a minimum of 10,000 supporters and 5 percent of the total national vote will be required for a party to put a member in parliament. Petr Pithart, another newly elected deputy and a leader of the Civic Forum, said he expected six to seven new political parties would be elected into parliament.

DOC.HEAD: D.C.-Area Residents Tapped for Jobs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he will nominate Michael Lorne Moodie to be an assistant director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Moodie, 41, is a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C., and a former special assistant to the U.S. ambassador to NATO. If confirmed, he would succeed Lynn Marvin Hansen as assistant director for multilateral affairs. He lives in Silver Spring, Md. The White House also announced that Bush is nominating Donald L. Ivers to be an associate judge of the new U.S. Court of Veterans Appeals. Ivers, 48, of Alexandria, Va., has been general counsel of the Veterans Administration, which became a Cabinet Department last year.

DOC.HEAD: Italy's Most Sought After Kidnap Victim Released by Abductors
DOC.TEXT: Cesare Casella, the young kidnap victim whose two years of captivity gripped Italy, was freed Tuesday night. Police said a military patrol found Casella, 20, chained by the wrist and the neck to a post near a bridge in the Aspromonte Mountain area of southern Italy where he was believed held by the Anonymous Kidnappers, Italy's notorious kidnap ring. The Italian news agency ANSA said the youth told police he was left chained to the post by kidnappers who told him to remain calm, that sooner or later someone would pass by and free him. The youth was examined by a doctor, found to be exhausted by his imprisonment but in good condition, police said. ANSA said his first request was for food. ``Give me something to eat, I haven't eaten for three days,'' the agency quoted him as telling the military patrol. Casella had become a symbol of the plight of kidnap victims in Italy. His mother, Angela Casella, was known as ``Mother Courage'' because she traveled to Aspromonte to make dramatic appeals and to protest the kidnapping and government inaction. She made her first ``trip of hope'' to the Aspromonte region of Calabria in October 1988 and returned for 10 days last June, sleeping in a tent ``as my son is doing in these months.'' Her complaints led to the resignations of all 42 mayors of the Aspromonte area near Locri in sympathy with her complaints. ``Cesare is that you, is that really you?'' she said in a choking voice when she spoke to him by telephone for the first time since he was kidnapped. ``Yes, yes, mama. It is me,'' he replied. Casella, abducted in the northern town of Pavia on Jan. 18, 1988, was released near the site of a Christmas Eve shootout between the Carbinieri, Italy's paramilitary police, and kidnappers who had come to collect the second installment of the ransom. Police said one of the kidnappers was wounded and captured during the shootout, but two others escaped. After the release of Casella, five people are thought to be in the hands of the kidnap gangs, including Patrizia Tacchella, 8-year-old daughter of Imerio Tacchella, co-owner of the sportsware manufacturing company Carrera. She has been missing more than a day, feared kidnapped from near her home in Verona. Casella, whose father Luigi owns a Citroen dealership, had been one of the longest held kidnap victims in Italy. His father reportedly paid the 1 billion lire ($800,000) ransom demanded by the kidappers in August of 1988 and his release appeared imminent. But despite the payment and emotional appeals by the mother, the youth remained a prisoner. It was not until early 1989 that the kidnappers responded, demanding a second payment of 5 billion lire ($4 million). The kidnappers did not provide any proof the youth was still alive until September, when they sent a picture of him holding the Sept. 3 edition of a local newspaper. On Nov. 10 a friend of the family received a letter from the youth. On Christmas Eve the Carabinieri took a sack of ransom money to a drop site but the transaction ended in a shootout and the capture of one of the kidnappers.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Insurgents Slain in Jungle Clash with Police
DOC.TEXT: A police patrol killed 18 leftist insurgents in a clash in Peru's eastern jungle and Maoist rebels murdered five people in a highland state capital, authorities said Tuesday. The Interior Ministry said a 25-member police patrol of counterinsurgency rangers surprised the 18 leftist rebels Sunday near Jatunhuasi, a village 160 miles east of this capital. The ministry communique did not indicate if the rangers suffered casualties or if rebel prisoners were taken. No spokesman was available to provide details. The communique also did not say if the rebels belonged to the Mao-inspired Shining Path guerrilla group or the much smaller pro-Cuba Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement. Both bands are active in Peru's jungle regions. In other violence, Shining Path guerrillas murdered five people before dawn Tuesday in Ayacucho, the rebel group's stronghold, accusing them of being government collaborators, police said. Rebels dragged two school teachers, a laborer, an artisan and a merchant from their homes in a shantytown in northern Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima, and shot them to death, police said. The guerrillas threw signs over the bodies with inscriptions in red ink that said, ``This is the way black heads die.'' The Shining Path calls government collaborators ``black heads.'' The name is a derogatory reference to the black ski masks used by army troops that patrol the mountainous insurgency zones. The Shining Path began its insurgency in the impoverished countryside around Ayacucho in May 1980. Since then, the violence has spread throughout Peru and more than 17,500 people, including soldiers, policemen, authorities, rebels and civilians, have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Grimace, Skiers Grin As Snow Blankets Northern New England
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th, `However, at...,' to UPDATE with store roof collapsing.
DOC.TEXT: Northern New England's biggest storm of the winter dumped up to 28 inches of snow and closed schools, a legislature and businesses Tuesday _ even part of L.L. Bean shut down _ and ended a snow drought for many ski areas. ``This is as close to heaven for a skier as you can get,'' said a jubilant Nancy Marshall, spokeswoman at Sugarloaf USA in Carrabassett Valley, Maine, which at midday reported 22 inches of fresh snow at the base, 24 inches at the summit and no sign the snowfall was letting up. ``It's a real old-fashioned snowstorm,'' said Vermont Highway Department spokesman Ray Burke. ``Lots of inches. That's Vermont.'' However, at least one traffic death in New Hampshire was blamed on the storm Monday and roads were snow-covered and slippery Tuesday across Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. In Dexter, Maine, a snow-covered roof collapsed late in the afternoon at the R.H. Reny department store, slightly injuring three people. Most customers had been ushered from the store when the roof began creaking shortly before the collapse. ``I heard this crash, it sounded like a roll of thunder,'' said a witness, Jerry Townsend. Two women and a fireman were treated and released from Mayo Regional Hospital in Dover, said hospital director Robert McReavy. By Tuesday afternoon, the day-long snowfall ended in much of Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont and the sky turned blue as the storm moved rapidly from the Gulf of Maine into Nova Scotia. But near-blizzard conditions continued in northern Maine's Aroostook County and state police said a 40-mile stretch of Interstate 95 between Houlton and Sherman was closed to all traffic for two hours Tuesday morning. ``We've got whiteout conditions, treacherous driving and numerous vehicles off the road,'' said a dispatcher at the state police barracks in Houlton. Snow accumulations in most of the region ranged from 1 to 2 feet. Andover, Vt., got 28 inches, while 15 to 20 inches of snow was reported along the eastern slopes of New Hampshire's White Mountains, according to the National Weather Service. Mount Holly, Vt., got 24 inches; Montpelier, Vt., got 20 inches; Nashua, N.H., 16 inches; and Portland, Maine, 11 inches. Eastern New York state also got heavy snow from the storm, with 17 inches at Utica, Piseco Lake and Bolton Landing, and 11 inches at Albany, the weather service said. Many youngsters got an unscheduled holiday Tuesday when schools canceled classes because of travel conditions. Some took advantage of the day off to go skiing. ``Schools may have closed but kids aren't having any problem finding their way here,'' said Dave Buckman, marketing director at Gunstock ski area in Gilford, N.H. A number of major businesses called off work for the day Tuesday. The manufacturing facilities and distribution center at L.L. Bean Inc., the supplier of clothing and gear for campers and would-be woodsmen in Freeport, Maine, were closed. The first shift at Bath Iron Works was shut down. Others, including National Life Insurance Co. in Montpelier, Vt., opened a few hours late. In New Hampshire, the storm forced a reshuffling of the legislative calendar. Tuesday's state Senate hearings were put off until Thursday, but the full Senate met as planned in the afternoon. The House postponed its Tuesday session until Wednesday.
