Howling wind and heavy seas snapped one of two tow lines being used to haul the Navy's new Aegis cruiser Gettysburg down the Maine coast from Bath to Portland, forcing some 35 shipyard workers and Navy officials to ride out the storm at sea, said Jim McGregor, spokesman at Bath Iron Works. No injuries were reported, but the ship dropped anchor outside Portland Harbor as a precaution. The storm ended a January snow drought for many ski areas, some of which had been forced to rely on man-made snow to keep their slopes white. ``It's the most snow we have had in one storm for the past two or three years. This is just what we needed,'' said Buckman at the Gunstock ski area. ``January wasn't a good month for snow,'' Sugarloaf's Ms. Marshall noted. ``Mother Nature is back in good graces with us now.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Blockades Alleged Drift-net Supply Ship
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer said Tuesday that officials had found no evidence to support claims by Greenpeace that a Philippine vessel planned to supply a Japanese drift-net fleet. He said the investigation was continuing, however. New Zealand and many other South Pacific nations oppose drift-net fishing. Environmentalists say the huge nets trap virtually everything they cover and could decimate marine life. Earlier Tuesday, Greenpeace said it made a ``citizen's arrest'' by tying the Philippine ship We Carrier with heavy chain at Auckland Harbor. Greenpeace said it acted after intercepting radio messages at sea in which a Japanese control ship told other vessels in the drift-net fleet to meet the Philippine tanker to refuel. Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries inspectors searched the tanker but found no evidence to corroborate Greenpeace's claims, Palmer said in a statement. He said officials of the Ministry of External Relations and Trade were investigating. Palmer said the government would be reluctant to take action without evidence. ``It is very unfortunate that Greenpeace is unable to produce firsthand evidence of the radio communications they overheard,'' he said. ``It seems that tape recordings were accidentally wiped.'' However, if evidence suggests the tanker was supporting the drift-net fleet, Palmer said he would ask the Auckland company to ``withdraw its arrangements'' with the vessel. At a meeting in Wellington in November, 20 South Pacific nations endorsed a pact aimed at banning the huge drift nets in their waters. Under the Wellington Driftnet Convention, nations can prohibit port access to drift-net vessels and to ships that supply drift-net fleets. Palmer said his government was preparing legislation to carry out the convention's provisions. Greenpeace claimed the We Carrier was preparing to resupply a fleet of 20 Japanese drift netters in the Tasman Sea Wednesday. ``We took this action as a continuation of our Tasman Sea drift-nets expedition against Japan and Taiwan,'' said Greenpeace drift-nets campaigner Mike Hagler. ``The resupply of the Japanese ... fleet must be stopped if we are to stop the drift-net slaughter of whales and dolphins and the decimation of the South Pacific albacore tuna stocks.'' The group said it feared hundreds of whales and thousands of dolphins would be killed before the end of the five-month fishing season in April.

DOC.HEAD: Subject in Mail Bomb Probe Gives Blood Samples to Federal Investigators
With AM-Bombs-Two Cities
DOC.TEXT: A man investigated in the mail bomb slayings last month of a federal judge and a civil rights attorney gave samples of his blood, saliva and hair to the FBI on Tuesday. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, accompanied by his attorney, was taken by police to a hospital, where he spent 45 minutes providing samples requested in a federal grand jury subpoena issued last week. Emerging from the hospital, O'Ferrell said he was happy to comply with the subpoena and told reporters he has cooperated with the investigation since the FBI arrived in this southeast Alabama city on Jan. 22. His attorney, Paul Harden, said the FBI did not tell him what they planned to do with the samples. O'Ferrell, a 46-year-old Enterprise junk dealer, has been questioned extensively in the FBI's investigation of the slayings of 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance of Birmingham and Robert Robinson, an NAACP attorney from Savannah, Ga. Similar package bombs were discovered and defused at the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Agents have confiscated typewriters from O'Ferrell. Federal sources speaking on condition of anonymity have said the printing on the bomber's letters matched that on a 1988 letter O'Ferrell wrote to the 11th Circuit concerning a case he lost before the court. Agents last week searched O'Ferrell's home and business and pumped out his septic tanks looking for evidence. The FBI has refused to say whether it found any clues, but dozens of agents remain in southeast Alabama. In another development, a pipe bomb mailed to a church in Houston exploded Tuesday morning, injuring Lisa Osteen, the 30-year-old daughter of the pastor, the Rev. John Osteen. Charles B. Kearney, an FBI spokesman in Houston, said there did not appear to be any similarities between the Texas bomb and the December mail bombs. However, O'Ferrell and Harden said the Houston bombing should demonstrate that O'Ferrell had nothing to do with any of the attacks. ``It's a sad state of affairs, but it does in my mind show Wayne O'Ferrell, who has been in Enterprise since day one, is in no way, shape or form involved,'' Harden said.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Asks for Membership in Council of Europe
DOC.TEXT: Poland applied Tuesday for full membership in the 23-nation Council of Europe, the oldest postwar organization for European unity. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki announced Poland's application in a speech to the Council's assembly: ``The Council of Europe, which has performed wonders in the defense of rights and freedoms and which is a rich fountainhead of European ideas and initiatives seems the right place for Poland.'' Poland, which has had observer status in the organization since June 8, is the second East European nation to apply for membership of the Strasbourg-based Council. Hungary, following Poland with its own democratic reforms, applied on Nov. 16. Set up in 1949, the Council is a political organization particularly active in human rights and legal and cultural cooperation and is separate from the European Community. Membership is open only to European countries that have a democratic and pluralistic parliament. Addressing this issue, Mazowiecki said that although Poland was ``confronted with the enormous task of reconstituting the rights and the institutions which characterize modern democracies ... Poland has already set to work.'' He stressed his government had drafted and enacted laws for the independence of the judiciary, for freedom of the press, freedom to organize and found political parties and for local self-government. The Polish premier appealed for help in the ``huge job'' facing Eastern and Central Europe to ``fill in the gulf between poor Europe and affluent Europe.'' He said ``we now need new guidelines to point our endeavors down a common European road, to no-one's exclusion and everyone's advantage.'' But unlike his counterpart from Hungary, Miklos Nemeth, who on Monday also addressed the Council of Europe, saying his country was paying ``particular attention'' to its relations with the 12-nation European Community, Mazowiecki hinted that membership in the EC was not upcoming for Poland. Europe at the turn of the century would ``certainly not be a European area with free movement of goods, capital and people,'' nor ``a Europe with a common currency,'' he said referring to the EC's plans to achieve a single market by the end of 1992 and its longer-term plans for monetary union. Instead, he said, the time had come to ``establish institutions genuinely encompassing the whole of Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Meeting in Moscow Set Back Amid Gorbachev Resignation Unconfirmed Rumors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf: ``Sen. David,'' to restore dropped words ``more difficult to,''
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials said they could not confirm a broadcast report Tuesday that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was considering relinquishing his post as head of the Soviet Communist Party. ``All I can tell you ... is that it's a rumor, and therefore it's not something that I think that we should respond to or react to,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters after the report was aired by Cable News Network. Baker spoke as an aide announced a rescheduling of talks in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and said the one-day delay was to avoid interfering with a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee. Baker will be in Moscow Feb. 8-9, said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``We're following the story, as I know you are, and we'll have a comment if we ever determine it's something more than just a rumor,'' Baker said of the CNN account. CNN, quoting a ``well-informed and usually reliable'' party source, said from Moscow that the re-emergence of Gorbachev on telvision on Tuesday did not rule out a dramatic resignation when the policy-setting Central Committee meets next Monday and Tuesday. Before the TV appearance on Tuesday, Gorbachev was last seen in public Jan. 20 explaining why Soviet troops had been sent to the Azerbaijan republic. According to the unnamed source, Gorbachev had resisted sending troops into Baku, the capital of the republic, and was suffering severe depression over the action, CNN said. White House chief of Staff John Sununu told reporters the administration has been ``trying for the last few hours to try and get some additional assessments, but I don't have anything at all.'' ``We would like to understand the details of what's involved and what's implied if such a change has taken place,'' he said. ``And frankly at the time we're talking here, I don't know if it's correct.'' Bush administration officials and intelligence sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there has been speculation for weeks that Gorbachev would yield his party post _ while retaining the presidency _ but that they had no information he would take the step. One senior administration official said that if true, the decision ``might mean that there's a move toward pluralism in mind, it might mean there's a problem, it might be a plus. And very frankly you can create scenarios on both sides. ... You can make an argument that it's a reflection of strength and you can make an argument that it's a reflection of weakness.'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., Senate chairman of the Senate Intelligence Commitee, said he had no confirmation of the report, but if true it ``may in fact enhance Gorbachev's chances for survival'' by making it more difficult for party bosses opposed to his policies to criticize him. Ever since his assumption of the top party post in 1985, Ghorbachev has sought to separate the party and the government. The party has ruled the country since the 1917 revolution, with the government a distinctly secondary entity. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said he had no independent knowledge of Gorbachev's plans but that a resignation as party leader would represent an important loss of power for the Soviet leader and throw uncertainty into U.S.-Soviet relations. Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said the report should mean caution about cutting military spending: ``Let's call off this mad rush to spend a dividend we don't even have yet.'' Baker said American diplomats in Moscow ``know just about the same thing that all the rest of us know right now _ that there's a rumor out there to this effect, and that's all we know.'' He said his talks in Moscow were ``still very much on.'' Asked about the CNN report, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``I have no idea. We've never heard of it before. I have no information.'' He said of the Baker trip to Moscow: ``It was just delayed one day.'' Baker and Shevardnadze will meet Feb. 8-9 in the Soviet capital, a day delay at the suggestion of the U.S. government, said Ms. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. Issues to be discussed include arms control and the war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed government and U.S.-armed rebels. ``It simply makes more sense to have the Soviets complete their plenum before beginning this important ministerial,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. Baker also is expected to make a brief visit to Czechoslovakia, although there has been no announcement on that. One U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there have been reports that Gorbachev was frustrated over efforts to reform the Communist Party. He said the speculation was that Gorbachev would remain in charge of the government as president, a post he has strengthened. However, he stressed there was no information to the effect that Gorbachev would take the step. Another administration official said Jack Matlock Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Moscow, had been asked about the CNN report and replied he was unaware of any such development. The intelligence sources said the report was given impetus by Baker's schedule change. Meanwhile, the report caused turmoil on Wall Street and a negative reaction on Capitol Hill. Stock prices were so volatile after the CNN report aired that one investment brokerage stopped trading temporarily while the market calmed down. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell immediately after the Gorbachev report but quickly recovered, finishing down 10.14 on a day when prices were also pushed downward by congressional testimony from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Rebel Chief Cuts Short Tour, Saying Offensive Launched
DOC.TEXT: Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi cut short a tour of Western Europe Tuesday, saying the government launched a major air offensive against strongholds of his UNITA guerrillas in that southern African state. He told a Lisbon news conference Soviet-supplied MiG and Sukhoi warplanes began bombing UNITA positions in southeast Angola Monday, between the Kuzumbia River and the rebel base of Mavinga, about 685 miles southeast of Luanda. Savimbi called the raids the biggest since civil war began in 1975 between his U.S.-backed rebels and the Marxist government that took power when Angola gained independence from Portugal. ``It's the first time in 14 years that we've had these sweeping raids,'' he said, with up to 14 planes being used in single attacks. A government official contacted by telephone Tuesday in Luanda, Angola's capital, declined to comment about air raids, but said forces under President Jose Eduardo dos Santos were creating serious problems for the rebels. Savimbi had arrived in Lisbon Saturday for an eight-day visit, planning to go on to West Germany, Belgium and Switzerland. Despite the raids, he hinted that chances for restarting stalled peace talks were increased by his visit here. ``There are movements again to start negotiations,'' he said. He said Portugal agreed to help as a link between UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ and the Luanda government. Savimbi said that for the first time Angola used sophisticated Sukhoi-25 ground attack planes supplied by the Soviets last year. He said about 11,000 civilians lived in the area under attack. The rebels shot down two MiGs and captured two pilots, Savimbi claimed. The United States supplies the rebels with Stinger ground-to-air missiles among a reported $50 million of U.S. military aid send yearly to UNITA. The rebel leader said Mavinga was in no danger of falling to government forces and that bush headquarters at Jamba was not affected by the bombing. In Luanda on Tuesday, a military official said Mavinga was surrounded and could fall soon. The state-run news media made no mention Tuesday of any fighting in the south. Savimbi said he will return to organize ground defenses along the Lomba River, an important natural barrier protecting rebel territory in the southeast. Savimbi's visit to Portugal was the first since Angola became independent. Portuguese authorities earlier refused to grant him a visa. During his stay, he met President Mario Soares and Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva. He suggested the raids were meant to counteract what he said was the public relations success of his visit. Efforts to reach a peaceful solution have floundered since a cease-fire sealed by a handshake between Savimbi and dos Santos last June in Gbadolite, Zaire, broke down amid renewed fighting. Cavaco Silva's center-right government has built up warm relations with the Luanda government and has recently begun high-level talks with UNITA. The United States has also stepped up diplomatic efforts to break the deadlock. Savimbi said that before returning to Angola, he will stop off at other African countries, not identified, for talks with leaders sympathetic to his movement.

DOC.HEAD: Defect Leads to Inspection of British Nuclear Submarines
DOC.TEXT: The Ministry of Defense said Tuesday night that a defect was found in the reactor of one of the Royal Navy's nuclear-powered submarines and that the entire fleet will be examined. A ministry statement said the ``technical defect'' was found during a routine check and that its decision to inspect the other 19 submarines was a ``prudent precaution.'' It did not describe the defect. Press Association, the British domestic news agency, said the defect was most likely a hairline fracture in the submarine's primary cooling system, which has to endure considerable temperatures and pressures. The agency said the fault was discovered during an examination of a Valiant class submarine at Devonport dockyard in Plymouth, southwestern England. A Ministry of Defense spokesman said on condition of anonymity that personnel working on the refit and crews at sea were not in danger. ``The submarines are not unsafe. Safety is paramount,'' he said. Submarines in the Valiant class are the navy's oldest and were built between 1966 and 1971. They include HMS Conqueror, which sank the Argentine battle cruiser Belgrano during the 1982 war over the Falkland Islands. Accounts of the campaign said the Conqueror's reactor experienced problems as the sub sailed to the Falklands but that the crew shut down the reactor solved the trouble. Conqueror is the only nuclear submarine of any country known to have seen action.

DOC.HEAD: Tunisian on Trial in Paris Bombings Says He is Islamic Terrorist
DOC.TEXT: A Tunisian accused of directing a bombing campaign that killed 13 people in Paris told a court Tuesday he is a terrorist pursuing holy war on behalf of Islam. ``I am a terrorist. One must terrorize the enemies of God, says the Koran, chapter eight. I am the Moslem who preaches holy war,'' Fouad Ali Saleh said in the second day of his trial. He remained calmer Tuesday than he had at trial opening on Monday, when he was expelled from the courtroom for the day after loudly declaiming, ``My name is `Death to the West.' You have killed Moslems. This is war.'' Saleh, 31; his French wife, Karima, and eight other men _ three Tunisians, two Moroccans and three Lebanese _ are being tried for terrorist conspiracy, possession of illegal arms, trafficking in explosives and drug offenses. They are to be tried again later this year on murder charges in connection with the 1986 bombings, which killed 13 people and injured more than 250. Eight others are being tried in their absence in this trial, expected to end next week. If convicted, the defendants face 10 to 20 years in prison. After Presiding Judge Henri Malerge described what the defendants are accused of doing, Saleh said, ``You say transporting explosives is illegal, but the West has transported tons of them to colonize the Moslems. France, Jews and Free Masons were the spearhead of colonization.'' In French criminal trials, defendants are allowed from time to time to explain or comment on the evidence being presented. Saleh commented about several women who were victims of the 1986 bombings and are attending the trial: ``I want to say to these women who are looking at me with eyes full of hate. ... They should know the exact reasons for our acts. We were not happy to be placing bombs. I don't hate them.'' Police say Saleh recruited and directed the people who hid explosives smuggled in from Lebanon and placed bombs in key locations in Paris. He is accused of taking orders from leaders of Hezbollah, the pro-Iranian, Shiite Moslem extremist movement in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Snipers Kill 10 in Ethnic Attacks; Police Clamp Curfew
DOC.TEXT: Snipers cruising by car and motorbike killed 10 people and wounded nine, officials said, and a curfew was imposed on the city. The attacks appeared to be the latest outbreak of violence between native Sindis and immigrants from India, called mohajirs. Officials say 23 people were killed in confrontations last month. Officials said Tuesday that after three weeks of calm, men in a car fired on a crowd of people in the Seroghat district just before noon, killing two and wounding three. Two men on a motorbike sprayed gunfire later in the Bhuleli district, killing eight people and wounding six, witnesses said. An angry crowd in Bhuleli protested the shootings by burning a local police station to the ground. Officials said the officers fled without injuries. Authorities then imposed a curfew on the city's 300,000 residents, and enforced it with army and police armored patrols. Officials said the shooting victims included Sindis and mohajirs but they refused to speculate on who the gunmen were. Hyderabad, 100 miles northeast of Karachi, has been the site of repeated Sindi-mohajir clashes since 1986. Hundreds have died and thousands have been wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Proceeds Quickly in Hazelwood Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 10 jurors questioned, four excused; picks up 4th graf, `After the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers said Tuesday a jury could be seated by the end of the week for the trial of the former skipper of the tanker Exxon Valdez, which caused the nation's worst oil spill. Under relentless prodding from Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, attorneys questioned 10 jurors Tuesday from a pool of 91 drawn for the trial of Joseph Hazelwood. Four were excused from the case. Two of those dismissed had expressed concerns about financial problems if the trial were to last two months or longer. The others said they already had made up their minds about who was responsible for the accident. ``This would be a tough one for me ... a lot of damage has been done,'' one prospective juror told the court. Johnstone pushed lawyers from both sides to speed their examinations. ``It's going much faster than I expected,'' said defense lawyer Dick Madson, complaining to reporters that Johnstone was limiting questioning. Asked if 12 jurors could be seated by Friday, he replied, ``If he keeps cutting off questions like he is, yes.'' Hazelwood, 43, faces one felony charge of criminal mischief and three misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating on a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. After the tanker Exxon Valdez ripped its hull apart on Bligh Reef last March 24, it spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. The sludge coated hundreds of miles of shoreline, killed thousands of marine mammals and prompted what Exxon said was a $2 billion cleanup operation involving tens of thousands of workers. Hazelwood's trial began Monday, with Johnstone rejecting another round of defense efforts to get charges dismissed. Madson had argued that charges should be dismissed because the state lacks jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet-Hungarian Talks on Troop Pullout Start Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Talks between Hungary and the Soviet Union on withdrawing all Soviet troops from the country by the end of the year open this week in Budapest, the state news agency MTI said Tuesday. Delegations headed by deputy foreign ministers on both sides will meet Thursday and Friday in the second such negotiations in Eastern Europe since a wave of democratization started loosening the Soviet grip over its Warsaw Pact allies. The first such talks, held in Prague on withdrawing Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia, ended inconclusively this month. A second round of Soviet-Czechoslovak negotiations is due in early February. The estimated 50,000 Soviet troops in Hungary, and about 70,000 in Czechoslovakia, are stationed on the basis of ``temporary'' agreements the Kremlin reached with the two countries after quashing revolts against Stalinism in 1956 in Hungary and in 1968 in Czechoslovakia. While Moscow has signaled willingness to discuss the demands from Prague and Budapest for withdrawal, it is not clear whether the Soviets want the pullouts coordinated with cutbacks due for agreement this year at the Vienna talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe. MTI said Thursday's talks will be attended by senior military figures on each side. Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth announced last week the negotations would begin after he had consulted with Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov on the subject. Nemeth said he and the Soviet agreed that ``the hitherto basis for the stationing of troops on Hungarian soil has outlived itself. There are neither military nor political reasons for their presence.'' Nemeth said Hungary's strategic and geographic position _ unlike Czechoslovakia, it does not border a NATO country _ and its policy meant the Soviet troops could withdraw ``at the earliest possible time.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Leaves Door Open to German Reunification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 17th graf, According to ... UPDATING with Lambsdorff remarks. Picks up 18th, `Modrow invited...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met Tuesday with East German Premier Hans Modrow and appeared to be more open toward eventual German reunification. Modrow told reporters after the meeting that Gorbachev ``did not rule out such a prospect in the future, and at the same time did not venture to set some time limits for that.'' Earlier, the Kremlin chief said any such decisions must include the four Allied powers and take into account European opinions. ``The development of events in the world, in East Germany, in the Soviet Union demand deep consideration and an analytical approach to deciding this problem,'' he said in remarks reported by the official news agency Tass. ``Time itself is acting on this process, giving it dynamism,'' Gorbachev said. ``We have to act responsibly and not decide this important question on the streets.'' Tass said Gorbachev emphasized that talks about restructuring relations between the two Germanys must involve ``all directly interested governments.'' Asked by an East German correspondent about his attitude toward reunification, Gorbachev said the question was not unexpected and that ``no one can cast doubt'' on the reasonableness of asking it. However, the English-language Tass translation indicated Gorbachev could have meant there were no doubts about reunification itself. Gorbachev's position was similar to that adopted by Communists in East Berlin on Tuesday. For the first time, the Communists acknowledged German unity as a long-term goal but said it must be imbedded in the process of overcoming Europe's overall divisions. The Soviet Union traditionally has strongly opposed any talk of German reunification, but Gorbachev has softened that position in adopting a policy that has allowed radical reform in Eastern Europe. Soviets say the question of German reunification is to be decided in the future. Gorbachev, in comments to reporters after meeting French President Francois Mitterrand in Kiev in December, reiterated his view that the existence of two German states is a fact based on the outcome of World War II. But he added, ``The present situation is the result of specific historical events, a specific historical process on this continent. So, history should decide the future of this continent.'' ``I don't think it is a topical question today. A different approach may create a situation that would complicate the entire European process, including the relations between the two German states,'' Gorbachev said. Modrow said the two Germanys could work toward confederation in phases with no time limit. He said he agreed with Gorbachev that reunification must be decided not only by East and West Germany, but all of Europe. According to Tass, the Soviet leader said any action on reunification must not infringe on the interests of either East or West Germany, the four Allied powers: France, Britain, the United States or the Soviet Union, or anyone else in Europe. Count Otto Lambsdorff, head of West Germany's Free Democratic Party, a partner in the governing coalition, said Tuesday in London that Gorbachev has adopted ``a more positive attitude'' toward German reunification. In a TV interview on Britain's Channel 4, he also urged ``economic union'' within 18 months as a prelude to full union of West and East Germany. Lambsdorff said that because of East Germany's political instability it had only two choices _ unification or chaos. Modrow invited Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov to visit East Germany and they accepted, Tass reported. Modrow arrived in Moscow late Monday. A Communist, he has moved forward the country's first free elections from May to March 18 and brought the opposition into a coalition that will govern until then.

DOC.HEAD: School Bus Crash Injures 36 Children
LaserPhoto MDT1
DOC.TEXT: A school bus skidded off a road and into a tree Tuesday afternoon, injuring 36 kindergarteners and first-graders and the driver, authorities said. Most of the vehicle's roof was sheared off in the accident, which occurred around 2:40 p.m. in this town 55 miles northwest of New York City. The bus was taking 38 pupils home from an elementary school. Thirty-six children were taken to six hospitals, State Trooper Robert Gillespie said. Six were admitted with serious injuries _ one in critical condition _ four with lesser injuries and 26 were treated and released, hospital officials said. Some of the children were still being evaluated, but at least three suffered serious head injuries, said Barry Bowman, a spokesman for Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. Gillespie said no charges would be filed against the bus driver, 63-year-old Andrew Callahan, who was hospitalized in fair condition. Troopers were still looking for the cause of the accident Tuesday night, he said. ``He was not speeding,'' Gillespie said. ``It was a dry road. It was sunny out when the accident occurred. We just have to determine why he drove off the road at that point.'' The accident occurred about 15 miles south of the site where a elementary school wall collapsed when a tornado struck last year, killing nine children.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Perform Heart Operations on Baby in Womb
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at a London hospital said Tuesday night they had conducted what they believe are the world's first successful heart operations on a baby still in the womb. Lindsey Allan, the doctor in charge of the fetal cardiology unit at Guys Hospital, said the team there had corrected a heart valve defect in an unborn boy using a balloon catheter guided into place by ultrasonic sound. ``As far as I know this is the first successful operation of its kind,'' she said. She said two operations were carried out on the fetus during the mother's pregnancy, one at 31 weeks and the second at 33 weeks. Ms. Allan said the baby was born prematurely on Jan. 4 _ one week after the second operation _ and underwent surgery for the third time a few hours after birth. She did not say why there had been a delay in disclosing details of the operations. ``The child is still quite seriously ill, but we have given him a chance he would not otherwise have had,'' Ms. Allan said. She said the parents, who did not want to be identified, lived outside London. The operations involved inserting a catheter down a hollow needle directly into the chest wall and heart of the fetus. Once in place, the balloon was dilated to open the heart valve. A catheter is a slender tube inserted into a body passage, vessel or cavity. Its normal uses include passing fluids and making examinations. Ms. Allan said the team that pioneered the technique included herself; Michael Tynan, professor of pediatric cardiology; and Darryl Maxwell, director of the hospital's fetal medicine unit. She said there were always ethical obstacles to this type of operation. ``I am not sure that we should be meddling sometimes. There is always discussion as to whether it is a reasonable request to make of the mother. On the other hand, one knows that the alternative is almost universally fatal,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria Drops Charges against Leading Critic
DOC.TEXT: The military government dropped criminal charges against a major critic Tuesday, and President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida said his administration will not try to muzzle public opinion. Gani Fawehinmi, a lawyer already sentenced this month to a year in prison for contempt of court, was to be charged Tuesday with trying to sabotage the military's plan for return to civilian rule. But prosecutors said they were told to drop the charges. Whether the decision will affect the contempt of court ruling was not clear. In remarks read for him Tuesday, Babangida said the military ``keeps an open door for well-considered, clearly articulated and constructive suggestions.'' Fawenhinmi was cited for contempt for telling a judge he had no faith in his impartiality. The Civil Liberties Organization, this West African nation's main human rights group, called his imprisonment ``a scandalous abuse of judicial powers.'' The country's bar association also appealed to Babangida to overturn the decision and drop all charges against the lawyer. The lawyers and human rights group also have campaigned for elimination of a decree that lets the military detain critics without charge. Babangida announced a relaxation of the decree last week, reducing from six months to six weeks the time detainees could be held without charge.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-State of Union
DOC.TEXT: Four television networks plan live coverage of President Bush's State of the Union address Wednesday and the Democratic response. NBC, ABC, CBS and the Cable News Network all said they plan to interrupt regular programming beginning at 9 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Sinks As Coast Guard Transfers Passengers; Two May Be Missing
DOC.TEXT: Waves swamped an overloaded Haitian sailboat as Coast Guard crewmen were trying to transfer the passengers to their cutter, and two people may have drowned in the confusion, authorities said Tuesday. The cutter Thetis arrived in Port-au-Prince Tuesday with the remaining 48 people aboard, and the Coast Guard has launched an investigation into the incident, said Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis. The sinking occurred Sunday afternoon when the Thetis intercepted the 30-foot sailboat about 400 miles southeast of Miami. After U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service determined the passengers were illegally attempting to enter the United States, the Coast Guard distributed lifejackets and began transferring the Haitians to the cutter. ``A large wave caused the Haitian vessel to capsize and sink, throwing the Haitians, the Coast Guard boarding party and the INS agent into the water,'' a Coast Guard release said. Four Haitians were injured _ one was cut and three nearly drowned _ and passengers reported two others were missing. But because the boat carried no passenger list, the Coast Guard could not determine if the report was accurate, the release said. A search was conducted, but no sign of the two was found, Karonis said. At the time of the accident, winds were 10 knots with seas of 5 to 7 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Editor Wins Damages in High Court Libel Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to DELETE reference to awards as derisory; pickup 7th, `The biggest...'
DOC.TEXT: Sunday Times editor Andrew Neil won a libel case Tuesday against a rival who questioned his taste in women, ending a trial that took the public into the world of Fleet Street's private passions. Neil sued The Sunday Telegraph and its former editor, Peregrine Worsthorne, over an editorial Worsthorne wrote last March saying Neil's affair with a call girl rendered him unfit to edit a quality newspaper. A second article and a cartoon were also cited by Neil. ``It's a clear vindication. I'm delighted,'' said Neil. ``It's been a tough battle. I'm happy with the award.'' Worsthorne, who had argued that his article was fair comment, claimed the damages ``were so derisory that it was as good as a victory.'' A High Court jury awarded Neil about $1,600 in damages, while his employer, Times Newspapers, walked away with just $1 _ the price of the paper. The awards were minimal, compared with the six- and even seven-figure sums handed out to libel victims lately. The biggest money winners were the lawyers. The defendants were ordered to pay an estimated $320,000 in court costs. Worsthorne said it was a case ``that should never have been brought and Mr. Neil should be ashamed of himself. Let this case teach all editors a lesson: Don't sue.'' Worsthorne's editorial, titled ``Playboys as Editors,'' claimed Neil's four-month affair with call girl Pamella Bordes had brought the Sunday Times into disrepute. Neil, a 40-year-old bachelor, sued, saying it was the ``most damaging attack on my professional integrity'' in his six years as Sunday Times editor. He insisted that contrary to what Worsthorne wrote, he did not know Ms. Bordes, 27, was a call girl until after their affair ended. Ms. Bordes was not in court. She became news when tabloid newspapers reported she had worked at the House of Commons as a researcher and had been escorted the previous year by Neil and another Sunday newspaper editor, Donald Trelford of The Observer. Trelford took no action. Neil's award, sniped Worsthorne on Independent Television News, ``wouldn't even pay for a weekend with Ms. Bordes.'' Neil countered that the outcome of the libel case was ``a victory for the new Britain against the old Britain'' _ a swipe at the crusty, conservative style of the Telegraph and 66-year-old Worsthorne. The damages suggested that the jury agreed with Judge Michael Davies, who said in summing up that the case might be ``much ado about nothing.'' Davies said the case reminded him of two great steam locomotives crashing head on.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Turn Out to Replace Savannah Councilman Killed by Mail Bomb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with two candidates to meet in runoff, recast; picks up 8th graf, `There is ...'
DOC.TEXT: Voters picking a successor to a city councilman killed in a rash of mail bombings narrowed the field from eight candidates to two on Tuesday. Educator Clifford Hardwick III and dentist Phyllis Mack led the pack in complete but unofficial returns, and are to meet in a Feb. 20 runoff for Robert Robinson's Council seat. Robinson, a black attorney who worked on civil rights cases, was killed when he opened a package bomb at his law office Dec. 18. A letter claiming responsibility threatened more attacks on black leaders. Hardwick received 920 of the 2,572 votes cast, Mack had 494 and Mary Evans Roberts had 444. The others received votes of 210 or less, including the candidate endorsed by Robinson's widow, Horace Hall, who got 201. Elections supervisor Patty McKenna said the 29 percent turnout was about normal for an election in the district, despite the high emotion provoked by the Robinson slaying. The Rev. Henry R. Delaney said some black people in Savannah are ``apprehensive'' about packages. A secretary at the Savannah office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People told a reporter she could no longer release the names of NAACP officers. ``In light of what's been happening to our people, I'm not at liberty to give out the names of any people affiliated with our organization,'' said the secretary. She declined to give her name. In Mountain Brook, Ala., there has been little discussion of fear for personal safety, although federal marshals still keep watch in the driveway of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance's home, where he was killed by an exploding package two days before Robinson's slaying. The judge's neighbors talk more about their desire to see the killer caught and whether the FBI's dragnet for evidence in southeastern Alabama will yield fruit. Vance's wife, Helen, was injured in the blast but said she has recovered. ``There is a lot of dismay over all the latest publicity, which doesn't seem to be coming to any conclusion unless there's an indictment,'' said the Rev. John Claypool, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, where Vance's ashes are interred. The FBI has searched the property of Enterprise, Ala., junk dealer Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, who denies wrongdoing and has not been charged. O'Ferrell says the FBI thinks he once owned a typewriter used in a letter claiming responsibility. Charles Ashby, the neighbor to whom Mrs. Vance rushed after the explosion last month, said life is returning to normal in the exclusive Shook Hill neighborhood, where estate-sized lots are sprinkled with tall pine trees. Robinson's City Council district in Savannah is 75 percent black, largely poor, an area where many turn-of-the-century homes have not shared in the coastal city's zealous historic preservation. There, the bombings have been followed by other racial threats. Delaney, pastor of St. Paul's Christian Methodist Church and a speaker at Robinson's funeral, recently received a hate letter after he appeared on a television program. A black state representative, Roy Allen, also got a threatening letter. But several people interviewed on the streets of Robinson's district said they don't believe average black Savannah residents feel more threatened now. ``I don't think it's created any excess fear,'' said city water department employee Pearlie Frazier. ``It's just added to the frustration that the average black person feels on a daily basis.'' In both cities, friends of the victims are looking for positive memories. Reuben Davis, a Jefferson County commissioner, wants to establish a memorial to Vance, who pushed for racial equality while chairman of the Alabama Democratic Party. He envisions ``a symbol of a man that worked in his community for peace and harmony and yet died such a violent death.'' In Savannah, state Sen. Al Scott said Robinson's death ``perhaps will draw attention to the senselessness'' of hate crimes and bigotry.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Protester Released from Jail Camp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with group saying anonymous supporter, rather than representative of group, paid fine. Picks up penultimate graf, `Terry originally...'
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion activist Randall Terry, who spent more than three months in jail rather than pay what he said was an unjust fine for trespassing, was released from a work camp Tuesday after the money was paid. Terry, founder of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, was released from Fulton County's Alpharetta Institution after a representative paid his fine of $500 plus a $50 assessment Monday, jail and court officials said. Jane Shepherd, a spokeswoman for Operation Rescue, said the fine was paid by an anonymous supporter, rather than a representative of the organization. Terry of Binghamton, N.Y., had for months refused to pay a fine, saying he could not in good conscience do so. Mary Ann Baney, a Georgia spokeswoman for Operation Rescue, said the group would make no statement about his decision to let the fine be paid. Terry originally received two one-year prison terms for criminal trespass and unlawful assembly. The terms were consolidated into a single one-year term in December, and officials at the time said that with time off for good behavior he could be eligible for release April 5. Terry was sentenced on Oct. 5 following his conviction on charges stemming from anti-abortion protests at the time of the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta in July 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Physicist Who Helped Establish Quark Model Dies
DOC.TEXT: Mirza Abdul Baqi Beg, a physicist whose theoretical work helped establish the model of the subatomic quark particle, died at his home here Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 55. In the 1960s, Beg's work helped verify the modern quark model of hadron structure, which describes hadrons _ nuclear particles like protons and neutrons _ as being composites made up of smaller entities called quarks, The Rockefeller University said in a release. Prior to working in particle physics, he made significant contributions to nuclear physics, the release said. Born in India, Beg earned degrees from Sind University in Pakistan, Karachi University and the University of Pittsburgh. He came to Rockefeller as an assistant professor in 1964 and was appointed a professor in 1968. Previously he was a research associate at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island from 1960-62 and a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., from 1962-64. Beg had been a consultant at Brookhaven since 1965 and was a member of its High Energy Advisory Committee from 1975-78. Beg was a fellow of the American Physical Society and the New York Academy of Sciences, and a trustee of the Aspen Center for Physics. He is survived by his wife, Nancie.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Blocks Unauthorized Biography of Scientology Founder
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked a critical book about Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard, finding that it violated the copyrights of his authorized biographer. U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton said the book, which is still in manuscript form, could be published after infringing passages were deleted. Melvin Wulf, lawyer for the book's publisher, said the decision was ``a dagger in the heart of the First Amendment'' and would not hold up on appeal. ``It would be a terrible incursion into our free speech rights,'' Wulf said. The ruling stemmed from a lawsuit by New Era Publications International, which has certain exclusive copyrights to Hubbard's private papers for the purpose of writing his authorized biography. The company also is the publisher of Scientology books. Hubbard, who died in 1986, founded the Church of Scientology and wrote dozens of books about the religion and his philosophy. He taught that spiritual competence is achieved by ``erasing'' mental images in the unconscious mind that cause irrational behavior. The disputed book, ``A Piece of Blue Sky,'' is written by former Scientologist Jonathan Caven-Atack, who became disillusioned with Hubbard's teachings after following them for nine years. According to Stanton's decision, Atack ``came to believe that Scientology is a dangerous cult and that Mr. Hubbard, far from being the gentle prophet portrayed in Church literature, was a paranoid, vindictive and profoundly disturbed man.'' After receiving permission from Stanton last summer to review the manuscript, New Era said 121 passages, slightly less than 3 percent of the book, were taken from copyrighted sources. The book's publisher, Carol Publishing Group, claimed the passages were allowed by a section of copyright law called fair use, which says copyrighted works can be used for criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching or research. Stanton, however, found that much of the copyrighted material in Atack's book was used by itself at the beginning of a chapter. ``The evident purpose of this device, which is carried out with some effect, is to use passages from Mr. Hubbard's work to set the tone for the sections they precede,'' he said. ``In essence, these passages use copyrighted materials as a literary device rather than a basis for a critical study of Mr. Hubbard.'' The judge said Carol Publishing could easily delete the infringing passages. ``The only apparent hardships resulting from an injunction are some delay in publication and a more stringent editing process.'' Wulf said Stanton had shown a ``total misunderstanding'' of the fair-use law. ``It really threatens to impair the right of biographers and scholars to study the works of other people who are of great public interest,'' he said. New Era's lawyer, Jonathan Rubell, said his client had never intended to stop the book's publication. ``It was the use of expression rather than factual presentation that we were complaining about,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Freighter Seized After Cocaine Found, Cocaine `Loaves' Wash Ashore
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran freighter's eight-man crew was detained Tuesday after federal agents seized about 1,100 pounds of cocaine found aboard the ship about 400 miles southwest of Miami, authorities said. Up the coast, authorities recovered 114 pounds of cocaine hidden in plaster molds shaped like bread loaves that washed up on beaches in affluent Boca Raton and Gulf Stream, and were indirectly linked to the Super Bowl. Coast Guardsmen seized the 195-foot Honduran freighter Katita on Monday evening after finding 362 numbered bricks of cocaine, worth an estimated $11.5 million wholesale, in the forward hold, officials said. The freighter was picked up by radar as it was being towed to Miami because of engine trouble. The Coast Gaurd cutter Dauntless released the tug and took the freighter and her crew to Key West, said Coast Guard Lt. Mac McCullough. The crewmen _ who are from Guatemala, Colombia and the Dominican Republic _ were being held Tuesday while U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents examined the freighter, McCullough said. The freighter's captain ``told us it was a controlled delivery, part of a sting with the DEA,'' said Cmdr. Chuck Beck of the Dauntless. ``We really didn't buy his story.'' DEA spokesman John Fernandes in Miami said the crewmen would be charged with conspiracy to import cocaine. No arrests were made in connection with the cocaine ``loaves'' that washed up on beaches Monday or the cocaine found in a gray suitcase abandoned in the U.S. Customs Service's section of the airport the same day, officials said. The cocaine loaves had an estimated wholesale value of $1.2 million and the cocaine in the suitcase had a value estimated at $366,000. Each ``loaf'' contained about a kilogram, or 2.2 pounds, of the drug. Customs officials believe traffickers threw them overboard during a Super Bowl Sunday drug sweep dubbed Operation Pigskin. ``They thought we'd all be watching the game,'' said William Boisatt, head of Customs' marine operation in Palm Beach County. The 50 pounds of cocaine that washed ashore in Gulf Stream shocked police and town officials in the wealthy resort. ``I have never had anything like this in my 21 fun-filled years on the New York City Police Department,'' said Gulf Stream police Officer Gary Ward. ``This is really an exceptional amount.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Feds About to Request Takeover of Longshoremen
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department is going to ask a federal court next week to take over the longshoremen's union because of accusations the union is controlled by organized crime, according to a television report Tuesday. The Justice Department is going to argue that a trustee should be named to oversee the International Longshoremen's Association because of its alleged criminal affiliation, ABC News reported. The report did not cite sources. A Bush administration official confirmed only that action against segments of the union, and not the entire association, is planned. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney of the Eastern District confirmed that the Southern District was looking into the union, but attorneys there had no comment. A spokesman for the union, Jim McNamara, said the international had not been informed there was an investigation and he was not aware of the action. The government has sought trusteeships in other cases where mob influence was alleged. Four Teamsters locals, for instance, are operating under court trusteeships. Last March, the U.S. attorney's office in the Southern District dropped part of a racketeering lawsuit against Teamsters leadership. In return, the union agreed to election rule changes and the appointment of three monitors with broad powers to oversee union elections and management. The three monitors were appointed by U.S. District Judge David Edelstein in May to serve until 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Rediscovered Radio Scripts Staged By BBC
DOC.TEXT: Radio comedy scripts written by the late Groucho Marx and his brother Chico that were unearthed by a researcher in the U.S. Library of Congress were performed for the first time in 58 years in a London broadcast. A live audience at a British Broadcasting Corp. studio broke into rapturous applause at the end of Tuesday night's performance in which British actors, playing the roles of the two American comedians, read the scripts of the ``Flywheel, Shyster and Flywheel'' show. BBC producer Dirk Maggs said the scripts had not been heard since being broadcast in the United States in 1932. He said the scripts were discovered about a year ago in the Library of Congress in Washington by researcher Mike Barson and that the BBC had successfully bid for exclusive rights to them. He did not explain the legal intricacies of the deal and did not say how much the BBC paid. The scripts for ``Flywheel, Shyster and Flywheel'' were part of a series Groucho and Chico Marx made for Standard Oil but which were never recorded, Maggs said He said the scripts were subsequently filed away and were thought to have been lost until Barson discovered them and realized their importance. Fans of the Marx Brothers stood in line in the rain outside the studio before the show to make sure of getting a seat. The BBC filmed the show and will broadcast it later this year, Maggs said. Groucho was played by Mike Roberts, complete with mustache and big cigar, Groucho's trademarks. Frank Lazarus played Chico. Maggs said: ``The great thing about the scripts is that many of the incredible sketches and gags which they later did in their movies are here in an earlier form and you can see how they developed their ideas. ``They have never been heard since they were first produced and finding the scripts was like finding Tutankhamen's tomb.'' In the scripts, the Groucho character Flywheel is an unscrupulous lawyer and Chico is his even more unscrupulous assistant, Ravelli.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Book Excites Art Lovers, Angers Some Locals
DOC.TEXT: The cover of the new Bradford telephone directory is a hit with art lovers, but many locals are less than enthusiastic about artist David Hockney's colorful, childlike painting of the city where he was born. Some Bradfordians prefer the previous edition's picture-postcard views of the cathedral, castle and surrounding moors, and they have been venting their irritation in letters to the press. ``The letters are all of the same ilk... `My grandchild could do a similar job','' said Malcolm Hoddy, editor of the West Yorkshire Telegraph and Argus. For instance, Vera G. Taylor wrote: ``What an insult to print this outrageous piece of so-called art on our telephone directory. ``Who do they think they are kidding? Not me! I have seen better drawings in our local first schools.'' Hoddy admits he would not recognize his hometown from Hockney's painting, but he has little time for the critics. ``Whenever Hockney paints anything that makes any kind of news, you get the same people writing in,'' Hoddy said. ``They're the same ones who are wondering why Picasso put an eye under an armpit. ``But what a lot of people tend to forget is that Hockney did this for no charge. It's not costing anybody anything, and they're getting a phone book with a Hockney picture on it under the door for free,'' Hoddy said. Hockney's supporters point out that the painter not only is a living rebuttal of Yorkshire's reputation for low-brow dourness, but he has stayed in touch with Bradford despite having lived in Los Angeles for 25 years. The 51-year-old artist has participated in other civic projects; designing the cover for a handbook for the disabled, and a ``Bradford's Bouncing Back'' poster for a campaign to invigorate the industrial city of 460,000 people. The phone company, British Telecom, printed 295,000 copies of the book to meet the needs of Bradford and surrounding places like Blubberhouses, Horton-in-Ribblesdale and Haworth, the hometown of the Bronte sisters. But British Telecom anticipated outside interest and printed an extra 5,000 copies, said spokeswoman Anne Crawther. ``We've received requests from people in Dallas, Seattle, Geneva and Germany,'' she said. She said 50 copies were being sent to Hockney, and a London collector has bought 500 volumes at $6 each. Hockney has retained the original painting and rights to its use, Ms. Crawther said. Hockney originals now fetch more than $1 million, but art expert John Kasmin doubted the phone book would appreciate in value. ``If people are buying the phone book because they think it will be worth something, I should think they are misguided,'' Kasmin said.

The Pentagon's plan to close or scale back 72 U.S. military installations has riled officials in large cities and small towns. Targeted communities nationwide are mobilizing to ``fight like the dickens'' to avoid the cuts. California would be the hardest hit under Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposal, with 10 bases employing more than 35,000 servicemen and 22,000 civilian workers slated for closure or reductions. But the closings also would hit hard in communities such as Charlestown, Ind., a southern Indiana town of 5,700 where the Defense Department plans to mothball a munitions plant and lay off about 900 workers. In announcing his $292.1 billion fiscal 1991 spending plan Monday, Cheney called for Congress to ``have the guts'' to make tough decisions about closing military bases.

Vice President Dan Quayle, home from a three-nation trip, is proclaiming a bright future for Panama even as some nations in the region refuse to recognize its U.S.-installed government. Jamaica underscored its refusal Monday on the last stop of Quayle's three-day trip. Quayle later said he gave President Bush a ``very upbeat'' report on his visit to Honduras, Panama and Jamaica during a telephone call on Monday, and planned to brief him in full today. However, the vice president acknowledged that while the United States is pressing for other Central American countries to recognize the government of President Guillermo Endara, Jamaica and Venezuela are insisting that elections be held there to legitimize Endara first.

Prosecutors have a second witness to corroborate the testimony of a convicted drug dealer who claims he sold crack cocaine to Mayor Marion Barry and smoked it with him, law enforcement sources say. James McWilliams, a longtime friend of convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, will plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge of aiding and abetting a drug sale and will cooperate with the investigation of Barry's ties to Lewis, a law enforcement source said Monday. Barry, who has denied using drugs, was arrested in an FBI sting operation on Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge for allegedly smoking crack in a Washington hotel room. He is in a private facility in Florida for what an aide says is primarily treatment of alcoholism. McWilliams, a motor vehicles department employee, is expected to appear before a grand jury investigating Barry's ties to Lewis, according to the law enforcement source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Researchers unveiled a prototype computer that uses light instead of electrical impulses to process data, and said it could be as revolutionary as the transistor that ushered in the computer age. The computer processor that Bell Laboratories displayed Monday was crude, with enough power only to operate something like a dishwasher. Within a decade, however, it could lead to development of light-based supercomputers operating at least 100 times faster than current machines, said Alan Huang, head of Bell Labs' optical computer research department. ``This stage says it can be done,'' said Bob Trier, technical program director for Research Consortium Inc. of Minneapolis, which studies high-performance computing. ``The next stage is to find out what can be done with this technology.'' For years, researchers have been looking at photons, the fundamental particles of light, as replacements for electrons in electronic equipment. Such a shift promises computers vastly more agile and powerful than today's machines.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Vignette: Nights of Song
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: While most of Beijing settles down for an evening of TV, a small segment is out on the town singing. Restaurants that dish out food in daylight turn into sing-along clubs called ``karaoke'' after sundown and have brought a little life to Beijing's otherwise dull nights. ``There's not much to do in Beijing at night, ...'' said hotel worker Qiu Jingshi, 20, between songs at the Yanhai Restaurant. ``But here, we can listen to music, dance and sing karaoke. I do songs by singers from Taiwan and China, not in English because I don't understand the words.'' He was one of about 60 young people who paid $4.20 each one recent night to sing along at the Yanhai, which provides soundtracks of well-known songs from 9 p.m. to 2 a.m. nightly and until 5 a.m. Saturdays. The Yanhai has a repertoire of songs in Chinese, and 364 English titles including tunes from Elvis Presley, Neil Sedaka and Perry Como to the Monkees, Madonna and Janet Jackson. Old favorites range from ``Three Blind Mice'' and ``Havah Nagila'' to ``Moon River'' and ``Rock Around the Clock.'' In the dim light, a couple sing a duet of ``Tennessee Waltz.'' A young man sings a Chinese song; later people dance to taped music. ``My friends told me it was a lot of fun, so I came to try it out,'' said Qi Hong, a 21-year-old coed. ``I can sing two songs in English: `River of No Return' and `Love Story'.'' Zhang Liang works nightly as a singer at the Mingxing Restaurant, a bright oasis of gaudy neon lights on a quiet Beijing back street. The 20-year-old bartender-by-day was hired to sing twice a night at the Mingxing to lend atmosphere and encourage timid Chinese vocalists to sing along with him. ``If things slow down, I'll come out and sing again,'' he says. With his flowing hair and acid-washed denim jacket with stainless steel studs, Zhang cuts a striking figure on the spotlighted stage as he belts out numbers in Mandarin and Cantonese. Nowhere are there foreigners, who usually go to more expensive bars and discos in joint-venture hotels reserved for them and often are barred from Chinese night spots. Zhang earns $6.40 a night, working from 9 p.m. to midnight. He loves dancing, especially ``pili-wu'' (breakdancing) and, like most Chinese his age, is a fan of Michael Jackson. ``I watch videos of the American Grammy awards every year,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Tuesday PMs, Feb. 6

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Family Savings Plan: Success or Failure?
DOC.TEXT: In proposing an inducement to saving, President Bush is seeking to uproot what has become an American tradition, one of living for the moment, of living in debt, of borrowing from the future. It is a pervasive habit, one so common you might say ``everyone'' does it _ Uncle Sam, corporations, households, and students who used to work their way through college. Lender or borrower, they're all hooked on debt. Insidiously, debt to support further spending tends to entrap, forcing the user to borrow again and again. Interest costs, for example, are one of the reasons Uncle Sam runs a budget deficit. He has to borrow to pay them. Once people try debt they seem to like it, and they'll go to any extreme to justify it. Corporations issue junk bonds that endanger their futures. Uncle Sam seeks budget balance by shoving items off the budget sheets. That's still not enough for many households. They commit what used to be thought of as a mortal sin, mortgaging the roof over their heads by taking out an equity loan. Many go further, borrowing on their insurance policies. There's a peddlar, a pusher on every corner. Banks that should know better offer cards and credit lines to strangers. Wall Street packages debt and sells it as securities. The media glamorize extravagance. Publishers push books on borrowing your way to wealth. And now, President Bush wants individual Americans to just say no. His proposal is this: a new ``family savings plan'' that would allow interest to accumulate free of income taxes. Under the proposal, couples could set aside $5,000 and individuals $2,500 a year and avoid any income tax on interest earned if the money remained in the account for at least seven years. Can the proposal encourage people to save? Maybe. Much depends on economic conditions. A high or rising inflation rate could endanger it, first by encouraging spending in advance of higher prices, secondly by undermining real returns. High inflation also could force households to cash out for living expenses. It also would require faith by savers. History shows that to some extent tax laws are changed every year. Tax benefits of IRAs, or Individual Retirement Accounts, for example, were reduced after a few years. Of course, if people already are living to the full extent of their incomes, and beyond, they might not have money to put away. Can it really change the general attitude toward borrowing and saving? It could be a start, if combined with other proposals, such as the president's idea of lowering capital gains taxes for investments held three years or longer, but the habit of borrowing rather than saving is imbedded. Bush certainly can make a beginning. Similarly ``impossible'' feats have been performed. A decade ago, for instance, some of the best minds in finance said single-digit home mortgages rates never would be seen again. How wrong! In seeking change, Bush has some things going for him: _Even stronger than the urge to save or spend might be the urge to avoid taxes. A decade ago all consumer interest was tax deductible. A gradual phasing out brings the deductible this year to just 10 percent of the total. Thus, one of the main inducements to borrowing has been or will be removed. _America is older. One reason for high borrowing and low savings was the population's age. There was a bulge of people age 20 years to 35 years, the big-spending years. That bulge is moving up in age, its big spending behind it. _The pressure is growing on Uncle Sam to reduce his own spending ways. There has been some success, and maybe more to come. If so, Uncle Sam might be the perfect role model.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, January 31

DOC.TEXT: Stiltsville is on its last legs. The cluster of rustic vacation homes rising out of Florida's Biscayne Bay will have to come down by the turn of the century, by decree of the government. For people like Thatcher Edmunds, it will be a paradise lost.

Thatcher Edmunds recalls back in the early 1960s when the stilt structures dotting the flats of Biscayne Bay were notorious hangouts for gamblers, boozers and flashy women. Characters such as Plucky Pierre and his right-hand man, Shipwreck Kelly, ran a joint called The Bikini Club, where a pink card gained entry for members any time of day or night. Seamen found their way to the Quarterdeck Club, which was fully equipped with a bar, table games, and, for a time, slot machines. ``Ours, though, was strictly for family,'' says Edmunds, who calls his dwelling on stilts the ``A house.'' So-named because of its distinctive A-frame architecture, the faded yellow retreat sits in several feet of water along with 13 other such vacation homes and weekend retreats off the southern coast of Key Biscayne. Pleasure boaters cruising Biscayne Bay can hardly miss the stilt homes that have become a veritable Miami landmark. Curious Miamians and visitors alike pass through Stiltsville's natural deep-water channels en route to the ocean and sometimes leave slashes in the sea grasses after dragging their engines on the bay bottom in the clear, shallow water around the homes. But even with its reputation considerably mellowed and more family oriented, Stiltsville will no longer exist at the turn of the century. Residents' leases for quarter-acre underwater sites won't be renewed after July 1, 1999, by decree of the Florida Cabinet. The state allowed the bay bottom to be leased through the next decade but prohibited new construction after the Legislature passed the Biscayne Bay Aquatic Preserve Act in 1974. ``We are taking this area, which is close to a large urban area, and returning it to its natural state,'' says Lisa Garvin, spokeswoman for the 173,000-acre Biscayne National Park. Although some people have called Stiltsville an eyesore and environmental concerns have been raised, Edmunds and others say the homes should be saved. ``Maybe they're jealous because they can't build,'' Edmunds says. ``We were there long before it was a national park. We're not bothering anyone.'' Edmunds, 61, a retired trucking company supervisor from Pembroke Pines, shares the retreat with three other families. The 40-by 50-foot, three-bedroom house, about six miles offshore from Miami and a mile from the Cape Florida lighthouse, has stood for 27 years. Hurricane Donna leveled the original structure. Residents now can rebuild homes damaged during storms only if at least 51 percent of the structure remains intact. It took about a year for the families to build the A-frame house themselves, towing scrap lumber and materials to the site in small outboards. ``It was almost like homesteading,'' Edmunds says. In 1965, he says, Ivan Tors Studios featured the house as the base of operations for an underwater coal mining company in the movie ``Round the World Under the Sea.'' Church groups and Boy Scouts also have borrowed the place for special retreats. Don't expect any luxuries here, Edmunds says, though it's the best getaway possible still within sight of the Miami skyline. ``You never run out of things to do _ relax, fish, water-ski, dive, or watch the boats go by,'' he says. There is no television, no telephone. They catch rainwater for showers and washing dishes. Generators provide electricity, and the breeze off the bay provides ``the world's best air conditioning,'' Edmunds says as he throws open the wooden doors off the combination sitting room-kitchen-dining area. The bay, its water patches of light green and indigo blue, used to offer some of the best bonefishing anywhere before Miami's population boomed, Edmunds says. But despite the decline in marine life, it's still easy to catch a panful of fish for supper. ``You can cast off the porch any time you want and catch all the fish you want,'' Edmunds says. Old pictures from family outings cram a large bulletin board inside the wooden house, many of them showing bloody sharks bigger than the young boys who caught them. Over the course of about 60 years, residents of Stiltsville have often helped boaters who became stranded or got caught in a bad storm. ``Through the years I can't imagine how many I've pulled off the flats or helped them repair their boats or towed them in,'' Edmunds says. Residents pay the state Department of Natural Resources $1,000 annually to lease the site. When the first structures began shaping Stiltsville, the bay bottom was leased for $1 an acre. The community peaked after World War II, with some 20 residences. Today, some of the structures have fallen into disrepair after years of constant exposure to wind and salt spray. Edmunds says it's a constant battle to keep up his retreat, replacing beams, painting and making repairs. He worries about Stiltsville's possible deterioration in the next decade because owners may decide it's not worth spending the money for repairs if they'll have to move or tear down the residences. If the state remains committed to eliminating Stiltsville, Edmunds says, it'll do more than just take away a slice of paradise for owners in the area. ``It'll take away a lot of pleasure for people who visit,'' he says. ``It's just the neatest place in the world.''
