DOC.HEAD: Eight Deaths Among Followers of Spiritual Counselor Prompt Investigation
An AP Extra
LaserPhoto DN1 of Jan. 29
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor investigating the deaths of eight followers of a housewife-turned-guru over the last 12 years is trying to piece together a criminal case with a hard-to-prove premise: that beliefs can kill. Four followers of mystical leader Terri Hoffman have committed suicide, including two of her four husbands, and two died in apparent accidents. Of those six, two told relatives they suffered from terminal illnesses, although autopsies showed they did not, and at least four bequeathed money and property to Ms. Hoffman. Then, in November, police linked the deaths of an investment counselor and his wife to Ms. Hoffman's pastiche of philosophy, ancient mythology and metaphysics. David and Glenda Goodman were found shot to death in their den, two handguns beside them on the floor. On a desk a few feet away lay two purple spiral-bound notebooks in which they recorded their devotion to Ms. Hoffman. In one book, Mrs. Goodman called ``the shooting'' the path to success and an escape from the sufferings of the physical world. Soon, she wrote to her husband, he would be able to come and go from the physical world at will, just as, she said, ``Terri'' can. The journals tell more: how the Goodmans, both 48, were considering leaving their home to Ms. Hoffman. Their check registers indicated they'd already given her $110,000 over three years, police say. In addition to the deaths of the eight devotees, a ninth person, a housekeeper, died when the car of one follower plunged off a Colorado cliff. Assistant District Attorney Cecil Emerson said he's trying to determine whether ``mind control'' can be legally blamed for contributing to a death, which might require breaking new legal ground. ``It's never entered anyone's mind that you could put together a case like this,'' Emerson said. ``I'm confident we can.'' Still, he conceded it would be a long time before he could put the case before a grand jury _ if it even gets that far. ``The theme of this investigation is murder,'' he said. ``The reality is probably theft.'' So far, investigators have gathered mostly autopsy reports, the files of police investigations into the accidents and the financial records of some of those who died. No criminal action has been taken against Ms. Hoffman, but two lawsuits have been filed against her. In 1982, the brother of follower Sandra Cleaver contested her will leaving everything to Ms. Hoffman, including a $300,000 life insurance policy and a house. Six days after the case went to trial, Ms. Hoffman and Ms. Cleaver's brother agreed out of court to split the estate. She faces a civil trial in March stemming from a wrongful death suit brought by the children of her fourth husband, Don Hoffman, who killed himself in September 1988. Ms. Hoffman's attorney, Fred Time, said she is being persecuted. ``It's witch hunting,'' Time said. ``She's supposed to have all these tremendous powers _ ridiculous. There's no history of that anywhere in the world.'' He said the suit and investigation would clear Ms. Hoffman, 51, who he described as a ``plain, ordinary person who gets money by counseling people.'' How does he explain the number of deaths among her followers? ``She listens to people who are in extremely transient stages of their life,'' Time said. Ms. Hoffman told The Associated Press she would answer questions only in the presence of Time, who said he would not allow her to speak to reporters while an investigation was pending. Ms. Hoffman became known in Dallas in the late 1960s and early '70s for her meditation classes, a blend of mythology and metaphysics in which ``masters'' were said to be reached. ``A Master is a high, evolved being who has great wisdom,'' she told The Monthly Aspectarian last year. She described for the Chicago-based magazine her first experience with ``masters,'' which took place at age 3, saying, ``They explained to me that they were beings that sometimes helped people that are in physical bodies or other bodies, and they come to teach them.'' In 1974, Ms. Hoffman founded Conscious Development of Body, Mind & Soul Inc. to sell tapes and booklets of her teachings. She sold thousands, Time said, and attracted hundreds of followers. David Goodman became one of them in the early '70s. He met Ms. Hoffman at Dallas' Southern Methodist University, where he was a business professor and she was teaching a meditation class, Emerson said. Ms. Hoffman counseled Goodman during his first divorce, they became friends and, years later, made business investments together. When Ms. Hoffman was sued by Ms. Cleaver's brother, Goodman testified on her behalf. And when he left SMU in 1987, she helped him start an investment newsletter. Goodman married and divorced twice more before he met his fourth wife, Glenda, also a devotee. They continued to adhere to Ms. Hoffman's teachings years after most followers abandoned them. Ms. Hoffman's classes began to dissipate in 1977 after the suicide of her second husband, Glenn Cooley. Some followers have said they became wary as Ms. Hoffman's meditations and spiritual sessions focused less on learning than on fighting ``evil'' forces. Cooley killed himself less than a week after the couple's divorce became final, the first of the nine deaths police now are investigating. In 1979, Devereaux Cleaver, the 14-year-old daughter of Sandra Cleaver, drowned rafting in Hawaii. Two years later, Ms. Cleaver and her housekeeper, who did not follow Ms. Hoffman's teachings, died in a car that tumbled off a Colorado cliff near land owned by some devotees. In 1987, another follower, Robin Otstott, shot herself after telling people she had viral hepatitis. Like Don Hoffman, who said he had cancer when he took a drug overdose, an autopsy showed Ms. Otstott did not have the disease she claimed. A Chicago follower of Ms. Hoffman, Mary Levinson, also killed herself in 1987. Just weeks before, she changed her will to dispose of her estate, valued at more than $125,000, in a manner that could not be traced, her parents told The Dallas Morning News. Ms. Hoffman told the newspaper she did not receive any money from Ms. Levinson, but would not answer other questions. Ms. Hoffman was a beneficiary in both her husbands' wills, as well as in Ms. Cleaver's and Ms. Otstott's, Time confirmed. Police have not found a will for the Goodmans, but their journals indicate they considered deeding their house to Ms. Hoffman. Those writings also suggest they were concerned about tax problems. Goodman lost money in a Dallas investment company whose leaders were convicted of tax fraud last year, Emerson said. Though Goodman was not implicated in any criminal activity, he lost thousands of dollars in the company's illegal shelters. In 1988, he reached an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service to retire a tax debt estimated at more than $300,000, the Morning News reported. The IRS declined to release details of the case. Goodman's father said the couple broke off contact with relatives and many friends in 1989. ``We had a fine, loving relationship up until then,'' said Leonard Goodman, 74, of Santa Maria, Calif. ``Something very unusual _ it turned out very tragic _ happened to break that relationship.''

The Goodmans' two purple notebooks contain some of the strongest evidence investigators have linking them to Ms. Hoffman. On page after page, David Goodman, calling himself Jupiter after the Roman god, asks questions of Glenda, addressed as Venus, about their quest to ``leave the physical.'' DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Richard Gere Back in the Movie Fast Lane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf to fix role Gere played in `Looking for Mr. Goodbar' to boyfriend sted murderer.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Returning to his bad-guy beginnings, Richard Gere is back in the movie fast lane after a lapse that had Hollywood wondering if he was more interested in causes than an acting career. Gere crashed onto the movie scene in 1977 as one of Diane Keaton's sleazy boyfriends in ``Looking for Mr. Goodbar.'' It was a small part and helped get him the lead as the male prostitute in the seamy ``American Gigolo'' in 1980. He soon became a top leading man, most notably in the 1982 hit ``An Officer and a Gentleman.'' A few bombs followed, then a long absence from the screen. He seemed to be devoting all his energies to alerting the public to the longtime Chinese repression in Tibet. Now Gere has returned to the movie bigtime in Paramount Picture's ``Internal Affairs,'' starring as a crooked cop. The film received mixed reviews from critics, but has found favor with audiences, earning $11 million in two weeks. Gere next appears in a romantic comedy with Julia Roberts, ``Pretty Woman,'' for Touchstone Pictures. ``Internal Affairs'' casts Gere as Dennis Peck, a veteran Los Angeles street cop who has become an expert in extortion and murder-for-hire. Andy Garcia is the detective who investigates him. Peck is a thorough sleaze and misogynist, but Gere doesn't see him that way. ``He doesn't think he's bad. You know, this was a very tough script. It was a very disturbing read, as well as to see it. I had to really look into it to see what was so disturbing and what was worthwhile about the film,'' Gere said. ``I realized that it was similar to Iago and Othello. It was that kind of evil: the evil of Iago. In Peck's case it was the same as Othello; it was jealousy that he pinpoints. ``The more I looked into him, the more I saw of this incredible megalomaniac control _ not the small kind that we have in most of our lives, but an extraordinary kind of octopus of arms and tentacles going out in all directions. He had five wives and ten kids, and he controlled these families as well as the police department. But on the other hand, he did not need to be more than a foot soldier.'' Gere plays his own age, 40, graying hair and all. He sounds like an old-timer when he comments about co-star Garcia: ``I saw in him _ he's in his early 30s _ a lot of myself when I was his age. I had the same level of intensity that he's coming from.'' He added with a grin: ``I keep telling them I can play 18 but they don't believe me. (Age) doesn't bother me either way. There are a couple of films I'm developing that would be aging movies, from the late 20s into the 50s. Certainly playing the younger of those characters I would dye my hair.'' Throughout his career, Gere has never been comfortable with interviews. But he seemed more at ease when he was recently here to promote ``Internal Affairs.'' Except for the little-seen ``Miles From Home,'' he has been absent from the big screen for three years. During much of that time he devoted himself to the cause of his longtime friend, the Dalai Lama. The actor helped establish Tibet House New York, aimed at preserving the country's heritage. Two events last year helped bring Tibet's plight to the world's attention, he said, citing the massacre during pro-democracy protests by Chinese students in Tiananmen Square, and the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama _ Gere attended the presentation ceremonies in Oslo, Norway. He said Tiananmen Square was ``perhaps 10 percent of what the Chinese have been doing every day in Tibet for 35 years.'' Gere was born in Philadelphia and grew up on a farm near Syracuse, N.Y. He remembers his debut as an actor: ``My first role was Santa Claus in the second grade. My mother made the costume herself, which she still reminds me of. In high school I played the president of the United States, and the entire audience of my peers started howling that Dick Gere was playing the president. ``At 19 I left college (University of Massachusetts), thinking I had done nothing with my life. That's when I went into repertory.'' After work at the Provincetown Playhouse and the Seattle Repertory Theater, he played off-Broadway roles and Danny Zuko in the New York and London companies of ``Grease.'' His film debut came in Terence Malick's ``Days of Heaven.'' He also co-starred in the Broadway production of ``Bent'' after ``American Gigolo.'' A series of mishaps _ ``Breathless,'' ``Beyond the Limits,'' ``The Cotton Club,'' ``King David,'' ``Power,'' ``No Mercy'' _ spelled trouble for Gere's career. But like John Travolta with ``Look Who's Talking,'' he appears on the rebound. Of his recent absence, he said: ``It wasn't the wisest thing in the world, but I'm in this for the rest of my life. As long as I can keep growing as an individual, the career will take care of itself.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Feb. 9-11

DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent Congress a $1.23 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 that keeps new spending below inflation and recognizes ``remarkable changes'' in the world by scaling back defense and rewarding emerging democracies. Bush called the spending plan an ``investment in the future.'' But Democratic leaders in Congress pounced on it Monday as a ``standpat budget'' and challenged its claim to halve the federal deficit, to $63.1 billion.

President Bush asked Congress to bolster Americans' savings rate by cutting taxes on capital gains and allowing families to earn tax-free interest on long-term savings accounts. His fiscal 1991 budget plan disclosed Monday recommends $15.7 billion worth of tax increases, but no general boost in income taxes, and a $5.6 billion increase in user and service fees. At the same time, Bush proposed $1.8 billion in tax reductions in addition to the capital-gains cut, including a new credit of up to $1,000 a year for each child under age 4 in low-income families.

Consumers who test drive a Chrysler Corp. product against any comparable car or truck will get $50 cash, even if they buy the competing vehicle, Chrysler said. The new offer, outlined Monday, could be costly to the nation's No. 3 automaker, which is seeking to cut $1 billion in costs from its $26 billion annual budget by 1991. If all of Chrysler's December car-buyers had test driven another company's model, Chrysler would have doled out $3.2 million.

Cash-strapped Bank of New England Corp. says it would sell its credit card business to Citicorp for $828 million. The announcement Monday follows Bank of New England's disclosure earlier this month it was trying to sell $6 billion worth of assets. The bank has said it expects a loss of more than $1 billion in 1989 because of bad real estate loans.

Researchers are focusing on light as the medium of information in the next generation of supercomputers, creating the possibility of vastly more agile and powerful hardware. AT&T's Bell Laboratories on Monday announced the development of the first prototype of a computer that processes data through light rather than electrical impulses, or the movement of electrons.

Consumer spending posted its largest increase in three years in 1989, the government reported, and analysts said robust incomes should result in continued purchasing strength in the first quarter of 1990. The Commerce Department said Monday spending totaled $3.47 trillion, a 7.3 percent gain over 1988 and the sharpest gain since a 6.1 percent rise in 1986. At the same time, the government said personal incomes rose 9 percent to $4.43 trillion last year, up from 7.6 percent in 1988 and the fastest advance since rising 9.5 percent in 1984.

Medical insurance costs for employers rose 20.4 percent in 1989, driven by increasing use of expensive medical technology and escalating costs of outpatient and substance abuse services, according to a new survey. The survey of 1,943 employers, conducted by employee benefits consultant A. Foster Higgins & Co. Inc. and released Monday, found the average cost of medical plans rose to $2,600 per employee last year from $2,160 in 1988.

The government banned some uses of the color additive Red No. 3, and the result may be that ``red'' may not be as ``red'' in lipstick, cake frostings, cough drops and some processed fruits and juices. The Food and Drug Administration announcement on Monday said some uses of the dye are being halted because Red No. 3 in high doses has been shown to cause cancer in rats.

US Sprint said some customers will be able to place long-distance calls with their voices by summer in what would be the first voice-activated dialing offered by a long-distance company. Sprint said Monday that the new service, targeted toward business travelers, would allow a caller to use a spoken password instead of a standard long-distance travel card, which requires callers to punch in as many as 24 digits.

The stock market settled broadly lower in volatile trading Monday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 5.85 points to 2,553.38. Bond prices sank. The dollar fell against major foreign currencies. Soybean futures prices rebounded sharply; grain futures advanced; oil futures rose strongly; pork bellies posted limit losses while livestock futures were mixed; and precious metals declined.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Market Regulators Get Boost in Funding
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration proposed increasing fees on securities and futures transactions to help fund higher spending by the federal agencies that regulate both industries. The government's fiscal year 1991 budget, released Monday, calls for a $47 million funding increase for the Securities and Exchange Commission, the independent agency that regulates the nation's stock and bond markets. The budget also seeks an 11-cent-per-transaction fee on futures trades to cover the expenses of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the nation's futures markets. Spokesmen for both the Securities Industry Association and the Futures Industry Association were not in their office when called for comment late Monday. The $1.23 trillion budget proposal seeks to increase the SEC's annual funding to $186.6 million, an increase of 34 percent or $47 million over outlays for 1990. Spending for the CFTC would increase by about $7.7 million, or 21 percent, to $44.5 million. The budget plan for the SEC noted that a temporary increase in securities registration fees beginning July 1 is expected to raise nearly $22.9 million, ``which is to be counted as offsetting receipts.'' That is, the amount would go toward funding the SEC's $139.5 million outlay for fiscal year 1990. All securities offered for sale to the public must be registered with the SEC, whose main mission is to protect the investing public. The SEC is not self-funding, although it collects nearly twice as much in fees than it is allocated in the budget. In addition to calling for making the registration fee increase permanent, the Bush administration plans to seek legislation to raise fees charged for all transactions on a securities exchange, for all mergers and proxy votes, and to extend the fee increase to securities traded over the counter that qualify for trading in a national market system. The budget proposal projected that those fee increases, if approved by Congress, would generate $80.1 million for the government in fiscal year 1991. The plan's 11-cent futures transaction fee, beginning Oct. 1, would cover additional expenses for the CFTC. Those expenses would include stepped up market surveillance and investigations called for by Congress in the wake of indictments at the nation's two-largest futures exchanges in Chicago last summer.

DOC.HEAD: Recovery Center's Location to be Confidential
DOC.TEXT: A Caribbean island retreat for chemically dependant professionals aims to let well-heeled clients kick the habit in style _ and in anonymity. ``We take it further than just explaining the disease and saying `abstain.' We teach people to enjoy life,'' said Karen Ann Crissy, president of the Ft. Lauderdale-based Caribbean Retreat Inc. ``It's more like a Club Med with a therapeutic focus.'' The 20-acre island is fully booked for the first 21-day session of therapy, sports and recreation, which starts next month, she said. The cost of treatment, which includes transportation to the island by private air charter, is $15,000. The retreat's program will focus on stress management and is based on therapies offered by Alcoholics Anonymous, Crissy said. Crissy and two other investors bought the tropical island for about $1 million from a New York syndication of companies that used it for corporate vacations. Clients must be drug- or alcohol-free for 30 days and in good health before being accepted for treatment, she said. Both clients and staff must sign an agreement to keep the island's name and locale confidential. To further protect clients' confidentiality, Crissy said the program will not do any third-party billing, so it will not be recorded on medical records or be covered by insurance. ``We stress anonymity, seclusion and privacy,'' she said. ``We want to protect the people who are going there.'' Caribbean Retreat features a program of individual and group therapy that promotes healing through a mix of metaphysics, meditation, philosophy and physical activity. Crissy said she has hired psychologists, sports coaches and hypnotists to work with her clients. She is marketing her recovery center to the directors of corporate employee assistance programs. Since those programs are confidential, they can pass the information along to employees in need. One such program director said he is not sure if it's a good idea to send someone with a drug or alcohol problem to an island retreat. Paul Heck, director of the employee assistance program at J.C. Penney Co. near Dallas, said the geographic isolation could make some families feel left out of the recovery process, and addicts could see the retreat trip as a chance to escape problems at home. ``This is a guy who lives for the job, comes home and is an absent husband,'' said Heck. ``Now he is off on a Caribbean island and we're supposed to be happy.'' Nevertheless, the retreat's seclusion could be attractive to some, Heck said. ``For many people, it would be worth the money to keep it confidential.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank Announces Deal to Sell Credit Card Business to Citicorp
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp., which has suffered heavy real estate losses and watched depositors withdraw millions of dollars, says it will raise $828 million by selling its credit card business to Citicorp. ``We are very pleased to announce the completion of this important step in our asset sales strategy,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said in a statement Monday. ``We are right on track with our strategic plan.'' Bullock was named interim chairman last week after the board forced out the previous chairman, Walter Connolly. Bank of New England announced earlier this month it was trying to sell $6 billion worth of assets because it expected to post a loss of more than $1 billion in 1989 because of bad real estate loans. The bank said it expected to make a profit of about $176 million from selling the credit card business. Analysts said the ability to raise more than $800 million in cash was more important. ``This relieves some of the funding pressure on them,'' said Gerard Cassidy, a banking analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. ``It gives them a little more breathing room.'' The bank last week had to borrow money from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston as small and large depositors withdrew millions of dollars. Bank and federal officials have not confirmed the amount borrowed, but it was believed to be around $450 million. The sale of the credit card business must be approved by banking regulators. Tom Lavelle, a bank spokesman, said approval normally would take about a month, but both Bank of New England and Citicorp are trying to get the deal cleared ``in short order.''

DOC.HEAD: The National, Daily Sports Paper, Debuts Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The National, the all-sports newspaper that debuts Wednesday in three big cities, is going to test the American appetite for sports with 30-plus pages of stories, analysis, color photos and slickly presented statistics six days a week. Publisher Peter O. Price and his old college buddy, Frank Deford, are going to give readers ``a regular diet'' of what Price says most men buy their hometown daily newspaper for _ sports coverage. Deford, the former Sports Illustrated writer, is the editor in charge of a 125-person editorial staff. Price says the owners have the patience _ and the money _ to give the new tabloid whatever time is needed to succeed. Wednesday's launch in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago is expected to cost $25 million. The paper will be published Sunday through Friday and cost 50 cents a copy. It will be available at first only at newstands and machines. The National is being backed by Emilio Azcarraga, a publicity-shy media baron from Mexico who is a major exporter of Spanish-language TV programming. Azcarraga is the lead member of a partnership that includes Price and others and is prepared, Price said, to spend $100 million to make it profitable. The National will offer a core of national sports coverage including columns, investigations, gossip and cartoons. Each city's issue will have expanded coverage of its local teams. Plans are to expand gradually into other major cities such as Detroit, Dallas, Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco, with a target of being in 15 cities by the end of 1990. The launch comes at a treacherous economic juncture. Forecasters are divided on whether a recession looms ahead, national ad spending has been sluggish and competition among media outlets for ads has never been fiercer. In addition, the paper faces the longer-term test of winning over a national audience. John Morton, newspaper analyst for the investment firm Lynch, Jones & Ryan, notes the country has seldom supported national newspapers. He said one of the few successes, Gannett Co. Inc.'s USA Today, already provides considerable sports information. Local papers, on the other hand, can easily expand their sports coverage if they sense a threat from the new national sports daily, he said. The key issue facing The National, Morton said, is this: ``Is there that much interest in spectator sports news on a daily basis?'' Price said the success of all-sports programming on cable television has demonstrated a hearty U.S. appetite for sports. A former publisher of the New York Post, Price said readers will buy The National in addition to their local paper. The National's ad sales director, Peter A. Spina, said discounted advertising sales are ahead of projections with almost 1,200 pages of ads ordered before the launh, surpassing an initial goal of 1,000. Advertisers include Procter & Gamble Co., Philip Morris Cos. and General Motors Corp. The newspaper is counting heavily on circulation for revenue, at least at the start. The initial target is average daily circulation of 200,000. ``Readers can expect the best-written and best-looking newspaper in the country,'' said Deford, who quit Sports Illustrated to take the editor's job and hired big-name columnists like Mike Lupica of the New York Daily News and Scott Ostler of the Los Angeles Times. Each day's paper will run 32 to 48 tabloid-sized pages with a minimum of 30 pages of editorial material and color photography, Deford said. Price said the venture is expected to reach the break-even point in five years, which would be something of a feat given that USA Today expects to make its first yearly profit in 1990 after losing $800 million over seven years. ``Putting out a national newspaper is an extraordinarily costly endeavor,'' said USA Today President Thomas Curley, adding that it would be difficult to contain losses for a national startup to $100 million. Some industry analysts expect The National will compete for readers with USA Today. One of USA Today's drawing cards has been getting West Coast scores into the papers distributed on the East Coast. Price said The National will ``be comparable to most of the papers'' in terms of getting late scores into the New York and Chicago editions. But he said that for the first month, only one edition will be printed for those two cities and the deadline will be between 12:30 a.m. and 1 a.m. EST. Despite the competition in the field, many observers of the publishing industry say they hope the paper makes it. ``We are usually very skeptical about things like this, but I think this one has a better than average chance to succeed,'' said Jack Irving, director of media operations at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. He said many countries have national sports dailies and the United States may be ready for one as well; the financing appears solid and Price and Deford are experienced. ``I look at it fairly positively,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: US Sprint To Offer Voice-Activated Dialing
DOC.TEXT: Harried business travelers weighed down with suitcases and overcoats will soon be able to let their voice do the dialing on long-distance calls, US Sprint said. The nation's third-largest long-distance company on Monday announced it would offer the first voice-activated dialing service sometime between April and June to customers in selected markets. The service would allow a caller to say his name and a password instead of using Sprint's long-distance travel card, which requires a caller to punch in as many as 24 digits. In addition, the caller could speed-dial certain pre-registered numbers by barking orders such as ``call home'' into a phone. ``These are the features the traveling public tells us they want,'' said Syd Courson, spokesman for Kansas City-based Sprint. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said it has the technology to offer similar voice-activated services and is conducting trials to determine what features customers want. AT&T spokeswoman Fran Anderson said some products could be announced in 1990. ``There's lots of technology out there,'' Anderson said. ``The real test now is applying it to what customers need.'' A spokesman for MCI Communications Corp., the nation's second-largest long-distance company, said his company is studying voice-activated calling but has no plans to introduce a service. ``We don't feel the technology is ready to roll out,'' spokesman Joe McNamara said in St. Louis. Sprint said its new system, aimed at business travelers, would guard against unauthorized use of calling cards by ensuring the caller's voice matched a pre-registered voice pattern. The system is designed to adapt to slight changes in a caller's voice over time, although there are some limits. ``Puberty might be a problem,'' Courson said. Also, the caller might have to punch in a code number if he or she had a bad cold or laryngitis, Courson said. The new Sprint system would not totally eliminate punching in numbers, Courson said. A caller would have to dial an 800 number to gain access to the voice-activated network before doing the rest of the dialing by voice. The Sprint system also would allow callers to leave voice messages at numbers that are busy or go unanswered. AT&T earlier this month announced a similar system using an 800 number, called VoiceMark messaging and currently available only in Atlanta. Courson said several hundred thousand customers could use the new Sprint system by early summer, but he would not specify what markets would get it first, or its price. Testing on the system began in December 1988, said Larry Lake, senior vice president of product management. The company unveiled the service Sunday in commercials broadcast during the Super Bowl. US Sprint, which controls about 8 percent of the domestic long-distance market, is owned 80 percent by United Telecommunications Inc. of Kansas City. GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn., owns the remaining 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Adds Test-Drive Incentive
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s newest wrinkle in the auto industry's patchwork of incentives could cost the financially strapped automaker millions of dollars. But Chrysler, which is offering $50 to anyone who test drives its cars or trucks against any other, thinks the gamble is worth it. ``Nobody ever said promotion was cheap,'' Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said Monday. ``The name of the game is to get people in the driver's seat.'' Chrysler, amid a program to carve $1 billion in costs out of its $26 billion annual budget by the end of the year, announced its newest incentive program Sunday in commercials during the Super Bowl football game. The new incentive offers $50 to anyone who test drives a Chrysler product and any other comparable car or truck, and buys either one. It doesn't matter which vehicle the consumer buys to qualify for the $50. The company also said it was extending to the end of next month some incentives announced Dec. 15 that originally were scheduled to expire Wednesday. It's anyone's guess how many people will take Chrysler up on its test drive, but if the company offered $50 only to the people who bought one of the 64,000 cars Chrysler sold last month, it would have handed out $3.2 million. Charles Brady, an automotive analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. in New York City, said he didn't think the cost of the test-drive promotion would be unreasonable. ``I don't think many people will go through the hassle for $50,'' Brady said. ``Probably half of them are going to end up buying a Chrysler. When viewed in light of all the other incentives, that's one-twentieth of a $1,000 rebate.'' Incentives have been denting earnings for Chrysler, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. for months. Each of the Big Three report their fourth-quarter and year-end earnings for 1989 within three weeks, and analysts are estimating they will be significantly lower than in the previous year. Some speculate that Chrysler may not turn a profit in the fourth quarter. If that happens, it would be the first quarter in which an automaker has lost money since the fourth quarter of 1982, when Chrysler lost $236 million and Ford lost $96.1 million. More than 90 percent of the cars and trucks Chrysler sells will be covered in the extended incentive program, Houston said. Missing from the extended program are Chrysler's popular minivans _ the Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town and Country. The incentive offers on those models, the first on minivans in Chrysler history, will expire Wednesday, as originally planned. The incentives had boosted sales strongly.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Stock Hits 7-Month Low On Buyout Pessimism
DOC.TEXT: Labor leaders at United Airlines say they'll make a formal bid for parent UAL Corp. in due time, but that's not what takeover speculators want to hear. UAL's stock plunged to a seven-month low Monday amid pessimism about the prospects that United's employees will succeed in their plan to buy 75 percent of the parent company. The airline's pilots, flight attendants and machinists are negotiating with representatives of UAL's board to develop a formal offer, a process that could take months. But time is not on the side of speculators who buy stock in anticipation of a takeover, said analyst Robert Joedicke of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. . ``If you're an arbitrager, time is money,'' Joedicke said. Speculators looking for a quick return will lose money ``if they're going to have to sit around and wait while there's a soap opera going on,'' he said. An arbitrage specialist at one large Wall Street brokerage said his firm had sold all its UAL holdings. ``We're just taking it easy and we're going to wait and see if the market corrects,'' said the arbitrager, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Union officials declined to comment Monday. But in phone-in recorded messages to their members, they pleaded for patience while buyout plans are negotiated. Other factors dampening investor enthusiasm for UAL are the current disarray in the junk bond market, a major source of funds for takeovers; a lack of details about the proposed UAL deal and a history of discord between United's pilots and machinists; and UAL's poor fourth-quarter results. ``The debt markets have turned so sour that investors may be telling the unions that even if you are getting together, the debt markets just aren't going to absorb any more debt from a new UAL,'' said Stephen Dexter, an analyst with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. UAL fell $13.50 in New York Stock Exchange trading Monday to $136.50, its lowest price since late June. United's unionized pilots, machinists and flight attendants proposed on Wednesday to buy a 75 percent stake in the Chicago-based company, leaving the rest of the stock with the public. On Thursday, UAL's board instructed its advisers to work with the unions in developing a formal bid. The union proposal did not mention the likely price of its offer, how it would finance the deal or the future role of Chairman Stephen Wolf and other top executives. Also on Thursday, UAL reported a 67 percent drop in its fourth-quarter profit because of takeover-related costs, high fuel expenses and an industry-wide decline in ridership. Analysts said economic uncertainty has created a poor environment for any debt-financed takeover attempts, let alone a bid for a company that has suffered one failed buyout already in the past six months.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Reports Record Sales, Profits for 1989
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. reported increased profits and sales for 1989 despite a 48-day strike by Machinists and dismal performance by defense segments. The aerospace and defense contractor also forecast Monday that its 1990 sales would climb by 35 percent to about $27 billion. Boeing is reaping the rewards of five straight years of record commercial jetliner orders, but said the strike by Machinists, which ended Nov. 20, resulted in sales being off by about $2 billion for its fourth quarter. Boeing said earnings fell nearly 56 percent in the fourth-quarter compared with the same 1988 period, while sales were virtually the same as a year ago. ``It's certainly better than I thought, even with the strike,'' said George Podrasky Jr., an analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Boeing had profits of $77 million, or 34 cents per share, on sales of $4.85 billion in the fourth quarter, compared with $174 million, or 76 cents per share, on sales of $4.88 billion in the 1988 quarter. For the year, Boeing reported profits of $973 million, or $4.23 a share, up 58 percent from $614 million, or $2.68 a share, in 1988. Sales were $20.3 billion, up nearly 20 percent from $17 billion a year earlier. In 1989, Boeing changed its method for computing income taxes, which had the effect of increasing 1989 earnings by $298 million, or $1.29 a share, the company said. Profits would have been up about 10 percent for 1989 without that change. Excluding the effects of the accounting change, the higher profits were due mostly to increased sales and lower research, development and other business costs for commercial jets and computing. But much of that was offset by the strike, large losses on some government programs, higher federal taxes and higher research and development costs on defense work, Boeing said. Boeing's defense and space businesses, which were consolidated Jan. 1, had an operating loss of $474 million for 1989, compared with operating profits of $29 million a year earlier. U.S. government and foreign military sales totaled $5.9 billion in 1989, up $371 million from 1988. A series of defense programs are behind schedule, including two new Air Force One jets that are more than a year overdue; a project to put new wings on Navy A-6 jets; the Peace Shield airborne warning and control system for Saudi Arabia; and the Airborne Optical Adjunct, a Star Wars project. While Boeing has been ``telegraphing they would lose money'' on defense, ``I think the enormity of the defense and space loss was a surprise,'' Podrasky said. Paul Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said the poor results may be temporary. ``Undoubtedly this is something that can be rectified over time,'' Nisbet said. He said most of Boeing's big money-losing contracts either will be canceled or completed within a few years. Boeing set an industry record for commercial jet orders in 1989, at 963 planes worth $47.5 billion. At year-end, the company had a firm-order backlog worth $80.6 billion _ $74 billion of that for commercial customers _ compared with $53.6 billion at the end of 1988. Since then, Boeing has picked up an order from Singapore Airlines for 15 747-400s and options for another 15, worth a total $5.5 billion, and America West on Monday ordered two 747-400s and took options on two more in a deal worth $280 million. International Lease Finance Corp. and Japan Air Systems also have said they plan large purchases of Boeing aircraft. Despite the strike, Boeing delivered 342 planes last year, five more than in 1988. For 1990, it plans to deliver 455 aircraft. The figures include turboprop commuter planes from its Canadian subsidiary, de Havilland. Boeing attributed its 1990 sales projection primarily to higher commercial aircraft deliveries and from some major defense and space programs, including the E-3 Airborne Warning and Control System, CH-47 helicopter, Navy E-6 communications plane and A-6 re-wing, and the space station.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pushes Again for Capital Gains Tax Cut; Proposes Family Saving Accounts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: When Democratic leaders of Congress balked at cutting capital gains taxes last year, they pointed to Bush administration estimates that a reduction would worsen the budget deficit in three of the next 10 years. President Bush renewed the battle on Monday with a new set of figures indicating a capital gains reduction would never reduce tax collections. ``We see no negative effect in any year,'' a senior Treasury Department official told reporters. The new estimates are based on projections that a larger number of taxpayers would sell assets in response to the lower tax rate, the official said. The administration predicted cutting taxes on capital gains _ profits from the sale of real estate, stock and other investments _ would actually increase tax collections in each of the next five years by a total of $12.5 billion. Bush's somewhat different proposal last year would have raised $16 billion by Treasury estimates over the first five years, lost $20 billion over the next three and then begun producing revenue again. Congressional analysts predicted small revenue increases in the first two years followed by declines in each successive year. Bush says a capital gains reduction is needed to spur investment in job creation and make the United States more competitive with foreign countries. He also called for a new tax break to encourage individual saving. Under those two major revenue proposals: _When fully effective in 1992, 30 percent of capital gains from property owned three years or longer would be exempt from tax; 20 percent from assets owned two years, and 10 percent from property owned at least one year. Most property, including real estate and timber but not collectibles, would qualify. _Retroactive to Jan. 1, a couple whose income is $120,000 or less could set aside up to $5,000 a year in a ``family savings account'' and interest earned would be tax-exempt if the account is held for at least seven years. Deposits of up to $2,500 a year would be allowed single people with income under $60,000. The deposits would not be tax deductible. Democratic leaders say a capital gains cut would begin undoing the landmark 1986 tax overhaul, which taxed gains at the same rates that apply to other income, and 80 percent of the benefits would go to those with incomes of $100,000 a year. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., revived the fairness argument Monday. ``At a time when President Bush wants to cut the capital gains tax for the wealthy and maintain punishingly high Social Security taxes on everyone else, I question whether his priorities are right for the times,'' he said. The president took note of a well-publicized proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would cut Social Security taxes to stop the government from using surplus Social Security revenues to pay for other programs. Bush declined to endorse such a reduction; instead, he proposed that once the federal budget is balanced, Social Security surpluses be used to retire government debt. Bush's budget recommends $15.7 billion in tax increases, but no general boost in income taxes, and a $5.6 billion increase in user and service fees. The president proposed $1.8 billion in tax reductions in addition to the capital gains cut, including a new credit of up to $1,000 a year for each child under age 4 in low-income families. Among other revenue proposals, the budget would: _Make permanent the 3 percent tax on local and long distance telephone service, which is due to expire Dec. 31. _Raise the 8 percent tax on airline tickets to 10 percent. _More than triple the fee on waterway shippers, to 0.125 percent of cargo value. _Require the 3.8 million state and local government workers who are not covered by a retirement plan to pay Social Security taxes. Also, state and local workers hired before April 1, 1986, would be required to pay the 1.45 percent Medicare tax that most such employees already pay.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Would Do More Audits With Bush Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congressional approval of President Bush's new budget would allow the Internal Revenue Service to increase the number of tax returns it audits _ but not by much. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. told reporters the agency anticipates auditing 102 returns per 10,000 that will be filed in 1990 and 103 per 10,000 next year. That compares with an all-time low of 97 per 10,000 returns for the 1989 tax year. ``The fact remains that there has been a continuing decline in audit coverage for a number of years, but now we are seeing a reversal of the trend,'' Goldberg said after Bush's proposed budget for the 1991 fiscal year was made public Monday. Although IRS officials agree that more returns should be audited, they point to concerted efforts over the past few years to target larger returns, those involving tax shelters and others likely to yield more revenue. Even so, Goldberg said, the audit statistics do not tell the whole story. He noted, for example, about 40 million couples and individuals file returns that are based almost entirely on income from wages, interest and dividends. IRS computers now automatically check those returns against backup documents filed by employers, banks and brokers to ensure that all income is reported. While those computer matches are not audits, Goldberg said, they are thorough enough to make it difficult for taxpayers to under-report such income. The agency's proposed budget for 1991 is $6.14 billion, up 11.6 percent from this year's $5.5 billion. A big part of that increase represents another installment on the agency's plan to replace an outmoded computer system. Goldberg said the new system will cost up to $6 billion over the next decade. One aim of the new system is to allow taxpayers to get answers to questions about their tax accounts as easily as they get information about a bill from a credit card company. The Bush administration estimates the IRS will collect an additional $3 billion next year because of management initiatives and the increase in the agency's own spending. Goldberg said the IRS will spend an additional $56 million and assign about 1,000 new staff members to reducing accounts receivable from a record level of nearly $60 billion. Those are taxes that have been assessed but not paid. The agency expects to spend $330 million in the new year for taxpayer service, which includes answering telephoned tax questions. That figure is up from $317 million this year, principally because last year IRS employees gave the wrong answer to one of every three telephoned questions.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other major currencies in calm European trading today. Gold prices were slightly lower in quiet European dealings. Despite some upward movement in the dollar, dealers said there was pressure on the currency because of market perceptions of weak economic growth in the United States. ``The dollar is going down,'' said a Milan trader. ``There's no hope for it in the short-term.'' Experts also were disappointed by the latest budget proposal by the Bush administration, which they said did little to pare the fiscal deficit. ``The market didn't react well to what Bush had to say,'' said a Frankfurt trader. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.03 yen to a closing 143.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 143.87 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6777 West German marks, down from 1.6795; 1.4880 Swiss francs, up from 1.4860; 5.6990 French francs, down from 5.7040; 1.8850 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8865; 1,248.25 Italian lire, down from 1,249.75; and 1.1905 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1888. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6805 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6775 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $418.40 a troy ounce, down from $418.50 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $417.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $417.75, down from $418.50 bid late Monday. After a week-long break, gold in Hong Kong rose $9.04 to close at a bid $416.35. The Hong Kong gold market last traded Jan. 24 before the Lunar New Year holiday. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.20 a troy ounce from Monday's $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Slide, Stocks Marginally Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended its five-day slide against the Japanese yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index edged up. The dollar closed at 143.25 yen, up 0.03 yen from Monday's 143.22-yen close. It opened at 143.10 yen and ranged between 143.05 yen and 143.50 yen. The dollar fell a total of 3.20 yen over the previous five trading days. Today, it gradually rose against the yen as market players bought West German marks for both yen and dollars, said Kenzo Shinomiya, a trader with Fuji Bank. ``Today's trading was dominated by dollar-mark and yen-mark dealings, rather than dollar-yen dealings,'' he said. ``Considering the recent slowdown in the U.S. economy, the market is expecting the dollar to be lower, though,'' he added. President Bush's fiscal 1991 budget, calling for a dramatic cut in the nation's trade deficit, did not have much favorable influence on the dollar here, Shinomiya said. Some $8.27 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from $6.66 billion the previous day. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 41.97 points, or 0.11 percent, closing at 37,215.67. Dealers attributed the gain mainly to stability in the Japanese government bond and foreign exchange markets. ``Trading was very thin and directionless, and buying and selling were mixed,'' said Satoru Nagayoshi, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. But index-linked buying by investment trusts boosted the index, he said. An estimated 450 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from Monday's 400 million. The Nikkei opened higher as market players were reassured by the smaller-than-expected loss in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York, which ended down 5.85 points after falling some 30 points earlier in the day, Nagayoshi said. But then the Nikkei eased down following a temporary slump in Japanese government bond prices, the yen's slight slip against the dollar, and Sony's announcement that it would issue new bonds, said Toshiaki Yui of Nomura Securities. Sony said it would issue 100 billion yen ($700 million) worth of unsecured yen bonds with warrants and unsecured yen convertible bonds in the Japanese stock market to refinance the acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment and the Guber-Peters Entertainment Co. It set the offer for Feb. 7-9. Yui said Sony's announcement discouraged market players who worried that an increase in the number of shares might push down share prices. Among today's gainers were steel and shipbuilding issues.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,800,000 net tons during the week ending Jan. 27, 1990, up 1.2 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 80.3 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,023,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 6,767,000 net tons, 9.6 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Vehicle Exports Fall for Fourth Consecutive Year
DOC.TEXT: Japan's exports of cars, trucks and buses fell 3.6 percent to 5.88 million vehicles in 1989, the fourth consecutive year of decline, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Tuesday. The association said the main reason for the drop was a 9.9 percent decline in exports to the United States, where local production of Japanese cars is expanding. It said six Japanese makers produced 1.25 million vehicles in the United States in 1989, up 40.6 percent from 1988. Meanwhile, exports to the United States from Japan fell to 2.43 million vehicles. Globally, Japan exported 4.39 passengers cars in 1989, down 0.9 percent from 1988; 1.46 million trucks, down 10.4 percent, and 35,149 buses, down 23.1 percent, the association said. Japan produced a record 13.023 million motor vehicles in 1989, up 2.6 percent from the previous year, and 7.26 million vehicles were sold in Japan, up 8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gap Debuts Clothes for Infants
DOC.TEXT: It won't be just pastel pink and baby blue at the new BabyGap store opened by Gap Inc. The San Francisco-based retailer, which debuted its new line of infant clothing and accessories at a local shopping center on Monday, plans to open 35 more BabyGap sections across the country within the next three months. The sections will offer a full line of clothing and accessories for children up to 2 years old, including shirts, pants, jumpsuits, caps, bibs, booties, blankets and diaper bags. The sections will occupy about 12 percent of the floor space of the average GapKids store, officials said. Colors will change every few months to reflect fashion trends. Two of the current colors for the infant clothing line are banana and peach. ``We've chosen a lot of colors that are not traditional baby colors,'' said a spokesman. The expansion follows the introduction of GapKids, which has been the company's fastest-growing division in percentage terms. Analysts estimate that GapKids stores sales boomed from about $40 million last year to about $70 million in the fiscal year ending this month.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data Reports Worst Loss In 32-Year History
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. today reported losses of $196 million for the fourth quarter and $680 million for last year, the worst annual performance in the computer maker's 32-year history. Lawrence Perlman, Control Data's president and chief executive officer, has said 1989 marks the end of a six-year restructuring that has included $1.4 billion in write-offs. For the October-December quarter, Control Data lost $4.63 a share on revenue of $524 million. That compared with a net loss of $12.8 million, or 31 cents a share, on $933 million in revenue in the same 1988 period. The 1989 net loss of $16.11 a share on revenue of $2.9 billion compares with a profit of $1.7 million, or 3 cents a share, on revenue of $3.6 billion in 1988. The 1989 loss eclipsed losses of $568 million in 1985 and $265 million in 1986. Aside from restructuring charges of $215 million in fourth quarter and net charges for the year of $663 million, Control Data was profitable in its last two quarters, Perlman said. ``The major restructuring actions Control Data carried out in 1989 have helped to focus the company and improve its opportunity for success in 1990 and beyond,'' Perlman said. The fourth-quarter charge was linked largely to the previously announced write-off for anticipated losses at chip-making subsidiary VTC, which the company will sell in 1990, Perlman said. VTC never made money in its five-year history. Other large write-offs for the year stemmed from the shutdown of ETA Systems, a money-losing supercomputer subsidiary, and a streamlining of the company's mainframe business. Another important move during the year was the sale for $470 million of Control Data's profitable disc drive subsidiary to Seagate Technology. It was completed in September and did not contribute to fourth-quarter results. Perlman has said the restructuring leaves the company poised to make between $50 million and $60 million in 1990 on sales of about $2 billion. Six years ago, sales at the company were about $5 billion. Gary Smaby, a Minneapolis computer industry analyst, said Perlman will have to make good on his projection for Control Data to be considered a legitmate turn-around stock. ``Perlman appears to be the right man,'' Smaby said. ``But just because they have gone through this gut-wrenching subtraction, it's not a slam dunk that they will be a success.''

Stock prices edged lower in volatile trading today as a slew of worries continued to unsettle the market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 11.04 points to 2,542.34 at 11 a.m. EST. The blue-chip indicator was down 2.70 points an hour earlier after opening slightly higher. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by nearly 3 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 908 issues down, 306 up and 488 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 56.09 million shares. Wall Street analysts said investors remained jittery about interest rates, corporate earnings and financing for takeovers as so-called ``deal'' stocks lead the market lower. The Dow Jones transportation average was down 34.85 points to 1,039.65 dragged down by continued selling of UAL stock. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 1.55 to 178.18. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.65 to 347.89. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, UAL, parent of United Airlines, was down 13\ to 123\, IBM was down \ to 97 and AT&T had fallen 1{ to 38. Sears Roebuck was up \ to 38], Bank of New England had gained ] to 4{ and General Electric was unchanged at 61}.

DOC.HEAD: Utah Businessman Offers To Sweeten Bid For Chemical Company
DOC.TEXT: A Utah businessman has offered to raise his bid for Aristech Chemical Corp. to at least $934.2 million if the company gives him more time to review its financial records. In a letter sent to Aristech's board Monday, Salt Lake City chemicals magnate Jon Huntsman asked the company to extend its deadline for bids until Feb. 14. Huntsman is trying to form a joint venture with General Electric Co. to acquire Aristech for at least $27 a share. A deadline set by a special Aristech board committee expired at 5 p.m. Monday. A special committee of the company's board set the deadline after the company's managers and Mitsubishi Corp. of Japan said their competing $26-a-share offer, worth $899.6 million, would expire at the end of business today. Aristech spokesman David Higie declined comment today. ``I want to emphasize to the special committee and the entire board that we genuinely want to acquire Aristech,'' Huntsman's letter said. ``The fact is, however, that is is not reasonable for you to expect us to make our formal proposal until we have had a reasonable period of time to complete a reasonable due diligence review of your company.'' Huntsman's earlier bid of $25 a share was rejected in November as inadequate. Pittsburgh-based Aristech has reserved the option of rejecting any of the first-round offers and suggested that if none is high enough it will reopen bidding. The company employs about 1,800 people in eight states.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Giant Reports 12 Percent Quarterly Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. on Tuesday reported a 12 percent drop in earnings for the 1989 fourth-quarter, blaming charges for engineering consolidation expenses and early debt retirement. For the period ending Dec. 31, MCI reported profits of $101 million, or 39 cents per share, compared with $115 million, or 46 cents per share, for the same 1988 period. Quarterly revenue increased 20 percent to $1.71 billion from $1.43 billion a year earlier. For the full year, the telephone giant said profits surged 58 percent to $529 million, or $2.09 a share, from $334 million, or $1.23 a share, in 1988. Annual revenue increased 26 percent to $6.47 million from $5.14 million. MCI said fourth-quarter traffic volume increased but the company had to take a $35 million pre-tax charge to consolidate some engineering operations in Texas and a $35 million after-tax charge for early retirement of $500 million in remaining principal on its original $1 billion debt issue. ``In a marketplace that has seen increasing competition and some downward pricing pressure, MCI's overall market penetration has grown by approximately 2 percentage points,'' Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI president and chief operating officer, said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Narrowly Mixed After Higher Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices turned narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after opening higher on bullish technical signals. On Monday, soybean futures rose sharply in what technical analysts called a ``key reversal,'' an indication that the market's six-week downward trend might have ended. The resulting across-the-board rally continued into today's opening, then stalled amid uncertainty about the strength of the turnaround. ``The market needs to go back down and retest support to give traders confidence that the key reversal is intact,'' said William Biedermann, director of research for the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. A drop to Monday's lows followed by a higher close would confirm the reversal, he said. Supply-and-demand factors were mixed. A weekly Agriculture Department report showing greater-than-expected amounts of corn and soybeans inspected for export last week was offset by concerns about the potential for a record large South American soybean crop. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.79\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $2.39{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $1.38{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $5.63\ a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed while pork bellies were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were unchanged to .15 cent higher with February at 79.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .05 cent higher with March at 83.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 49.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .22 cent to 1.10 cents lower with February at 51 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed on Monday. Pork bellies fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound amid a bevy of bearish technical and fundamental factors.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega-Linked Money Laundering Case Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with opening arguments; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `On trial ...'; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: International bankers were told _ but didn't care _ that suitcases of cash deposited in their vaults came from Colombian cocaine dealers, prosecutors said today as a $32 million money-laundering trial opened. The six defendants include Amjad Awan, an international banker who once claimed to handle Manuel Noriega's secret accounts. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rubenstein described how proceeds fom cocaine sales were turned into cash and filtered through the defendants' institution, the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International. An undercover Customs agent in Detroit would pick up suitcases of cash from strangers, then call a contact in Medellin, Colombia, to advise him, he said. The money was converted into certificates of deposit, which were used first as collateral for loans, then to pay them off as they matured. The undercover agent told Awan where the money came from, Rubenstein said. ``And Awan responded, `It's not any business of mine who the customers are,''' the prosecutor quoted the agent as saying. The defense was expected to begin its opening arguments later in the day. U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges on Jan. 17 denied a defense motion to block any mention of Noriega during the trial. Awan, a former Latin American assistant division director for the Bank of Credit and Commerce, told a Senate panel in 1988 he managed secret accounts for Noriega that held up to $23 million. On trial with Awan are Rudolph Armbrect of Medellin, Colombia, and four former employees of the bank. Just before the start of jury selection two weeks ago, guilty pleas were entered by the Luxembourg bank and a Colombian who prosecutors said ran a network to help traffickers hide the source of their drug money. As part of a plea bargain, the bank, one of the world's largest private financial institutions, agreed to forfeit a record $14 million in assets frozen by the government and to cooperate against other defendants. Gonzalo Mora Jr. pleaded guilty to drug trafficking, conspiracy and money laundering. The indictment resulted from a two-year sting in which an undercover agent conned his way into an international money laundering network. After that, agents helped direct profits from cocaine sales in American cities to Colombia through Panama, eventually building a global laundering operation worth an estimated $32 million, investigators said. Customs agents claimed the money was intended mainly for Colombian drug traffickers, including the Medellin cartel. Awan was arrested while attending a phony stag party for a groom who was an undercover Customs agent. Noriega is being held in Miami on charges he accepted millions of dollars in bribes for allowing the cartel to launder money and process and ship drugs through Panama to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Lane Bryant Leaving New York For Ohio
DOC.TEXT: The Limited Inc. will move offices of its 720-store Lane Bryant division from New York into a $110 million complex being built in a Columbus suburb, Gov. Richard Celeste and company officials said Tuesday. Lane Bryant, a women's special size apparel retailer, is expected to move into its new headquarters in May or June of 1991. Kenneth B. Gilman, Limited's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said a significant, but undetermined, number of the 240 employees at Lane Bryant's Manhattan headquarters were expected to move to Ohio. Three other New York-based divisions _ Henri Bendel, Brylane, and Lerner _ that together employ 800 to 1,000 people, will remain in New York. Gilman said at a news conference that the Lane Bryant division is expanding. ``Our plans for Lane Bryant include building that business to achieve sales in excess of $2 billion. It's somewhat less than $1 billion at this point,'' he said. The home office work force will be significantly higher than 240 people once the sales goal is achieved, he said. The Lane Bryant offices and distribution center will be housed in one of two buildings at a site in Reynoldsburg, about 10 miles east of Columbus. In addition to the 950,000 square feet Lane Bryant building, a 910,000-square-foot structure will house Victoria's Secret stores and catalogue offices and distribution centers. The Limited, a leading specialty apparel retailer based in Columbus, already employs 4,000 people in central Ohio. It operates 3,176 stores around the country under the names Limited, Express, Victoria's Secret, Henri Bendel, Lerner, Lane Bryant and Abercrombie & Fitch. Celeste viewed the switch as an affirmation that a national business can thrive from a base in central Ohio. ``What to me is more important than the size of the site is what it means to bring the Lane Bryant headquarters here to join with the already very enormous commitment that The Limited has to Columbus and central Ohio,'' Celeste said. The state has committed $2 million to widen a highway leading to the project site.

DOC.HEAD: Borden Posts 6.5 Percent Quarterly Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: Borden Inc. on Tuesday reported a 6.5 percent fourth-quarter earnings gain despite a 1.5 percent sales drop due largely to a decline in the dairy business. A previously announced $570.7 million pretax charge resulted in a $60.6 million loss for all of last year. Borden earned $99.91 million, or 67 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from $93.85 million, or 63 cents a share, in the corresponding 1988 quarter. Sales fell to $1.95 billion from $1.98 billion. R.J. Ventres, chairman and chief executive officer, said Borden's grocery and specialty products divisions improved substantially during the quarter, led by the pasta business. But the growth was partly offset by ``the severe squeeze on profit margins in our dairy division.'' The reserve, which came to $404.4 million after taxes, or $2.73 a share, was established to cover the costs of a corporatewide reconfiguration and various restructuring programs. A major portion of the plans announced Sept. 28 involved restructuring Borden's dairy operation and getting out of overcrowded markets. The sum set aside led to the 1989 loss, which amounted to 41 cents a share, and compared with a profit of $311.88 million, or $2.11 a share, in 1988. Last year's sales rose 4.8 percent to $7.59 billion from 1988's $7.24 billion. Excluding the one-time charge, Borden said its 1989 earnings increased $31.9 million, or 10.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mellon Bank Selling Consumer Finance Unit
DOC.TEXT: Mellon Bank Corp. said Tuesday it is seeking a buyer for Mellon Financial Services, its Illinois-based consumer finance company. If the sale goes through, Mellon said it won't issue common stock in connection with its plan to purchase 54 PSFS branches from Meritor Savings Bank in Philadelphia. Mellon previously said it had expected to finance the acquisition by issuing common stock, preferred stock and debt. ``Mellon Financial Services is a profitable, well-run consumer finance business, but it is not essential to the achievement of our retail banking strategy,'' said Mellon Bank Chairman Frank V. Cahouet. Mellon Financial Services, based in Oak Brook, Ill., employs about 375 people at 97 offices in 17 states, mostly in the Midwest and West. It specializes in consumer lending, dealer sales finance plans and resort time-sharing loans. As of Dec. 31, Mellon Financial Services had assets of about $550 million, liabilities of about $495 million and equity of about $55 million, Mellon said. Goldman, Sachs & Co. has been retained by the corporation to assist in identifying potential buyers and evaluating their bids, Mellon said.
