DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts `Coupon Connie' of Conspiracy, Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of scam, potential sentence; No pickup; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A woman with a passion for clipping coupons and proof-of-purchase seals was convicted today of swapping and redeeming counterfeit coupons in an alleged $2 million scam. A federal jury deliberated five days before reaching its verdict against Connie Arvidson, 34, of Boca Raton, Fla. The woman dubbed ``Coupon Connie'' was convicted of conspiracy and mail fraud and could receive up to 15 years in prison and $750,000 in fines at sentencing March 23. David Rees of Center Point was found guilty of conspiracy, said Maureen Ruprecht, court coordinator for U.S. District Judge Sidney Fitzwater. A third defendant, James Floyd Richards of San Antonio, was cleared of all charges. Prosecutors had charged that the three defendants counterfeited and redeemed or swapped more than 600,000 copies of coupons issued by 47 companies, including Procter & Gamble, Nabisco Brands Inc. and Campbell Soup Co. Participants in the scheme used the coupons to purchase the products and then sold the items at flea markets, authorities said. Proceeds were used by Mrs. Arvidson to purchase a fashionable Florida home and two expensive cars, U.S. Attorney Steve Sucsy said. The judge set bond for Mrs. Arvidson at $10,000. Rees was freed on his own recognizance. Mrs. Arvidson, who became known as the ``Dumpster Lady'' for rummaging through the trash for coupons and proof-of-purchase seals, turned a passion into a profitable business. She estimated she took in $200 a week at her peak. She and nine others were indicted in June. Prosecutors said she knowingly took part in a scheme to swap and redeem bogus coupons. Mrs. Arvidson maintained didn't know the coupons she bought through an advertisement in a coupon magazine were counterfeit.

A report that Mikhail Gorbachev may resign as Soviet communist party chief jolted the stock market, sending it into wild gyrations and some traders to the sidelines. Prices were so volatile shortly after 2 p.m. EST that traders at one investment brokerage stopped trading temporarily while the market calmed down. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which fell immediately after the Gorbachev report, rebounded and then slipped again, was down 16.89 points to 2,536.49 at 3 p.m. EST. An hour earlier, the blue-chip indicator was 19.82 points lower. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by nearly 4 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,204 issues down, 330 up and 408 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 157.10 million shares. ``Confusion is reigning supreme. Most professional traders are on the sidelines,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst for MKI Securities Corp. in New York. Jensen said that from one minute to the next prices soared and dropped. ``We haven't seen a market of this kind for sometime. It's pulsating, vibrating without any sense of direction,'' Jensen said. Analysts said the news alternately hit the financial markets, currency markets and commodities and metals markets. The report on Cable News Network that Gorbachev may resign as the head of the communist party fueled the stock futures market, which in turn drove the cash market. Analysts said after the initial reaction, traders were attempting to get clarification on the impact of a possible resignation. Before the report, interest rates and concern about financing for takeovers were the market's chief worries. Analysts said the market also interpreted as negative this morning's remarks by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan before the Joint Economic Committee in Washington D.C. Greenspan said the probability of a recession is less than 50 percent, lower than previously anticipated, and that the current 4.5 percent inflation rate is ``unacceptable.'' ``Greenspan seemed to be signaling there would be no accommodation by the Fed on interest rates,'' said Larry Wachtel, analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 2.01 to 177.72. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 4.31 to 345.23. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, AT&T was down 1{ to 38, Unitel was off 2\ to 30} and Philip Morris was unchanged at 37.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Triples in 4th Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. said its fourth-quarter earnings more than tripled from a year ago, reflecting a huge one-time gain from the sale of its stake in Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. The soft drink giant's net income for the fourth quarter was $757.2 million, or $2.22 a share, up from $235.5 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 11 percent to $2.25 billion from $2.03 billion a year earlier. The quarterly earnings included a gain of $509.4 million from the sale of Coca-Cola's 49 percent stake in Columbia Pictures in November, the company said. Without the gain, the quarterly earnings per share would have been 72 cents, Coca-Cola said. For the full year, net income was $1.72 billion, or $4.92 a share, up 65 percent from $1.04 billion, or $2.85 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 7.5 percent to $8.97 billion from $8.34 billion a year earlier. After excluding the gain of $1.47 per common share from the sale of Columbia Pictures Entertainment and a 10-cent gain on the sale of Belmont Water Springs Co. in August, yearly net income per common share was $3.35, the company said. ``Our global soft drink business experienced another year of record achievements in 1989,'' Coca-Cola Chairman Roberto C. Goizueta said in a statement. He said the company's share of the global soft drink business increased to more than 45 percent in 1989 from 38 percent, including a rise to more than 40 percent of the U.S. market from 36 percent. Goizueta said the company is ``extremely well positioned to continue to achieve strong profitable growth in 1990 and for the remainder of the decade.''

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Increase 54 Percent
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said Tuesday its earnings increased 54 percent in the final three months of 1989, reflecting strong gains in the company's steel and energy businesses. Fourth-quarter earnings totaled $244 million or 91 cents a share on revenues of $4.9 billion. That compared with $158 million or 55 cents a share on revenues of $4.4 billion in the same 1988 period. Earnings for all of 1989 increased nearly 28 percent to $965 million or $3.53 a share on revenues of $18.7 billion. That compared with $756 million or $2.62 a share on revenues of $16.9 billion in 1988. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said the company's operating income increased to a record $1.6 billion in 1989 from $1.4 billion in 1988. Operating income in the energy segment more than doubled to $987 million in 1989 compared with $475 million in 1988. Fourth-quarter operating income was $166 million in 1989, compared with $116 million in 1988. The steel division's operating income totaled $430 million in 1989, compared with $501 million in 1988. The reduced income was due partly to the sale of the Lorain, Ohio, steel works to a 50 percent-owned joint venture in the second quarter of 1989. The steel division's fourth-quarter operating income was $75 million, compared with $16 million in 1988. The fourth quarter of 1988 included a $46 million loss in connection with 1986 steel plant shutdowns. Marathon Oil Co. reported operating income of $166 million on sales of $3.1 billion in the fourth quarter. That compared with $123 million on sales of $2.4 billion in the same period of 1988. ``Our energy segment is well-positioned to benefit from an improving energy market,'' Corry said. ``In the steel segment our efforts through the 1980s to cut costs and improve efficiency and product quality will enable us to continue competing profitably in the worldwide steel marketplace. ``There are signs of recovery in the oil country tubular goods market where we hold a preeminent position.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Lower On Gorbachev Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade following an unconfirmed report that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev might resign as Communist Party chairman. The midafternoon report on the Cable News Network stirred fears of a change in the Soviet Union toward more isolationist policies and less foreign trade, including fewer purchases of foreign grain. The CNN report, attributed to an unidentified source, said Gorbachev would remain president of the Soviet Union. A White House spokesman said the Bush administration had no information on the report. The report overshadowed bullish sentiments linked to Monday's strong rebound in the soybean market, which some analysts had said could mark a turnaround in the market's six-week decline. But crop futures were trading lower even before the CNN report surfaced. ``There was no follow-through from yesterday,'' said analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.76 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.38\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 5 cents lower with March at $5.58{ a bushel.
The stock market was broadly lower in late afternoon trading. About five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 10.36 points at 2,543.02.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data a Mere Chip of Former Self
DOC.TEXT: Once self-proclaimed the most innovative company in the world, Control Data Corp. has entered the 1990s as a much smaller business scarred by $1.4 billion in losses in the past five years. The loss of $680.4 million for 1989, reported Tuesday, was the worst performance in the computer company's 32-year history. It eclipsed the 1985 loss of $567.5 million, the previous worst batch of red ink. In fact, in the 1980s, Control Data lost twice as much money as it earned: $1.43 billion vs. $664.1 million. To fix things, management has lopped off huge subsidiaries and parted ways with founder William C. Norris. The moves will reduce sales to an estimated $2 billion in 1990 compared with $5 billion in 1984. ``They've cut off the patient's legs, arms and nose,'' said Peter Zidek, a supercomputer consultant who once worked for Control Data. ``There's not much left to operate on.'' Launched as a maker of mainframe scientific computers, Control Data diversified quickly into financial services by leasing industrial equipment and selling insurance. In 1977 for example, Control Data made about $10.6 million on insurance sales, six times what the entire company earned in 1988. The company's far-flung enterprises also came to include windmill farms, factories built in ghettos, incubation centers for small businesses and a training program that encouraged city dwellers to take up farming. ``We were in too many businesses,'' said Control Data spokesman Frank Ryan. ``Management's focus can only go so far.'' The remedy, carried out mostly by Norris' successor, Robert Price, has been to sell more than 20 businesses or product lines since 1984. The selloffs in 1989 included a disk drive subsidiary that accounted for a third of Control Data's $3.62 billion revenues in 1988, and the shutdown of supercomputer subsidiary ETA Systems. The latter lost more than $230 million in its six-year life and cost $335 million to close. Another major down-sizing occurred in 1986 and 1987, when Control Data cut all ties to Commercial Credit, the financial services subsidiary that throughout much of the 1970s generated more profit than the company's computer business. The changes have coincided with a 72 percent reduction in employment at Control Data _ from a high of 60,600 in 1981 to about 17,000 at the end of 1989. Later this year, 400 more jobs will be cut from Control Data when the company sells it VTC chip-making subsidiary. Mostly to cover anticipated losses at VTC, the company wrote off about $214.7 million in the fourth quarter, resulting in a net loss of $196.4 million, or $4.63 a share. Newly appointed President Lawrence Perlman has said VTC should be the last write-off in Control Data's six-year effort to transform itself into a computer-based services company. He is projecting a profit of up to $63 million this year. Gary Smaby, a computer industry analyst in Minneapolis, said Perlman must meet that projection if Control Data is to be considered a legitimate turnaround stock. In 1983, the stock traded as high as $63.25 a share. On Monday it closed at $16.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. A darling of securities analysts, Perlman made his mark at Control Data by transforming the money-losing disk drive subsidiary into a major profit center before it was sold. ``But just because they have gone through this gut-wrenching subtraction, it's not a slam dunk that they will be a success,'' Smaby said. What's left of Control Data includes an installed computer base of 1,500 mainframes and 1,500 workstations. Maintaining the base is a huge business, but the company isn't likely to add greatly to its own hardware, Smaby said. Instead, Control Data will be devising new applications with hardware made by others. ``You don't have to be designing the computer anymore. You can't sell enough of them to underwrite the costs,'' said Lloyd Thorndyke, a co-founder of ETA Systems. ``Control Data is down to services _ using computers to manipulate data the way customers like it.'' Control Data divides its businesses into two categories: data services and data systems. Services includes the Arbitron TV ratings unit, payroll processing and Ticketron. Data systems is the computer core. Zidek said much of the malaise at Control Data stemmed from the overall softness in the computer industry. But the company was hurt more than others because its direction under Norris was diluted by social endeavors, he said. In addition, Zidek said, the engineer-laden leadership didn't pay enough attention to marketing. In Control Data's 1979 annual report, Norris wrote, ``Simply stated, there is no more innovative company in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Marriott Selling Roy Rogers To Hardee's
DOC.TEXT: Marriott Corp. took the first step in retreating from the fast food business Tuesday by announcing the sale of its Roy Rogers restaurant chain to rival Hardee's for $365 million in cash. The deal represents the third major acquisition for Hardee's Food Systems Inc., and puts the Rocky Mount, N.C., company firmly in third place ahead of Wendy's in terms of the number of restaurants nationally, analysts said. McDonald's and Burger King are first and second. ``Hardee's has found a way to expand its presence without diluting its penetration,'' said Daniel R. Lee, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York, who called the deal a brilliant move. ``And Marriott gets out of the (fast food) business where they couldn't grow and compete effectively.'' Marriott said last month it would sell the Roy Rogers fast food chain consisting of over 600 restaurants located primarily in the Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York areas as part of a restructuring. J.W. Marriott Jr., chairman and president of the hotel and lodging company which bears his family's name, said the sale of the Roy Rogers restaurants, which the company formed in 1968, ``will help us to concentrate our focus on our lodging and contract service operations in the 1990s.'' Marriott is also selling most of its other family and fast-food restaurant holdings, including 235 Bob's Big Boys and an assortment of moderately priced restaurants it runs under the Howard Johnson's, Wag's, Bickford's and Allie's names. It said it hopes to raise at least $500 million from the sales. William E. Prather, Jr., Hardee's president and chief executive, said the acquisition would improve his company's presence in the Northeast. ``It's a sound strategic fit for us,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``We look forward to a successful blending of the chains.'' Prather said the company-owned restaurants will be converted to Hardee's on a market-by-market basis. Existing Roy Rogers franchise agreements will be honored. ``We have an obligation to run the Roy Rogers chain forever, if necessary,'' he said. Tuesday's deal is the third major acquisition by Hardee's. The 200-unit Sandy's system was purchased in 1982, and the 650-unit Burger Chef chain was bought in 1982. Hardee's annual sales through 3,300 restaurants in 40 states and nine foreign countries amount to about $3.5 billion. Marriott has 1990 projected sales of $7.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Warner-Lambert Records 19 Percent Jump in Quarterly Profits
DOC.TEXT: Warner-Lambert Co. reported Tuesday that its fourth quarter profit rose 19 percent over a year ago, capping a year of higher earnings. The health and consumer products giant netted $92.30 million, or $1.37 a share, compared with earnings of $77.54 million, or $1.14 a share, in 1988. Sales rose to $1.04 billion from $997.88 million in the year-ago period. For the year, Warner-Lambert earned $412.66 million, or $6.10 a share, on sales of $4.19 billion. That was up 21 percent from net income of $340.30 million, or $5 a share, and $3.90 billion in sales. Chairman Joseph D. Williams called 1989 the company's best year, and predicted strong results in the near-term, too. Williams told securities analysts last week that he expected 1990 per-share earnings to increase by about 15 percent based on sales gains of 8 percent. During 1989, worldwide sales of Warner-Lambert's prescription products rose more than 9 percent to $1.3 billion, and its non-prescription health products grew 6 percent to $1.4 billion. Sales of its cholesterol regulator, Lopid, rose by around 50 percent to $285 million last year. The anti-convulsant Dilantin and cardiovascular drug Dilzem also performed well, the company said. Warner-Lambert noted gains in non-prescription products including Halls cough tablets, Listerine mouthwash, Rolaids antacid and its gum and mint division.

DOC.HEAD: Outside Directors Gain Control of American Brands Board
DOC.TEXT: A shakeup on the board of directors of American Brands Inc. Tuesday gave outside directors control of the diversified company, which sells everything from cigarettes to life insurance to Jim Beam bourbon. The changes quickly incited speculation that American Brands might become a takeover target. The company's stock closed up $1.25 to 66 on the New York Stock Exchange in heavy trading. In a brief statement, William J. Alley, American Brands chairman and chief executive officer, announced that five management directors have resigned from the company's 17-member board of directors. Alley also announced that Gordon R. Lohman, president of Chicago-based AMSTED Industries Inc., had been elected to the board. Lohman's election gave outside directors seven of the 13 spots on the board of directors. One analyst said the move could foreshadow a buyout attempt by the board, but others saw the shakeup simply as part of a trend toward outside control of large companies. ``The trend is in that direction, toward more outside directors.'' said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst for PaineWebber. ``I wouldn't venture to say that anybody's out to take anybody over at this point.'' Said Eugene R. Anderson, a New York lawyer and one of the seven outside directors, ``This is kind of a non-event in the history of American Brands.'' The company's stock closed at 66 Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, up from 64{ when the market opened Tuesday. One analyst, Allan Kaplan of Merrill Lynch, noted that several of American Brands' divisions would be attractive as individual properties. He said the changes on the board of directors could foreshadow a buyout offer by the directors. ``I don't know of any other reason why they would do that,'' he said. The company has four core divisions: tobacco, distilled spirits, life insurance and office products. Its brands include Carlton, Lucky Strike, Tareyton and Pall Mall cigarettes, Gilbey's gin and vodka, Jim Beam bourbon and Titleist golf products. The company reported earnings of $631 million or $6.51 per share on sales of $11.92 billion in 1989, and earnings of $580 million or $5.44 per share in 1988, said spokesman Roger Baker.

DOC.HEAD: December Construction Contracts Up 1 Percent
DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Contracts for new construction nationwide grew 1 percent in December, halting a steep slide in contracting during the previous two months, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported Tuesday. However, a generally weak fourth quarter left 1989's total of newly started construction barely even with 1988 at $261.2 billion, the company said. The Dodge Index, which uses 1982 as its 100 base, averaged 166 throughout 1989, the same as in 1988. In 1987, the index stood at 165, extablishing a three-year plateau of uncommon stability for the usually volatile construction industry, the company said. In December, contracts for non-residential buildings grew 4 percent to an annualized $88.3 billion, while the value of residential work increased by 1 percent to an annualized $116.4 billion. Non-building construction contracts, such as for public works and utility projects, declined by 5 percent in December to an annualized $46.2 billion, due mainly to a cutback in highway and bridge contracts, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Reports Quarterly, Annual Income
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines reported Tuesday that its fourth quarter profit tumbled over a year ago but earnings for all of 1989 nearly doubled. In the final three months of last year, the company netted $1.13 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with earnings of $19.06 million, or $1.18 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose to $278.25 million from $211.83 million a year ago. For the year, America West's net income totaled $20.18 million, or $1 a share, on revenue of $993.4 million. That compared with 1988 earnings of $9.36 million, or 51 cents a share, and $775.67 million in revenue. A.E. Frei, America West's chief financial officer, attributed the weaker quarterly results partly to higher fuel prices. ``Fuel prices continued to to climb in January 1990 and will certainly affect early 1990 earnings,'' Frei said. The airline provides service to around 60 cities in the United States and western Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Order $3 Billion in Boeing, Douglas, Airbus Jets
DOC.TEXT: International Lease Finance Corp. said Tuesday it had ordered nearly $3 billion worth of Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and Airbus Industrie jetliners, with options to buy another $3.3 billion worth of planes. The big winner in the deals was Seattle-based Boeing Co. International Lease Finance exercised options for $1.055 billion in Boeing planes, made firm orders for $795 million more, and acquired new options worth $2.535 billion in Boeing 737s, 747s, 757s and 767s. In all, International Lease Finance, which leases planes to airlines, ordered 66 planes and acquired options for 67 more. It was the biggest order for International Lease Finance since it ordered $6.6 billion in jets from Boeing and Airbus in May 1988. St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas Corp., snubbed in that last big order, got a piece of the action Tuesday. International Lease Finance ordered 15 of the company's new MD-90 twin-engine jets for $562.5 million and took options on another 15 at the same price. The MD-90, an embellished version of the MD-80, is produced at McDonnell Douglas' transport aircraft division in Long Beach, Calif. Delivery of the first plane is scheduled for early 1995. International Lease Finance placed new orders with Seattle-based Boeing for 15 planes: one 747-400, three 757-200s, three 767-300ERs, and eight 737s of various designs, with the first to be delivered in January 1995. In addition to that $795 million order, the company exercised options acquired in May 1988 for 24 Boeing jetliners valued at $1.055 billion. International Lease Finance acquired options for 48 additional jetliners _ $2.535 billion in all. The leasing company also said it had placed firm orders for 12 A321-100s from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, with first delivery scheduled for 1995. The order is worth $510 million. International Lease Finance also placed options for four more of the A321s, worth another $170 million.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Pull Back
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished lower Tuesday after crude oil prices temporarily spiked higher on an unconfirmed report that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev may resign as Communist party chief. Market analysts said petroleum trading was generally uneventful otherwise and volume was average. The contract for March delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 34 cents to $22.46 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, more than wiping out Monday's gain of 24 cents. Later delivery contracts also declined. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, No. 2 heating oil for February delivery dropped 0.60 cent to 60.51 cents a gallon, erasing a substantial portion of Monday's 1.51-cent increase. It was the last trading day for the February heating oil contract. The March contract, which becomes the near-month contract starting with Wednesday's session, tumbled 1.04 cents to 58.18 cents a gallon. The April and May contracts ended with more moderate declines. The expiring February contract for unleaded regular gasoline shed 0.9 cent to 62.73 cents a gallon following Monday's rise of 0.7 cent. The March gas contract fell 0.35 cent to 62.69 cents a gallon. The April and May contracts also finished lower. Futures trading frequently is more volatile near the expiration date of contracts. There was little news to account for the weakness in the refined products and said trading seemed to be steadying as the nearby contracts expired, said Greg Dreis, an analyst at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. A CNN report that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was considering resigning as Communist party chief injected uncertainty into many financial markets and spurred buying in the crude oil pits. But the impact of the report from Moscow was short lived.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Fall In Nervous, Volatile Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout; SUBs 10th graf pvs, `Analysts said ... to clarify
DOC.TEXT: The stock market closed broadly lower Tuesday after being jolted by a news report that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might resign as Soviet communist party chief. ``The report produced a technical bounce in the market. It was jerking all over the lot,'' said Michael Metz, technical analyst for Oppenheimer & Co. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished the session 10.14 points lower at 2,543.24 after flip-flopping throughout the day. Declining issues outpaced advancers by nearly 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,156 issues down, 399 up and 431 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 186.03 million shares, up from 150.77 million in the previous session. Analysts said the report about Gorbachev's possible resignation on Cable News Network caused reactions throughout the financial markets. Stock prices became so volatile shortly after the 2 p.m. EST report that traders at one investment brokerage stopped trading temporarily until the market calmed down. The Dow, which was heading lower during the afternoon, intensified its slide after the news report. Off more than 27 points at 2:30 p.m., the average jumped back into the plus column briefly before finishing lower at the close. ``We haven't seen a market of this kind for some time. It's pulsating, vibrating without any sense of direction,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst for MKI Securities Corp. in New York. Aside from the Gorbachev report, interest rates and concern about financing for takeovers remained the market's chief worries. Analysts said the market also interpreted remarks by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan before the Joint Economic Committee in Washington D.C. as a sign that the central bank would not reduce interest rates anytime soon. Greenspan said the probability of a recession is less than 50 percent, lower than previously anticipated, and that the current rate of inflation is ``unacceptable.'' ``Greenspan says he's not going to tolerate 4.5 percent inflation, which makes me think interest rates aren't going lower,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. Traders said computerized program strategies, which have become an increasingly bigger part of trading volume after declining late last year, contributed to the market's volatility. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 215.39 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market declined $27.18 billion, or 0.87 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.30 to 178.43. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, AT&T fell 1} to 37}, New Germany lost { to 24[, Federal National Mortgage declined 1] to 29\ and Unitel slid 1~ to 31[. UAL, which lead transporation stocks lower, tumbled 15{ to 121. Among gainers, IBM was unchanged at 97\, Bank of New England advanced { to 4|, Mobil climbed ] to 58{ and Boeing increased ~ to 58\. Standard & Poor's industrial index closed down 2.39 at 371.92, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 2.22 to 322.98. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 7.39 to 410.72. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 345.50, down 4.04.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up on Gorbachev Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar jumped in panicky trading Tuesday on an unconfirmed news report that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev would resign as Communist Party chairman. Gold prices were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold fell $1 to close at $418.10. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $418.30 a troy ounce, up 10 cents from Monday. The report by Cable News Network about 2 p.m. EST said Gorbachev may step down as party leader but retain his post as president. CNN quoted sources as saying the move would alllow Gorbachev to distance himself from the party amid internal turmoil in the Soviet Union. In New York, the dollar soared to a high of 146 yen from 142.98 yen late Monday and to 1.7130 West German marks from 1.6770 marks the day before. The dollar eased somewhat by late afternoon but did not give up all its gains. ``It reached panic proportions,'' said Mike Ballow, a currency markets analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The move was incredible and probably irrational.'' Richard Levine, vice president for precious metals and foreign exchange at Elders Futures Inc., said, ``I don't think the rumor can be denied or confirmed, but I think the market's reaction to even the possibility of further instability really tells us the story: That when push comes to shove, if one has to hold currency there's no safer currency in the world than the U.S. dollar.'' At the very least, the Gorbachev scare gave traders the opportunity to reverse the dollar's recent direction. ``I think the central banks have artificially kept the dollar down by their relentless intervention'' through dollar-selling, Levine said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.25 Japanese yen from 143.22 yen Monday. Later in London it rose to 144.05 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 144.65 yen, up 1.669 yen from late Monday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6830 from $1.6775 late Monday. In New York, it fell to $1.6725, down from $1.6810 Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday rates, included: 1.6990 West German marks, up from 1.6770; 1.5005 Swiss francs, up from 1.4815; 5.7620 French francs, up from 5.6950; 1,260.50 Italian lire, up from 1,248.00; and 1.1865 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1871. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Monday: 1.6805 West German marks, up from 1.6795; 1.4890 Swiss francs, up from 1.4860; 5.7040 French francs, unchanged; 1.8880 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8865; 1,249.50 Italian lire, down from 1,249.75; 1.1902 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1888 The late bid price of gold in London was unchanged from Monday's close at $418.50 a troy ounce. In Zurich, gold rose to $419, up from $418.50 bid late Monday. After a weeklong break on the Hong Kong gold market, the metal rose $9.04 to close at a bid $416.35. The market last traded Jan. 24 before the Lunar New Year holiday. Silver prices were unchanged to lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.207 a troy ounce, down from $5.215 a troy ounce Monday. In London, silver bullion was unchanged from Monday, closing at a late bid price of $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Unit Announces Faster Computer Networking Systems
DOC.TEXT: Timeplex Inc., a Unisys Corp. subsidiary, on Tuesday announced new products to connect computers that it says are vastly quicker at transferring data than existing systems. Timeplex says its computer networking products can speed the time of transferring complex computer data, such as a three-dimensional representation of a product, to about 30 seconds from the current 12 to 15 minutes. It says the systems would be useful in engineering applications as well as at financial institutions and other companies where vast amounts of data are moved from one computer to another, either across the room or across the country. Timeplex, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said the products already are being used by the Strategic Air Command at Offutt Air Force Base, Omaha, Neb., for the new SAC Intelligence Network, a new communications network. The systems allow the transmittal of so-called broadband data, which contain more information than narrow-band data.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Futures Plummet After Early Rally Fails
DOC.TEXT: Sugar futures prices fell sharply Tuesday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after a rally prompted by a reduced world production forecast sputtered and failed. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures fell; energy futures were mostly lower; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metal futures retreated. Sugar futures settled .36 cent to .46 cent lower with the contract for delivery in March down .43 cent at 14.44 cents a pound. The market rallied strongly early in the session after the West German statistical firm F.O. Licht released a revised 1989-90 world sugar production forecast of 106.5 million metric tons, about 1.2 million tons below its previous estimate. Licht said crops in several countries had not lived up to expectations, and the resulting tightening of supplies created the potential for explosive upward price movement if a large consumer country such as the Soviet Union, China or India were to enter the world market as a buyer. Unconfirmed rumors of Soviet buying kept traders on edge last week. Tuesday's rally pushed the March contract's price up to 15.05 cents a pound, but buyers turned sellers when it became apparent the March price would not top its lifetime high of 15.38 cents. ``The thing just fed on itself and we had the market ending flat on its face,'' said Arthur Stevenson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. From a fundamental perspective, he said, the initial response to the Licht report may have been tempered by expectations that an upcoming companion report will predict a decline in world sugar consumption. Grain and soybean futures settled moderately lower on the Chicago Board of Trade following a report that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev might resign as Communist Party chairman. The mid-afternoon report on the Cable News Network stirred fears of a change in the Soviet Union toward more isolationist policies and less foreign trade, including fewer purchases of foreign grain. The report overshadowed bullish sentiments linked to Monday's strong rebound in the soybean market, which some analysts had said could mark a turnaround in the market's six-week decline. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.76 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.37\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 5 cents lower with March at $5.58{ a bushel. Energy futures ended mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report, which showed larger-than-expected supplies across the board. The API reported a smaller-than-expected 678,000-barrel decline in crude-oil supplies last week, a 7.3-million-barrel increase in gasoline supplies and a 4.7-million-barrel rise in supplies of petroleum distillates, which include home heating oil. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 5 cents to 34 cents lower with March at $22.46 a barrel; heating oil was 1.04 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 60.51 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .09 cent to .55 cent lower with February at 62.73 cents a gallon. Pork-belly futures fell sharply for the third straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid continuing concerns about weak demand, high slaughter rates and low cash prices. Live cattle settled unchanged to .65 cent higher with February at 79.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent lower to .20 cent higher with March at 83.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .27 cent higher with February at 49.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.30 cent lower with February at 50.90 cents a pound. In precious-metals trading on New York's Commodity Exchange, gold finished 70 cents to $1.20 lower with February at $418.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.8 cent to 1.4 cents lower with February at $5.207 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Offer to Sweeten Bid
DOC.TEXT: A Utah businessman who missed a deadline to submit a bid for Aristech Chemical Corp. said Tuesday he hasn't given up hope and might sweeten his offer. Salt Lake City chemicals magnate Jon Huntsman has asked Aristech to set a new Feb. 14 deadline to give him time to review financial data and form a joint venture with General Electric Co.'s GE Plastics division, based in Pittsfield, Mass. The 50-50 joint venture could enable Huntsman to offer at least $27 a share, or $934.2 million, for the Pittsburgh-based company, according to a letter Huntsman sent Tuesday to Aristech board member R.S. Evans. His earlier $25 a share offer was spurned. ``I want to emphasize to the special committee and the entire board that we genuinely want to acquire Aristech,'' said Huntsman's letter, which was publicly released. ``The fact is, however, that it is not reasonable for you to expect us to make our formal proposal until we have had a reasonable period of time to complete a reasonable due diligence review of your company.'' A deadline set by a special Aristech board committee expired at 5 p.m. Monday. The company's stock remained unchanged at $25.25 at the close of trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. The committee set the deadline after Aristech managers and Mitsubishi Corp. of Japan said their $26-a-share offer, worth $899.6 million, would expire at the end of business Tuesday. The senior management group is led by Aristech Chairman Thomas Marshall. Mitsubishi spokesman Peter Rosenthal declined to comment Tuesday on the status of that offer. Aristech spokesmen David Higie and Harry Varner also declined comment Tuesday. Aristech, which employs about 1,800 people in eight states, has reserved the option of rejecting any of the first-round offers and suggested that if none is high enough it will reopen bidding. In his letter, Huntsman said he needs to see more Aristech financial records to finalize an offer. After signing a confidentiality agreement Jan. 24, Huntsman received ``certain limited financial information on Aristech,'' his letter said. ``However, as we have advised you, we need access to considerable additional information and people.'' Huntsman also complained he hasn't had time to visit Aristech's facilities, review various documents at the company's headquarters, meet with the company's independent auditors or talk with most of the company's senior officers.

DOC.HEAD: Moving From New York
DOC.TEXT: The Limited Inc. said Tuesday it is moving headquarters of the 720-store Lane Bryant division from New York to a Columbus suburb so it can be in a better position to help the specialty women's apparel chain improve. Kenneth B. Gilman, executive vice president and chief financial officer for the Columbus-based parent company, said the move involving 240 jobs did not reflect a decision to cut costs. ``It was a desire to improve the performance of that business,'' Gilman said. Gilman said he did not know how many of the buyers, accountants and other Lane Bryant employees would transfer from New York when the new headquarters opens in May or June of 1991. Three other New York-based divisions _ Henri Bendel, Brylane and Lerner, which together employ 800 to 1,000 people _ will remain in New York. ``They operate well in that environment. We think Lane Bryant, which has, I think, suffered a bit in recent years, would benefit from being located in the central Ohio area,'' Gilman said. The Limited and all other divisions are based in Columbus. ``Our plans for Lane Bryant include building that business to achieve sales in excess of $2 billion. It's somewhat less than $1 billion at this point. When we achieve that goal, of course, the home office work force will be significantly higher than 240,'' Gilman said. Donald Trott, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, said Lane Bryant has been struggling to find its ``fashion identity'' in trying to appeal to customers who prefer contemporary designs and thoses who are conservative. ``The sales have not kept pace with the other major divisions of The Limited,'' he said. ``The challenge has been in trying to find some middle ground ... of direction.'' The Limited operates 3,176 specialty apparel stores nationwide through The Limited, Express, Victoria's Secret, Henri Bendel, Lerner, Lane Bryant, and Abercrombie & Fitch. It also distributes through the Victoria's Secret, Lerner, Lane Bryant and Roaman's catalogues. The Limited acquired Lane Bryant in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: CenTrust Stock Trading Halted at Bank's Reqest, Probe Grows
DOC.TEXT: Centrust Savings Bank on Tuesday asked the American Stock Exchange to halt trading in Centrust shares while the thrift revises its financial statement, which had been criticized by federal regulators. The bank reported a $119 million loss in its report for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. Its stock would have resumed trading Tuesday following a five-day suspension ordered by the Office of Thrift Supervision, which alleged CenTrust filed inaccurate and misleading financial statements. Centrust continues to deny the substance of the OTS allegations, but nevertheless will amend its report to respond to the regulator's comments, according to a statement the savings bank released Tuesday afternoon. The revised report should be submitted on or about February 1, and Centrust officials have asked that trading be halted until the report is filed. The amended report will not change Centrust's $119 million loss or other previously reported financial results, bank officials said. Centrust stock closed at 75 cents before the OTS suspension was imposed. It was halted on the American Stock Exchange before trading began Tuesday. Meanwhile, Florida banking regulators expect to continue assisting a federal probe into junk bond trading practices at CenTrust. The State Comptrollers Office has provided documents to Securities and Exchange Commission investigators looking into a trading network involving CenTrust, Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., and others, comptroller spokesman Terrence McElroy said Tuesday. The SEC is examining an alleged ``daisy chain'' operation in which Centrust bought hundreds of millions in high-risk bonds and participated in several securities trades with junk bond whiz Michael Milken and Lincoln executive Charles Keating Jr. Milken and some thrifts allegedly rotated junk bonds and stock sales among themselves to manipulate profits.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Rally on Gorbachev Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Yields on... to CORRECT changes to reflect Monday auction; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `A basis...
DOC.TEXT: Prices of U.S. Treasury bonds surged Tuesday following an unconfirmed report that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was considering resigning as Communist Party chief. Government bonds, which had been down as much as ] point, boomeranged after the mid-afternoon report and finished with gains of up to \ point. The Treasury's closely watched 8[ percent 30-year bond finished 9-32 higher, a gain of about $2.81 per $1,000 face amount. That pushed the yield down to 8.55 percent from 8.57 percent Monday. The junk bond market, which declined sharply last Friday and again Monday, stabilized Tuesday because of a recovery in the price of high-yield bonds issued by RJR Nabisco. An unconfirmed report by Cable News Network around 2 p.m. EST said Gorbachev may step down as party leader but retain his post as president. ``It was predominately the Gorbachev report that moved it up,'' said Bob Sbarra, senior vice president at Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc. Market professionals accounted for most of the buying, Sbarra said. The CNN report also pushed the dollar sharply higher, reinforcing the recovery in bonds, dealers said. A stronger dollar makes U.S. bonds more attractive for foreign investors. If the Gorbachev report turns out to be true, ``the market effects will not be lasting,'' Sbarra speculated. Such a resignation would merely mirror events elsewhere in Eastern Europe, where some leaders have resigned from Communist parties but hung on to government positions, he said. Treasuries had weakened in the morning following Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan in which the Federal Reserve chairman warned that inflation remained unacceptably high and said that the risk of recession had eased. The comments dampened hopes that the Fed might lower interest rates any time soon, said Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Fargo & Co. in San Francisco. ``It's bearish for the market,'' he said. In the secondary market for Treasuries, prices of short-term bonds gained 1-16 to 5-32, intermediate maturities rose 1-8 to 7-32 and long-term issues advanced as much as 9-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.49 to 1,157.82. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.99 percent from their level at auction Monday as the discount was off 3 basis points at 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills auctioned Monday fell to 8.12 percent as the discount dropped 2 basis points to 7.71 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.06 percent as the discount declined 4 basis points to 7.52 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Monday. In the corporate bond market, prices of high-yield issues, or junk bonds, steadied after two days of big declines. A recover in the price of bonds issued by RJR Nabisco Inc., the bellwether for the market, helped stabilize prices, said Alan Schlesinger, head of junk bond trading at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. RJR Nabisco's 13.71 percent bonds due 2007 rose about 3~ to 63{ and its 13.71 percent bonds due 2009 rose about 2~ to 68{. The bonds had fallen as much as 20 points, or $200 for each $1,000 face amount, over the past two days. Among other widely traded junk bonds, Kroger's 13[s due 2001 gained \ to 101{ bid. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 12-32 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.47 percent from 7.44 percent late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Cohen's Strategy for Shearson Was His Undoing
With AM-Shearson-Cohen
DOC.TEXT: In some ways, Peter Cohen fell victim to the same problems as several prominent takeover stategists: He had big dreams for his company but ran into trouble after big acquisitions failed to bring the success he expected. Cohen, who resigned Tuesday as chairman of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., built the company from a largely retail brokerage into the second-biggest investment firm on Wall Street. The company that started as Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. took over Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. in 1984 and E.F. Hutton & Co. in 1988 and became a powerhouse. The 43-year-old Cohen, who joined one of the firm's predecessors in 1971, rose through the ranks to become chief executive officer in 1983 and chairman one year later. Shearson and Cohen were riding high when the stock market crash of Oct. 19, 1987, interrupted Wall Street's great bull run and sent Shearson profits skidding. Cohen tried with little success to patch things up recently with a senior management shakeup, 800 layoffs and a reduction in broker commissions. But the chairman himself has made some strategic blunders that didn't help his firm's recovery. Perhaps the most notorious came in 1988 when Cohen sided with RJR Nabisco Inc. President F. Ross Johnson in Johnson's multibillion-dollar attempt to take the food and tobacco company private. Cohen tried and failed to cut a deal with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. for a joint bid, and then went down to defeat with Johnson against KKR's winning $25 billion offer. Cohen, a New Yorker born in 1946, attended Ohio State University and the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. After a short stint at Reynolds Securities Inc., he joined CWBL-Hayden Stone Inc. in 1971 and spent seven years there. Following a one-year hiatus at Republic National Bank, he returned to Shearson in 1979. Once chairman, Cohen went about expanding the investment firm into the merger and acquisition field with the blessing of parent company American Express, which acquired Shearson in 1981. At first, most of Shearson's merchant banking business came from small deals and takeover strategists considered corporate raiders, including Asher Edelman. The company did have several big successes, including two pairings with Kohlberg Kravis: the $2.43 billion leveraged buyout of Jim Walter Corp. and the $1.2 billion LBO of Stop & Shop Cos. In 1988, Shearson was an equity partner in the $1.8 billion buyout of Koppers Co. by the British firm Beazer PLC. But the deal, which began as a hostile bid, earned Shearson, and American Express, a lot of bad press in Pennsylvania, Koppers' home state. Cohen saw the RJR Nabisco deal as a chance to put his firm on top among investment bankers, and make enough money in fees to help its sagging bottom line. However, the failure of the Johnson offer remained a black mark for Shearson and Cohen.

DOC.HEAD: States File Suit Against Asbestos Companies in U.S. Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-nine states sued 26 asbestos companies Tuesday, claiming the companies have a duty to reduce hazards created by the substance. The suit filed with the U.S. Supreme Court asks it to find the defendants liable for the cost of abating asbestos hazards in public buildings and order restitution to the states, said Washington Attorney General Kenneth Eikenberry. ``We are alleging that the defendants had the responsibility to provide products that were safe for their intended uses or warn the states of the danger posed by their products. They did neither,'' said Eikenberry, who is acting as lead attorney in the case. ``The products installed in state buildings simply were not safe and the states must expend significant sums of money to provide a safe environment.'' It is unusual for suits to be filed directly with the nation's high court, but the states did so in this case because the issue ``raises major public health, environment and finance issues and no other adequate forum exists where all the defendants could be sued and the resources equitably apportioned after finding liability,'' said a press release from Eikenberry's office. Eikenberry said Washington has been seeking payment for its asbestos-abatement projects. The state recently filed claims totaling $927,938 with the Manville Trust, which was created after the Johns-Manville Co., another asbestos manufacturer, filed for protection under the federal bankruptcy laws, he said. The state anticipates having to spend about $490 million to reduce the asbestos in its buildings. The estimate for eliminating asbestos hazards in all public and commercial buildings across the country ranges from $51 billion to $750 billion, the press release said. Asbestos is a fibrous material that was used widely as fireproofing and insulation in buildings around the country. Fibers from the material, if inhaled, can lodge in the lungs and cause asbestosis and other diseases. Matt Gonring, spokesman for USG Corp. in Chicago, one of the defendants, said he could not comment on the lawsuit because USG officials had not seen it. Calls to several other defendant companies failed to reach officials qualified to comment. Defendants in the case are W.R. Grace & Co., National Gypsum Co., United States Gypsum Co., USG Corp., American Biltrite Inc., Armstrong World Industries Inc., Azrock Industries Inc., Basic Inc., Carey-Canada Inc., The Celotex Corp., Certainteed Corp., Crown Cork & Seal Co. Inc., Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. Also Fibreboard Corp., The Flintkote Co., GAF Corp., Georgia Pacific Corp., H.K. Porter Inc., Keene Corp., Kentile Floors Inc., Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., Owens-Illinois Inc., Pfizer Inc., Raymark Industries Inc., Sprayed Insulation Inc. and Turner & Newell Ltd. Other states involved in the lawsuit are Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Maine, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont and Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: Board of Hotel-Casino Concern Discusses Future of Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Tuesday sted Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. directors, who hung out a for-sale sign last summer, faced a tough decision Tuesday: accept a much lower offer than expected, restructure the lodging-casino company or take down the sign. Hilton's board met to consider those alternatives, but the company gave no assurances that any decision would be reached Tuesday. The meeting ``may go tomorrow and it may go the day beyond that,'' said the company's general counsel, William C. Lebo Jr., adding that it was possible there would be no announcement from the board meeting at all. In announcing the meeting, Hilton had said the directors would ``consider a number of alternatives for the company, including proposals to acquire the company, as well as restructuring alternatives which would not involve a sale of the company.'' Hilton said it was possible it would not pursue any of the alternatives. Hilton stock was trading at $63 a share when Barron Hilton, son of founder Conrad Hilton, settled a dispute over his father's estate last May. When the hotel-casino chain put itself up for sale last summer, analysts said Hilton might fetch $120 a share or more. The stock soared to a high of $115.50 last August, and Lebo indicated that Hilton had been contacted by potential buyers from around the world, particularly Asia. However, sources of junk bond and bank financing began to dry up, and reports in The Wall Street Journal indicated that the Asian bidders had dropped out and that the highest bids for Hilton were in the $90-a-share range. On Jan. 24, the stock plunged $8.75 to close at $65.50 on rumors that one of those offers, from JMB Realty Corp. in Chicago, had been lowered or withdrawn. Hilton shares continued to slide this week, closing at $57.75 Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange _ precisely half their high last August.

DOC.HEAD: TV Report on Gorbachev Roils Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `The report... to UPDATE with government comment on rumor; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `In currency...; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The nation's financial markets were rocked Tuesday by a cable television report that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was considering resigning as Communist party chief. The report by Cable News Network's Moscow bureau immediately sent the dollar climbing against foreign currencies and spurred a rebound in the bond market, traders said. Stock prices gyrated wildly and oil futures prices also rallied. In almost every case, the moves were short-lived as the report remained unconfirmed through the close of the markets in the United States. ``It was a dull day before it happened,'' said William Hand, a trader with First Pennsylvania Bank in Philadelphia. The report by CNN around 2 p.m. EST said Gorbachev may step down as party leader but retain his post as president. CNN quoted sources as saying the move would allow Gorbachev to distance himself from the party amid internal turmoil in the Soviet Union. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker said the report was ``a rumor, and therefore it's not something that I think that we should respond to or react to. ``We're following the story, as I know you are, and we'll have a comment if we ever determine it's something more than just a rumor,'' said Baker. The same day, Baker's spokeswoman announced that talks in Moscow between Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze have been postponed a day to Feb. 8-9 to avoid interfering with a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee. Bush administration officials and intelligence sources told The Associated Press that there has been speculation for weeks that Gorbachev would yield his party post _ while retaining the presidency _ but that they had no information he would take the step. In currency markets, the dollar soared to a high of 146 yen in New York from 142.98 yen late Monday and to 1.7130 West German marks from 1.6770 marks the day before. The dollar eased somewhat by late afternoon but did not give up all its gains. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond finished 9-32 of a point higher, a gain of about $2.81 per $1,000 face amount. The bond markets had been slumping for weeks. On the New York Stock Exchange, prices were so volatile that traders at one brokerage temporarily stopped trading until calm was restored. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been sliding during the afternoon, fell more sharply after the Gorbachev report before recovering some lost ground by the end of the day. At 2:30 p.m. EST, the Dow was reported off 27.25 points. It rebounded into the plus column briefly, then fell back to finish down 10.14 points for the day at 2,543.24. In the energy markets, prices for crude oil futures spiked higher on the Gorbachev report but finished lower with the the contract for March delivery of West Texas Intermediate off 34 cents to $22.46 per 42-gallon barrel. Much of the frenetic activity was stirred by uncertainty over what would happen to the Soviet and world economies should Gorbachev step down. The financial markets typically react to a range of news reports and rumors. ``If he steps down, if he loses his stature, if somebody else gains stature _ who knows what happens,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International Inc. in New York. The rise in the dollar against foreign currencies and bond prices was attributed to the perception that U.S. financial instruments are a safe haven in times of turmoil.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Stock Hits $121, Below Pre-Buyout Talk Figure
DOC.TEXT: The stock of UAL Corp. took another nosedive Tuesday, falling below the price at which it traded before takeover bids for the parent United Airlines first surfaced last June. Analysts blamed the stock's tailspin on growing skepticism about the likelihood of any new takeover attempt succeeding. Arbitragers expecting a takeover at a higher price had held large positions in UAL stock. UAL plunged $15.50 a share to close at $121 on the New York York Stock Exchange. Since Thursday, UAL stock has tumbled from $164. The stock reached a high of $294 back in September when United pilots were working on a $300-a-share buyout bid. That attempt collapsed for lack of financing, helping to trigger a 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in October. ``What we've seen in the last three days is continued arbitrage selling and firms closing arbitrage departments,'' said Samuel Buttrick, a New York analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. ``Layer that in with Moody downgrading RJR (Nabisco) securities, uncertainty in the high-yield market, all the trouble with deal stocks, and you create a weak backdrop.'' The price of RJR Nabisco's high-yield bonds plunged on Friday and Monday after Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings on the securities. The decline spread gloom throughout the markets about the ability of the junk bond market to provide financing for major takeovers. Nevertheless, Buttrick said the drop in UAL's share price could make it easier to arrange a buyout because the price would be cheaper. ``It's basic math _ it makes it easier to do,'' he said. UAL and United's unions declined comment on the stock price drop. The airline's pilots, flight attendants and machinists last Wednesday proposed to buy 75 percent of Chicago-based UAL and leave the remaining shares in public hands. The employees are negotiating as a unit with representatives of UAL's board to develop a formal buyout offer, but the process could take months. On Thursday, UAL reported a 67 percent drop in its fourth-quarter profit, blaming the poor showing on takeover-related costs, high fuel expenses and an industry-wide decline in ridership.

DOC.HEAD: Fuller Industries Buys Fuller Brush Division From Sara Lee
DOC.TEXT: Fuller Industries has purchased the Fuller Brush Division of the Sara Lee Corp., a move that will unite the manufacturer of Fuller brushes with the group that markets them. ``We are delighted that this opportunity came available and believe that by concentrating our efforts we can continue to develop the business,'' Russ Immler, presdent of Fuller Industries, said in a statement Tuesday. The purchase price was not disclosed. Fuller Industries was formed last June when a group of Kansas investors acquired the Fuller Brush manufacturing operation in Great Bend. The transaction announced Tuesday involves the Fuller Brush direct sales and retail divisions. Fuller Brush has about 12,000 independent sales representatives and several outlet sotres throughout the country. Sara Lee said it wanted to concentrate on its food products and personal products divisions.

DOC.HEAD: Samsung Seeks Ties with Japan's Honda
DOC.TEXT: Samsung Group, a leading business conglomerate in South Korea, is seeking to produce cars with technical assistance from Japan's Honda Motor Corp., Samsung officials said Wednesday. The officials declined to elaborate, but The Hankook Ilbo, a newspaper in Seoul, said Samsung plans to build an assembly line this year to produce 150,000 cars a year by introducing Honda's technology and its models. The newspaper said the Korean company wants to double its production capacity by 1994 and export independent models.

DOC.HEAD: Scott Paper Earnings Drop 11.5 Percent In Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Scott Paper Co. blamed continued high pulp costs and mechanical breakdowns in its printing paper business for an 11.5 percent drop in profit in the final quarter of 1989. The company said it earned $71.6 million, or 97 cents a share, on sales of $1.293 billion from October through December. For the same period in 1988, Scott made profits of $80.9 million, or $1.05 a share, on sales of $1.285 billion. For the full year, Scott's earnings fell 6.3 percent to $375.5 million, or $5.11 a share, from $400.9 million, or $5.23 a share. Sales rose to $5.06 billion from $4.73 billion. Philip E. Lippincott, chairman and chief executive, said the 1989 results were ``dissappointing.'' Besides higher pulp costs and equipment failures at S.D. Warren printing and publshing, Lippencott said price controls in Mexico and costs associated with the company's food-service investment in Europe also hurt earnings. ``Demand for our personal care and cleaning products and our printing and publishing papers is strong, and I remain convinced that our strategies are sound,'' Lippencott said. ``Yet it is clear we have to do a better job of implementing our growth strategies and meeting our manufacturing objectives.'' In 1989, the company's earnings included a gain of $1 a share on the sale of timberlands in Washington and other items. The earnings in 1988 included a gain of $1.22 a share, partially from the sale of Scott's interest in Brunswick Pulp & Paper Co.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuits Filed Against Ex-Operators of Rocky Flats, Fernald
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with Fernald lawsuit, no comment from Rockwell, Dow, background. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Property owners around Rocky Flats and two unions sued two former operators of the nuclear weapons plant Tuesday, alleging that slipshod treatment of hazardous wastes caused environmental and health problems. In Ohio, a $2 billion lawsuit was filed against a former operator of another federally owned weapons materials factory, the Fernald uranium processing plant. NLO Inc. and its parent company were accused of subjecting employees to a hazardous, radioactive workplace. In U.S. District Court in Denver, two class-action lawsuits alleged that Rockwell International Corp. and its predecessor, Dow Chemical Co., were careless and negligent in the treatment of hazardous wastes at Rocky Flats. Their actions resulted in repeated releases of both radioactive and non-radioactive hazardous substances into the environment and violations of state and federal environmental health and safety laws, the lawsuits alleged. Five residents near the plant west of Denver filed one of the lawsuits on behalf of about 10,000 property owners within a five-mile radius of Rocky Flats and up to 50,000 people who live within six miles of the plant. Rocky Flats, which manufactures plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons and has been in operation since 1953, is 16 miles northwest of Denver and is near the cities of Arvada, Westminster, Broomfield and Golden. Dow Chemical operated the plant from 1953 until June 30, 1975, when Rockwell took over. Last year, the Department of Energy replaced Rockwell with EG&G Inc. after the FBI and the Environmental Protection Agency raided Rocky Flats, looking for evidence of illegal disposal of hazardous wastes. In their lawsuit, the property owners asked the court to issue an order preventing further releases of plutonium and radioactive and non-radioactive hazardous substances from Rocky Flats. The other lawsuit was filed by the Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, and the Construction Trades Council on behalf of more than 10,000 current and former workers at the plant. That suit asks the court to order the defendants to create a fund to finance reasonable medical monitoring and surveillance services, including independent scientific studies of adverse health effects. Rockwell officials in El Segundo, Calif., declined to comment, saying they had not seen the court documents. Dow Chemical officials at company headquarters in Midland, Mich., did not reply to calls seeking comment. Several property owners named as plaintiffs in the lawsuit declined to comment, referring questions to their attorneys. ``We think the lawsuits are historic. It's time to abandon the public relations games surrounding Rocky Flats,'' Bob Ozinga, business manager of the Colorado Building and Construction Trades Council, said in a statement. ``Hopefully, the lawsuits will benefit the workers, the community and the plant's operations,'' Ozinga said. Attorney Bruce H. DeBoskey, who is representing all the plaintiffs, said the lawsuits ``stem from people's concern and their fear over whether or not they have lost money and whether or not their health has been affected by the operations at the plant.'' ``That fear was heightened by the FBI raid last summer,'' DeBoskey said in a telephone interview. ``People are afraid. They're afraid and they want to know the truth from people other than the ones who have caused the pollution.'' DOE last year identified Rocky Flats as the most hazardous site in the nation's nuclear weapons complex, saying toxic chemicals contaminated an underground reservoir and threatened nearby city water supplies. Energy Secretary James Watkins suspended plutonium processing operations at Rocky Flats in November. He said the shutdown would remain in effect until DOE is convinced safety and health standards are being met. The Ohio lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Cincinnati, accused NLO and parent NL Industries Inc. of failing to properly store or contain highly radioactive substances at the Feed Materials Production Center in Fernald. The plant, located in Fernald 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati, processes uranium for use in the Energy Department's production elsewhere of nuclear weapons. The lawsuit says the employees suffered loss of income, emotional distress including increased fear of cancer, and diminished ability to obtain other jobs or insurance. It seeks $2 billion in damages plus unspecified punitive damages and payment for extended medical monitoring of the employees. Cincinnati lawyer Thomas Kircher, who filed the lawsuit, said he is asking U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel to declare it a class-action lawsuit on behalf of all former NLO employees in addition to subcontractors who worked there while NLO operated the plant from 1952 to 1985. NLO turned over operation of the Department of Energy plant to Westinghouse Materials Co. of Ohio in 1986. Bob Weidner, NLO's manager in suburban Cincinnati, declined to comment on the lawsuit, saying he had not seen a copy.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Maker Reports Big Gain in 4th Qtr Earnings
DOC.TEXT: PACCAR Inc. said its earnings more than doubled in the fourth quarter because of a $52 million one-time gain, but predicted lower production this year because of weakening demand for its trucks. The maket of Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks also reported record sales and profits for the full year on Monday. PACCAR had profits of $98.9 million or $2.83 a share in the last three months of 1989, compared with earnings of $46.4 million or $1.30 a share in the comparable period a year earlier. The latest quarter's profits include a $52.4 million after-tax gain from the sale of PACCAR's Wagner Mining Equipment Co. division and a fleet of rail cars. Revenues slipped to $861.8 million in the quarter from $884.6 million a year earlier. For the year, net income increased 37 percent to $241.9 million or $6.90 a share from $175.8 million or $4.90 a share. Revenues rose 7 percent to $3.52 billion from $3.27 billion. PACCAR became the largest U.S. manufacturer of heavy-duty trucks in 1989, said chairman and chief executive officer Charles M. Pigott. Demand for new trucks dropped significantly in the second half of the year, but PACCAR had enough backlog to stay at near-capacity, he said. Lower production is anticipated this year because of the weakening demand, he said.
